HEADLINE: To Keep Czecho-Slovakia's Hyphen

 BODY:
Communism can pass easily into nationalism. The two creeds have much in common. Each offers a simple key to tangled problems. One exalts class, the other ethnic kinship. Each blames real grievances on imagined enemies. As a Russian informant shrewdly remarked to David Shipler in The New Yorker: "They are both ideologies that liberate people from personal responsibility. They are united around some sacred goal."
In varying degrees and with different results, old Bolsheviks have become new nationalists in Serbia and many former Soviet republics. And now the same phenomenon has surfaced in Czechoslovakia, where fragmented election results leave the 74-year-old federation in doubt. 
 The big winner in the more populous Czech lands was Vaclav Klaus, an unbending advocate of a swift transition to capitalism. But in smaller, poorer Slovakia, voters turned to Vladimir Meciar, an ex-Communist turned nationalist who opposes rapid market reforms.
As talks on forming a new government proceed, the larger burden for their success lies with Mr. Klaus, who speaks for the more powerful partner -- sometimes with an arrogance that fans Slovak outrage. And unless these rivals somehow work together, the country formally designated, down to the hyphen, as the Czecho-Slovak Federal Republic could well break apart.
This is not Yugoslavia. Europe's peace need not be unsettled if Czechs and Slovaks agree to go their separate ways. Yet Americans are right to be concerned about toxic nationalism -- and to worry about Mr. Meciar. His devotion to democracy can be gauged by his post-election call for the firing of journalists whose work he disapproved.
Adept at switching horses, Mr. Meciar first served the Communists, then joined the Slovak wing of the pro-democracy movement that made the Velvet Revolution in 1989. Sensing disenchantment, he formed a new populist party that has tapped separatist sentiments among Slovaks, who have long felt patronized by sophisticated Czechs. He found an eager audience, especially since unemployment in his eastern republic is nearly 12 percent, whereas the Czech rate is 3 percent, the lowest in Europe.
It is difficult to see what besides pride would be gratified should 5 million Slovaks press for independence from 11 million Czechs. Together the two republics could be welcomed as members of the European Community. Slovakia lacks the capital, skills and resources to expand an industrial base now chiefly made up of arms factories.
And there is a greater moral danger, described long ago by Thomas Masaryk, the founding President of Czechoslovakia, whose own nationalism was joined inseparably to belief in democracy. "Chauvinism is nowhere justified," Masaryk wrote in 1927, "least of all in our country." And he went on to say that:
"The new order in Europe, the creation of new states, has shorn nationalism of its negative character by setting oppressed peoples on their own feet. To a positive nationalism, one that seeks to raise a nation by intensive work, none can demur. Chauvinism, racial or national intolerance, not love of one's own people, is the foe of nations and of humanity."
It is a good standard for judging tolerance, on both sides of Czecho-Slovakia's hyphen.

HEADLINE: 1-800-TROUBLE

 BODY:
"THE DIGEST'S PRESIDENTIAL POLL IS ON!" the editors of The Literary Digest trumpeted on Aug. 22, 1936. "THE DIGEST'S smooth-running machine moves with the swift precision of thirty years' experience to reduce guess-work to hard fact." So saying, the editors sent out postcards to 10 million Americans and on the basis of the replies, predicted that Alf Landon would demolish Franklin D. Roosevelt.
Roosevelt won, 523 electoral votes to 8, and The Literary Digest went out of business. 
 Public understanding of statistics has vastly improved since 1936. Yet The Digest's monumental blunder is brought to mind whenever Ross Perot declares his devotion to the idea of the "electronic town hall." By that he means instant telephone voting by television audiences after he and various experts discuss an issue and lay out several blunt policy options.
The first problem with Mr. Perot's idea -- and hardly the only one -- is that calls to his 800 number would be likely to produce results as flawed as The Digest's postcards. The Digest miscalculated because it polled automobile owners and people listed in phone books. It systematically missed millions of people too poor to have either cars or phones in a Depression-bound society.
In Mr. Perot's case, the millions who respond to his 800-number appeals are likely to be better-educated people who care passionately about issues. But even if his policy option programs were riveting, millions will neither watch nor respond, for lack of interest or access to the kind of telephone or home computer needed. Mr. Perot would thus, like The Digest, be tapping a highly unrepresentative sample of the population.
It's easy to see why Mr. Perot is captivated by technology. Bypassing party structure and the primaries and relying on phone banks and live talk shows, he has jumped ahead of both President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. If techno-politics works so well, why not techno-governance? The idea suggests efficiency and citizen democracy on a huge scale -- a proposition with great appeal to voters who feel disenfranchised by politics and who are eager for the grass-roots engagement once provided by the political parties.
Yet techno-governance's perils outweigh its promise. Quite apart from its unrepresentative response, the electronic town hall idea assumes an almost instant grasp of complex questions that can hardly be understood, let alone answered, in an hour of TV time.
In Mr. Perot's hands the system might also be used to end-run the Constitution. Indeed, on two occasions he has suggested stripping Congress of its constitutional authority to make tax policy so as to place that power directly in the hands of his electronic audience.
Nor would the system be safe from the manipulation Mr. Perot deplores. Norman Bradburn, director of the National Opinion Research Center at the University of Chicago, points out that a Perot Administration would be in charge of producing the programs, facilitating loaded selection of speakers and scripting of questions.
A CBS News program broadcast on Jan. 28 illustrates that danger. "America on the Line" invited viewers to call a toll-free number with their opinions of Mr. Bush's handling of the economy. One of the last images they saw was of a weeping, unemployed man; the people who called in were overwhelmingly unfavorable to Mr. Bush. A true random sample conducted by CBS at the same time, however, produced less negative percentages.
Even a plebiscite that worked perfectly might not always make sense. That's because good policy is often painful policy -- defending free trade against protectionist instincts, for example, or finding some way to help the Russians even when people generally are sick of foreign aid.
These policy decisions are not usually the product of tabulations from a call-in system. They are the product of deliberation, often raucous give and take and, frequently, the courage of leadership. A President needs that far more than an 800 number.

HEADLINE: Airport Noise Relief Still Lies Ahead

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Contrary to a May 21 news article, the House of Representatives has not given local jurisdictions increased power to enact noise regulations more stringent than Federal standards. The House passed the 1992 Federal Aviation Administration reauthorization package, which does not increase or decrease local power over aircraft noise. 
 In a somewhat bizarre attempt to rewrite the legislative history of the Airport Noise and Capacity Act of 1990, the House report accompanying the reauthorization package contains language indicating what several members of Congress state they really meant when the 1990 act was passed. The report's language is contrary to the public statements of Senator Wendell H. Ford, one of the major architects of the 1990 act.
The time has come for less rhetoric on this issue and more cooperation between all parties to reach common ground to achieve a quieter environment, while insuring shippers the service they need to compete in the world economy. Public officials should back off and let the 1990 act work; in places other than New York high-profile confrontations have been averted by a willingness by local officials to compromise. Attempts to achieve the same results with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey have been met with a stone wall.
 
STEPHEN A. ALTERMAN
Exec. V.P., General Counsel, Air Freight Association
Washington, May 21, 1992

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
 DINKINS CHASTISES EDUCATION OFFICIALS
Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday lashed out at the Board of Education, the day after school officials blamed city budget cuts for disappointing results in reading and math scores. But in a three-page statement, the Mayor never mentioned the test scores, which dropped sharply this spring. Instead, he focused on the board's quarrelsome handling of a new AIDS curriculum and what he called its "ineffectual governance" of the school system. Page 1.
 
CARDINAL'S MARCH CALLED TACTICAL SHIFT
John Cardinal O'Connor's decision to lead a march to an abortion clinic today is being viewed on both sides of the abortion battle as a striking departure from his usual tactics, one that even his allies in the anti-abortion movement acknowledge reflects frustration over recent setbacks in the efforts to stop legalized abortion. Page 27.

FINANCIAL EXCHANGES PLAN JOINT MOVE
In a development project that could bring all of New York City's major financial exchanges under the same Wall Street roof, executives of the New York Stock Exchange, the American Stock Exchange and the city's five commodities exchanges are in preliminary negotiations to build a new trading complex. The proposal, acknowledged yesterday by several senior executives, and outlined in greater detail in discussions with people close to the negotiations, is being advocated aggressively by City Hall. Page 27.
 
REGION
 
POLICE OFFICERS SUSPENDED IN NEWARK
Six Newark police officers under investigation in the shooting of a 17-year-old suspected car thief were suspended from duty without pay yesterday, and the city's Mayor and police director complained that the officers' statements about the shooting were too sketchy. Mayor Sharpe James has expressed concern about the possibility of street disorders since the youth, Howard Caesar, was shot early Tuesday as he walked away from a stolen car. Although emotions did not seem high around West Side Park, the scene of the shooting, Mayor James said that the officers' "cover-up" of their roles in the shooting had placed Newark "at risk." Page 1.
 
 MAN CHARGED AS TEEN-AGER'S ACCOMPLICE
A Brooklyn auto supply salesman has been charged as the mystery man who sold Amy Fisher the gun used in the shooting of Mary Jo Buttafuoco and who acted as her driver. Miss Fisher, 17 years old, is accused of shooting Mrs. Buttafuoco on the doorstep of her Massapequa home. The police have said she was having an affair with Joseph Buttafuoco, a 36-year-old auto body repairman, and plotted for several months to kill his wife. Page 28.
 
 NEW JERSEY LAND PLAN ADOPTED
After more than six years of debate and revisions, New Jersey adopted statewide land-use guidelines yesterday that are aimed at forcing growth into compact population centers and away from random sprawl. State and local regulatory agencies are expected to base decisions about development according to the plan's five planning areas, from densely populated urban districts to environmentally sensitive, off-limits areas. Page 28.
Regulators declare American Savings Bank insolvent. Business Day, Page 42.
F.B.I. seizes records of builder of Iroquois Pipeline. Business Day, Page 42.

HEADLINE: FASHION;
Buyers' Market

BYLINE: By Carrie Donovan

 BODY:
DESIGNERS CAN DESIGN. THE PRESS CAN rave or rant. But it is retailers who turn fashion into reality.
During the five show-packed days in April when New York designers and manufacturers present their fall collections, Seventh Avenue vibrates with tension and anticipation. Prestige -- and, in some cases, economic survival -- is on the line. More than ever, in these difficult times, designers depend on retailers to get their messages across. And it is the retail executives' decisions -- and commitments of impressive sums of money -- that determine what will actually become available. 
 Neiman Marcus, with 26 stores around the country, has a reputation for consistently committing big money to high fashion. For example, the store's management will invest $24 million in the Donna Karan name for the fall season. Cynthia Marcus, the buyer for designer sportswear, has an intuitive feel for fashion typical of the store's executives. This time, Marcus found the American collections superb. "I feel strongly about giving customers options, and the market supplied them," she says.
Bloomingdale's is known for hopping on a hot trend and translating it into merchandise for sale at many price levels. This fall, the store will put more than a quarter of a million dollars into stylish leather.
Kalman Ruttenstein, Bloomingdale's senior vice president for fashion direction, is legendary in the industry for his ability to spot a trend and act on it. Now he's pursuing "men's wear, animal patterns, leather, the color gray and 'glamour.' " No doubt, come fall, this is what Bloomingdale's merchandise will reflect.

HEADLINE: TV VIEW;
For the Right, TV Is Half the Battle

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR

 BODY:
Marlon Riggs, a 35-year-old film maker, now has the unenviable distinction of having come under fierce attack from both sides of the right wing that have made television a primary target. They are the religious right, which pounces on sexual permissiveness, a favorite target being any program that casts gay men or women in a less-than-diabolical light, and the political right, which levels charges of left-wing bias and elitism. And one man's encounters with them are perhaps indicative of the larger spectacle of a quite serious turf war now being waged for nothing less than the whole of American popular culture.
Last year, Mr. Riggs's documentary "Tongues Untied," a personal essay about being black and gay, a minority within a minority, was shown on "P.O.V.," a PBS series featuring independently produced films with strong viewpoints. The film unleashed a storm of outrage in powerful right-wing circles, not least in the offices of both Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, and Pat Robertson's Christian Coalition. The latter went to the trouble of putting together, for circulation in Congress and other power mills, a seven-minute tape of scenes from the film, which, out of context, thoroughly distorted Mr. Riggs's intentions. 
 Tomorrow night at 10, "P.O.V." (Channel 13) will present Mr. Riggs's "Color Adjustment," a survey of the depiction of blacks on prime-time television, from Amos 'n' Andy to Bill Cosby. The format is conventional, bringing in cultural critics like Henry Louis Gates Jr. and Alvin Pouissant to reinforce some of Mr. Riggs's observations about the often dramatic differences between television images and public reality. Few viewers are likely to be startled; some may even gain fresh insight into the recent racial explosions in Los Angeles.
They won't include, certainly, the editors of a publication called Comint, the Journal of the Committee on Media Integrity, which aims, it says, "to promote balance in government-funded media." Comint, which is dedicated almost exclusively to attacks on public television, has published an unsigned review of "Color Adjustment," branding Mr. Riggs an "outlaw" and his film "dishonest." The indignant conclusion: " 'Color Adjustment' is cheap and uninteresting propaganda. It provides a clear example of how the public-television funding system is easily abused by an irresponsible and extremist fringe." Mr. Riggs, be assured, is neither irresponsible nor extreme.
 
Recent Skirmishes In a War Over Turf
 Suddenly, it seems, television finds itself surrounded by political skirmishes, triggered for the most part by the conservatives. Bill Moyers and independent documentarians. "Murphy Brown" and "The Simpsons." You name it, and someone, somewhere, will pop up with a diatribe on ideological bias or sexual permissiveness, often in tandem with a solemn defense of "family values," mantra of the moment. And the Senate vote 11 days ago that reassured public broadcasting of Federal financing through 1996 while re-emphasizing the need for objectivity and balance in "programming of a controversial nature" has not quieted those voices.
Much of the fuss might be compared to an unseemly fistfight, complete with bullying tactics and reckless rhetoric. But that would be underestimating the importance of a battle that may largely determine the role of censorship in our future.
One of the more piquant ironies is that conservatives who have long knelt at the altar of a free market can now be found advocating restraints, if not outright censorship, in culture and the arts. The travails of the National Endowment for the Arts aren't taking place in a vacuum.
At a Washington seminar on "the new global popular culture," hosted in March by the American Enterprise Institute, Irving Kristol, a co-editor of The Public Interest, noted, with a not-so-veiled swipe at television, "Over the past 40 years our popular culture has conquered our high culture." He maintained that "American popular culture is today less an ornament of American democracy than a threat to it." Robert H. Bork, a onetime Supreme Court nominee now affiliated with the American Enterprise Institute, concurred: "The proportion of popular culture devoted to trashing our values is on the increase . . . . The amount of corruption in culture is increasing."
 
Who Should Tend 'High Culture'?
 So popular culture, once a treasured weapon in the Cold War, falls victim to second thoughts. Now, increasingly, efforts are being made to control the ideas embedded in that culture if they don't mesh comfortably with one official line or another, or with someone's conception of "our values." At the top of the hit list is television, public television being particularly vulnerable to pressure campaigns because some 40 percent of its financing comes from Government sources.
Mr. Kristol makes a valid point about the erosion of high culture in this country, but one reason for that erosion, as far as television is concerned, is the virtual absence of coherent Government policies. Television has taken the mantle of First Amendment protection for its news operations and steadily expanded it to cover its entire schedule. Even vague guidelines for providing, say, quality children's programs or outstanding cultural events are just about nonexistent.
So the bulk of commercial television has been free to pursue its endless quest for bigger profits with more and more "accessible" entertainments. "Studs," the smarmy syndicated dating-game show, didn't happen by chance. Todd Gitlin, a sociologist at the University of California at Berkeley, puts it this way: "The problem is that American values have included the primacy of the market. The maximization of box office is not conducive to what is euphemistically and nostalgically called the marketplace of ideas."
Any significant consideration given in this country to elevating television content in terms of "high culture" -- a responsibility traditionally recognized by the British Broadcasting Corporation, for one -- has been left largely to public television. In 1967, the Carnegie Commission envisioned a system that would encompass "all that is of human interest and importance which is not at the moment appropriate or available for support by advertising." Indeed, any viewers interested in the performing arts or sometimes provocative documentaries, not to mention relief from commercials, will find very few "free" sources other than public television.
From the beginning, however, sufficient financing was a problem, and, with production costs soaring, tighter budgets have whittled away at lofty ideals. The current glut of old movies and reruns of "The Lawrence Welk Show" can hardly be considered of pressing importance. Yet, instead of devising ways to make public television more vigorous, certain segments of the right seem bent on destroying the system altogether.
 
Making Slippery Use Of an English Model
 The argumentative terrain of some conservative sectors can be slippery. Consider Comint's recent reprint of a lecture, "Public Television at the Crossroads," given by Laurence Jarvik at the Heritage Foundation. Mr. Jarvik argued that the system should be allowed to sink or swim in the commercial marketplace, effectively controlled, of course, by corporate interests generally partial to the status quo. He took a club to the fledgling Independent Television Service, which was created to finance public television programs done by independent producers. The service is currently financing some documentaries (one title: "Endangered Species: The Toxic Poisoning of People of Color") that are certain not to pop up on the networks during prime time.
Contending that new technologies have made the need for public television superfluous, Mr. Jarvik notes that "today approximately 90 percent of American homes are passed by cable lines." The statistic is pointless, except perhaps to cable operators. According to a recent A. C. Nielsen study, cable penetration of American homes is now about 60 percent, meaning that a whopping 40 percent still do not have access to cable.
Then, quoting some trenchant criticisms of public television made in 1988 by the documentary film maker Frederick Wiseman, Mr. Jarvik, recalling that Mr. Wiseman suggested the system be reformed along the lines of England's Channel 4, declares that "Channel 4 is a private commercial channel supported by advertising sales." That's far from accurate.
Created by an act of Parliament a decade ago, the British service is financed by money siphoned from commercial producers on another channel and does not directly depend on income from advertising. It commissions programs, and, by law, a substantial proportion of them must be obtained from independent producers. (This structure will change next year, and there is already talk that Channel 4 will be effectively neutered.) Innovation and experiment get top priority. "My Beautiful Laundrette" was a made-for-Channel 4 movie. Overall, the service has been partial to precisely the kind of material now being explored by the Independent Television Service.
Once again, the core issue is control. Charges that public television's content leans too far to the left are less than compelling when its schedule includes, on a weekly basis, William F. Buckley Jr., Morton Kondracke and John McLaughlin, in addition to such periodic specials as "The Conservatives" and a forthcoming series with Ben J. Wattenberg as host. Financing comes largely from foundations and corporations tilted to the right, often the same ones underwriting conservative critics of the system. Predictably, some commentators on the left find public television too conservative, citing an abundance of weekly and daily shows covering business but not one about labor or consumer issues.
Is the system elitist, a charge favored by the columnist George Will? Analyses of audience demographics can be interpreted either way, but just for the sake of argument, let's assume it's true. So what? Upscale, educated, discriminating viewers are sorely neglected by most network and cable programming. As presumably diligent taxpayers, they deserve to be recognized and pampered somewhere on the television spectrum.
And, evidently, they are reasonably satisfied with what they are getting from PBS. An intense campaign by Senator Robert Dole of Kansas and six other conservative Republicans to reduce proposed Federal spending on public television was resoundingly rejected in the Senate this month. No doubt reflecting their constituencies, the vast majority of senators concluded that editorial independence and freedom from Government interference remain ideals worth cherishing.
The current step-up in antitelevision salvos from the right must have its reasons. Perhaps, if nothing else, the conservative right senses that the heady empowerment gained during the Reagan era has peaked and now is the time to push as many agendas as possible. Most social commentators, left and right, agree that the country is going through a period of uncertainty, trailing the excesses of the 80's and the ensuing recession.
As ideological battle lines are drawn, easy labels tend to be blurred. If some conservatives worry about cultural erosions, a middle-of-the-road liberal like Michael Kinsley can write, in The New Republic, "Even conservative social critics have made the point that free-market capitalism, in its constant stimulation and satisfaction of appetites, is the most powerful force eroding traditional values and social arrangements."
Tough questions must be faced, and television-dominated popular culture is certain to play a major role in shaping the answers. It is only within the context of the gathering storm that the curious spectacle of a Vice President of the United States bullying a television character named Murphy Brown makes perfect sense.

HEADLINE: DANCE VIEW;
For Ballet Theater, Putting on a Good Show Is All

BYLINE: By Anna Kisselgoff

 BODY:
As American Ballet Theater enters its final week at the Metropolitan Opera House, it is clear that the season is ending on a very different note than expected. Last month, halfway into this engagement, Jane Hermann announced that she did not wish to renew her contract as the company's director, a title she shares with Oliver Smith.
Any appraisal of Ballet Theater cannot ignore this development. But neither should the season's performances and productions be neglected: Ms. Hermann's imprint has been felt more strongly than ever during her three-year tenure. The dancing this year reached a new peak, and the premieres were provocative, if not first-rate. 
 Those looking for a scandal will find it not within Ballet Theater but in the lack of sufficient national subsidy comparable to those that foreign governments give their arts institutions. The dance world may be bandying around names of directors of European companies or alumni of Ballet Theater and New York City Ballet to succeed Ms. Hermann after Sept. 1, but the truth is that there is no obvious candidate.
Not everyone is eager to run a ballet company under the stringent financial conditions that were imposed upon Ms. Hermann by the board. She will be remembered for having kept Ballet Theater together during one of its most difficult periods and for maintainingstandards in the bargain.
The main issue before the company is the same one that has been facing it for the last three years: Ballet Theater's board cannot or will not intensify efforts to raise money unless cost-cutting measures first go into effect.
Ballet Theater has no home theater and depends upon touring. Ms. Hermann once expressed hope that the board would subsidize the troupe's touring and that she could produce a money-making "Nutcracker" aimed at local audiences in several cities. (The children in the casts would come from those cities.) These experiments did not materialize. Although Ms. Hermann said she raised $2 million, the board did not give her the additional support she requested.
Stephen J. Friedman, Ballet Theater's new board chairman, has given assurances that the company will continue, and a search committee is busy looking for an artistic director. That is telling in itself: Ballet troupes in America are no longer run by zealous founders but by artistic directors who are employees of a board.
That Ms. Hermann was not a dancer or choreographer but an arts administrator may actually have been in her favor. Historically, very few ballet troupes in the world have been directed by artistic figures with major careers as dancers. A prime example is Ballet Theater itself. The founder was Richard Pleasant, a manager who was succeeded by other managers, including Sol Hurok, until 1945 when Mr. Smith and Lucia Chase became co-directors. Ms. Chase did consider herself a dancer, but the fact is that she performed with Ballet Theater because she was also the company's chief backer.
A choreographer who will impose his or her choreography on Ballet Theater and a director who insists on dancing are exactly what the company does not need. Ms. Hermann's lack of artistic reputation may have been resented by some of the troupe's board members and dancers. But her artistic staff, which includes the coaches recruited by the previous director, Mikhail Baryshnikov, did the actual staging and rehearsing.
A star name at the helm may lend excitement for a few months. But he or she will end up facing the same problems of every company that plays more than two weeks in New York: Declining attendance in a recession when ticket prices rise to meet costs, plus a dearth of major classical choreographers.
In the end, an eclectic company like Ballet Theater has always been about dancers dancing rather than about a single esthetic. Ms. Hermann was faithful to this vision: She put on a good show.
This season, for instance, showed off soloists and an ensemble in top shape, as seen in the fairies' variations in "The Sleeping Beauty" and the corps of "La Bayadere." Kenneth MacMillan's 1987 "Beauty" has been especially well coached by Georgina Parkinson, making for an astonishing unity of style. The troupe's male soloists are the best in American ballet, and the principals displayed general excellence.
Oddly, this overall high level gives the impression of uniformity, which can be mistaken for the routine. Even the guests (Fernando Bujones, Sylvie Guillem, Laurent Hilaire, Steven Heathcote) left little impact. It takes the super virtuosity of a Julio Bocca to stand out in relief. But Johan Renvall was able to do the same in less classical roles through the power of both his technique and his presence in two revivals, Antony Tudor's "Undertow" and Glen Tetley's "Rite of Spring."
Because the full-evening 19th-century classics and the MacMillan "Romeo and Juliet" were presented in weeklong blocks to save on backstage costs, the premieres dropped out of sight too soon.
Nonetheless, the lineup was imaginative. "Firebird" came back in a superior staging by Nicholas Beriozoff; the first American production of Frederick Ashton's "Symphonic Variations" will probably settle in once the dancers get used to its lyrical approach to Neo-Classicism. Michael Smuin's version of Prokofiev's "Peter and the Wolf" has enough virtuosity and wit to appeal to children and adults alike. (It returns Thursday through Saturday.)
More sketchy efforts came from Agnes de Mille in "The Other," a variation on Schubert's "Death and the Maiden" theme, and from John Selya in "Jack and Jill," a young-love duet that was also a showcase for its dancers. (Mr. Selya's "Moondance" was not seen at this writing.)
The equivalent of an adult movie was Ulysses Dove's "Serious Pleasures," whose subtext of sexual fantasies was loosely outlined. The company premiere of "Grass" by Mats Ek was in a similar vein, although a psychological cartoon that dissected a male-female relationship. Mr. Ek is not much at putting movement together, but he has a feel for the sharp theatrical image. The set, a cluster of green poles, recalls the more refined reeds that Isamu Noguchi created for the swamp of marital discord explored by Martha Graham in "Embattled Garden." While the choreography itself fails to build fully into a picture of mutual frustration, the sight of a man and woman thrashing through this grass makes the point.
Ms. Hermann chose new ballets based upon dramatic rather than formal concerns. As such, these premieres differed from the pure-dance works commonly seen elsewhere. It is a direction still worth exploring.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kathleen Moore and Johan Renvall in the Ballet Theater revival of "Undertow." (Marty Sohl/American Ballet Theater)

HEADLINE: Japan Unfolds Through Many Images

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY

 BODY:
Early in "Rising Sun," Michael Crichton's bestselling suspense novel, a Los Angeles police detective is dumbfounded to learn that the Japanese doorman who stands in front of an otherwise ordinary middle-income apartment building is a member of the yakuza, the Japanese mafia.
"You must understand," says the detective's older, more worldly partner, a font of wisdom about all things Japanese. "There is a shadow world here -- in Los Angeles, in Honolulu, in New York. Most of the time you're never aware of it. We live in our regular American world, walking our American streets, and we never notice that right alongside our world is a second world . . . a shadow world, available only to the Japanese." 
 As entertainment, "Rising Sun" falls somewhere between "Uncle Tom's Cabin" and "Reefer Madness." Its story suggests an updated version of "Invasion of the Body Snatchers," in which the aliens are little yellow men who dress in dark blue business suits and, like Godzilla, thrive on carcinogens. Why else would they smoke cigarettes nonstop? The message of "Rising Sun": unless we come to our senses, we'll all wake up one morning to find ourselves turned into Japanese pod people.
Daniel Burstein would agree, but for more convincing reasons. In "Yen!," published four years ago, he presents a worst-case scenario about the consequences of Japan's new global economic power. It's possible, he writes, that by 2004 Japan will be in a position to force the United States into financial receivership. He even quotes a prominent Japanese securities broker as suggesting that when the time comes for Japan to bail out this country, it should demand, and be given, the state of California, which would be turned into a joint U.S.-Japanese economic community.
Not since Pearl Harbor has Japan-bashing been such big and popular business. It's easy to understand why. The Japanese are nouveau riche and we are their nouveau poor. They sell. We buy. We scrape together our last pennies to acquire a shiny new Acura we don't desperately need. We jog with Sony Walkmans that make our ears sweat. We watch Japanese-manufactured videocassettes on Japanese VCR's through Japanese television sets. The purchase of Rockefeller Center was the last straw: who can take the Music Hall's all-American Easter pageant seriously, now that the Rockette-nuns are performing their sacred rites on what is, in effect, Japanese turf?
Mr. Crichton's novel is speaking to a receptive public, giving dramatic substance to the sort of statistics about creditor and debtor nations, gross national product and balances of trade that usually appear only on our financial pages or in more straightforward studies like "Yen!" "Rising Sun" is Japan-bashing for the bedside table and the beach.
It also is not the whole story, nor does it mean to be. Yet it doesn't discourage the idea that the Japanese can be safely characterized as a shifty, mendacious lot. "Rising Sun" encourages simple-minded attitudes and answers. It denies the magnitude of everything we don't understand about the variety, differences and contradictions within Japanese culture.
While I was plowing through "Rising Sun," images from Japanese films and passages from Japanese novels kept interrupting what was supposed to be a good read. There was no easy way to reconcile the Crichton stereotypes with, say, Akira Kurosawa's film "Dreams" and the transcendent wonder of a small boy as, against all instructions, he spies on the foxes' magical wedding procession deep in the forest.
There is no accommodation in this kind of literature for the farcical (and failed) double suicide that is the penultimate sequence of "Confessions of Love," the exquisite novel written in 1935 by Chiyu Uno, a sort of Japanese Colette who, when last heard from, was still going strong at 95.
Propaganda as apparently effective as "Rising Sun" not only oversimplifies American-Japanese relations, but it also freezes interest in a culture that, just possibly, may have a lot to teach us. Assuming an air of patriotic disgruntlement gets us no place. So they build a better mousetrap. So, once, did we.
At the time of Pearl Harbor, Japan was as much of a blank for me, at age 17, as it had been for most Americans in 1853 when Commodore Perry sailed into Tokyo Bay. Not many of us in 1941 had even heard of Lafcadio Hearne's essays about his life in Japan at the end of the 19th century. To my generation, anything stamped "Made in Japan" was a joke. As the box was opened, the object inside fell apart. Even the way the war was fought certified our differences. What kind of lunatics would become kamikaze pilots? Being willing to commit suicide for the Emperor was not only mad, we felt, but also unfair. If at all possible, we wanted to survive.
I saw my first Japanese film, or at least a part of a Japanese film, in January or February of 1946 in Otaru, a small seaport on the west coast of Hokkaido. This most northern of the big Japanese islands looked much like New England to the crew of an American LST. Facing the harbor, where our ship was anchored, was a large billboard advertising a local ski maker. Superimposed over the figure of a very Oriental-looking G.I., swooshing down a snowy slope, were the words, "Silver Manted Mountains Are Beckon" (sic).
One afternoon, after skiing, some of us went to a local movie as a lark. We squeezed into too-small seats near the back of the theater and, for no more than 15 minutes, watched a costume drama that was unintelligible and scarcely moved. It seemed to be composed entirely of close-ups of the rice-powdered faces of geishas as they talked, alternating with long, meaningful reaction shots in which their lowered eyes signified nothing. After much snickering, we fled.
I now sometimes fear that we could have walked out on something by Kenji Mizoguchi (1898-1956), whose films in celebration of women have long since secured a treasured place in the international film canon. It might even have been his classic "Utamaro and His Five Women" about the artist Kitagawa Utamaro (1753-1806), except that Mizoguchi used close-ups sparingly. "Utamaro and His Five Women" was made in 1946, but it seems unlikely that it could have been showing in a small provincial theater so quickly after its completion. Whatever it was, it meant nothing to any of us.
Mr. Crichton's description of the shadow world, which exists alongside ours but remains unseen in contemporary Los Angeles, Honololu and New York, would as accurately describe the world inhabited by the Japanese in Japan in relation to the American occupation forces at the end of the war. The Japanese remained largely invisible, unknowable.
Yet they knew about us. They grew up on American movies. The Hollywood stars -- Charlie Chaplin, Shirley Temple, Laurel and Hardy, Gary Cooper -- were as popular in Japan as they were in the United States. Even today, Japan is the largest, most avid offshore market for American movies in the world, second in size only to Canada. Though Japanese economic power is felt everywhere in this country, and though Japanese products are ubiquitous, our knowledge of Japan isn't much greater than it was a half-century ago.
According to the records of The New York Times, the first Japanese sound film to be released in New York was Mikio Naruse's "Kimiko," which opened at the Filmarte Theater on April 12, 1937. Naruse's particular fondness for stories that, like their protagonists, avoid open conflict at all costs did not amuse the Times's critic. Though Naruse's gently furious family dramas are today regarded as being the near equal of those of Yasujiro Ozu, New York did not see another Naruse film until the release of "When a Woman Ascends the Stairs" in 1963.
Japanese films and novels have never had a success in this country to equal that of European works but, since 1951 and the praise heaped on Kurosawa's Oscar-winning "Rashomon," their influence has been accumulating. For someone who, like me, had spent many months in Japan and seen virtually nothing that wasn't an American landscape, the effect was astonishing and invigorating, also intimidating. How was it possible not to see when I was there?
In fact, there is no way of seeing, as a Government-paid tourist, what one sees in the work of Kurosawa, whether in his samurai epics, culminating in the majestic "Ran," in his early social dramas such as "Scandal" and "Ikiru," or in his two last, most beneficent works, "Dreams" and his elegy for the nuclear age, "Rhapsody in August."
Thanks to Dan Talbot's fondly remembered New Yorker Theater, we were given the opportunity in the 1970's to appreciate nearly the full body of Ozu's work, though the artist himself had died in 1963. Of special interest are Ozu's postwar films, culminating in his "Tokyo Story," released here in 1972, which, though it never raises its voice, is a ferocious consideration of the effect of newly shifting values, hastened by the American occupation, on one Japanese family.
Far more lethal is Shoei Imamura's uproarious "Pigs and Battleships," made in 1961 but not released here until 1986. Though not characteristic of Imamura's other, more poetic films, "Pigs and Battleships" is a matchless, sometimes vicious melodramatic comedy about the small-time hoods, hustlers, whores and influence peddlers who gather around the U.S. Naval Base at Yokosuka.
Quite late, and on an irregular basis, the breathtakingly beautiful period films of Mizoguchi have become available, including "Utamaro and His Five Women" and the grandly cautionary ghost story, "Ugetsu." Over the years these works by the acknowledged masters have been supplemented by the films of an irreverent younger generation of directors led by Nagisa Oshima. Mr. Oshima's most notorious film to date, "In the Realm of the Senses," has still not been generally released at home because of its hard-core sex sequences.
The problem with a novel like "Rising Sun," and with Japan-bashing in general, is that it seems to make every Japanese look and sound alike. Gone are all of the exceptions to the rule that testify to the vigor of any culture. As much as anything else, this is the point of the Lincoln Center Film Society's current series, "Changing Japan: New Ways in a Traditional Society," now in its last week at the Walter Reade Theater.
There is still time, however, to see Kazuo Hara's bold documentary, "The Emperor's Naked Army Marches On" (1987), about an obsessed World War II vet. This aging fellow, mad as a hatter, roams contemporary Japan trying to assassinate Government ministers and distributing pornographic pictures of the Emperor. On one earlier occasion, it seems, he attempted to hit the Emperor with lead pellets fired with a slingshot.
The high point of this week's program at Lincoln Center: two films by Juzo Itami, "The Funeral" (1985), one of the most hilarious and humane movies ever to come out of Japan, and the lyrically funny "Tampopo" (1986), which pretends to be about the art of noodle making but is about the art of living in a world in the midst of momentous change.
(Mr. Itami, who has been relentless in satirizing the coziness of big business and government figures with members of the mob, particularly in his two "Taxing Woman" comedies, is now recuperating from what the Tokyo police have described as a yakuza-backed assassination attempt. The director was badly knifed but not robbed by four men outside his house on May 22.)
The extent of the changes in Japanese life can be appreciated only if one does some exploring. One has to go back to Kurosawa, to Ozu, to the novels of Junichiro Tanizaki (1886-1965) (particularly to the epic "The Makioka Sisters"), to the classic "Pillow Book of Sei Shonagon," a record of court life in 10th-century Japan, even to Yoji Yamada's hugely popular series of Tora-san comedies, which have been coming out twice a year since the 1970's, to celebrate the small-community values few Japanese recognize anymore.
"Rising Sun" tells us gravely that a building is "typically Japanese" because the outside gives no indication of what is inside, that it's very important for a Japanese to save face, and that, most frightening of all, "Everything works in Japan . . . Trains are on time. Bags are not lost."
Possibly as much to point is the career of the nonagenarian former flapper, Chiyo Uno, whose story, as reported by her translator, Phyllis Birnbaum, embraces a nearly nonstop succession of marriages and love affairs, all of which became material for her novels and stories. Uno, writes Ms. Birnbaum, "demonstrated dazzling pluck as well as a genius for emotional catastrophe." She was not exactly your average Ozu housewife. But the Ozu housewife takes on enriched significance just because there was Uno.
Their Japan is the Japan I want to know about. The other Japan can be Made in Hollywood.

HEADLINE: POP VIEW;
The Jazz Festival Revisits Itself

BYLINE: By Peter Watrous

 BODY:
When the JVC Jazz Festival rolls into town, as it does this Friday, it usually sets critics off in a head-scratching flurry: what, they wonder, is the state of jazz, expecting the festival to produce some answers. Because it's the largest American jazz festival and takes place in a city where jazz is a substantial part of the cultural scene, it has signficance. And it can provide some answers.
If we believe what this year's festival is telling us, the jazz world has become lackluster. The order of the day is the tribute, the re-creation and the just plain dusty -- a bad sign. 
 Here are some shows that prove the point: there will be two tributes for Dizzy Gillespie, who deserves it, though he has been celebrated regularly over the last year in honor of his 75th birthday. There will be one for John Coltrane, who has also been feted a lot lately; one for Stan Getz, who died last June, and likewise for the trumpeter and band leader Buck Clayton, who died in December. Clifford Brown is honored by a mediocre jazz trumpeter, Arturo Sandoval, who is paired with Thelonious Monk's son. Lionel Hampton gets an evening, and Gerry Mulligan is recreating the 1949 Birth of the Cool session, which featured Miles Davis, with a 10-member group.
Not that most of this will be bad, given the caliber of the people performing. And tributes in themselves aren't wrong; they've occasionally offered up some terrific music. But there's a blandness and predictability to the schedule, a trotting out of all the same suspects to perform the same old roles.
Where are the combinations of musicians that bring something new to the story? Where are the little signs that show that the festival's programmers know what's going on in the clubs, know the history of the music, know which musicians have special works locked up in a drawer somewhere, works that would make for thrilling and revelatory listening? And where are the new faces, the young musicians to be put on stage with the older ones, making it clear that jazz has some continuity?
The forthcoming festival, which runs through June 27, is a retreat. Last year's event, one of the best in a decade, included a host of young musicians; festival organizers were acknowledging that a mainstream jazz renaissance had occurred and they had to begin grooming younger musicians. That doesn't exist this year, with only a few exceptions. This exclusion is programming suicide: it keeps young musicians from learning how to deal with larger halls and keeps audiences from being introduced to new faces and ideas.
But the grayness coursing through the festival seems endemic to much of the jazz world at the moment. The growth of jazz over the last decade is slowing simply because there has been a startling lack of imagination on the part of just about everyone involved in the music, from concert producers and record companies to critics, musicians and audiences. It's no wonder that the music is often not taken seriously, given the sloppiness of the productions (granted, often because of jazz's limited economic base) and the redundancy of some performances.
And though the state of jazz can't continue to languish, change hasn't happened yet. In clubs, still hothouses for innovation, where musicians can show off their intellectual finery, the music can be immensely exciting. But more often, musicians run through the same tunes the same way, accentuating a sense of stasis. It is as if the entire culture is suffering a momentary intake of breath before the assault on the top of the mountain is taken on.
Even the thrill of the new, in the form of ranks of aspiring musicians arriving in New York, has cooled. After a decade of influx that shows no sign of receding, the expectation that should greet young musicians isn't there anymore. Having signed up all the promising musicians, labels can't deal with the next generation because of their limited resources. And the young musicians themselves aren't progressing as fast as they should; promise, in some cases, is in the process of wilting. In the mid-1980's, it was important to have generations dedicated to learning the fundamentals of jazz. But now that there are hundreds of musicians capable of playing mainstream jazz proficiently, it seems time to emphasize the art over the craft.
There are easy ways out of the problem. For every 10 mundane, badly produced jazz records, there is a record like Joe Henderson's perfectly produced "Lush Life, the Music of Billy Strayhorn" -- thoughtful, carefully experimental and cross generational. For every routine concert, there are the occasionally brilliant shows at Lincoln Center, where new ways of looking at old subjects get explored and where old and young musicians mix it up.
For every club show of endless solos, there can be an exhilarating performance like that of the drummer Art Taylor's group, meticulously arranged and conceived and also cross generational. Or events like the monthlong Dizzy Gillespie tribute at the Blue Note in which a different period from his career was featured each week. And that's nothing compared to the fecundity to be found at the margins of jazz and new music, where ideas flourish faster than ability and tradition plays a much smaller role.
Part of this generally rundown mood may stem from comparisons to what's happening elsewhere within jazz. Young musicians like Bobby Watson and Wynton Marsalis are working a deft balance between composition and improvisation, and at the same time have retained a dedication to swing. In the process, they have made mainstream jazz an experimental form again, leaving the standard theme and variation of most small-group jazz sounding limited. As for programming, the imagination shown by Lincoln Center's new season, which starts in August, with its thematic programming and its attention to history, leaves most other programs looking shabby. What might have passed as workable several years ago now comes off as drab.
The point is fairly simple: the jazz world has to start looking outside the jazz world for ideas. Young musicians have to figure out how to get beyond the standard forms without losing the essence of improvisation and swing. Jazz record producers and the people at labels who sign young talent have to start going to clubs to find what's there, who's doing what.
It is the right time. Institutional support for mainstream jazz is greater than ever, there are probably more young jazz musicians learning their skills than at any time since the early 1960's, and there is more exposure to the music than there has been for 20 years. There are even hints of a new direction being offered by some musicians. It's now up to the packagers and the producers to take advantage of the situation; the frame of the music should be at least as creative as the music itself. The lack of foresight puts jazz back where it has been for most of the century, at the back of the bus, a second cousin to the culture it represents.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Dizzy Gillespie, above (David Gahr), and John Coltrane -- Tributes like those planned for the two jazz greats aren't in themselves wrong. But do they satisfy the appetite of audiences for new faces and ideas? (Chuck Stewart)

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: F.D.R. Jr.'s Homestead;
An Upscale Project Upstate

 BODY:
Most developers are adapting to the rigors of the recession by building smaller, less expensive houses. But the developers of Dalton Farm, a residential community in Beekman, N.Y., are taking a different tack. On their 560-acre tract, the former homestead of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., the late son of the 32d President who served as a United States Representative from New York, they have begun building a more upscale section, an 18-home enclave called Pondwood.
Dalton Farm opened in 1988 with plans for 162 modest town houses and 378 one-family homes. So far, 51 of the one-family houses and 48 town houses have been built. 
 Earlier this month, L.M. Dalton Corporation of Poughquag, N.Y., the builders, unveiled the Pondwood section, and buyers put deposits on eight of its homes. The project architect is Do Chung of Stamford, Conn.
Pondwood homes have 1,900 to 3,000 square feet of space, as opposed to 1,375 to 1,956 square feet for the other one-family homes in Dalton Farm.
Prices range from $215,000 to $320,000. The smaller models are priced from $165,000 to $232,000.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Downtown Brooklyn;
Planning Strategies for a New Retail Environment

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD

 BODY:
WHEN Alan Frisher decided to expand his health-food store last year, in the middle of a recession, people wondered if he might have overdosed on his own vitamins.
"Everyone thought I was crazy," he said, "But I thought if any area is going to come out of the recession, it will be downtown Brooklyn." He based his optimism on the explosion of new commerical development in the area in the last few years. 
 Since the late 80's, three major office complexes have been built and have already attracted such high-profile companies as Goldman, Sachs and Company, Morgan Stanley and Chase Manhattan Bank. In local radio commercials, the new downtown district is now being called "Wall Street East."
So far, the developments, some not yet complete, have brought a total of 10,000 new employees to the downtown, which stretches roughly from the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridge entrances to Atlantic Avenue and Court Street. And 4,000 more office workers are expected by this October.
All this has local retailers scrambling to expand and to find just the right formula to entice the burgeoning market into their stores. It might not be an easy sell, since the downtown shopping district is considered rundown and somewhat unsafe.
"We all know that just because people work in an area doesn't necessarily mean they shop there," said Francesco P. Cantarella, senior vice president of A & S, the district's major anchor, on the Fulton Street Mall. "These developments can be like wombs where people stay because they feel safe."
To draw them outside, retailers are sponsoring block parties, open-air fairs and other social events "to help familiarize people with the neighborhood," Mr. Cantarella said, "and to let them know the streets are perfectly safe and have a lot to offer."
Downtown booster groups, like the Fulton Mall Improvement Association and the Metrotech Area Business Improvement District, have been trying to rally merchants to spruce up their images to compete more effectively.
A year ago, Mr. Frisher moved his Downtown Natural Foods Market from Jay Street to Willoughby Street, in the new Metrotech Center, a $1 billion commercial and academic complex. In the process, he tripled his work space, from 900 to 2,800 square feet, and spent $250,000 on renovation.
"I call it classically modern with nice molding and upscale touches," Mr. Frisher said. "It was done to welcome all the new people from Metrotech."
In recent months, Mr. Frisher said, he has begun to attract some new customers. "I'm definitely seeing more business suits," he said. At the same time, he has managed to hold on to his regular clientele, mostly people who live in the neighborhood.
"The two groups have different wants and needs," he said. "The business people ask a lot of medically oriented questions, which I love."
To meet the needs of his new customers, Mr. Frisher, who holds a Ph.D. in nutrition, has also expanded the store's vitamin section and tripled the size of the juice bar, which is popular with the lunch crowd.
For some other shopkeepers, many of whom had to relocate to make way for the new buildings, finding their way in the new marketplace has not been as easy. One stumbling block is the rising cost of retail space.
When the new construction was first announced, retail rents skyrocketed to a high of $150 a square foot. "They've since leveled off to a more realistic level of about $50 to $75," said Jill Kelly, executive director of the Fulton Mall Improvement Association.
EVEN so, several shopkeepers either went out of business or had to leave the area. The survivors are still struggling to find a niche in what they consider an alien environment.
Sid's Hardware and Home Center, a fixture on Jay and Myrtle Streets for 60 years, had to move when Metrotech took over its space. It was relocated to one of the new development's office buildings.
"I had two buildings before, with 60,000 square feet," said a co-owner, Hymie Wengrosky. "Now I have about 25,000 square feet and very limited storage space." He said that having less inventory has sometimes hurt sales, "but I'd rather lose a few sales than have to pay the astronomical cost for dead storage."
If things go according to plan, rents could get even higher. Several more projects are being planned, including a 31-story hotel and office tower and a 2-million-square-foot office, retail and housing complex above the Long Island Rail Road terminal.
Stores with the best chance of surviving in this crowded atmosphere will be those with nationally known brands and upscale merchandise, said Paul Travis, chairman of the Ratner Group, the developer of Metrotech.
Two and a half years ago, Ratner also bought the Albee Square Mall, an indoor shopping center at Fulton Street and DeKalb Avenue. "We bought it in conjunction with the building of Metrotech," he said. "It is our belief that there'll be a great need in the area for an indoor shopping mall. So we're now working to upgrade the physical attributes of the mall and bring in nationally known tenants."
A prime example of Mr. Travis's preference for upscale shops is the opening of Au Bon Pain, a unit of the bakery and cafe chain, in the Metrotech Center last April. Paul Hinksman, the store's manager, said it is already a success. "We made $1,500 on opening day," he said, "and now we make $4,800 a day. This shop is doing much better than some of our Manhattan locations."
There are also positive signs in other product areas, such as consumer electronics. Radio Shack, in the Albee Square Mall, recently doubled its floor size, said Mr. Travis. And the Wiz, on the Fulton Square Mall, is opening another, even bigger, store on the same street. One will sell records, tapes and compact discs, the other, electronics.
Retailers like the Wiz have been in downtown Brooklyn through all its ups and downs. The store on Fulton Street, the first Wiz ever opened, dates to the 60's.
An even older presence on the street is the 112-year-old Gage & Tollner, the oldest restaurant in New York City, according to its owner, Peter Aschkenasy. Mr. Aschkenasy bought the restaurant four years ago, when the office developments were first announced. Since then he has been working out strategies to take advantage of his new market. First he changed the menu to "more universally accepted food, like lobsters and steaks," he said. Then he expanded the nighttime hours. '
"WE'RE starting to get regular customers from the new office buildings," he said. "And it can only get better.
Some of the other older retailers have been a bit more skeptical about the latest talk of yet another economic bonanza. They remember being promised more business, in 1984, after the $24 million renovation of Fulton Street, which transformed the street into a brick walkway, with landscaping and wooden benches. After that, the street lost the Mays department store in 1988, and merchants became skittish about what was next.
It was at that time that the new projects were proposed. "Many of the shopkeepers, especially the old timers, didn't believe that what happened would happen," said Ms. Kelly. "They were totally unprepared."
That was not going to happen to Victor Ashok Vora, an Indian immigrant who started out in downtown Brooklyn 20 years ago by working in a card store on Fulton Street.
He now owns two Hallmark stationery stores and a Baskin-Robbins in the Metrotech Center and another card store on Flatbush Avenue. He is hoping to open another Baskin-Robbins downtown and has great hopes for the future.
"It's like the immigrant's dream come true," he said. "I've paid my dues in downtown Brooklyn. Now it's time to take the benefit from it. I don't think there's any downside. The future will be bright. I'm glad I stayed around all those years."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gage & Tollner on Fulton Mall, left, changed menu to attract office crowd. New Brooklyn Union Gas building in Metrotech complex rises over Jay Street. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Streetscapes: The Empire State Building;
A Red Reprise for a '31 Wonder

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
In the biggest window replacement ever authorized by the Landmarks Preservation Commission, more than 6,300 new windows are going into New York's tallest landmark, the Empire State Building.
The new glass and frames give the 1931 building an airy, fresh appearance. The frames are also are a bit of a surprise because they are red, an unexpected contrast with the gray and silver skyscraper. An additional surprise is that research has shown that the original window frames were that color. 
 The Empire State was conceived as a 50-story loft building to succeed the old Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on the west side of Fifth Avenue between 33d and 34th Streets. That project faltered and the site went to new developers, including a General Motors executive, John J. Raskob. According to Hamilton Weber, the renting manager, the new owners got into the height race going on in New York and proposed an 86-story tower to beat Walter Chrysler's new spire at 42d and Lexington by four feet.
But the architects, Shreve, Lamb & Harmon, revised the plan for a greater margin, adding a giant metal finial to bring it to 1,250 feet. This was widely ridiculed as a meaningless gimmick in a pointless race for height, but the promoters said the finial was to function as a mooring mast for dirigibles. It never did.
Although the building is usually described as Art Deco, it is not so much a style as "a logical and simple answer to the problems set by the economic and technical demands," according to the architect William F. Lamb.
"As far as possible, handwork was done away with," he wrote in 1931, to favor the fastest, most economical construction techniques. The vertical strips of nickel steel and limestone could go up independently and railroad tracks were laid on each floor to speed delivery of materials. The demolition of the hotel and completion of the world's tallest building in May 1931 took 19 months.
The emphasis on systematic design and construction leaves the building outside of neat stylistic divisions. Some of the decoration is of the linear Art Deco of the 1920's, other elements are more abstract and streamlined, belonging to the Moderne of the 1930's. The limestone and metal trim give the building a very traditional, conservative cast, but the planarity of the facade -- the windows are flush with the wall instead of set in, another efficiency measure -- suggests contemporary European modernism.
The architectural critic Douglas Haskell thought that the limestone was a silly historicism, and that if metal had been used instead, the "swift and unfussy shaft" would have been a masterpiece. But Edmund Wilson, writing in the New Republic, called the building "New York's handsomest skyscraper," its neutral color reflecting the varying tones of the sky -- bluish gray, bisque pink, pale gray, silver -- "like a cake of ice."
The building's 3 million square feet opened only 46 percent rented, but The New York Times said that the income from admissions to the observatory was $1 million a year. A large transmission mast was added in 1953, but the World Trade Center and then the Sears Tower in Chicago beat the Empire State for height in the 1970's. It was designated a landmark in 1981.
THE original windows were typical of the time -- machine-produced rolled steel. Although more expensive nonrusting metals were used for the decorative elements, William C. Shopsin, the building's preservation consultant, says the windows were originally painted for protection against corrosion.
Over the last several decades most of the window frames were repainted in darker shades, although those in the lower part were more recently painted green.
When all of a building's windows are replaced at once instead of piecemeal, the Landmarks Preservation Commission requires testing for the original paint color with microscopic and chemical analysis. Both the commission and Mr. Shopsin were surprised when these tests showed the original color was a deep, tomato-soup red -- it seems out of character with perceptions of the Empire State's coloration as neutral.
But the use of color was a strong current in modern architecture at the time and indeed the windows of the McGraw-Hill Building of 1931 at 330 West 42d Street were originally the same color.
Although the replacement program will take several years, the effect is already striking. The new windows draw attention to the planar modernism of the facade and the color seems like a striking departure from the building's familiar sobriety. Together they produce a new-old view of the building that will take some time to come into focus.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Empire State Building in 1931. More than 6,300 windows are being replaced, with frames that match the original tomato-red color. (Irving Underhill/Museum of the City of New York)

LENGTH: 1653 words

HEADLINE: 2 G.O.P. Leaders Push New State Agenda

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
BY all accounts, Donald T. DiFrancesco, President of the Senate, and Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, Speaker of the Assembly, are potentially the most powerful political figures in the state. With Republican majorities in the Senate and Assembly large enough to override a gubernatorial veto, the two Republican leaders are positioned to determine what will become law between now and the end of 1993.
"Right now," Mr. Haytaian said, "the office of Senate President and the office of the Assembly Speaker are probably more influential than they have ever been." 
Since the beginning of the legislative term in January, the two men have produced a torrent of bills and proposed constitutional amendments that, if enacted, would result in the most dramatic changes in governmental policy in recent memory.
The Republicans have already flexed their political muscle by pushing through, over Gov. Jim Florio's veto, a rollback of the state sales tax from 7 percent to 6 percent. Their bills tightening the death-penalty statute and toughening the statutes on child pornography have been enacted into law.
Now they are developing legislation for changes in the automobile insurance laws, the state budget process, the health-care system and the Quality Education Act. And they have proposed as many as 10 constitutional amendments on issues ranging from initiative and referendum and the death penalty to limits on legislative terms and a requirement that the state pay for new municipal and county programs it mandates.
"The Republicans in the Legislature have taken on a major agenda of constitutional revision," said Alan Rosenthal, who is the director of the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University in New Brunswick. "I think they are hoping to restructure government to a very considerable extent."
At the same time Mr. DiFrancesco and Mr. Haytaian have pursued this wide-ranging agenda, they have been struggling to cope with a flood of bad news, ranging from reduced tax revenue of $310 million (not counting the $608 million loss from their own sales tax cut) to the threatened loss of $450 million in Federal Medicaid funds.
What remains to be seen is whether Mr. DiFrancesco and Mr. Haytaian can control their troops. Mr. DiFrancesco has the more formidable task, since the Republican majority in the Senate, 27 to 13, is exactly the number required to override a veto by the Governor, who is a Democrat. A single renegade Republican senator could kill an override attempt. In the Assembly, where the Republican majority is 58 to 22, Mr. Haytaian has a four-vote override cushion.
"My sense is that a lot of the Republican legislators have their own agenda," said Ross Baker, a professor of political science at Rutgers, "which means they can stray off the reservation."
The Senate minority leader, John A. Lynch, Democrat of New Brunswick and the former Senate President, added, "Even in the best of circumstances, it's difficult to get 27 legislators to agree on anything."
The two point men leading the Republican charge are a political odd couple -- Mr. DiFrancesco, a slender, soft-spoken 47-year-old lawyer, and Mr. Haytaian, a bulky, blustery 54-year-old electrical engineer.
One recent afternoon, Mr. DiFrancesco sat in his office in the State House, his elbows on his desk, his chin perched on clasped hands. His unlined face, eyeglasses and precise, measured speech made him seem like an economics professor ready to lecture a class of sophomores.
On the other side of Mr. DiFrancesco's uncluttered desk sat Mr. Haytaian. Even sitting still, Mr. Haytaian radiated energy, as though at any second he might jump from his chair to bound off to his next appointment. His face is all contours and curves, etched with a permanent smile, and the words seem to tumble out of him.
 
 When they speak of their legislative goals, more differences emerge. Mr. Haytaian hammers away at themes that have aroused great public interest -- sales taxes, automobile insurance, limits on legislative terms. Mr. DiFrancesco wants to improve the way state revenue is predicted, in order to craft the state budget more accurately.
"The item first and foremost on my agenda is the budget process," he said. One possible change, he said, would be to provide for independent forecasting of state revenue so that income expectations can be predicted more accurately and future billion-dollar shortfalls avoided. Under current practice, revenue predictions are made by the State Treasurer's office.
He also said the Legislature would be looking at ways to make the Quality Education Act more efficient by "loosening up on the regulatory aspects of education" in the districts that are performing well, and by devoting greater attention to those districts that are below par.
"If we have kids in classes that don't have books because there isn't enough money to buy the books," he said, "then we're doing something wrong. Maybe we should buy the books ourselves."
 
Changes in Auto Insurance
 Other items high on his agenda: the revision of the state's hospital billing system, which was invalidated last month by a Federal judge, and changes in the automobile insurance laws that would encourage greater competition among insurance providers.
In the Assembly, Mr. Haytaian pointed out, Republicans are drafting amendments to the auto insurance law that would reinstate rate differentials based upon such factors as sex, age and geographical location. Governor Florio's Fair Automobile Insurance Reform Act of 1990 eliminated such differentials.
"It is not a 'fair' act," he said. "The act was a fallacy."
Mr. Haytaian emphasized the Republicans' determination to put at least some of their proposed constitutional amendments on the ballot in November.
 
Initiative and Referendum
 One measure legislators are grappling with is a constitutional amendment on initiative and referendum -- the process whereby registered voters in the state can directly enact new laws by placing proposed legislation on the ballot by petition.
Two versions of such an amendment are being considered by the Legislature. One would allow proposed legislation to be placed on the ballot upon the presentation of petitions bearing the signatures of 6 percent of voters who voted in the last gubernatorial election. The other would allow both proposed legislation and constitutional amendments to be placed on the ballot, but increases the petition requirement to 8 percent for legislation and 12 percent for amendments.
Another constitutional amendment being considered is the legislative veto, which gives lawmakers the ability to void regulations made by state agencies if the Legislature decides that the regulations do not reflect the intent of the enabling legislation.
Yet another amendment being considered by legislators, Mr. Haytaian said, is the issue of "state mandate, state pay," under which the state government would pick up the cost of any new municipal or county programs that the Legislature requires. A related constitutional amendment proposal, which would require the state to pick up the cost of county courts, is now before the Senate.
The list of potential constitutional amendments also covers such issues as the right of the electorate to recall the governor and legislators from office, changes in the death-penalty statute, a prohibition on forced regionalization of school districts and a provision to limit the terms of legislators.
 
Limiting Number of Amendments
 Mr. DiFrancesco, while supportive of such initiatives, said he would prefer not to put too many constitutional amendment questions on the ballot in any one year. More than four or five, he said, would be cumbersome and could be confusing to voters.
The ultimate success of the Republican agenda, political experts say, is dependent upon the extent to which Mr. Haytaian and Mr. DiFrancesco can maintain party discipline. And their ability to do that emanates from the built-in powers of their offices and the loyalties they have built up over their years in the Legislature.
Before a bill can come up for a vote in either house, it must be approved by one or more legislative committees, and the decision to post a bill for a committee vote is made by the committee chairman. The Assembly Speaker and the Senate President appoint the chairmen of the committees in their respective houses, and the committee chairmen tend to be sensitive to the political views of those who appointed them.
 
'Little Debt of Gratitude'
 The Speaker and the Senate President also exert considerable influence on other legislators because of their ability to raise campaign funds and distribute them to favored legislators. "If the Speaker or President raise a lot of money and give some of it to a guy who's running for the first time," Mr. Rosenthal said, "there's a little debt of gratitude there."
But political experts warn that the powerful potential to override a gubernatorial veto may not always be available. Some of the Republican legislative proposals, Professor Baker of Rutgers said, are an effort to make good on politically popular campaign promises, like initiative and referendum, that make some legislators uneasy.
Initiative and referendum, for example, is seen by some legislators as a dilution of their legislative responsibilities. And a constitutional amendment limiting legislators' terms -- a pet project of Mr. Haytaian -- is not exactly a popular topic among lawmakers.
Senator John H. Ewing, Republican of Bedminster, emphasized the difference between the override potential in the Assembly and the Senate. In the Assembly, he said, the Speaker can allow four legislators who confront "special circumstances" on a given issue to abstain or vote against an override.
"But in the Senate," he said, "we have no members to spare, so you can't let anybody off the hook."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Donald T. DiFrancesco, left, President of the State Senate, at the podium during debate. Above, Garabed Haytaian, the Assembly Speaker, conducting business on the Assembly floor. (Photographs by Chet Gordon for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
