HEADLINE: World Markets;
The Latin American Rebound

BYLINE: By Michael Quint

 BODY:
From riches to rags and back to riches. That is the uneven road followed by many banks in their lending to Latin American countries.
In the heady days of the 1970's, when banks were flush with deposits from oil-producing countries, lending to Latin America was good business, producing handsome fees and interest payments. By 1982, when Mexico defaulted on its loans, the business had soured and large banks around the world took big losses. But in the past few years the pendulum has swung again, as many Latin American economies have strengthened and their stock markets have soared. 
 "Recent economic reforms have been very beneficial to local economies in Latin America, and that has been reflected in their stock markets," said William R. Rhodes, vice chairman at Citicorp, a leading lender in many of those countries. Citicorp has benefited from rising stock prices, Mr. Rhodes said, because it has sizable investments in local companies. Many of these investments occurred when the bank accepted stock in a company in exchange for a bank loan that could not be repaid.
The last several months have been heady times in the Latin American stock markets, as capital that fled those countries in the 1980's has been invested locally once again. In Brazil, stock prices have increased 40.9 percent so far this year, after adjusting for the exchange of cruzeiros for dollars. In Chile, the gain in dollar terms has been 35.4 percent; in Mexico, 29.4 percent, and in Argentina, 21.4 percent.
In the United States, by contrast, the stock market has fallen 2.1 percent this year, and in Japan, the decline has been 23.1 percent.
According to Morgan Stanley & Company, which compiles data on stock market performance in about three dozen countries, Brazil has been the world's second-strongest market this year, following Hong Kong. Chile has been the fourth-strongest; Mexico, the sixth, and Argentina, the seventh.
Kevin J. Mulvaney, head of global banking at the Bank of Boston Corporation, noted that many banks, including his, are benefiting from the rebound in Latin American economies. In some cases, loans are proving to be worth more than banks had estimated years ago when they set aside reserves to cover expected losses. "Over the entire cycle, banks still suffered from their lending excesses, but in many cases they are now approaching a break-even point," he said.
Mr. Mulvaney added that companies like the Bank of Boston and Citicorp are earning strong profits at their large banks in Argentina and Brazil that accept deposits and make loans to local businesses and consumers.
American bankers have been slow to publicize their gains, partly because they are still negotiating with Brazil and Argentina over new loan terms. "We can't appear to be gloating over how much money we are making on some of our investments because of the political implications in Latin America," said one American banker, who spoke on condition that he not be identified.
At Citicorp, the most active American lender in Latin America, problems with its loans have been much better documented than their recovery. Profits were reduced at Citicorp by $4 billion in the late 1980's, when it increased its reserves to cover losses it expected on loans to less developed countries that were not paying their debts on time. In the past year, however, Citicorp has pulled $200 million from that reserve to apply against other problem loans.
John S. Reed, Citicorp's chairman, said last week at a conference sponsored by Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, a securities firm, that the value of Citicorp's various stock investments was now greater than the original amount of the loans that were exchanged for the corporate stocks. Mr. Reed, who is trying to persuade investors that Citicorp is stronger than indicated by its current stock price of $20.375, was not willing, however, to elaborate on the value of its stock investments, the companies involved or Citicorp's plans for those stocks.
The most recently disclosed gain at Citicorp came in the first quarter, when the company earned $218 million after taxes from the sale of various investments, including some in Latin American companies.
Mr. Rhodes said in an interview last week that Citicorp had already taken several hundred million dollars of gains from investments it took in exchange for loans. He added that "where the markets are right now, we would have several hundred million more."
Ronald Mandle, banking analyst at Sanford Bernstein, has estimated that Citicorp could have $1.5 billion worth of investments stemming from its earlier loans to Latin American countries. He noted that the company carries those investments on its books at only $600 million, but cautions that the $1.5 billion estimate could be off the mark by a few hundred million dollars.
Companies in which Citicorp is known to own shares include Telebras, the Brazilian telephone company; Fensa, Mexico's No. 1 soft drink bottler and brewer (Corona beer is one of its products), and several companies in Chile. In Argentina, where Citicorp owns part of Intel, a telephone company serving Buenos Aires, the value of its investment has tripled since late 1990.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Solidarity in Silicon Valley

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
Stung by the steady exodus of jobs and manufacturing from Silicon Valley, some of the region's biggest companies have come together in an unprecedented coalition aimed at restoring the area's economic vitality. Joint Venture: Silicon Valley, as the coalition is called, released a preliminary report last week showing that the valley lags the San Francisco Bay Area and the nation as a whole in the creation of new jobs.
High real estate costs and strict land use regulations have for years prompted companies to shift operations out of the valley, an area south of San Francisco that is home to many computer and semiconductor companies. But it is only recently that executives came to any kind of consensus about the damage these moves have caused. That helped to get arch competitors to join the coalition, said Thomas Hayes, chairman of the group. 
 "Enough pain was shared that people were motivated to come together," said Mr. Hayes, 32, who is also the manager of global corporate relations for Santa Clara-based Applied Materials Inc., a maker of semiconductor manufacturing equipment. "If I had tried to get this group together a year ago it wouldn't have happened."
Participants include Apple Computer, Hewlett-Packard, I.B.M., Intel and Tandem.
Mr. Hayes says the aim of the group is to persuade companies to stop moving plants to places like Austin, Tex., or Portland, Ore., two fast-growing high-tech areas.
"There are so many pretenders to the throne, so many Silicon Islands, Silicon Glens or Silicon Prairies," he said. "This area can offer you not only a critical mass of technology, but a creative tension you won't find elsewhere."
The group has commissioned SRI International, a Menlo Park research concern, to develop an agenda for the public and private sectors to cure the area's ills. Mr. Hayes conceded that the birth of Silicon Valley was a happy accident, and that any formal attempt to reinvent the valley would smack of "industrial policy," heresy for entrepreneurs.
"We're not trying to tamper with the core advantage of the valley -- the entrepreneurial spirit," he said. "But when you look at what is ailing us, it has a lot to do with the environment here."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Will Somebody Please Borrow A Little Money?

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
If nobody goes shopping, is it really a recovery?
That is the question that economists may soon have to confront. The early 1992 burst of consumer spending has faded, and American consumers are reaching for their wallets not to spend but to pay off debts. "There is a worrisome trend toward prudence," said James Grant, editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer. 
 Last week the Federal Reserve reported that consumer credit outstanding fell by $3.8 billion in April, the largest one-month decline since June 1980, when credit controls were crunching the economy.
 That is not, to put it mildly, the normal course of events after a recession ends. "There is no past recovery where we can find this happening," said Susan Sterne of Economic Analysis Associates in Stowe, Vt. Ed Yardeni, the chief economist at C. J. Lawrence, said it is raising the chances of a "triple-dip recession."
The weakness in credit creation has lasted longer than anyone expected. It used to be assumed that consumer credit always rose, no matter what. After all, the figure showed declines in just nine of the 120 months of the 1980's. So far in the 1990's, it is down for 14 of the 28 months reported.
Until last week, analysts could at least take comfort from retail sales, which seemed to be moving along at adequate levels, if not at the smart pace of January. But the Commerce Department said, in effect, "never mind," and revised downward the figures for February through April, at the same time announcing a puny 0.2 percent increase for May.
Wall Street's reaction was to heave a sigh of relief. When stock prices slipped early last week, the seers somehow concluded that inflation fears might have something to do with it. But the evidence of a weakening economy reduced those fears, and, according to the Wall Street consensus, provided another reason for the Fed to cut interest rates. This generation's economic patent medicine, guaranteed to cure whatever ails you, is lower rates.
In fact, lower interest rates may be part of the problem. With bank savings rates so low, the much higher rates on loans seem extortionate, and that may be discouraging some would-be borrowers. Or perhaps the trend reflects a demographic development, with the heavy-borrowing age group of 25- to 34-year-olds now declining for the first time since the 1950's. Maybe, suggests Ms. Sterne, "the 1980's taught the consumer it was more rewarding to own financial assets than tangible assets. He would rather buy G.M.'s stock than its cars."
In the long run, it is probably good for Americans to save more and spend less. But for now the figures throw doubt on the belief that consumer confidence is growing, and they make a vigorous recovery appear even less likely.
And that, in turn, makes it probable that most of this quarter's earnings surprises, unlike the first quarter's, will be the kind that make stockholders cry rather than cheer.

HEADLINE: The 'How' in Home Improvement

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Depot Don, meet Martha Stewart.
At Home Depot, the nation's largest chain of warehouse-sized do-it-yourself stores, socket wrenches and lawn mowers are now available through a bridal registry. And homeowners can get interior design advice along with their paint and wallpaper, and then have their preferences put on file for better service the next time they shop. 
 Customers can also find greenhouses in an expanded gardening section and get special guidance on energy-saving products.
These are among the newest services and test programs being introduced by the home-improvement chain whose dedication to service, epitomized by "Depot Don" how-to displays throughout its stores, has helped it shine in an otherwise troubled industry. Featuring customer training, low prices and more than 34,000 items, Home Depot has leapfrogged over all its rivals over the last five years and is currently more than twice the size of its nearest competitor, a feat considering that the Atlanta-based retailer is only 13 years old. Now it hopes that the latest innovations plus an ambitious expansion plan will help that growth continue.
Not that its growth appears in jeopardy. Home Depot has been setting performance records in the $115 billion home-improvement industry, with sales increasing more than 35 percent each year over the past 10 years. In the last quarter alone, sales rose 38 percent and earnings jumped 55 percent. And since the beginning of last year, the company's stock price has soared 160 percent.
Others in the industry, meanwhile, are scrambling to get back into the game after falling behind amid intense competition and price wars. Some, like No. 2 Lowe's, Channel Home Centers and Hechinger, are adapting Home Depot's warehouse strategy, while others are setting up smaller stores to target merchandise niches the leader doesn't have, like furniture. The Rickel's chain, for instance, has decided to open a specialized store in New Jersey.
Among other stores, Mr. Goodbuy's was forced to close its chain in Philadelphia last year because of a competitive squeeze. And Pergament Home Centers is now rethinking its strategy after opening and closing several small home-improvement specialty stores.
"Home Depot is creating both a consolidation and a fragmentation in the home-center business," said Ken Schept, editor of National Home Center News.
Home Depot's two guiding lights, Bernard Marcus and Arthur Blank, who founded the company in Atlanta with one store in 1979, preached that in a do-it-yourself time, it was as important to teach people how to do it themselves as it was to provide the materials. And so to a greater extent than any other home-improvement retailer, Mr. Marcus, as chairman and chief executive, and Mr. Blank, president and chief operating officer, have trained their salespeople to train the customers in home repair and refurbishing.
Over the last 10 years, their efforts have driven sales up a hundredfold, from just $52 million to more than $5 billion. For the latest fiscal year, net income rose 52 percent, to $249.2 million, and sales climbed 35 percent, to $5.13 billion.
Following an already aggressive expansion plan that has put the chain in 15 states, the company now aims to triple its number of stores from 184 now to about 525 by late in the decade. As part of the chain's strategy, it clusters its stores around a big city, with 14 Home Depots, for instance, in the Atlanta area. The clusters are heaviest in Florida, with 42 stores, and in California, with 56.
The current expansion is mainly in the Northeast, where the company plans to add 15 stores this year to the 25 it now has. While New England has been nothing less than a disaster area for many retailers during the recession, it has been one of Home Depot's strongest markets.
The chain's new-store thrust plus its compound sales growth are causing many to liken it to Wal-Mart, the nation's largest retailer. In about 25 years, Wal-Mart sprung from its Arkansas base to jostle Sears, Roebuck from its No. 1 perch by building the country's largest chains of discount stores and warehouse clubs. But some analysts see Home Depot as even stronger in its field than Wal-Mart is in its.
"If we could own just one retail stock for the next three years, our choice would continue to be Home Depot," said Dan R. Wewer Jr., retailing analyst for the Robinson-Humphrey Company, an Atlanta brokerage firm. "No other billion-dollar retailer has the potential to grow 30 to 35 percent annually with such a low level of business risk."
Mr. Wewer cites the chain's high average annual sales per store -- about $31 million, or one-third higher than its competitors; its skill in teaching do-it-yourselfers, and its rising market share. He predicts Home Depot's market share will jump from about 6 percent this year to about 14 percent by 1996.
Yet bright as most analysts see Home Depot's prospects, some doubt it can sustain its growth rate through the decade.
"Statistically, if Home Depot continues to rack up its current growth rate and the market keeps up its 4.6 percent annual rate, Home Depot could virtually own the home-improvement business by the year 2000," says Walter Johnson, senior editor of Do-It-Yourself Retailing, a publication of the National Retail Hardware Association, based in Indianapolis. But he quickly adds that he does not believe it will happen because the company won't be able to open enough stores in enough markets to support that growth.
"A lot of Home Depot's growth is coming from the mid-sized D-I-Y chains, and once a consolidation of these retailers ends, the industry's sales trend must slow," he said.
And Christopher Vroom, of Alex Brown & Sons in Baltimore, observed that the company recently suffered some first-quarter erosion in its gross margin, which is the difference between the total cost of the goods and the final selling price, after enjoying an increase in the previous six quarters. He attributed the decline to "a more aggressive pricing stance in several markets, including the important San Diego trade area, and to increased sales contribution from lower-gross margin lumber products." But Mr. Vroom said Home Depot's expense-cutting program helped to lift operating profit in the quarter.
In separate interviews, both Mr. Marcus, 62, and Mr. Blank, 49, stressed the importance of strong employee motivation to the company's past and future success. New salespeople are not hired for their product knowledge, Mr. Blank said, but for their ability to raise the customer's enthusiasm about a product or project. The sales people "bleed orange," Mr. Marcus said, referring to the orange aprons that all store employees, including executives, wear.
As incentives, salespeople are paid 20 percent to 25 percent more than those at rival companies, Mr. Blank said. And the company contributes to an ESOP that is available to all employees, as is a standard employee stock purchase plan. The company's stock price gains have enriched many of its employees, although, like many growth stocks, the shares have slowed their climb this year; at $68.375 on Friday, the stock is up $1 this year.
But both executives cited three other important reasons for the company's high sales growth and strong profits.
Since the company's founding, Home Depot has avoided the middleman or wholesaler, buying directly from the producer to keep prices lower than those of the competition.
In addition, Mr. Black said, the company has continually stressed cutting expenses. Since 1985, expenses as a percent of sales have fallen from 19.2 to 18.1 percent last year, one of the industry's lowest ratios.
Finally, the company has tried to keep its merchandise assortment current through continuous customer testing. Says Mr. Marcus, "One of the biggest lessons we learned was that we had to listen to our customers, whether they had requests on specific kinds of merchandise, needed help or counsel or just wanted to complain. Now it's like a religion in our company."
On the merchandising aspect, Mr. Wewer, the Atlanta analyst, observed: "Home Depot is continually testing new merchandise ideas. Some of the ideas, such as the addition of greenhouses to the lawn and garden department, could have a major impact, while the test of a bridal registry probably will not prompt us to change any earnings estimate but looks like a great idea."
Analyst Bo Cheadle, managing director of Montgomery Securities, the San Francisco stock brokerage firm, likes Home Depot for its hard-nosed internal discipline. He cites the fact that the company's "S.P.I." -- store productivity improvement -- test program is now being extended to all new stores. The program involves using night hours for internal store cleaning, restocking and packaging.
With the industry growing about 5 percent to 7 percent a year, Mr. Marcus believes the field can reach $200 billion by the year 2000 through higher sales marked by company consolidations and new entrants. Shooting for sales next year of about $6 billion, Home Depot should be able to lift its 6 percent market share to about 25 percent by the turn of the century, meaning sales of about $50 billion, Mr. Marcus insists, adding: "We think there's room for 1,000 Home Depots in the United States."
 
 
 
MAKING A SPLASH IN ELMONT, L.I.

It took only a little more than a year for the Home Depot in Elmont, L.I., to rack up a weekly sales total that was not only a record for itself but for all stores in the chain.
Home Depot's top management saw the achievement as the occasion for a celebration and rewarded the store's 360 employees and guests with a party on May 17.
"It was an expensive proposition," admitted Harry Alfred, the regional manager, "but it was worth it. It was like a happy family get-together."
The Elmont store, which opened in February 1991 and is one of seven on Long Island, quickly became the biggest volume producer in the entire chain. Home Depot isn't saying how much the store did in sales in that record week, nor which week it was. But it was clearly a good chunk of business for the company to show such appreciation.
Like other Home Depot stores, the one in Elmont upholds the importance of teaching the customer. Much is made of "Depot Don" displays throughout the 140,000-square-foot store. Named for a "Don Someone" in a Texas Home Depot who came up with the idea, the displays demonstrate how to install various products.
But clinics, as many as four a day, are the store's main customer aid. Trained staff or supplier representatives teach customers how to install dry wall, put up a fence or plan a new kitchen, among other projects. A year ago, the store hired three interior decorators to assist the customers in color matching and other design considerations, reflecting a new trend in the do-it-yourself field.
"We keep a file on customers, so that we know what they like in wallpaper, paint and lighting and can help them over the telephone," said Marina Lopez, one of the interior decorators who is a graduate of New York Institute of Technology. Asked if home-improvement stores were invading the previously sacrosanct province of furniture specialty stores by staffing decorators, she shrugged and replied: "Why not? It makes a lot of sense, doesn't it?"

HEADLINE: Business Diary/June 7-12

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
In the Failure to Balance the Budget, Who Gains? Who Loses? 

In support of the constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget, President Bush held a prime-time news conference, made speeches and invited Congressional leaders to the White House to talk up the measure. But the amendment failed by nine votes. Mr. Bush may have received a measure of consolation from the defeat: He can continue to run for re-election against Congress' record. Business, however, got no such break. For companies -- and their competitiveness -- the real issue was the impact of the deficit on interest rates. "We have high long-term interest rates because the demand for funds from the Federal Government is draining savings that should go into investments in plants and equipment and into modernization," said Richard D. Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities Inc. In the balanced-budget 1950's, "real interest rates were 2 to 3 percent. Now they are 4 to 5 percent," he said.

Continental v. American Airlines
 
No market is more competitive -- or merciless -- than the airline market. But when American Airlines lowered its fares and reduced its advanced purchase requirements, Continental Airlines -- which is operating under the protection of Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy code -- said it had gone too far. In a suit filed in Federal District Court in Galveston, Tex., Continental said American was practicing "predatory pricing." Continental asserted American's pricing strategy can only earn it a profit if one of its rivals is driven out of business. "Preposterous," said Al Becker, a spokesman for American Airlines. Continental's charges, which rely on highly technical data, will be difficult to prove.

Seattle Mariners, by Nintendo
 
Not since the Brooklyn Dodgers moved to Chavez Ravine have baseball aficionados been in such a tizzy. But last week, the baseball commissioner, Fay Vincent, stunned fans by announcing that the Baseball Group of Seattle will be permitted to take over the Seattle Mariners for $125 million. What alarmed fans even more than the Mariners 15-year losing steak --they lost more games than they won each season -- was that 60 percent of the cash will come from the Nintendo Company of Japan. It is the first time a company outside of North America has taken an interest in a major league team. Nintendo promised it would be a passive investor. That was enough to persuade Mr. Vincent.
 
Gerber Cuts a New Tooth
 
The biggest problem for the Gerber Products Company, the nation's No. 1 baby food maker, is that all of its best customers grow up. To grab a share of the toothsome-toddler set, Gerber announced plans to introduce a new line of vegetables, snacks and stews aimed at 2- to 3-year-olds. Do toddlers really need a line of canned goods when theyalready have peanut butter? "It is a completely unnecessary product," said Kate Clancy, a professor of nutrition at Syracuse University.

Critic Pans -- and Is Panned
 
Critics are supposed to be tough but fair, and movie studios are supposed to take their lumps along with their laurels. But last week, Paramount Pictures changed the rules when Daily Variety, a trade newspaper, ran a scathing review of "Patriot Games," Paramount's newest big-budget release based on the novel by Tom Clancy and starring Harrison Ford. The critical review, written by Joseph McBride, described Mr. Clancy's novel as "a right-wing cartoon of the current British-Irish political situation," -- not exactly the kind of quote Paramount can use to promote the film. The review prompted the studio to withdraw its ads from Variety. Peter Bart, Variety's editor, apologized to Paramount.

Two Utilities Link Up
 
When the Entergy Corporation of New Orleans said it planned to buy Texas-based Gulf States Utilities for $2.3 billion, it did so saying it would achieve economies of scale. The two companies told analysts the combination will save $600 million in fuel costs over 10 years. Under the terms of the agreement, Entergy will pay $20 a share for Gulf States stock either in cash or in its own shares at the option of shareholders. It would also link the two companies' power transmission grids and let other companies tap into their network. Wall Street liked the deal. Gulf States stock closed up $1.25 to $15.75 after the announcement and finished the week at $15.

U.P.I. Holds Its Breath
 
When TV-evangelist Pat Robertson withdrew his $6 million offer last week for United Press International, the 85-year-old wire service with 2,000 outlets worldwide, it looked like the end for the company. U.P.I., which filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code last summer, has just $22 million in assets and $60 million in debt. Mr. Robertson estimated it would take $31 million over 18 months to save it. But hours before it was supposed to close, Leon H. Charney, a New York lawyer and TV commentator, came through with an offer -- of sorts. Mr. Charney is providing $180,000 to keep U.P.I. open until June 22. During that period, he will study the service's books and possibly submit a bid to save it. "We are not making a whole lot of plans for coverage next week at the moment," said Doug Levy, a U.P.I. reporter.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Tokyo: How Much Is Enough?
 
Last month Japan's overall trade surplus jumped 88.9 percent from a year ago, to $7.87 billion, the Finance Ministry reported. Japan's trade surplus with the United States jumped 51 percent from a year ago, to $2.92 billion. But it seems even that was not enough for Tokyo. Last week, it accused the United States of unfair trading practices. The United States has a "buy American" provision in some Government contracts, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said. The United States trade representatives' office disagreed: "Everybody knows the United States has the most open market in the world."
 
On the eve of his visit to the United States -- and with the prospect of $24 billion in aid looming -- Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin said he would soon issue decrees lifting some of the barriers to privatization.
 
G.M.'s Saturn Hits Taiwan
 
The General Motors Corporation has been pummeled by its critics for its losses, but it is being praised now for the performance of its Saturn Corporation subsidiary. The cars have adorned the covers of the buff books, its dealers have scored high marks for customer satisfaction and the car's quality is rated at Japanese levels. But until last week, when the Saturn went on sale in Taiwan, Saturns were only available here. G.M. won't be turning the trade deficit around all at once-- not even America's deficit with Taiwan. Only a few hundred Saturns will be exported initially. And they won't come cheap. Though Saturn prices begin at $8,395 here, the cars will cost $22,800 in Taiwan, which is attributed, in part, to a 30 percent duty Taiwan will impose.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
A Cleaner-Car Council
 
When Detroit's Big three get together, it's usually to lobby in Washington. But last week they met to set up a program to design and manufacture cleaner cars. The United States Council for Automotive Research will conduct "pre-competitive" research in areas including battery technology for electric vehicles, pollution control, recycling and computer-aided design and manufacturing. The program "will enable us to reduce vehicle emissions in a more rapid and cost-effective manner than we might achieve independently," said John P. McTague, head of technical affairs at the Ford Motor Company. General Motors, Ford and Chrysler will be joined in the project by oil and utilities companies. Why are the Big Three making nice to each other with regard to technology? California's tough pollution controls go into effect in 1997 and so far they look lobby-proof.
 
Hunkered-Down Consumers
 
Nudging the nation's economy into the fast lane has not been easy. Last month retail sales rose by a slim 0.2 percent, the Commerce Department said.. Sales of clothing and building supplies actually fell, counterbalancing a rise in new-car sales. According to Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company, "the consumer remains in a hunkered-down position, cautiously spending."."
 
Bad Guys: Energy and Tobacco
 
After behaving for months, prices at the producer level shot up last month by 0.4 percent, the largest increase in 19 months, the Commerce Department said. Sharply rising prices for energy and tobacco were responsible for most of last month's jump in inflation at the producer level. "We have to keep one eye cocked on inflation. It's still out there," said Robert Dederick, chief economist at Northern Trust in Chicago. "It hasn't died."
 
Consumer Prices Hold
 
Producer prices may be soaring but consumer prices' wings seem clipped. The Commerce Department's Consumer Price Index increased by 0.1 percent in May -- barely a budge. Why the difference between the two indexes? While the producer index is heavily weighted with raw materials and energy, "the consumer index is weighted toward services and housing," said Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist at Fuji Securities in Chicago. But if the two indicators differ, what's the real inflation rate? "About 3.5 percent, a number we can live with, " Mr. Kahan said.

The Federal Trade Commission brought charges against the three largest makers of infant formula last week for overcharging the Special Supplemental Food Program for Women, Infants and Children, which is funded by the Federal government and the states.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
A Busy Agenda Gets Busier

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
One of the duties of a company leader is to get involved outside the company. John L. Clendenin, chairman and chief executive of the BellSouth Corporation, clearly is dutiful. He is the national president of the Boy Scouts of America. He is a trustee of the Conference Board, a business research group. And he sits on the boards of the Coca-Cola Company and the New York Stock Exchange, among others.
Now, Mr. Clendenin, as busy as he is, has taken on still one more outside post: chairman of the Committee for Economic Development, a prestigious New York-based business group that looks at economic problems, recommends solutions and tries to get some action. 
 "That's part of my role," Mr. Clendenin said in an interview last week, "to involve myself in some of these external organizations when I feel that doing those kinds of things is important for the country."
Which is not to say that doing those things isn't important to BellSouth, too. "The future work force of America is important to us, as it is to any major employer," Mr. Clendenin said. "It's not like working on education, for example, is foreign to my concern about BellSouth. I've got to worry about where we will get our employees in the next decade."
Education, he said, ranks "right up there among the great problems," and the Committee for Economic Development has a history of work in education policy.
Mr. Clendenin, 59 years old, succeeds Owen B. Butler, former chairman of the Procter & Gamble Company, as chairman of the committee. Mr. Clendenin has been chief executive of BellSouth, based in Atlanta and the largest of the regional Bell companies, since 1984.
And just how does he manage all his outside activities? "I spend a lot of time on this kind of thing before the hour of 7 in the morning and after 5 at night," he said.

HEADLINE: At Work;
New Questions About Arbitration

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
Like an investor who signs on with a broker, employees of stock and commodities exchanges and the National Association of Securities Dealers must agree to submit any grievances to an arbitration panel. In both cases, the panel is typically dominated by people with industry ties, and people filing complaints have long grumbled that the process is stacked against them.
Now, with a rise in awareness of sexual harassment since the Anita Hill-Clarence Thomas controversy last fall and with the enactment of the Civil Rights Act of 1991, an increase in the number of harassment and discrimination grievances is widely expected. Critics say such cases are particularly inappropriate for the arbitration process. Employment discrimination "is a complex area of law," said Richard M. Gelb, a securities litigator in Boston. "Industry arbitrators know the industry, but they have no expertise in the area of employment discrimination. You're asking management to judge itself." 
 For years, controversy has roiled around the resolution of disputes between brokers and individual investors. The investors' argument that the process favors the brokerage houses got support last month from a two-year General Accounting Office study that concluded that arbitration programs, while not biased, do not "provide a reasonable level of assurance regarding either the independence of the arbitrators or their competence in arbitrating disputes."
The rules for investor-broker contretemps apply as well to employees of the brokerage industry. They sign a "Form U-4" agreement, which binds them to arbitration if they have complaints about the conditions of their employment -- or termination.
Theoretically, arbitration is economical and efficient. Proponents say conflicts that take years to resolve in court take mere months of arbitration, at a savings in legal fees and energy. "There's a light at the end of the tunnel," said Samantha Raybin of the Securities Arbitration Commentator, a newsletter in Maplewood, N.J.
But critics say the process is an involuntary quasi-legal nightmare, in which arbitrators are told they do not have to follow the law. Discovery, the method by which the facts of a case are elicited before trial, is truncated; proceedings are carried out virtually in secret, and many panels are not required to disclose how they reached a decision. "If the proceedings are private, a company can merely calculate in simple dollars what it costs to discriminate and budget it in," said Cliff Palefsky, a lawyer in San Francisco who is leading efforts by the National Employment Lawyers Association to change the arbitration system. He thinks public decisions would provide a greater incentive for companies to follow the law. "If potential employees could find out who has a reputation for discrimination, who has lost sexual harassment cases, they could make informed decisions," he said.
Mr. Palefsky complains that the lists of arbitrators drawn from pools established at N.A.S.D. and the exchanges are not made public, though arbitrators are required to disclose any potential conflicts in a proceeding. "You get a printout of where people have worked for five years," he said. "You should be able to ask, 'Have you ever been sued for sexual harassment? Do you believe in sexual harassment or civil rights law? Would you have trouble imposing the law?' You don't have the right to question arbitrators the way you would question a prospective juror."
The simplicity of the system is its beauty, according to proponents. Ideally, a complaint could be pursued pro se -- by the employee alone, without counsel. But even those who on balance favor arbitration are concerned that the process has come to resemble a legal proceeding, with a multiplication of briefs and motions, and more lawyers. "It has become a litigation practice, not an arbitration," said Thomas D. Giachetti, a Princeton, N.J., lawyer and stockbroker who has handled arbitration cases for several years. "You can't do it on a pro se basis anymore. You need experts."
Mr. Palefsky is preparing to file suit challenging the requirement that employees of the brokerage industry waive their access to courts and protections under the Civil Rights Act. Other such challenges have not fared well in the courts. Last year, the United States Supreme Court ruled that a former stockbroker suing under a Federal age-discrimination statute was bound by his compulsory arbitration agreement. In April, the New York State Supreme Court ruled that a sex-discrimination complaint brought by a Goldman, Sachs employee must be submitted to arbitration. Mr. Palefsky, who clearly relishes his barrister-on-the-barricades role, is convinced that this time the court will see his light.
 
 
 
LAWYERS NEED NOT COMPLAIN
 Deborah Masucci, director of arbitration at the National Association of Securities Dealers, strenuously objects to claims by employees' lawyers that her arbitrators do not have the expertise to hear employment cases.
"Arbitrators generally have a background in the disputed area," she said. "If we can't locate one, we will ask the parties to agree to an arbitrator."
Predictions that the Civil Rights Act of 1991 would provoke a rush of complaints have yet to materialize in arbitration offices. Ms. Masucci said some of her 6,000 arbitrators have heard harassment cases, but none has had a civil rights case.
The 2,900 arbitrators of the New York Stock Exchange also rarely see sexual discrimination or harassment cases, according to James E. Buck, secretary of the exchange. But should cases turn up, they would pose no problem. "Discrimination is not something where expertise is necessary," Mr. Buck said. "It's not like admiralty, where you have to know about arcane rules. The evidence is understandable to ordinary men."

LENGTH: 1116 words

HEADLINE: Dan Quayle Steps Front and (Right of) Center

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FOR months and years, he was all but invisible to the public, unless he made some foolish mistake. He was dismissed as a political cipher. People laughed at him in the spiteful way people laugh at the class geek.
But the wheel of electoral fortune has turned, and suddenly Vice President Dan Quayle is at the center of things. Like it or not, he has found ways to impress his views more sharply on the public consciousness than any other candidate for top office this year -- certainly far more vividly than the man he works for, George Bush, whose somnambulant behavior and cloudy message have given his Vice President the chance to grab the spotlight. 
 What he is trying to accomplish (it is far from clear whether he is making much headway) is the repair of the fraying coalition that elected Richard M. Nixon and Ronald Reagan and, in 1988, Mr. Bush and Mr. Quayle.
The key to that coalition was the group of voters who have come to be known as "Reagan Democrats" but who have, in fact, been voting Republican for President since they gave one last heave for their own party in 1964.
White, often eastern or southern European in origin, blue-collar or newly white collar, clustered in suburbs like Parma, Ohio, and Warren, Mich., and in urban quarters like Queens and South Boston, they flocked to the Republicans because economics mattered less to them than social issues such as busing, sexual permissiveness, drugs, long hair, patriotism, law and order.
Those Archie Bunkers and their families cheered George C. Wallace when he derided the "pointy-headed intellectuals" who he said "couldn't park a bicycle straight" and applauded Spiro T. Agnew when he spoke about the "nattering nabobs of negativism" who he said dominated the press.
In 1992, those voters have been slipping away from the President, partly because they feel he has betrayed them on taxes and on racial quotas, but also because the issues that Mr. Bush featured in 1988, largely through symbols -- patriotism through his visits to flag factories, law and order through the Willie Horton commercials -- have been declining in saliency.
Jobs, health care and education have come to the fore, and those are Democratic issues in most elections. At the height of the dominance of social issues, in 1968, with a generation in rebellion, Hubert H. Humphrey almost snatched a victory at the last minute by refocusing the attention of many voters on basic economic questions. Mr. Bush is highly vulnerable there this year.
So Mr. Quayle is trying to shift the focus back, playing the populist card as fervently as Ross Perot, who has caught the imagination of many of the Reagan Democrats in the last two months.
Unlike Mr. Perot, Mr. Quayle was born to privilege as the scion of a newspaper-owning family, but that has not stopped him from donning the robes of the common man determined to face down a "cultural elite" that mocks religion, family values and patriotism.
The White House did not seem quite prepared when the Vice President attacked the heroine of the "Murphy Brown" television show, criticizing the character as if she were real for having borne a child out of wedlock. Mr. Bush and his aides gulped and fumbled when asked for a response, fearful perhaps that it was bad politics to tangle with so popular a show.
But Mr. Quayle and his advisers, notably William Kristol, thought otherwise and pressed on.
Speaking to the Southern Baptist Convention in Indianapolis last week, he denounced sex education in primary schools, free condoms and homosexual parents and spoke of warring American cultures.
"They'll try to mock us in newsrooms, sitcom studios and faculty lounges across America," he said. "I wear their scorn as a badge of honor."
No wonder. Journalists rank almost as low as politicians in opinion polls, college professors have always been suspect to many in this frontier-rooted nation and few people have ever identified with Hollywood mores.
But different families have different values. Some exalt money, others exalt service. Some are religious, some are not. And some are opposed to abortion, like the Vice President, but a larger number support it in some form.
A new survey for The Reader' Digest suggests that one thing setting family units apart from one another is their structure. Married people with children, the national poll discovered, are likely to be far more conservative, more opposed to abortion, less enthusiastic about women working outside the home and less tolerant of the idea of homosexual marriage than single persons or childless couples.
Abortion in many ways typifies the complexity of the issues which Mr. Quayle seeks for political purposes to simplify. He himself told The Washington Post a year ago, "I think people make a mistake trying to exploit it in the political realm."
But in Indianapolis and again at an anti-abortion rally in Washington on Thursday, Mr. Quayle did just that, even though exit polls in California, for example, showed that even Republicans are overwhelmingly opposed to the absolutism of the Bush-Quayle position.
Is the Vice President bent on political suicide? Not necessarily, given the potential arithmetic of a hard-fought three-way Presidential race.
Charles R. Black Jr., the senior strategic adviser to the Bush campaign, put the matter as plainly as possible in a talk with reporters on Thursday:
"In any campaign, the first task is to solidify the base. In a three-way race, 38 to 40 percent may be enough. And in a three-way race with two pro-choice candidates" -- Mr. Perot and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas -- "I believe that the one pro-life candidate has an advantage."
Mr. Bush greeted the second round of thunder from Mr. Quayle more warmly than the first. But some of his advisers think that the Vice President, ever eager to cement his conservative standing for 1996, may push the President into a campaign that begins and ends with the conservative base and leaves most voters happy to chose between Mr. Perot and Mr. Clinton.
Without his bellicose advisers of 1988, Roger Ailes and the late Lee Atwater, the President has seemed willing to let Mr. Quayle stir the controversy on social issues, then follow up himself if the reaction seems favorable.
Those tactics have not stood him in good stead; he now trails Mr. Perot in most polls, and his overall job approval has plunged from 90 percent or thereabouts in March 1991 to about 35 per cent early this month.
But Mr. Quayle, for all his bristling combativeness, hasn't done much better. A Washington Post/ABC News Poll showed him with a 39 percent favorable rating last February and a 26 percent figure post-Murphy Brown.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Vice President Quayle with Wanda Franz, president of the National Right to Life Committee, at the organization's convention in Arlington, Va., last week. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times) (pg. 1)
 
Chart: "Quayle's Targets"
 
In recent days Vice President Quayle has singled out a number of people and groups for criticism during his speeches. Here are some of them:
 
The cultural elites . . .
 
". . . respect neither tradition nor standards. They believe that moral truths are relative and all 'lifestyles' are equal. They seem to think the family is an arbitrary arrangement of people who live under the same roof -- that fathers are dispensable and that parents need not be married or even of opposite sexes."
--Tuesday, in a speech to the Southern Baptist Convention in Indianapolis.
 
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo . . .
 
. . . is trying to "fall in with the crowd who wants to dismiss the importance of values." "The Governor knows better than that. He understands the importance of family values."
-- Wednesday, during a news conference at a community center in Hempstead, Long Island.
 
Ross Perot . . .
 
" . . . is a false solution to our problems. . . It would be a very bad idea to replace a genuine statesman with some temperamental tycoon who has contempt for the Constitution of the United States."
 
Senior Senators
 
"Since the constitution has limited Ronald Reagan and George Bush to two terms, we ought to be fair to the other elected branch and limit the terms of people like Ted Kennedy and Howard Metzenbaum."
-- Friday, speech to Federalist Society for Law and Public Policy Studies convention in Washington. (pg. 3)

HEADLINE: Conversations/Warren Zimmermann;
Haunted by What the U.S. Didn't Do in Yugoslavia

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER

 BODY:
THOUSANDS of Serbian artillery shells raining death and destruction on Sarajevo. United Nations relief convoys attacked by irregulars. The ancient port of Dubrovnik under fire again. More than 15,000 killed and more than 1.2 million made homeless by 11 months of war. No end in sight.
These are scenes Warren Zimmermann left behind when he was recalled by the Bush Administration in mid-May from his post as United States Ambassador to Yugoslavia. The withdrawal of the Ambassador was an act of protest against the Serbian leadership for its aggression against the newly independent republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina. 
 When he took up his post in Belgrade in March 1989, the Soviet Union and its East European bloc were intact. So was independent Yugoslavia. Though riddled by inflation and threatened by nationalist forces, Communist Yugoslavia was a country with a promising future.
Now there is no Soviet Union and no bloc, and the federal Yugoslavia the world and 23 million Yugoslavs knew for 46 years lies in ruins.
During Mr. Zimmermann's tenure it seemed as if United States policy toward the Yugoslav crisis veered between relative indifference and hands-on activism. Last week, in a quiet Washington office, the 57-year-old diplomat reflected on the nature and consistency of U.S. policy.
"If U.S. policy shifted toward Yugoslavia, it shifted at the beginning of the Bush Administration," he said. "We made it clear to Yugoslavia that we would continue to support the unity of the country, but that the disappearance of the Soviet Union as a major adversary made our support dependent on a different set of factors. We were ready to support unity, but only in the interest of human rights, only insofar as it was not to be maintained by force.
"Parallel with this," he continued, "was our analysis -- which turned out to be true -- that if Yugoslavia split up it would only do so with maximum violence. That explained why we urged Croatia and Slovenia to remain in Yugoslavia, and if they could not, at least to negotiate their way out. I think we maintained an entirely consistent approach to Yugoslavia and continued it past the outbreak of war."
 
Washington Reverses Itself
 Mr. Zimmermann was asked why Washington initially opposed the European Community's decision to recognize the separate republics of Croatia and Bosnia, and then reversed its stance.
The United States, he replied, was fearful that recognition would prolong the fighting in Croatia and trigger a war in Bosnia. "With regard to Bosnia, our fears proved out."
Was he implying that the German push for early recognition of Croatia provoked more violence?
"We opposed the German initiative at the time. I continue to think the initiative was wrong, but it is now a part of reality."
Did the United States step aside from the Yugoslav mess?
"We made a conscious decision a year ago to cede the leadership role to the E.C. for two reasons," he said. "First, the Community wanted the lead role. Second, Yugoslavia is in Europe. But we weren't sitting on our hands. It's easier to see with hindsight. We couldn't predict a year ago that the Community would have problems getting itself together -- problems with Greece, with Germany. We do represent something in Yugoslavia that Europe doesn't -- a democratic tradition, a country that helped Yugoslavs individually and collectively for many decades. So we cannot be absent from future dealings with Yugoslavia and we won't be."
So what would he have done differently?
"Obviously I have spent a lot of time thinking about this. It might have helped if we had urged earlier a very loose confederation rather than taking a neutral stance. But I am not even sure about this. You had competing and aggressive nationalisms that were not going to be influenced by democratic appeals. The greatest culprit is Slobodan Milosevic [President of Serbia]. In invoking the unity of Yugoslavia he did more than anyone else to destroy it."
After three years of Milosevic-watching, Mr. Zimmermann concluded that he was dealing with a split personality. "There were two Milosevics: The Milosevic I saw many times arguing that he had nothing to do with Bosnia, that Serbs there were not threatened, that no irregulars from Serbia were in combat in Bosnia, that his only wish was a negotiated settlement leading to peace.
"The other Milosevic -- never on public display -- was the man who gave moral, political and military support to the most extreme Serbian fanatics in Bosnia, who worked hand in glove with the army to stake out two-thirds of Bosnia for a Serbian population consisting of only one-third of the entire population.
"I hope he will ponder the contradiction between what he promised the Serbian people when he ran for election in 1990 -- peace and economic prosperity -- and what he delivered: two wars and economic disaster."
 
Critic of Nationalism
 As for Washington's intentions toward Belgrade, Mr. Zimmermann said, "U.S. policy is to get Milosevic to change his mind or, if he doesn't, to get the Serbian people to put the kind of pressure on him to cause him to change his mind."
He then appraised the situation of President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia. "Tudjman is a nationalist leader who made some very bad mistakes early in his presidency toward Croatia's Serbian minority. He also advocated a partition of Bosnia and Herzegovina between Serbia and Croatia. He has given at least passive support to Croatian military forces in Bosnia. That said, he is a man who has learned from his mistakes."
In the months before he was recalled from Belgrade, Mr. Zimmermann, a student of history, had been reading classics of Roman and Greek civilization and studies of contemporary Europe, which influenced his thinking. "Yugoslavia is a paradigm," he mused, "for other countries in Central Europe and the Soviet Union of a collectivist ideology of Communism replaced by another collectivist ideology, nationalism.
"Being collectivist, the ideologies are exclusivist: If you are not a member of the collective, you are an enemy and have to be liquidated. This ideology places total value in the collective and none in the individual. It is real in Yugoslavia and in other areas ."
Mr. Zimmermann spent seven years in Yugoslavia and remains deeply affected by the unending calamities. "Our thoughts will never be far from that tortured place," he said. "My wife and I decided to make a small compensation for all that we gained from our friendships with Serbs and Croats by bringing back with us a refugee." The 22-year-old woman's native city, Vukovar, was leveled by the Yugoslav Army last year. The Zimmermanns have given her a new home, and offered to help pay her college tuition.
As for the future he said, "I remain convinced that there are democratic forces throughout the territory of what used to be called Yugoslavia. But the fevers of nationalism are going to have to abate. I don't know how many more will have to die before it does. At some point or other there will be a strong impetus for those people who lived together for so long to come back into some form of an association. We're talking decades here. But I predict that this will happen."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ambassador Warren Zimmermann in Washington. (Michael Geissinger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Diplomatic Notebook;
The Odd Art of Summitry Without a Cold War

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
PRESIDENT BORIS N. YELTSIN and President Bush will hold their first full-scale summit meeting this week in a weird twilight moment of Russian-American relations -- a moment when the two countries have stopped being enemies but aren't quite allies yet. Consider a few recent scenes from the relationship:
It is last Tuesday, and Russia's Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, has just spent two days in Washington trying to explain to the Bush Administration why the Russian military is reluctant to give up all of its SS-18 intercontinental ballistic missiles, as Washington was demanding in the latest nuclear arms reduction talks. Mr. Kozyrev's discomfort shows as he leaves a meeting with President Bush at the White House. After all, his country is asking Washington for billions in economic assistance, but his military wants to keep its most advanced nuclear missiles. Mr. Kozyrev somewhat sheepishly explains to American reporters on the White House driveway: "I want to make one thing absolutely clear: We do not need those arms and we are not going to use them against the United States." 
 Well, that's good to know.
It is Sunday night and Mr. Kozyrev has just attended a private dinner given by a Russian artist at the hot new Washington Tex-Mex restaurant, Red Sage. Much of the dinner talk was about the importance Russia attaches to American economic aid, and the concerns in Moscow over America's inward turn. After dinner, Mr. Kozyrev walks out the door and finds himself looking straight at a shirtless panhandler sitting on a curbside bench. The man is cradling a white begging cup in his lap and has a cane by his side. He is totally befuddled by the security guards and police cars surrounding Mr. Kozyrev. A bizarre tableau takes shape with Mr. Kozyrev, standing at the panhandler's elbow, asking his American security guards whether he can walk back to the Russian Embassy, for exercise. He is told no: 14th Street is not safe and he might get mugged.
Who needs help from whom in this picture?
In a Senate Foreign Relations Committee staff office, Congressional aides are working on the language of the Bush Administration's multi-billion-dollar legislative package to assist Russia and other former Soviet republics, which is now slowly working its way through Congress. But they suddenly get word from the Administration that Russia is about to sell ballistic missile technology to India. Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Delaware Democrat who is probably the staunchest advocate in the Senate for the Russian aid package, demands that the bill be amended to say that if the Russians go ahead with the sale, Washington will not provide any Government-to-Government assistance.
Says one member of the committee staff: "We looked at this sale and said: 'Hey, wait a minute. Why should we write a check to the same Russian Government that is receiving a check from India for selling missile technology we think is wrong and violates an international standard on nonproliferation?' We decided to try to force them to make a choice in the same bill. But it was an odd position to be in."
Odd indeed. But it is probably best to get used to such bizarre contradictions, because they are going to be a staple in Russian-American relations for the foreseeable future -- for several reasons. To begin with, as Americans are just beginning to understand, the fact that the cold war is over and the fact that a freely elected President now inhabits the Kremlin do not mean that the interests of Russia and America will be compatible in every case, or even that their arms race is over.
"Russian nationalism, Russian history and Russian pride make some degree of strategic parity with the United States still very important to Russia," said Michael Mandelbaum, an expert on East-West relations at Johns Hopkins University.
 
Symbols of Power
 Although Russia is no longer an ideological enemy of the United States it is still a great power, and great powers don't just bid farewell to their past and willingly accept a diminished role. Ownership of the most advanced nuclear missiles is precisely what makes Russia a global player, and what distinguishes it from China or India or Ukraine. Russian democrats understand this. As aides to President Yeltsin are fond of saying: Russian democrats cannot afford not to be nationalists or they will be swept away. That means they cannot afford to look weak defending the symbols of Russian nationalism either, and among the most powerful of those symbols remains a global nuclear capacity.
Another factor is economics. Russia needs both American aid and markets abroad for its huge military-industrial complex -- a holdover from the cold war that cannot be converted overnight from making machine guns to making sewing machines. Mr. Yeltsin, for the near future, needs to be able to sell arms, win Western aid, and begin converting military factories to the sale of consumer products. It is going to be a tough circle for him to square. It is worth recalling that since the end of the ideological struggle between Washington and Beijing, American-Chinese relations have actually deteriorated -- partly because of China's human rights record, but also because of its trade policies, particularly its missile exports and the dumping of cheaply made goods from its state-owned factories on the American market.
There was a time when the mere arrival of a Soviet leader in Washington would electrify the city, and whoever was President could expect an automatic boost in stature -- and air time -- from the chance to demonstrate leadership at a summit. But in advance of Mr. Yeltsin's visit, Washington seems bored and distracted. Unlike cold war summits, there is no life-or-death quality to this encounter. To many, Mr. Yeltsin seems just another foreign leader begging for money that should go to American cities.
He comes, after all, at a time when America is looking only in the mirror. Indeed, last week when Mr. Kozyrev emerged from his discussions with Mr. Bush, the last question he got from the White House press was: "Mr. Foreign Minister, in your discussions with the President, did Ross Perot's name come up?"

HEADLINE: Wild Youth, Angry Police, and Shots in Newark

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD with JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, June 12

 BODY:
There was, perhaps, a certain inevitability to it all. For months, the police in this troubled industrial city chafed at legal restraints that kept them from controlling youths who, mostly for fun, stole about 40 cars a night, screaming through darkened streets doing "doughnuts" at deserted intersections and ramming police cruisers to explode their air bags.
Hampered by restraints prohibiting them from high-speed chases and prevented, because most of the thieves are juveniles, from imposing strict penalties on those caught, the police seethed in frustration. 
 To the youths, some of whom were not yet in their teens, it was a game, a taunt at the authorities in a city that offered little hope. "This is a ghetto," said Barbara Davis, a 53-year-old nurse and local advocate who lives in its heart. "These kids don't have much. Car theft is all the kids have to do."
 
Average Night Gone Awry
 Tuesday, several hours before dawn, those two cultures clashed again, as they had every night for months. But that morning, something went awry. Police officers trying to apprehend 17-year-old Howard Caesar fired several shots. Mr. Caesar was gravely wounded.
Six officers have been suspended without pay amid an investigation by the Essex County Prosecutor's office into a possible cover-up. Mayor Sharpe James of Newark has said that the officers' statements are sketchy and provide conflicting accounts.
The events of the early-morning hours of June 9 are not entirely clear, but a reconstruction by The New York Times, based largely on the accounts of neighborhood witnesses and on the limited details provided by Mayor James and the police, indicates the following:
*Police officers at the scene fired their weapons in clear violation of strict New Jersey regulations.
*They may not have known Mr. Caesar was hit because he was able to run away swiftly, disappearing into a relative's house.
*Officers at the scene were later observed searching a grassy area at the edge of the park with flashlights, apparently in an attempt to recover spent cartridges. No shell casings were recovered at the scene later, police officials say.
*At least one officer cleaned his gun before turning it in to investigators, in violation of standing rules. The reports required after an officer fires his weapon were either filed late or falsified, police officials say.
The six officers suspended in the inquiry are Kenneth Holloway, 30 years old; Michael Cavallero, 28; John Costa, 25; Naftalis Mendez, 31; Jose Montalvo, 23; and Gerard Piacenza, 23. Lawyers for the officers have said their clients are cooperating with the inquiry, but have declined to provide details of the officers' accounts.
The night, like so many others in the neighborhood, started with idleness and ended in gunfire.
Edna Williams, Howard Ceasar's aunt, said her nephew left home with several friends about 6 P.M.
By midnight they were in Mr. Caesar's old neighborhood, near West Side Park, where the family lived until this year. There they milled about outside one of their regular haunts, King's Fried Chicken, a simple fast-food store on 16th Avenue near 17th Street where workers stand behind a bulletproof shield. Residents of the neighborhood say it is a hangout for drug dealers, and even on weekdays several young dealers usually squat near the store, waiting for customers.
 
Simple Video Games, Or Tag With Police
 William Anderson, an unemployed 28-year-old, was at the restaurant that night and says that a group of several dozen young men, including his friend, Mr. Caesar, lounged about playing Street Fighter II, a video game based on karate. Sometime after midnight, Mr. Caesar, who is called "Bucky," left the store with friends.
Between 2 and 3 A.M., Mr. Anderson said he saw a black Camaro leading three police cars in a chase down 16th Avenue. That car chase, Mr. Anderson said, was typical of the nightly games of cat and mouse played by the police and local youths. As Mr. Anderson watched, the cars screamed past the restaurant and vanished. They returned several times over the next few hours, but Mr. Anderson said he could not tell who was in the vehicles.
After about an hour, at least one of the police cars parked on a road inside the West Side Park, Mr. Anderson and several other residents said. There, it apparently lay in wait for the Camaro, in a practice so familiar it is known by the slang term, "squatting."
Four of the six police officers later identified as being at the scene were from the West District, which encompasses the park. The two others were from the North District, where the car was believed to have been stolen from the mother of a Newark police officer.
By 4 A.M., the black Camaro drove into sight, paused at the intersection of 16th Avenue and 17th Street, then turned in several squealing, tight circles -- "doughnuts" -- that left black tire smudges on the asphalt.
Although commonplace, the noise awoke many residents. On the street, Mr. Anderson saw the Camaro slam into a curb, breaking its axle. The driver gunned the engine several times and then, leaving the radio blaring, emerged to check the damage. The driver was Mr. Caesar.
 
'Kill Him. Kill Him.'
 Over at the chicken store, Mr. Anderson and several others called out a warning that the police were nearby. Mr. Anderson said he saw Mr. Caesar start to run, then heard shots.
In an apartment nearby, Walter Brown, a 45-year-old welder, had leftfor dawn prayers at his mosque. "I was trying to go back to sleep," his wife, Vera, said. "But then I heard shots. There were two of them. Pow. Pow. And I heard someone shout: 'Kill him. Kill him.' "
Mrs. Brown, a 30-year-old factory worker, did not go to her window out of fear. But she did look at her clock. The red digital numbers showed 4:14.
A witness on the street, Shawn Freeman, 17, a student at Central High School, said Mr. Caesar had just gotten out of the car to look at the broken wheel when he was shot. "He grabbed himself and started to run," he said. "I couldn't understand it, but he was moving fast."
 
A Chase on Foot, An Injured Youth
 By that time, many residents were at their windows. In one apartment, a 15-year-old and a 26-year-old watched as two police officers chased the wounded Mr. Caesar down the street. A third officer, a heavyset man later identified as Officer Holloway, chased a passenger from the Camaro north up 17th Street.
As the chase continued on foot, Mr. Caesar, running fast despite injuries to his abdomen, liver, stomach and spleen, disappeared around the corner at 18th Street and into the stairwell of his cousins' home.
"When he ran by, I realized it was Bucky," Mr. Anderson said. "The way he was running, you wouldn't know he was shot."
The police returned to the park, having failed to catch either suspect. There, witnesses said, they searched for something in the grass with their flashlights.
Mr. Caesar, meanwhile, was bleeding profusely from his stomach. When Mr. Anderson and several others reached him, he lay just inside the front door, clutching his side. His friends carried him to the second-floor apartment, where the cousins, after a brief debate over whether to notify the authorities, called an ambulance. Mr. Caesar is listed in critical condition, and is on life-support equipment, at University Hospital.
The specific times of these events remain somewhat unclear. A police dispatcher called at 4:41 A.M. for response to a shooting. One minute later, the Camaro, which the authorities say was registered to the mother of Police Officer Dino D'Elia, was reported stolen by Officer D'Elia's brother.
 
A Vast Web of Regulations
 The six officers were in trouble. Under New Jersey law a police officer may fire at a suspect only if the officer thinks his own life or someone else's is danger. If a Newark police officer fires his service revolver, he must, under departmental rules, immediately give the weapon -- uncleaned -- to Internal Affairs investigators. Moving shell casings violates department regulations and state laws against evidence tampering. The officer must file a report to Internal Affairs.
Howard Caesar had been in trouble with the law before. Caught several times riding in stolen vehicles, he was sentenced to a state center for juvenile offenders last year. He was there when his father, Edward Caesar, a custodian for the Newark Board of Education, died of cancer, on June 14, 1991.
The death shattered the young man. "He wasn't here when his father died and he couldn't even talk to him before he died," his aunt said. "Sometimes he felt things were hopeless. There were a lot of things that discouraged him."
Like so many young men in Newark who look to a future without money or prospects of steady employment, he turned to the streets. Week after week, he sank further into an anarchic world in which cars are stolen for wild drives and the police are enemies to be outfoxed and outpaced.
Newark has the highest car theft rate per capita in the nation. "There's nothing else to do," said the 15-year-old charged as Mr. Caesar's passenger. "Everybody does it."
"We just joyride," said the boy. "We don't sell them." He said most cars can be entered in about two minutes and started with a screwdriver.
 
Growing Contempt From Police Officers
 The police, faced with dozens of thefts a day, and angered by accidents that just this year have hospitalized at least two officers and caused the death of a woman from Elizabeth, N.J., have responded with growing contempt of their own.
Several youths in the area this week described times when police officers "squatting" in the parking lot of the Eleganza Lounge on 16th Avenue, near where Mr. Caesar was shot, would fling bricks and stones at stolen cars in an attempt to scare or startle the drivers. A man who would identify himself only as Jabaar said, "I've seen them break windows of cars. They try to chase them, but they can't catch them."
Police officers are sometimes taunted at stop lights by juveniles in stolen cars. The youths make obscene gestures, then speed off. And two young men arrested for car theft were released on their own recognizance -- only to steal officers' cars as they left the police station.
According to Sgt. Henry Alston, an officer with the Newark auto theft squad, 1,623 cars were stolen in the city in May. Another 216 attempted thefts were foiled. Stressing the age of the boys involved, Sgt. Alston held up a computer printout about 7 feet long that represented the arrest records of two juveniles. One boy was 15 years old, the other 11. "We have situations where kids steal cars to go on dates," he said.
 
 
 
'DOUGHNUTS' TO BULLETS

HEADLINE: THE EARTH SUMMIT;
NEGOTIATORS IN RIO AGREE TO INCREASE AID TO THIRD WORLD

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 13

 BODY:
Less than 24 hours before the end of the Earth Summit, North and South finally compromised today on principles that encourage richer countries to increase aid to the third world, clearing the way for formal approval of the global cleanup plan that is the centerpiece of the conference.
After 13 days of negotiations, third-world countries finally abandoned their campaign to extract a specific commitment from the industrialized world to nearly double aid to poorer countries by the year 2000. The money would help guarantee that the third world's development is environmentally sound. The compromise, worked out in a small group and approved in an informal general session this evening, will be formally adopted on Sunday.
 
Accepting U.S. Position
 Under the compromise, instead of pressing their demands for precise commitments of money, the third-world countries accepted that the United States was unwilling to be bound by a longstanding United Nations goal of raising aid levels to 0.7 percent of a country's economic output and that Britain, Japan, Germany and several other big aid donors refuse to commit themselves to that target by any particular date. 
 President Bush left the conference defending his environmental record and the Administration's stance on the major treaties at the Earth Summit, saying Americans are "the leaders, not the followers," on environmental issues and will be "pre-eminent" in carrying out accords signed at the conference. [Page 10.]
 
Japan Vows Leading Role
 Japan, too, made a promise today to "play a leading role" in future world pollution control. Japan's Prime Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, in a speech circulated here, promised to increase foreign aid for environmental projects and embrace pollution control as a scientific challenge. He did not join the other leaders gathered here because of debates in Japan's Parliament.
Japan's environmental aid will average $1.45 billion a year, compared with the $1 billion level of the last three years. Japan now contributes 0.3 percent of its gross domestic product.
In today's unusual North-South exchange, one of the rare occasions on which the third world enjoyed genuine leverage, the industrialized Northern countries committed themselves to reach the 0.7 percent target "as soon as possible" and pledged to see that the environmental goals in the plan, known as Agenda 21, are fully met. Implicit in the compromise is that the North must find more money for the third world.
The agreement notes that the planned Commission on Sustainable Development will monitor progress toward the aid target. And it says that a "review process" should "systematically combine the monitoring of implementation of Agenda 21 with the review of the financial resources available for such implementation."
Although the third-world countries accepted the compromise, they have serious reservations about the success of Agenda 21 without specific commitments of money. On Sunday, during the concluding session, Pakistan, the current chairman of the Group of 77, as the third-world countries are known at United Nations meetings, will express the bloc's disappointment at the financial offers the North has made so far.
 
A Warning on Financing
 And Pakistan will implicitly remind the North that it cannot significantly improve the environment without Southern cooperation. The statement will warn that without the additional assistance, the developing South will be unable to develop in an environmentally sound manner.
"We are saying we cannot generate the new resources needed to start up Agenda 21 without new help, so if the North wants us to meet those goals they must treat us more generously," Pakistan's United Nations representative, Jamsheed A. Marker said.
Third-world countries say they are owed that assistance because the developed Northern nations are responsible for most of the damage industrialization has inflicted on ecological systems so far. Third-world countries say the North should be willing to pay for the limits it has imposed on the development of poorer countries.
Other countries have their objections as well. Britain, Germany, Spain, Portugal, Greece and Ireland are reluctant to commit themselves to reach the target by the year 2000, saying it would be unrealistic. Germany also said it wanted the summit meeting to acknowledge that it faces an exceptional financial burden as a result of unification, which leaves it short of funds for the third world. That irritates developing countries that have long feared that Communism's collapse would divert Western aid to Eastern Europe.
Saudi Arabia is continuing to object to passages in Agenda 21 that commit the world to save oil by using such "economic measures" as carbon energy taxes. Saudi Arabia, backed by several other oil producers including Kuwait, Iran and Libya, argue that those pledges, which threaten to reduce demand for their oil, are no longer necessary now that the Earth Summit has approved a new convention on stabilizing the atmosphere by curbing emissions of warming gases created by burning fossil fuels.
Western and most third-world countries oppose the Saudi stand and many delegates say that if Saudi Arabia persists in its opposition it may be voted down at Sunday's closing session.
Delegates also agreed today to give "special consideration" to a proposal put forward by the World Bank president, Lewis T. Preston, to replenish the International Development Agency, which lends on favorable terms to the poorest countries, at a level of $18 billion over the next three years and to add an "earth increment" of about $5 billion to provide inexpensive loans for environmental projects.
But they refused to give any specific commitment to adopt the World Bank president's proposals as the Group of 77 has demanded, saying that to do so would prejudice the outcome of the separate replenishment negotiations scheduled for next month in Dublin.
The 12 European Community countries have also said they will provide about $4 billion in environmental financing to insure that Agenda 21 gets off to a quick start in the third world, but it remains unclear how much new money is included in that offer.
