HEADLINE: Russians Ask, 'What Country Do I Live In?'

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 13

 BODY:
A 16-year-old boy from Rubtsovsk, a town set deep in Siberia, recently sent a letter to a newspaper asking a question that is disturbing many Russians as they come to terms with the loss of the Soviet Union.
"I am a citizen of a nonexistent state, and I don't know where I live," Aleksei S. wrote to Komsomolskaya Pravda. "Is it the Commonwealth of Independent States, or is it the Russian Federated Republic? Is it Siberia, and is it the Sovereign Republic of Altai?" 
 Such confusion is not just a question of borders or competing claims of sovereignty. It is psychological and for some even traumatic. As it turns out, the collapse of the Soviet Union lighted a slow fuse that is still burning in the Russian national consciousness, leaving many people feeling robbed of a sense of place, of purpose and of identity.
 
'An Idea' Is Needed
 For the smaller republics, the union's final demise in December meant the birth of a new state and liberation from Moscow's tyranny. But for ethnic Russians the loss of the union has opened up an old and painful question: Without an empire, or a mission, what is Russia?
"An idea of Russia is needed," Sergei B. Stankevich, an adviser to President Boris N. Yeltsin, said in a recently published interview. "Now it is lacking."
The problem dates back to the Russian Empire, a vast continental sweep patched together through wars and treaties by an imperial dynasty that was first ousted and then wiped out by the 1917 revolutions. United by their culture, their church and fealty to the Czar, Russians have never known a nation-state in the West European sense. The very issues involved in the transition are causing President Yeltsin to go to the United States on Monday for talks with President Bush about aid, arms and economic reform.
 
25 Million in Other Republics
 What is called Russia today -- the Russian Federation, with its 130 nationalities and ethnic groups, its 31 autonomous republics and regions -- was carved out of the old Russian Empire, to make up the core of the Soviet Union. About 82 percent of the 150 million people living in Russia are ethnic Russians, and 25 million more are scattered through the other former republics.
Unlike Austria, which emerged as a homogenous country after the collapse of the Hapsburg Empire in 1918, Russia is itself still a mini-empire, held together more by inertia than by a common identity.
"The fact is that Russia is only now building its statehood, something it never had," said Oleg T. Bogomolov, director of the Institute of International Economic and Political Studies, who says he fears a trend toward regional separatism as local authorities grab more and more power away from a weakened Moscow.
 
More Painful Than Expected
 The breakup of the union has turned out to be more painful than many Russians had expected. Initially, it was widely seen as another aspect of the collapse of Communism, a way of getting rid of "the center." But after a delayed reaction, Russians are only now beginning to understand what it means to live in a truncated country, to see its status a world superpower reduced to one of an ailing regional giant, to be scorned by neighbors they once thought of as "brothers."
People joke bitterly about needing visas to go on summer holidays on the Baltic or Black Sea coasts, about having to change money to go to Ukraine, or about passing through "customs" to go to Kazakhstan. "Did you see my foreign car?" one Russian asked wistfully, as he pointed out his new Zaporozhets, produced in Ukraine.
"Russians have an identity crisis," a Western diplomat said. "They haven't come to terms with the idea of Russia within its current borders. Some wanted to see the commonwealth as a stage on the way to a renewed union and expected that the other republics, especially Ukraine, would want to come to a new relationship with Russia. Most people cannot conceive of Russia without Ukraine."
Ukraine's bolt for independence is difficult for many Russians to comprehend, given the historic links binding the nations. Furthermore, Ukrainian independence has meant the loss of the Crimea and the Black Sea Fleet -- two icons of Russian history known to every schoolchild from Moscow to Vladivostok.
 
A Cultural Riddle
 It also exposes the riddle of Russian identity, which is more rooted in culture than in geography. The empire left a legacy of many nations sharing one language. The result is a cultural knot that is practically impossible to untie: Nikolai Gogol, for instance, was a Ukrainian who wrote in Russian. The Soviet Encyclopedia calls him a Russian writer, while the Ukrainians claim him as their own.
Some, like the philosopher Aleksandr Tsipko, a director at the Gorbachev Foundation, argue that today's Russian Federation is a fiction, and thus vulnerable to challenges from within and without.
"The collapse of the Soviet Union along current internal borders leads not only to the death of the Soviet Empire, but also to the collapse of the state's historic core," he wrote in October, at a time when President Yeltsin was pushing the old union out of his way. "The Russian Federated Republic is not a 'metropolis,' as the British Isles were to the British Empire. It is the heart of the Russian Empire, the place where its boldest imperial conquests were concentrated."
In a recent interview, Mr. Tsipko predicted further decomposition, as parts of Russia itself drift away from Moscow, which has neither the power nor the will to hold them. In the meantime, he said, Russian nationalists, feeding on feelings of national humiliation, are bound to grow in strength.
Mr. Yeltsin's challenge, as he tries to pick his way past the "national" questions that keep erupting inside and alongside Russia's borders, is to define Russia's interests. But Russia is not of one piece, nor does it lie within one set of borders. The Chechen republic, a patch of the North Caucasus, has declared its out-and-out independence from the Russian Federation, while the Russian majorities in Ukrainian Crimea and in the Trans-Dniester region, a tiny sliver of independent Moldova, are clamoring to get back in.
 
Mixing Past With Present
 The Communists' antinational policies left other former Soviet republics with arbitrary borders and mixed populations, some of which are now the source of conflict and dispute. But Russia is alone with its vestigial imperial mentality, one that repeatedly confuses the idea of a multinational empire with the interests of a newborn state.
"People often mix up the Russian Federation of today and the historic Russia, which was the Russian Empire," said Otto Latsis, a commentator at the newspaper Izvestia. "People say the Black Sea Fleet was Russian, but it belonged to a Russian Empire, which consisted not just of Russia but of Ukraine. The problem is that the Russian people and the Russian Government want to see our Russia today as the full heir of the Russian Empire, but this is not so."
Without Ukraine, Belarus and the Baltic states, Russia's center of gravity has shifted eastward, a fact that Moscow seems to have understood better in recent months as it increased its diplomatic overtures to the new Central Asian states.
In an interview this week, Mr. Yeltsin brushed aside doubts about Russia's statehood. He said Russia's rich and ancient culture, and not the number of its nuclear warheads, would determine its status as a great power. "Today in any corner of the globe, people know what Russia is," he said. "This means Russia has a history, a rich history."
 
Western Dictation Seen
 But the fact is that without the union or the empire, Russia's standing as a world power has diminished drastically. Not only is Moscow no longer on a par with Washington, but there is also a growing perception that the West is dictating the terms of Russia's recovery.
Many Russians also have the sense that Russia, by far the largest of the former Soviet republics, has let itself become a punching bag for its neighbors. This sense of humiliation comes on top of the realization -- for many, only a recent one -- that the Communist system under which they lived for seven decades was not only fraudulent but also criminal.
"In the days of America's Wild West, there was a saying that a good Indian is a dead Indian," Mr. Stankevich said. "We have almost the same: A good Russian is a Russian in tears, repentant, pulling his hair out, showing how bad his country and people are, along with its whole history."
Understanding what Russia is is the nation's biggest challenge, Mr. Stankevich said. "The tragedy is that we don't know our own country," he wrote. "We don't want to know it, and what's more, we are proud of that."

HEADLINE: Washington Journal;
Monument to Jewish Culture Makes a Comeback

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13

 BODY:
With its boarded-up windows and weed-infested yard, the abandoned stone building on lower 16th Street in downtown Washington looks more like a forgotten mausoleum than a monument to the capital's once-thriving Jewish community.
But members of a new generation of young Jews, who are replacing the thousands of an older generation who fled to the suburbs, hope to change that. They plan not merely to give the old Jewish community center a facelift but to restore it to its role as a social and cultural focal point for Washington's Jews. 
 From 1925 until it closed in 1968, the community center, a 55,000-square-foot edifice at 16th and Q Streets, was the vibrant focal point of Washington's tightknit Jewish population. From the building's grand front entrance, new immigrants could see the White House. Inside, amid its ornate marbled columns, they could meet in its health club, classrooms and theater and kibitz about their plans for prosperity.
Some of those newcomers of the 1930's and 40's are among the best-known names in Washington today: Abe Pollin, owner of the Bullets and Capitals, Washington's basketball and hockey teams, and Charles E. Smith and Morris Cafritz, two of the area's leading real estate developers.
In the 1950's and 60's, with Jews joining the exodus to the suburbs, the Washington center became a casualty of its own success as Jews assimilated into the suburban culture. A 25-acre complex in Rockville, Md., a suburb of Washington, became the area's new Jewish community center.
In 1968, riots set off by the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. left the area around the Washington center in a shambles, and so the center's leaders decided to sell the building to the city government, which made it part of the Federal City College. But the college moved uptown to become the University of the District of Columbia, and the building has been vacant for 10 years. Today, though the row houses around it have been renovated with the gentrification of the neighborhood, the center remains an eyesore.
But the young Jews who have moved into the city and who plan to renovate the building hope to use it to encourage their generation to turn inward and preserve their heritage. They have already started a new center, now operating out of a town house as the District of Columbia's Jewish Community Center.
Whereas the old center served to Americanize Jewish immigrants, "the new purpose of Jewish centers is to help 'Judaize' Americans," said Elaine Mann, the assistant executive director of the Rockville center.
After several years of fund raising, the District's Jewish Community Center bought the building from the city government for $2.3 million in 1990. The remodeling is expected to cost $10.2 million, of which $3.2 million has been raised.
Some of the suburban Jewish leaders have questioned whether restoring the Washington center is the best use of members' money. They note that three times more Jews live in Montgomery County than in the capital. They say that almost half of the 30,000 Jews who live in Washington are young and single, and thus are less likely than suburban Jews with families to be "affiliated" -- that is, to socialize with other Jews and worship regularly.
But Arna Meyer Mickelson, director of the Jewish Community Center, says that is precisely why the remodeling should be "an enormous priority." She and other Jewish leaders in the area say that for younger, less-religious Jews, community centers are often better re-entry points into Jewish culture than synagogues.
Ted Farber, executive director of the United Jewish Appeal Federation, said the concern about the city's young Jews is reflected nationwide. "We realize that as we become more and more a part of the economic and social mainstream of America, we have to find ways to help our young people identify positively with their heritage," Mr. Farber said.
When the District's center considered new quarters, planners examined several possibilities. David Posner, assistant executive director of the center, said the history of the old center and its site, five minutes from a subway stop, settled the matter. "It was built within view of the White House, as a symbol of Jewish arrival in America," he said, "and this was always in our minds."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Undeclared Candidate;
Behind Two Issues, Outlines of Perot Presidency Emerge

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13

 BODY:
He has been scorned by his rivals as the Stealth Candidate, swooping into the lead in the Presidential race despite -- or because of -- his views' being virtually unknown. Yet while details remain almost nonexistent, the outlines of Ross Perot's vision for a Presidency are coming into view.
In interviews he has granted since he began flirting with a possible campaign, Mr. Perot has sketched out a set of principles that form the bedrock of his candidacy. As a successful business executive, Mr. Perot holds views that amount to a starkly pro-business platform, one that could easily be adopted by a Republican or by a Democrat like Paul E. Tsongas, the Massachusetts Democrat whom Mr. Perot admires. 
 But on the Government role in directing business, Mr. Perot departs sharply from the laissez-faire economics of the Reagan and Bush Administrations, arguing for a level of intervention often identified with liberal Democrats.
His overarching opinion is that the cure for the nation's economic ills is to place in the Oval Office an executive with clear-eyed business principles: strategic planning, test marketing, protection of markets, enhanced productivity and reduction of debt.
"Never forget," Mr. Perot said in a speech at the National Press Club in March, "the United States Government is the world's largest and most complex business. With that thought in mind, ask yourself which of these candidates for President would you let run your medium-sized business."
 
2 Issues and Then a Gap
 In essence, Mr. Perot is a two-issue candidate. Along with economic development, his emphasis is on reducing the influence of undefined "special interests" and making the Government more responsive to popular will. He would curb lobbying and political action committees, make all tax increases subject to public approval and involve voters in critical decisions through the use of "electronic town halls."
Once past those two broad issues, Mr. Perot's interest and ideas flag. Environmental policies, health care, gun control, abortion, foreign aid, affirmative action and education are, at this point, clearly second-tier concerns where he is much fuzzier.
"The point is, we have serious core problems in our economy," Mr. Perot said in April on the "Evans and Novak" program. "This is the overriding thing. You can bring up, you know, what are we going to do with every stray dog in Washington, and this, and this, and this, and this. I don't have positions on those things, haven't thought about it."
 
Critics Take Aim
 Critics of Mr. Perot say his proposals have not been well thought out. They note that linking new taxes to referendums would make it difficult to close loopholes that could inadvertently end up in the tax code. Barring campaign contributions from PAC's of foreign-owned companies would violate constitutional protections of free speech, and Federal laws and Congressional rules already restrict former Federal officials' lobbying of the Government.
The Bush campaign, in particular, is beginning to argue that questions about Mr. Perot's temperament and how he would carry out his sweeping proposals make his election too great a risk for the country.
Perot aides have said that such attacks are the type of character assassination typical of recent Republican Presidential campaigns. Mr. Perot and his advisers argue that he will be filling in details over the next few months and that as a newcomer to the campaign trail he cannot be expected to have legislative and administrative details at his fingertips, as do Mr. Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton, the perspective Democratic nominee.
Here is a sample of a Perot platform as gleaned from interviews.
ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT. Mr. Perot advocates a strong role for the Federal Government in developing a long-range industrial strategy. He believes the Government should undertake an industry-by-industry study of various economic sectors to see how they can be strengthened. He says the United States should study Japan's Ministry for International Trade and Industry, which co-ordinates government and private-sector economic strategy for that country, and adapt such a model for America.
He favors loosening regulations to let banks make more loans to small businesses. A bank is currently required to maintain a reserve of cash or stock totaling 8 percent of all its loans to small businesses.
Mr. Perot, a computer services executive, also favors weakening Federal anti-trust laws, which he believes prevent large corporations from competing effectively with foreign companies.
In an interview with The New York Times in April, he said he would use the Securities and Exchange Commission to prevent heads of corporations from stacking their boards with hand-picked directors who would rubber-stamp their decisions.
TAXES. While Mr. Perot has supported tax increases in the past, he now says he is "absolutely opposed to raising taxes," except in times of emergencies like war. He opposes the type of middle-class tax cuts that have been proposed by Mr. Clinton, asserting they will do little to stimulate the economy.
"We've got Congress up here working on all kinds of tax fixes to give the average guy 300 bucks, which won't mean a thing," Mr. Perot said in February on the "Larry King Live" television show where he first announced his willingness to be drafted as a Presidential candidate.
Instead, though he is loath to use the phrase, Mr. Perot favors a reduction in the capital gains tax for small businesses, arguing that such enterprises have th makes sense for that money -- which is high-risk money, which is going to stay there for a long period of time -- to be taxed on a favorable basis," he said on the show.
BUDGET DEFICIT. While Mr. Perot has inveighed against the Federal budget deficit and the national debt, his plans to reduce the red ink have been attacked in several quarters as woolly. He has said he would save $180 billion a year by ferreting out fraud and would ask Congress to give him a line-item veto to curb future spending. He has not said where he would cut.
He has said he would save $100 billion a year by persuading America's European and Asian allies to pay more for their defense, but he has not said what he would do if they refuse. He has said he could save $20 billion a year by eliminating Social Security payments to upper-income beneficiaries. But, according to the Congressional Budget Office, retired individuals with annual incomes over $100,000 will receive only $9.1 billion in Social Security benefits next year, and they already pay nearly $1.4 billion in income taxes on those benefits.
The mainstay of Mr. Perot's assault on the deficit is to stimulate the economy. Like Presidents Reagan and Bush, he believes the country can grow its way out of debt.
TRADE. Mr. Perot denies he is a protectionist, but he often says that a tougher policy is needed in negotiations with American trading partners, especially Japan. In a recent interview with the Los Angeles Times, he said he would make the Japanese say, "We'll take the same deal on cars we've given you." He has expressed opposition to a free-trade agreement with Mexico, saying it would mean the exodus of jobs to Mexico. But he has also said his mind was not completely made up on the proposed agreement.
OPENING UP GOVERNMENT. Mr. Perot believes that the Federal Government is controlled by too many "special interests" and that average citizens have too little influence. To redress that, he has proposed a $1,000 limit on campaign contributions from PAC's, a ban on former Federal officials lobbying Government agencies and Congress, and having the polls open on weekends to encourage more people to vote.
A centerpiece of his campaign is the "electronic town hall," where the public would be sampled for its views on crucial policy issues. But he acknowledges flaws in the concept. Asked in April how he would know that such a gathering would produce a representative sample of public attitudes, Mr. Perot said the results would be confirmed by using opinion polls. But he told "TV Guide" this week that the concept of electronic town halls was "just an idea," adding, "I'm not stuck with this."
ABORTION. Mr. Perot has clearly said many times that he believes it is up to a woman to decide if she wants to terminate a pregnancy. It is unclear though whether he supports Federal financing of abortions for poor woman, and he appears to favor laws requiring minors who want an abortion to notify their parents first.
GUN CONTROL. While many early press reports described Mr. Perot as favoring restrictions on firearms, he has yet to express support for any gun-control measure. He is against both registration of handguns and mandatory waiting periods before a person can buy a gun.
He has said he wants "to get guns out of the hands of violent people," but he has not spelled out how he would do that. This week, in an appearance on the NBC News "Today" program, he essentially endorsed the National Rifle Association's view that what is needed is stiffer penalties for people who use guns to commit crimes.
AFFIRMATIVE ACTION. Mr. Perot's record of hiring women and minorities while he was chairman of Electronic Data Services was not exemplary. He has said he understands the basis of racial preference programs, but on balance he seems to oppose the concept of affirmative action.
"It produces some advantages," Mr. Perot said this week, "but it produces tremendous stress and increases the level of stress in society if a less-qualified person is promoted over a more-qualified person. He said he "didn't want to do anything" that put stress between people.

PUB-DATE: June 14, 1992

SECTION: Section 1; Page 41; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 3141 words

HEADLINE: A Grim Wasteland on News at Six

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
Another night, another nightmare.
The teen-age killer gives way to the subway slasher. The mob slaying segues into a spot on kids with guns. The face of a weeping mother dissolves into a close-up of a blood-stained shirt. House fires become "raging infernos." Traffic snarls. Kids fall out of windows. Babies die in random shootings. Manhunts are commonplace. 
 On a quiet afternoon marked only by a humdrum commuter crisis and a rehashed murder case -- "They said the rosary, then they murdered their friend" -- an early summer news stupor is spiced by accounts of a Royal ruckus. Did Princess Diana almost kill herself? Then, the weather.
Welcome to New York. Day after day, from 4 P.M. to midnight, at almost any time, the nation's largest city is investigated, poked, tossed and turned in quick-cut images projected to a potential viewership of some 18 million people, a population about the size of Iraq's.
The result, says Jay Rosen, a media critic and associate professor at New York University, is an "image of the city as a hellhole, an image the rest of the country is only too happy to accept."
In more than 80 interviews over several weeks, journalists, scholars and other New Yorkers, ranging from janitors to teachers to corporate executives, described New York -- as portrayed by television -- as a grim wasteland that bears almost no relation to their lives. The city thus exposed is a sustained scream, a bloodied mess.
It flutters on the screen as an unrecognizable distillation of its failures, a force of its own. Cumulatively, its images produce a distorted mirror for its citizenry -- one that, Joan Cooney, the former president of the Children's Television Workshop, says, "is injuring our brains."
New York is the media capital of the world. All told, some 4,500 members of the press are authorized to cover fires, riots and other mayhem. Of those, more than 1,000 are foreign journalists who beam New York's worst nightmares around the world. Home-grown competition is fierce, too.
Three tabloid newspapers are in a circulation battle that may end with the death of one of them. Six television stations vie for viewers. An all-news channel planned by Time Warner Inc. is scheduled to begin this fall.
Yet in the view of many people, all that competition has done little to raise the quality of the news that is carried. "We run a ton of garbage," complained Gabe Pressman, the senior reporter for WNBC-TV, one recent morning as he wove his car through traffic on his way to City Hall. "The whole thing is: Can we be more outrageous and sensationalist than the next guy? Can we tease people into the 10 o'clock news?"
The result, he lamented, is a jumble of bloodied sidewalks and an ever-changing image of a dangerous, disease-plagued town that does not really exist.
Some of the bleakness is starting to wear on viewers. "Every auto you see must blow up in a fireball, and every street is unsafe," said George Sickles, a 78-year-old resident of Greenwich, Conn., during a recent visit to the city. "I am afraid of the television. If I were dictator of the country, I would ban it."
That said, the retired union official shuffled through the concourse at Grand Central Station and into the "tunnel of death," which most New Yorkers refer to as the subway.
 
'An Ethic of Toughness'
 Mr. Rosen, who is working on a book to be called "What Are Journalists For?" says the media take pride in their unruliness. "There is an ethic of toughness that is almost completely unquestioned," he said. The result is that the city's better side lives in perpetual shadow. "There are certain ways that New York is a more civilized place than anywhere else. But you would never know it."
 
Striking a Balance
Tough Problems Or Exaggeration?
 Many journalists and news executives defend their portrayals as accurate reflections of a city wrestling with extraordinary problems.
"There's a cacophany of social insults and danger out there," said Chuck Scarborough, the WNBC-TV anchor who has worked in local news for 18 years. "The economy is off. Real estate prices are depressed. The homeless and poor haven't been decent enough to keep out of sight, and street crime remains a pervasive problem. "The atmosphere in the city is somewhat corrosive right now, and I suppose after you've been out there all day, it's not that reassuring to go home and flip on the news," he said.
Yet, a number of people in the business, though they acknowledge that much of the news is responsibly reported and presented, say balanced coverage has given way to reports that sensationalize the bizarre.
Kay Delaney, the international sales manager and senior vice president of Turner Broadcasting Sales Inc., faults the bottom line. "There are eight million of us running around here, and we are not all getting raped and mugged and pillaged every day," she said. "But people just think there's someone with a machine gun on every corner. I have friends who won't even come to town from Scardale!"
The tendency to highlight crime coverage may have peaked with the 1990 crime wave that prompted The New York Post to run the headline: "DAVE, DO SOMETHING." The coverage, said Albert Scardino, a former press secretary to Mayor David N. Dinkins and a former reporter for The New York Times, amplified existing problems, twisting them out of proportion. He described the coverage as "factual, but not fair."
Mr. Pressman agrees. "I felt at the time that we were exaggerating this stuff," he said. "People thought this place was just busting with violence, cruelty, inhumanity and corruption, and it's just not true.
"But we've been on an orgy of crime coverage for years now in this city."
 
The Daily Beat
Sacrificing Depth For What's Easy
 It was not always that way.
Back in the black-and-white days, when "I Love Lucy" was the top network show and Mr. Pressman was New York's only 'round-about-town reporter on television, he envisioned something bold and grand and new in the history of news: a swarm of reporters bringing New York right into our living rooms.
Today, his vision is a reality. The moment trouble strikes, high-tech vans drift across the three-state region, radios blaring, their retractable 40-foot antennae set to beam the latest tragedy directly to the family set.
But Mr. Pressman is having second thoughts. "The barbarians are always trying to get in the gates, and I think they are in the gates now."
Two forces have combined to whittle away at in-depth coverage. Consultants, citing the growing menu of viewers' options -- including the Fox television network -- continually stress the need for short, snappy reports that can hold the attention of the MTV generation. A weak economy that has trimmed newsroom budgets and withered revenues has also cut into resources for research and story development.
The easiest reaction, more than a dozen television news reporters and executives said in recent interviews, has been to cover the easiest stories. And those, said Michael Horowicz, a former producer at WABC-TV, tend to be "the murder du jour."
 
Fox Takes the Leap
 Many in the industry say that Fox was first to try the short-and-not-so-sweet approach. It still holds. On a recent afternoon at the Fox news studios on East 67th Street, a nightly newscast was falling into shape. On this day, the 7 P.M. report would present 25 stories and 3 commercial breaks in a half-hour.
The top story, on the closing of the Alexander's Inc. department store that put 5,200 people out of work, would run for 2 minutes and 15 seconds. It was considered long. A Newark drug bust was 13 seconds. A feature on models over 40 years old received about the same amount of time as a report of an organized-crime trial. Sixteen pieces clocked in at under a minute. Then, the weather.
Ian G. Rae, the station's executive vice president, says a good newscast should give viewers "a comprehensive view of what happened in the world." So at the news meeting, he approved a piece ("Yeltsin-Drunk?") that examined in 11 seconds whether Boris N. Yeltsin might be an alcoholic.
To get "a good news story into the mix," Mr. Rae approved a feature about a boy receiving a heart transplant. That ran for a minute and 41 seconds.
 
The Crime Story
 Crime is always a hit. "It tends to be dramatic," said Mr. Scarborough in an interview last Tuesday at WNBC. "It's reasonably easy to shoot, and the cast of characters is readily available. So we do a lot of it."
As Mr. Scarborough spoke, he reminisced about a series he did in 1983 that ran on 3 days, consuming more than 30 minutes of air time. The series, called "Anatomy of Murder," involved extensive interviews, complicated planning and several camera crews.
Today, he said, "there would be a lot of resistance" to such a series "because we have to grind out our stories more rapidly."
The result is palpable.
The 11 P.M. newscast of Dec. 6, 1979, a tape of which was supplied to The New York Times by WNBC, opened with a segment on the Iranian hostage crisis. That was followed by reports on inflation, a contested real estate law affecting Manhattan loft dwellers, a protest by residents of the Lincoln Towers apartment complex over fuel surcharges, a segment on gasoline costs and on a possible strike at the Long Island Rail Road.
Crime did not appear until more than half-way through the program, in a report about the arrest of several muggers and developments in a beheading case. After the news, sports and the weather, the show closed with a feature on a SoHo artist.
Last Tuesday, Mr. Scarborough reviewed the night's offerings and paused during the interview to tape a 4-second promotion for the 6 P.M. news: "Water guns lead to a shooting in New York. At five."
The news that night began with a report on the actor Ben Vereen, who had been struck by a truck outside his home in Malibu, Calif., followed by a segment on the number of children killed with guns. Then, on to that most irrepressible of stories, the saga of Amy Fisher, and an update on the Queens bus strike.
Then, Mr. Pressman provided a report on national politics. The program closed with a segment on a Long Island pet cemetery and a live report about a wild bear in New Jersey.
 
The Defense
Not Everything Is 'Bright and Sunny'
 William L. Bolster, the recently named president of news at WNBC, did not apologize for the station's news selection. "The very nature of the news is usually that we are telling you bad stuff," he said. "We're not in Faribault, Minn., here, where everything is bright and sunny."
The focus on disasters and mayhem, not the good news story in Harlem or the Bronx, is only natural, he says, because it sells. "People may say they want good news," Mr. Bolster says, "but it reminds me of the F.D.R. Drive: Everyone honks when they are tied up in traffic. But when they get to the wreck, they look, too."
"People are just less likely to read the editorial pages than watch the car wreck," he said.
Too, the complex pieces, reporting about the national debt, the savings and loan crisis and other arcania, he says, just do not make for good television. "It would take more time than we have, and it still would not be interesting."
 
Clammor for a Change
 Some voices are calling for change. Osborn Elliott, the former editor of Newsweek who is now the dean emeritus of the Columbia School of Journalism, calls it the "curled-lip school of journalism." He condemned the press for its relentless negativism and called for a new approach to news.
"It's time for the press of this city to wake up and recognize the fact that they are important members of the community and they should get with it," he said. "I'm certainly not asking the media to ignore crime, grime and whores. But they've got to start taking responsibility for art, culture, commerce and community life as well."
Such have long been the dinner party laments of some intellectuals who would have The New York Review of Books set the standard for tabloid journalism. But a strange thing is happening across New York's newsrooms. Collectively, it sounds rather like a clamor for good news.
Liz Smith, the nationally syndicated gossip columnist who writes for Newsday, says the city's press corps has slipped from the bonds of decency. "If you watch TV," she said, "you just think the whole city is falling apart. And yet you go out on the streets and New York is pretty much the same as it always was. I know we have problems. But there's no reason for the press to keep everyone in this state of horrifying anxiety.
"If they do a story about someone putting a baby in an oven, I don't want to see it four times before bedtime and then again when I get up in the morning," Ms. Smith added. "It just makes people feel really sick. When I get out of town, I just feel this sense of relief!"
 
Too Many Studies
 Bud Carey, who was recently named general manager of news at WCBS-TV, says excessive focus on market research has moved news coverage too far from its roots. He sees his mandate at the third-ranked station in the region as returning the network to more in-depth reports.
"This business," he said, "is always searching for the holy grail. One of the great tyrannies we deal with is overnight ratings."
Another tyranny is the city itself. To those who want to stress the sensational and grotesque, it is endlessly accommodating. Somewhere, at any time, a crime is being committed, a tragedy is unfolding. The region's reporters have but to move out in pursuit of the mayhem, chattering on cellular telephones and weighed down with beepers, pens, tape recorders and notebooks.
 
The Evolution
Fox and Tabloids Spicen the Stew
 No one can quantify when or how the shift in coverage began. But Pablo Guzman, a reporter with Fox, has a theory. "We all held our breath when Fox was taken over by Murdoch because we knew his track record," he said. "We were looking at all the guys over at ABC and CBS and NBC to hold the line. But after awhile, their newscasts started to get more and more like ours By the time the Trump stories hit, everybody scrambled as though this were World War II."
Donald J. Trump remembers the period with bitterness. "I've had reporters go up to people on my staff and tell them they knew something was incorrect, but they had to go with it because it would sell," he said.
Headlines do sell, whether they're the promotional spots for the 11 o'clock news or the huge type on the front of The New York Post. "A tabloid page one," said Donald Forst, the editor of New York Newsday, "ideally has an emotion and has to smack you in the eye. It has to go to the gut and make you say, 'wow,' or 'holy smoke,' or 'goddamn,' or whatever it is that you say."
Articles printed inside the newspaper are more sober, but it is the headlines that tend to linger: "TORTURE IN THE SUBWAY," "BODEGA TERROR," "PAID ME IN SEX."
 
Not a New Phenomenon
 In reality, the New York press corps, like some overgrown, obstreperous adolescent, has always had its moments of aggression and bad taste.
In 1851, competing with The New York Herald, The New-York Daily Times carried several tantalizing headlines on page one: "Woman Poisoned," "Accident to an Omnibus Driver," and "Arrest of an Escaped Prisoner." A short feature described the scandal of the moment, the appearance of women clad in bloomers lingering amid a crowd of conservatives that "manifested its hostility."
And through later years, crime has been a staple of the competitive battles among New York's great papers, including The Daily News and The Herald.
Today, The Times is again reacting to competitive pressures, trying to combat an impression that the paper is more interested in Botswana than the Bronx. "It didn't take a lot of study to figure out that the Metro section of old was shortchanging our readers," said Gerald M. Boyd, metropolitan editor of The Times. "We didn't have adequate resources in New York. Ditto Connecticut. Ditto Long Island." The paper responded by expanding bureaus across the region and adding pages to the section.
 
The Tabloids' Challenge
 The tabloids' challenge is more immediate and more difficult. "We're talking about declining readership and People magazine selling out like crazy," said Matthew V. Storin, just days before he said he would leave his post as executive editor of The Daily News to join The Boston Globe. The three papers, in a sense, are in a fight for survival. And the net result is that the tabloid wars are almost a parody of tabloid journalism."
"We turn the volume up on people," he added. "We definitely do."
On television, the increased volume is seen in a developing blur between the local news and "reality" programs like "A Current Affair" and "Hard Copy." And that energy is transferred back and forth daily between television stations and the tabloid press.
"The tabloids sort of validate what you can do every day," said Mr. Horowicz, who recently became the assistant news director at KCBS-TV in Los Angeles after spending two years with the "Geraldo" television show. "In New York, you can get away with doing a story about Donald Trump and Marla Maples, and you can lead the newscast with it day after day. It has no news value at all. But the public just eats it up."
So, the press keeps dishing it out. "New York is the trash journalism center of America right now," says Richard M. Clurman, who has spent 20 years at Time magazine and is the author of several books on the media. "There's a news chain now. What starts in the supermarket tabloids goes on up the chain."
 
Rethinking 'Good News'
 Mr. Clurman said he had begun to doubt his own longstanding belief that good news is not news. "That old cynicism we have been carrying, it's part of the atmosphere," he said. "It's a sort of self-fulfilling hypothesis. If you read every day that everything is crumbling and terrible, you start to feel crummy and terrible, and maybe you start to act crummy and terrible."
Some viewers just turn the bad news off. "It's depressing," said Marcia A. Buchanan, who lives in the Bronx. "They make it seem like everything is crime. Or it's gossip and it's stupid."
When Ms. Buchanan was laid off recently from her job at a New York advertising agency, she hardly blamed the nightly news. Still, she thinks the city suffers in indefinable ways.
"It affects the way people see themselves," she said. "Look at the Los Angeles riots. Everyone was scared to death. I live in a neighborhood that is black, Hispanic and white. But nothing happened there."
Mr. Scarborough is unfazed.
"Maybe we should be glad that we aren't running good news," he said. "Just think of it. We really will have to worry when the news is: 'Man arrives safely at work. Details at 5:00.' "

PUB-DATE: June 14, 1992

SECTION: Section 1; Page 30; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 683 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Platform;
BROWN IS VOWING A FIGHT ON ISSUES

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTA FE, N.M., June 13

 BODY:
His campaign for the Presidency over, Edmund G. Brown Jr. threatened today to disrupt the plans of Democratic leaders for unity behind the party's platform.
Mr. Brown, his ruddy complexion reflecting days spent in the sun and not on campaign planes, went before the platform drafting subcommittee this afternoon to insist that the party take strong stands behind disputed positions on economic policy, foreign affairs, labor law and other matters. 
 "I don't want to impale the nominee," Mr. Brown declared. But he maintained that "the Democratic Party at this point in history desperately needs to define itself in a way that can touch people's hearts and distinguish it from its two competitors."
What the former California Governor has in mind is not clear. Under the rules, the only way he can get a debate on his platform planks at the Democratic convention in New York next month is to rally the support of 20 percent of the 186 members of the party's platform committee. But that committee is filled with supporters of Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, who has sewed up the Presidential nomination, and Mr. Brown conceded today that he did not have sufficient support to cause trouble on the convention floor.
 
'Live From New York'
 At a news conference after appearing before the drafting panel, Mr. Brown said mysteriously, "Either inside or outside, we go live from New York."
Mr. Clinton and the party's leaders are putting together a platform that takes strong stands on matters like civil rights, legal abortion and gun control about which the party is more or less unified. But it takes more general positions on issues like health care, intervention in the conflict in what was Yugoslavia and tax policy, about which differences in the party are greater.
Mr. Brown, one of the few prominent Democrats who has not endorsed Mr. Clinton (the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska are others), ran through a litany of his positions on subjects like urban aid and nuclear disarmament on which he is to left of Mr. Clinton and the party's mainstream and demanded more specific language in the platform. "Are we going to bite the bullet or are we going to gum the marshmallow?" he asked.
Responding to Mr. Brown, members of the drafting subcommittee adopted a conciliatory tack. Steve Grossman, chairman of the Massachusetts Democratic Party, said many of Mr. Brown's points were worthy of consideration, but he added: "When we are together, we win. When we are divided, we lose."
 
Nothing Written Yet
 No decisions were made at the two days of platform discussions here. A platform document is to be written in the next two weeks and will be presented to the full platform committee in Washington on June 27.
But while words were not written here, the discussions left no doubt that these themes would be prominent in the platform:
*Overall economic growth will be stressed rather than a redistribution of wealth to the less affluent.
*More emphasis will be given to tax cuts and other breaks for business than was the case in previous platforms.
*National health care will be advocated but no specific system will be endorsed.
*The platform will avoid down-the-line support of organized labor.
*Strong support will be expressed for legal abortions and Government financing of abortions for women who cannot afford them.
*On gun control, the Democrats will endorse a waiting period before handguns can be purchased.
*To counter Republican emphasis on what it calls family values, the platform will decry teen-age pregnancies and emphasize the need for people on welfare to find jobs.
That is not enough for Mr. Brown. "There is a view of the world," he told reporters, "that says the platform should be verbal cellophane."
But instead, Mr. Brown added, "the soul of the party must be carefully delineated and expressed."
So what does he intend to do?
"We have 600 delegates," Mr. Brown responded. "I don't believe they are going to New York to be extras in a 'B' political movie. They want to be participants in a live debate and process."

HEADLINE: THE EARTH SUMMIT;
Lessons of Rio: A New Prominence and an Effective Blandness

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 13

 BODY:
The Earth Summit, history's largest gathering of world leaders, is winding up after a fractious 12 days of diplomatic free-for-all among 178 nations. A few clear lessons may already be emerging from the fracas.
One is the new-found prominence of the environment as an international issue, bidding to rank with economics and national security. 
 After Rio, "You can't be treated as a world leader on any issue without being a player on the environment," said Dr. Michael Oppenheimer, a senior scientist with the Environmental Defense Fund, a research and advocacy organization.
Many diplomats here remarked on the paradox that the Bush Administration, immobilized in placating the American right wing during an election year, is abdicating leadership of the worldwide environmental movement just as the issue is moving to center stage.
 
'Landmark in a Process'
 A second lesson is that blandness can sometimes prove a surprisingly effective bludgeon. The parcel of treaties signed here have been portrayed by disappointed advocates as pitiful gutless creatures with no bite. But they have hidden teeth that will develop in the right circumstances.
That is why seasoned diplomats like Richard E. Benedick, the former State Department official who helped negotiate the ozone-layer treaty, said on the very first day, "The history books will refer back to this day as a landmark in a process that will save the planet from deterioration."
The Earth Summit, he said, "should not be judged by the immediate results, but by the process it sets in motion."
It might be years, he said, before the results are apparent.
A case in point is the climate treaty which, at Washington's insistence, has no targets or timetables for reducing emissions of greenhouse gases. Yet it commits ratifying countries to control emissions so as to protect natural ecosystems.
 
Imperfect Treaties
 The treaty also has built-in flexibility allowing for stronger measures if the threat of global warming appears more serious than at present. The recent complete phase-out of chlorofluorocarbons was set off by just such a provision in the Montreal protocol governing protection of the ozone layer.
"This is a launching pad, not a quick fix," said Maurice Strong, the executive secretary of the conference.
Everything depends on how well the principles enunciated and the bargains struck in Rio between rich and poor countries are put into force.
The climate treaty, already signed by most of the 178 nations attending the conference, is now widely seen as a promising start to the arduous task of curbing the heat-trapping gases, chiefly carbon dioxide, that threaten to disrupt the earth's climate.
Most countries, the United States being the chief exception, also signed a treaty aimed at better conserving the world's dwindling inventory of living species. The two treaties are far from perfect, but between them they set in motion a long-term process for dealing with the two most pressing environmental concerns.
 
Guide for Issues
 By the end of the conference, despite early pessimism, an agreement emerged on basic principles for managing and conserving the world's forests. Of all the issues that divided north and south, haves and have-not countries, that was among the most contentious.
The new accord enables the United Nations to start negotiations on an international forest treaty, a result fervently sought by the United States but flatly resisted by certain third-world countries jealous to preserve sovereignty over their forests. Environmentalists attacked the pact as hopelessly weak, even a step backward, but it appears to have put forest management firmly on the international agenda for the first time.
Another important product of the Rio deliberations is a general statement of principles for sustainable development, along with a voluminous compendium of rather general recommendations, called Agenda 21, for nations to follow as a guide on virtually every known environmental issue. Probably no one has yet read or digested it all.
On the debit side, the agreements all tend to run toward the lowest common denominator, perhaps an inevitable result when an entire planet's welter of interests clash on matters involving economics.
 
Attention to Population
 Population, while it is addressed in Agenda 21, clearly received less attention than deserved even though, along with rich countries' wasteful consumption patterns, it lies at the root of the global environmental problem. A major world conference on population is scheduled for 1994.
Still unsettled was the crucial question of mechanisms and commitments for transferring money from rich countries to poor ones to promote economic development compatible with protecting the environment. The delegates had also not agreed on the establishment of institutions to carry out the summit meeting's recommendations.
On the scorecard of north versus south, the developing countries clearly succeeded in their goal of making economic development as important as environmental protection. While almost everyone agrees that economics and environment must go hand in hand, some environmentalists were disturbed that the Rio Declaration, the summit talks' over-all statement of principles, says explicitly that "human beings are at the center of concerns" for sustainable development.
Putting humans at the center of things, with the implied right to dominate and exploit the rest of nature, is what has caused the problem in the first place, environmentalists contend.
 
Role of U.S. Election
 Many delegates say that the conference would have been more productive had the United States adopted a leadership stance instead of a "defensive crouch," in the words of Jessica Mathews, a vice president of the World Resources Institute.
Had it done so, said Russell E. Train, chairman of the World Wildlife Fund in the United States, its specific objections on particular issues might have been taken more seriously. The United States stance is widely attributed to President Bush's need, in a three-way Presidential race, to shore up the Republicans' core conservative constituency.
Tommy Koh of Singapore, the take-charge gavel wielder who was chairman of the conference's main working session, was heard to remark that "This will teach the United Nations not to hold a conference in an American election year."
Delegates from many other countries readily agreed with Mr. Bush's assertion in his speech here yesterday that the United States domestic record on the environment is exemplary. But American allies expressed regret that he had brought so few international initiatives with him.
The Americans challenged the allies to join in a doubling of international aid for protection of forests, sweetening the proposal with an initial down payment of $150 million a year. Europeans reacted with interest, but reserved judgment pending a further review of the proposal and their budgetary situations.
"We've always been very happy to follow the American lead when we felt it was going in the right direction said Margaret Brusasco-Mackenzie, head of the European Commission's Division of the Environment. But the response she would now give to the President, she said, is that: "You've stopped somewhere down the road. We would like you to look outside instead of inside at the elections."
Once what a country did in its own backyard was its own concern. After the Rio conference, the world is more likely to be watching.

HEADLINE: Noriega Says Bush Deserved Protests for an 'Insulting' Visit

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ATLANTA, June 13

 BODY:
Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian leader who was ousted in 1989 and brought to the United States for trial, says President Bush deserved the protests and tear gas he encountered in Panama City this week.
In an interview with Cable News Network, parts of which were broadcast on Friday, General Noriega said Mr. Bush's visit to Panama on Thursday was arrogant and highhanded. He said the stopover had been handled "in an insulting way toward a country that still has not found all of its dead" from an invasion by the United States in December 1989. 
 After the invasion, General Noriega was captured by American forces and brought to Florida for trial on drug and racketeering charges. He was convicted on April 9 and faces sentencing on July 10.
At a news conference at the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro, Mr. Bush said today that he was unconcerned about the opinion of "a discredited drug lord."
"As if his criticism means anything," he said.
 
'Panama Is Free'
 On Thursday, President Bush was hurriedly escorted from a city square in Panama City after police officers fired tear gas and warning shots to disperse protesters. The incident prevented him from delivering a speech hailing Panama's progress toward democracy.
The President said today in Rio that while "a handful of demonstrators" dominated the news, "that should not obscure the fact that Panama is democratic, Panama is free." He said the "warmth from the Panamanian people was overwhelming."
At least 325 Panamanians died in the United States invasion. Some Panamanian groups put the figure much higher, and General Noriega, speaking through an interpreter, asserted in the interview that Washington has covered up incidents of brutality.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	WASHINGTON, June 13 (Reuters) -- A $420 million aid package to Panama that was intended to invigorate the economy and foster good will toward the United States after the 1989 military invasion has been ineffective, The Washington Post reported today.
Quoting from the draft of a yearlong study by the General Accounting Office, the paper said analysts had concluded that the aid had had "no significant impact on the economy" or on the underlying causes of political instability in Panama.
The G.A.O. also found that too much money had been spent on bolstering the banking sector after United States officials "overstated" the threat of a post-invasion run on the banks that never materialized, the Post said.

HEADLINE: Colin Cameron, 65, Hawaiian Who Led Pineapple Company

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Colin Campbell Cameron, a descendant of missionaries to Hawaii who became a major resort developer and pineapple industry executive, died on Friday while swimming near his home in Spreckelsville on Maui. He was 65 years old.
He was found unconscious in the ocean, and rescue workers said the apparent cause of death was a heart attack. 
 Mr. Cameron was chairman and president of the Maui Land and Pineapple Company, the largest company on Maui, and president of the Maui Publishing Company, which publishes The Maui News.
His pineapple operations were the third-largest in Hawaii, and he was an early developer of resorts in Kapalua, in the 1960's.
He was also involved in a controversy in the late 1980's over his plans to build a 450-room beachfront hotel at an ancient burial site at Honokahua. After several years of excavating and protests, he agreed to restore the graves and find a new site for the hotel.
Mr. Cameron, a native of Maui, was a descendant of the Baldwins, a family that arrived from New England as Congregational missionaries in 1836 and became one of the Big Five families that dominated Hawaii before World War II.
He graduated from Harvard in 1950 and earned a master's degree in business administration there in 1953. He started work in a family pineapple company and became its executive vice president and general manager, then quit after a dispute with management. He later returned to buy a controlling share.
He was chairman of the Maui Economic Development Board and served on the boards of the Haleakala Ranch Company, the Bank of Hawaii, the Hawaii Electric Company, the High Technology Development Corporation, Bancorp Hawaii, the Hawaii Trust Company, the Lahaina Restoration Foundation and the Hawaii Resort Developers Conference.
He is survived by his wife, the former Pamela Andelin; two sons, Richard and Douglas; two daughters, Frances Ort and Margaret Alvidrez, and several grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Still Reeling From Gulf War, Jordanians Harden Attitudes

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan

 BODY:
Fifteen months after the end of the Persian Gulf war, attitudes here in the Arab country considered crucial to a Middle East peace settlement are hardening against Israel, the West and moderate Arab nations.
The process is being quickened by Jordan's continuing sympathy for Iraq in the face of international criticism during and after the gulf war; a severe economic crisis stemming largely from the war for which most Jordanians blame fellow Arabs and the West, and Jordan's disputes with Arab nations in the gulf. 
 The gulf crisis forced this country to absorb 300,000 Jordanians of Palestinian origin, most of whom were expelled from Kuwait in retaliation for Jordanian and Palestine Liberation Organization support for Iraq. Many of the Palestinians from Kuwait are still stranded here, penniless and jobless.
The blow to the economy of Jordan from this influx has been compounded by a cutoff of Arab aid in retaliation for its pro-Iraqi leanings. The lost aid includes free oil, mostly from Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, a subsidy worth $700 million a year.
 
Elite Turning Against U.S.
 Jordan has been further penalized by the United Nations sanctions imposed on Iraq, its largest trading partner, with which trade has been sharply curtailed. Because Washington has taken the lead in imposing the sanctions, many among Jordan's once pro-Western elite are becoming hostile to American policy in the region altogether.
"Most people here feel the United States is applying a double standard of justice," said Rami Khoury, who manages a publishing company. "They see the continuing campaign against Iraq and the new campaign against Libya as an anti-Arab undertaking, not a question of international law."
[Angered by continued warm relations between Jordan and Iraq since the end of the gulf war, the United States said on June 8 that it was putting off indefinitely joint military exercises with the Jordanian Army originally scheduled for May.]
As a result of such tension, there appears to be overwhelming sentiment among Jordanians of all classes and political views to hold out for Palestinian statehood as part of a Middle East peace settlement.
Jordan's four milion people, divided nearly equally between native Jordanians and Palestinians who carry Jordanian citizenship, appear united in the view that there should be a separate Palestinian state in the West Bank, to which Palestinian refugees living here can return.
 
'Economic Suicide'
 "The Israelis call this demographic suicide, but look at it from our side: it is also economic suicide for us to continue to receive huge numbers of populations on short notice," Crown Prince Hassan ibn Talal said in an interview. He was referring to the hundreds of thousands of Palestinians who flocked to Jordan to flee Arab-Israeli wars in 1948 and 1967 and those who fled the gulf crisis last year.
Many Palestinians stress that the gulf crisis and its aftermath have deepened convictions among Palestinians and Jordanians on this issue and that Jordan's national unity could not withstand any other outcome of the peace talks.
"After what happened in Kuwait, Palestinians need a Palestinian state as a place where they are not second-class citizens," said Rashida Abeidoh, a Palestinian refugee who settled here in the 1970's. "This will not happen in Jordan or anywhere else. It can only be so in a Palestinian state."
A growing sense of isolation here is clearly evident.
"One byproduct of the gulf war is that the gulf countries and other Arabs have distanced themselves from the Palestinian problem, leaving Jordan and the Palestinians alone to face the situation," said Elsayed Yassin, director of the Arab Thought Forum, a scholarly institute in Amman.
The most popular play in town is a scathing political comedy called "Hello: The New World Order." It has been playing to packed houses in the Stars Theater in downtown Amman every night, delighting audiences with a savage assault on the West and Arab governments and rulers, particularly those of the Arab gulf region and Egypt.
 
The King Is Rebuffed
 Over the last few months, several attempts by King Hussein to repair ties with Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf countries in the hope of easing the country's isolation have been rebuffed. These slights have pushed even moderate Jordanians to rally around the notion of opposing any reconciliation with the gulf countries.
Many Jordanians and Palestinians stress that their support for King Hussein is premised now on maintaining a helping hand toward Iraq, which is seen as unfairly persecuted.
This attitude first manifested itself in a burst of enthusiasm for President Saddam Hussein of Iraq when he refused to pull his occupying forces from Kuwait, and it seems to be the common creed of various political groups from Muslim Fundamentalists to Arab nationalists to Palestinian groupings.
"That the King stood up to the West and that he refuses to apologize or humiliate himself in front of the gulf rulers enhances his domestic support," said Asaad Abdelrahman, a prominent Palestinian in Jordan who heads a Palestinian scientific and cultural foundation.
In the last few weeks, a new dispute with Saudi Arabia over Muslim holy sites in Jerusalem revived deep antagonism toward the Saudis.
The religious and civil authorities were infuriated by the Saudi move to displace Jordan as custodian of the sites, a move seen as another in a long list of slights.
"Reconciliation?" said Taher al-Masri, a former Prime Minister and member of Parliament. "There is none at the moment. In fact, it is getting worse."

HEADLINE: Crucial Vote for Israelis, but Few Seem Interested

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEVASSERET ZION, Israel, June 13

 BODY:
Through the last 36 years of living and breathing elections since he emigrated to Israel from Spain, Yosef Mosianu never saw a campaign quite as dull as this one.
This has always been a country obsessed with politics, a roiling, fractious place where you could put two people in a room and somehow wind up with three political parties. To most Israelis, a dull election is an oxymoron. 
 But standing the other day at the cash register of his grocery store in this western Jerusalem suburb, Mr. Mosianu shook his head and said he could not get over his neighbors' lack of interest in the June 23 national election.
"Usually, they're running all over the place, handing out leaflets, arguing, fighting,"he said. "I feel nobody wants to talk about it now. The times when you tried to persuade somebody to vote your way are over."
 
Importance Dismissed
 With little time left before the vote, Israeli politicians and professional analysts are stunned by the apathy that voters have shown to what on paper should be one of the more important elections here in many years.
In many ways, the country is at a crossroads, involved as it is in difficult peace talks with its Arab neighbors, worried about ragged relations with the United States and faced with profound demographic change as a result of large-scale immigration from the former Soviet Union.
But those dominant issues have been little discussed as the major parties focus instead on personal attacks, evocations of old triumphs and disasters, and Tarzan-like chest-pounding over who really cares about Israeli security, the implication always being that the other side would sell the country down the river.
Moreover, there is no big-party leader with the commanding presence or tub-thumping speaking style of, say, Menachem Begin, the former Prime Minister who died three months ago.
As a result, signs of indifference are everywhere.
Campaign meetings are so sparsely attended that the parties have started canceling them. Standard features of past years like bumper stickers, banners and posters are scant. Party television commercials, once avidly watched as sources of entertainment if not enlightenment, are said by pollsters to be drawing as little as 20 percent of the viewing audience, which for the first time can divert itself by switching to a new second state channel or to one of 40 cable stations.
 
Final Mass Rallies Abandoned
 So anemic is the voter response that Likud and Labor are planning to abandon the mass rallies in Tel Aviv that are traditional campaign closers organized to put loyalists in a fighting mood.
"Once it was worth dying on the altar of a party -- to go wild, to be arrested and above all to vehemently hate the rival party," wrote Lili Galili, a commentator for the newspaper Haaretz. Now, many Israelis think like Shmuel, an unemployed and disenchanted young man tinkering with his car on a street here.
"The state," he said, "isn't worth voting for."
Regardless of where they normally fall on the political spectrum, many Israelis interviewed at random complain about their leaders in almost identical phrases like "they're all corrupt." In a recent telephone poll for the Israel Democracy Institute, two Israeli university professors, Yitzhak Galnoor and Yohanan Peres, found that 39 percent of the 1,200 people surveyed felt that their voices were not heard in the formation of Government policy.
"This is very pessimistic," Professor Galnoor said.
The disaffection seems to be especially keen on the right, leading many political commentators to wonder if Likud, after 15 years in power, is about to lose because some of its traditional supporters feel it is due for a comeuppance.
 
Likudnik Is 'Fed Up'
 Labor and Mr. Rabin are banking on people like Nomi Shamai, who lives in the poor Jesse Cohen neighborhood of Holon, near Tel Aviv, with five small children in two and a half rooms and money problems stacked up to the ceiling. She is fed up.
"I've always been a Likudnik," Mrs. Shamai said. "But Likud just spins its wheels. If Rabin is a human being, he'll help us."
A staccato of scandals has hardly helped the governing party. A new one burst open this week over allegations that Jewish farmers, including settlers in the occupied Gaza Strip, had embezzled millions of dollars from the Government by submitting deliberately inflated bills from Palestinian contractors who had built greenhouses for the Israelis.
According to the newspaper Hadashot, investigators are looking into the possibility that part of the payments to the contractors ended up in the hands of Palestinian terrorists as a form of protection money.
Opinion polls consistently show Labor to be leading Likud, but they also suggest a virtual dead heat on which of them will be in the better position to form a new government. Since no party in Israel has ever commanded a parliamentary majority on its own, the important question is not so much who winds up in first place but rather who is more likely to find enough coalition partners to control 61 of Parliament's 120 seats.
 
Less Interest, Less Violence
 A commonly held view among political specialists is that neither of the big parties will be able to form a Government on its own, and so inevitably they will turn to each other to reconstitute the "national unity government" that they maintained from 1984 to 1990. It is not an exciting prospect for many Israelis, and that, too, may explain the low-key nature of the campaign.
Not that relative calm is all bad.
Campaigners on the political left are particularly relieved, for in the past they could anticipate violence from supporters of Likud and small far-right parties, who would smash their cars and even drop lighted cigarettes into their opponents' pockets.
"It's a lot milder than anything in the past," said Galia Golan, a Hebrew University professor of political science and a campaigner for the left-wing Meretz Party. "I think the passions aren't there on the right the way they once were."

HEADLINE: Vienna in Bidding War for an Agency of Peace

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VIENNA

 BODY:
Not even many Austrians know that the first woman to win the Noble Peace Prize was a Viennese aristocrat, Baroness Bertha von Suttner, who received the award in 1905 for her book "Lay Down Your Arms."
Her advice was not heeded and World War I broke out nine years later. 
 But Austrians are being reminded of her achievement these days by a glossy brochure their Government is distributing as part of its campaign to get Vienna chosen as home of the only big new international bureaucracy that anyone is currently planning to create.
That will be the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, which is to be charged with inspecting the world's chemical industries to insure compliance with the ban on such arms that is expected to be agreed to in Geneva this summer.
A likeness of the Baroness stares out from the brochure's pages superimposed on a picture of the Congress of Vienna, which created the post-Napoleonic European order in 1814, to support Vienna's assertion that it has always been a city of peace and would make a fitting site for the new disarmament organization.
But the prestige of being host to the organization and the extra business that its well-paid international civil servants would bring to the local economy have drawn The Hague and Geneva into the race as well.
And those three cities are now engaged in a bidding war, dangling an array of inducements in front of the governments negotiating the ban who will also decide where to house the new inspectorate.
Vienna's more recent peace credentials include being host city of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe and the European conventional-arms reduction talks as well as providing a home for the International Atomic Energy Agency, the agency charged with halting the spread of atomic weapons, and several other United Nations agencies.
"My country considers its offer the continuation and logical consequence of it's efforts made over decades to promote peace and arms reductions," said Austria's Foreign Minister, Alois Mock.
But after the oratory comes the cold cash. And Austria is offering to build the new chemical-weapons organization a tower along side the atomic energy agency's headquarters for a peppercorn rent of 1 Austrian Schilling a year -- or about 11 United States cents. But the organization pays the operating costs.
In addition, Vienna promises the future chemical-arms controllers unlimited supplies of Strauss waltzes, Sacher Torte and long summer evenings in the wine gardens of Grinzing, where Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert once drank.
The Netherlands is emphasizing the practical benefits it sees in choosing its capital city of The Hague.
Those include lower living costs than either Vienna or Geneva, more international flights for the chemical-weapon inspectors to jump aboard at nearby Schipol airport as they race off to check reports of cheating, 15 mosques and the Dutch people's linguistic versatility, which makes everyone feel at home.
The Netherlands is offering the organization a new Peace Tower completely free of charge for the first eight years, after which it must pay rent.
In contrast to the vigorous self-promotion by Vienna and The Hague, Geneva seems almost half-hearted in pressing its case, only entering the lists the day before the closing date for offers after many polls had shown most citizens oppose taking in any more international organizations.
A preliminary United Nations report on the three bids describes Geneva's as financially "the most onerous."
Switzerland is offering only $1.7 million toward start-up costs and an inexpensive mortgage for a building.
It is also stricter on administrative questions like work permits for relatives and spouses.
On the other hand, Geneva probably would be the easiest choice on the third world's purse strings, since 137 countries already have diplomatic missions there, compared with 98 in Vienna and 84 in The Hague.

HEADLINE: French Dispute Ended, Canada Goes Fishing

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, June 13

 BODY:
A quarter-century boundary dispute with France has ended with Canada's winning most of the fishing waters it has claimed off southern Newfoundland. The decision was welcomed as the first good news in months for the economically battered Atlantic province.
Officials in Ottawa and St. Johns said that all key areas for cod and other fish, which are critical to the livelihood of the south coast's 80,000 people, are now within the Canadian zone. 
 "Clearly we are very satisfied," said Victor Rabinovitch, Assistant Deputy Minister of Fisheries and Oceans, in a telephone interview from St. Johns. He added that Newfoundlanders had close ties with the small population on the French-owned islands of St. Pierre and Miquelon, and that "it should be possible to work out reasonable cooperation with them in the future."
The 25-year dispute over the waters between the two islands and Newfoundland was resolved amicably in a 3-to-2 judgment handed down this week in New York by the International Court of Arbitration. Both sides had agreed to accept the panel's decision as binding.
In Ottawa, the External Affairs Minister, Barbara McDougall, hailed the result as "a good day for Canada and for our relations with France."
A French Government statement called the ruling a step toward better relations in the North Atlantic.
Canada has been at odds with France and other members of the European Community over what it considers excessive European fishing.
To placate Canada, the European Community in an unexpected action last month suspended fishing for cod in the northwest Atlantic, but warned that it might resume fishing in the fall if stocks are deemed to have recovered sufficiently.
Because of severe depletion of stock, Canada drastically reduced cod catch limits in February, causing widespread layoffs among fish-plant workers and trawlermen from the province. Unemployment has been running at over 20 percent, or twice the national average.
In the border quarrel, Canada had wanted France limited to a 12-mile zone around the two islands with no channel to international fishing waters in the Atlantic. France had laid claim to an area the size of Nova Scotia -- four times larger than the 3,607 nautical miles it was finally awarded.
The French zone now includes waters within a 24-mile limit of the two islands in addition to a 10.5-mile-wide corridor running south for 200 miles to international waters.
But Canadian officials said they were heartened by the discovery that most of the major concentrations of cod and other fish are in the newly decreed Canadian waters. They said that only 9 percent of the cod were in the waters awarded to the French.
Now France will have to negotiate an agreement with Canada on the management of fish stocks if it wants to have access to fish in the Canadian waters, Canadian officials said.
The area is not only a rich fishing grounds but may also contain reserves of oil and gas.
The ruling means that a moratorium on issuing oil and gas exploration permits that has been in place since 1967 will now be lifted. International oil companies had expressed interest in the region after the quadrupling of oil prices in the 1970's, but their excitement has waned as prices have subsequently receded.

GRAPHIC: Map of part of Canada and its coastal waters off Newfoundland, indicating new French zone.
