HEADLINE: COMMENCEMENTS;
Chicago and University Share Outlook, Graduates Are Told

 BODY:
The relationship between the University of Chicago and its city was extolled yesterday at the university's 100th commencement ceremonies.
"It's no mistake that the Chicago school of economics grew up here, with its emphasis on open enterprise," David Bevington, a professor of humanities at the university, said in his address. 
 "The very phenomenon of the Chicago 'school' is a tribute to the University's openness," Professor Bevington said. "The university has encouraged not economic or political conservatism but rather a tolerance for multiple points of view including those that happen not to be politically correct."
"To me, this is quintessentially Chicagoan and reinforces the bond between our university and a city that for so long has contested the rival positions of wealth and social conscience, free enterprise and public responsibility," he said.
The university conferred more than 2,057 degrees this weekend. The graduate degrees were presented in three ceremonies on Friday, and the undergraduate degrees were presented yesterday at the Rockefeller Memorial Chapel on campus. Professor Bevington delivered the convocation address at all four ceremonies.
As a longstanding tradition at the university, honorary degrees are given only for outstanding scholarly achievements and only after lengthy consideration by several committees made up of scholars in the candidate's academic field.
For the centennial, 25 honorary degrees were presented to various scholars in such fields as economics, social science, biology, geochemistry, law, religious history, linguistics, paleoanthropology and astrophysics.
 
Carleton College
 Ceremonies for the 118th commencement of Carleton College were held yesterday at the campus in Northfield, Minn.
The 455 graduating seniors were addressed by the three recipients of honorary doctoral degrees. They were former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, now the chairman of the National Democratic Institute for Public Affairs; Mary-Claire King, a professor of epidemiology and genetics at the University of California at Berkeley; and Peter D. Baird, an Arizona lawyer who in 1966 helped defend Ernesto Miranda in the case that resulted in the "Miranda warning," whereby arrested suspects are entitled to be informed of their rights.
 
Bennington College
 Bennington College awarded bachelor's degrees to 126 graduating seniors yesterday morning, in the college's 57th commencement ceremonies. Two master of fine arts degrees were also conferred.
The previous evening, on the Vermont college's campus lawn, the graduates heard a commencement speech from Harvey Fierstein, the Tony Award winning playwright and actor.
The graduates were also addressed by Mark Spitz, a senior representing the graduates, and by Louise Friedberg Strouse, an alumna from Bennington's first graduating class, in 1936.

HEADLINE: Life Beyond the Subway Is Subject to Its Own Disruptions

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
Even on the best days, Danita Woodley's trip to work oppresses her. She leaves her house in St. Albans, Queens each morning, towing her toddler son, and rides a bus to Jamaica Center, where she catches the J train to her son's baby sitter in Brooklyn and then to work at Public School 290 in East New York.
An hour and a half -- and any number of possibilities for delay. 
 So when five privately operated bus companies that serve 225,000 people in Queens and parts of Brooklyn and the Bronx stopped running during a three-day strike last week, Ms. Woodley felt many things -- inconvenience, frustration and anger -- but surprise at the disruption was not among them.
The strike has underscored the fragility of the peculiar network of buses in Queens that has evolved over the decades into a lifeline for thousands who live beyond the subways' end. It has also aroused a lingering sense of resentment toward the city's mass transit system, which leaves many residents in Queens feeling isolated and underserved.
"I hate it," Ms. Woodley said, as she stood in a bustling throng of commuters at Jamaica Center on Wednesday evening, waiting for her mother to drive her home. But she added, with a scowl of disgust, "It's nothing new. It's always like this."
 
'Not an Easy Commute'
 Jonathan L. Gaska, the district manager of Community Board 14 in the Rockaways, where no buses at all ran during the strike, agreed.
"Even when transportation is working at its best, which is not very often, it is not an easy commute to Manhattan or to other parts of Queens," he said. "We truly are the end of the earth as far as transportation is concerned."
The city's transportation officials say subway and bus service in Queens meets the demand for it. But they acknowledge that the strike underscored two problems: the economic fragility of the privately operated, publicly subsidized bus companies, and the growing popularity of the illegal vans that siphon passengers from the buses.
The strike also gave impetus to the city's consideration of a variety of options that could change the companies' arrangement with the city.
Mass transportation in Queens has evolved as much through the vagaries of history, economics and demographics as by any clear, articulated design.
All across the city, neighborhoods developed as the subway lines stretched toward the city limits early this century. Woodside, Jackson Heights, Corona -- all sprouted along the No. 7 line to the village of Flushing. Rego Park, Forest Hills and Kew Gardens grew along the E and F.
 
Growth Beyond the Lines
 But there the subways stopped, leaving vast neighborhoods to the east to develop without service.
For that reason, large sections Queens, more than any other borough, have had to rely on buses as the only form of public transportation.
The bus lines, like the subways, were at one time all private companies, often fierce competitors. As they began to fold in 1950's, the city gradually took them over until most of their routes were incorporated in 1962 into what became the Transit Authority.
Only seven companies -- four of them in Queens -- remained in private hands. They are the only private companies in the country that provide traditional bus service on local street routes, city officials say.
The companies -- Command Bus Service Inc. in Brooklyn, Liberty Express Lines Inc. and New York Bus Service in the Bronx, and Green Bus Lines Inc., Jamaica Buses Inc., Queens Surface Corporation and Triboro Coach Corporation in Queens -- operate like the Transit Authority's buses, holding franchises on their routes and charging the same fare.
 
City Subsidies Growing
 Since 1974, however, the city has subsidized them, at first almost entirely with Federal funds, but increasingly with the city's own money. In 1980, the city paid $3.9 million, the state $12.8 million and the Federal Government $8.5 million. Last year, the city paid $57.7 million, the state $40.1 million and the Federal Government $4.1 million.
Janet Lanphier, deputy commissioner of the city's Department of Transportation, said that the subsidies basically covered the companies' losses and guaranteed a 3 percent profit (which can increase to as much as 6.3 percent if the companies pass certain standards of timeliness and cleanliness).
Also, the department, using Federal funds, has replaced the entire private bus fleet and the city now owns the companies' buses.
The strike last week by five of the seven companies -- those in Queens and Brooklyn -- came as a result of the increasing financial pressure on the companies, transportation and company officials said.
The strike ended after three days when the companies and the unions reached an agreement that gave the workers 6.5 percent raises over three years and improved benefits.
 
Economics Have Changed
 But even as the commuters returned to their routines, the city is considering a variety of options for dealing with the bus companies, including taking over the buses themselves or turning them over to the Transit Authority.
"Historically, it was cheaper to have the private buses, even with the subsidies," Joseph De Plasco, a spokesman for the Department of Transportation, said. "We think that is less and less the case."
Two other developments are likely to put greater pressure on the private companies and even cause some to go out of business. For one, under the new City Charter, three to six years from now the city will put the companies' franchises up for competitive bidding.
For another, there is continued growth in the illegal livery vans that shadow the bus routes, offering cheaper fares and quicker service. At Jamaica Center during the strike last week, a stream of commuters flowed from the subway terminal and poured into the vans jockeying for position as their drivers shouted a bewildering array of bus routes like carnival barkers.
"It's the chicken and the egg," said William Scarborough, the district manager of Community Board 12 in Jamaica, where scores of illegal vans operate. "They say they can't put more buses out because the vans are cutting into their ridership, but because of the level of service, people are tempted to take the illegal vans."
 
A System Is Lacking
 The vans have been so successful that the Mayor's office has sponsored legislation in Albany to give the city power to regulate the vans and perhaps integrate them into the system.
An integrated system, residents and officials complain, is exactly what has been missing in Queens.
Claire Shulman, the Borough President, said that it sometimes seemed that the mass transit system -- including the highways and railroad -- existed only to shuttle people from Manhattan to Long Island, but nowhere in between.
The Borough President's office has campaigned for more buses, more subways and an expansion of the Long Island Rail Road and has proposed building a light rail system linking the airports and other points in Queens.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Tries to Mend Frayed Relations to L.I.

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FIRE ISLAND, L.I., June 8

 BODY:
As the great engines of government began to throttle down in the far-off State Capitol, there was Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, in a beige rain hat and white paper booties, stalking blobs of renegade oil on a drizzly, storm damaged Long Island beach.
"We can use more people to pick up the blobs," Mr. Cuomo declared, surveying what turned out to be modest pollution on a three-mile stretch of beach. As he walked, he offered an extemporaneous discourse on the legal definition of erosion, culled from a long-remembered legal brief. 
 With dreams of a Presidential bid behind him, a state budget secured and the Legislature getting ready to go home, Mr. Cuomo is stepping up his presence around the state at a time when his popularity -- and that of most other incumbent politicians across the country -- has plummeted.
Nowhere is the challenge he faces greater than on Long Island, a vast expanse of expensive homes, high taxes and economic worries -- a place where many residents wonder whether the American Dream has gone sour, and where Mr. Cuomo more and more is viewed as a frayed and remote figure.
 
Links in Italian Ancestry
 In the past, Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat, has had unusually strong support from this traditionally Republican bastion, where one of four residents is, like Mr. Cuomo, of Italian ancestry. But now polls show that his support has eroded more deeply here than in other parts of the state.
Battles over his cuts in school aid, which have led to higher property taxes in affluent suburbs, and skirmishes with business leaders have led many Long Islanders, including some Democrats, to conclude that the Governor has all but written them off.
Last year, in a budget fight, the Cuomo administration even proposed closing Robert Moses State Park, the site of the oil globs, as an economy move. Amid a public outcry, Mr. Cuomo disavowed the idea.
"There is an enduring sense that too many people have that there is some political bias against Long Island," said James L. Larocca, the president of the Long Island Association, a business group. "I do not believe that is true."
 
The Ghost of Gatsby
 According to this view, Mr. Cuomo, the scion of a poor family from Queens, long viewed the Island as a Gatsby-like refuge for wealth and privilege -- a Republican heartland, where even Democrats backed Mr. Cuomo's opponent, Edward I. Koch, in the 1982 primary that propelled Mr. Cuomo to the governorship.
To the support this, Long Islanders share remarks they attribute to the Governor about Long Island "fat cats" and "polo ponies," and they swap stories about supposed snubs.
In one story -- apparently apocryphal but widely circulated and vehemently denied by Mr. Cuomo's aides -- the Governor was presented with a cake in the shape of the state, and with his first cut, neatly sliced off Long Island.
Paul Townsend, the editor of The Long Island Business News, regularly publishes a series titled "Albany Is Shortchanging Long Island," citing among other evidence a report by an economist at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, that Long Island pays 17 percent of state taxes, but gets only 12 percent of state spending.
 
Plays Down Poll Standings
 Asked about his fall in public standing here, Mr. Cuomo said only that he remains far more popular than many other governors and has the highest approval rating of "anyone in the state." His visit here on Monday included a tour of a renovated theater at Jones Beach and a meeting with a business group.
Mr. Cuomo's aides deny that he has any bias against Long Island. Indeed, they attribute the complaints to Republican legislators searching for a scapegoat.
"His brother lives in Copaigue, and his sister in Williston Park," said Stephen Villano, Mr. Cuomo's New York press spokesman. "He knows what Long Island is like."
But many Long Island officials, Democrats and Republicans alike, said they had detected a resurgence in interest in Long Island only in the last year or so, as Mr. Cuomo suffered in the polls and the Island hit rough economic times.
 
'A Positive Thing'
 Lewis J. Yevoli, a Democratic Supervisor from the town of Oyster Bay, said that Mr. Cuomo may have hit bottom, and that there may have been "some unhappiness with his lack of presence on Long Island."
"There may be some basis in the frustration," Mr. Yevoli said. "But what the Governor is attempting to do is to focus on Long Island and to provide some assistance, and that is a positive thing."
A series of polls by the Marist Institute of Public Opinion, showed that Mr. Cuomo's approval rating on Long Island was as high as in the rest of the state through much of his time in office -- peaking at 77 percent in early 1988. But as his overall ratings faltered, his approval rating on Long Island fell five percentage points below the entire state.
A New York Times/WCBS-TV poll late last year put Mr. Cuomo's approval rating at 30 percent on Long Island, compared with 35 percent in Westchester and Rockland, and 41 percent in New York City. The margin of error ranged from three to five percentage points.
Through most of his term in office, Mr. Cuomo was identified with two issues on Long Island -- closing the Shoreham nuclear power plant and shifting state aid from relatively wealthy school districts to poorer ones.
 
Warring With Business
 Mr. Cuomo's decision to force the closing of the plant because of concerns over evacuation plans, made him a hero with environmentalists, but set off a bitter war with organized business groups. They blamed the closing for rising utility rates that, they say, are choking off new business in the region.
And last year, as the state struggled through deep fiscal problems, $300 million in school aid to Long Island was cut -- a quarter of all state aid to the region.
Mr. Cuomo railed against overpaid school administrators and called for the politically unpopular merging of independent school districts. A Democratic Assemblyman from Long Beach, Harvey Weisenberg, accused the Governor of viewing all of Long Island as "rich and spoiled" and using the children as scapegoats.
But as the recession became the worst on Long Island in a generation and Mr. Cuomo's standing continued to fall, he began a long and sometimes difficult courtship with business leaders. Last year, business groups were furious when, after an outcry from environmentalists, he dropped a proposal to set up a state economic development authority for Long Island.
Finally, Mr. Cuomo went to Long Island last fall and put forward his own economic blueprint -- speeding up some projects, including a fourth lane for the Long Island Expressway, reiterating some old proposals and offering a few new ideas.
 
An Airport in the Pines
 The keystone of the plan was state support for a proposal to expand an airfield in Calverton, L.I., in the midst of the island's fragile pine barrens, into a commercial freight jetport. The project, still under study, has so far succeeded mainly in alienating environmentalists.
A few years back, in what may have been Mr. Cuomo's most poignant connection with Long Islanders, he spent two hours visiting with Carolyn Schiller in her dining room in Levittown, after she wrote him in despair over the high taxes that were driving her from her home.
"I came away with a clearer understanding of the role of the state and a clearer understanding of the pressures the people of Levittown are facing," Mr. Cuomo said after the meeting.
Irving Gerber, the executive director of No More, an antitax group that once counted Mrs. Schiller as a member, said she had since "sold her home" and "moved upstate, where she pays one-third to one-quarter the property taxes."

 1. Balanced Budget by Statute: Vote on a Democratic leadership plan to deal with the budget issue with an ordinary statute that would require the President to propose balanced budgets and direct Congress to propose budget resolutions that were balanced. Rejected 220 to 199, June 9.

HEADLINE: GOLF;
Couple's Swing: The Big Easy

BYLINE: By JAIME DIAZ

 BODY:
If Fred Couples wins the 92d United States Open, which begins Thursday at Pebble Beach in California, he will be be completing one of the greatest sustained 12 months of golf in the last 30 years: He would have two major championships, seven North American victories over all, and a run of top-six finishes equal to the most consistent years of Palmer, Nicklaus, Miller and Watson.
But no matter what happens at Pebble, Couples, like every significant player, has already contributed the identifying emblem of his swing, a hitting style that will be remembered as raw, electrifying and elegant all at the same time. 
 From the moment he joined the PGA Tour in 1981, Couples was noticed and envied by his peers for having an unhurried, unencumbered motion that produced both unbelievable power and a tremendous capacity to hit different kinds of shots. Even as he was compiling 10 years of respectable but unexceptional results, Couples was spoken of as a man with a gift.
Of course, the gift alone did not carry Couples to six significant tournament victories in the last year, culminating with the Masters in April. On the contrary, his biggest breakthrough has been in finding a way to score respectably on those inevitable days when the gift is nowhere to be found. Toward that end, he obtained from Tom Watson a metal-headed 3-wood that has become indispensable on tight driving holes, and solidified his short putting.
But amid the flux, Couples's big swing has remained unchanged. It is still essentially the same one he taught himself by belting balls around public courses in his boyhood home of Seattle.
"It's the way a 12-year-old would swing if you handed him a club," said Dave Williams, the former University of Houston golf coach who had Couples on his team from 1978 to 1980. "There's nothing doctored up about Fred's swing. He is just the most natural player I've ever seen."
Sounds wonderful, but not a guarantee of success. There has been a persistent view that golf is an unnatural game in which natural impulses are best restrained through adherence to contrived body positions. Because Couples's freewheeling motion creates some uncharted angles, there are those who believe his reign at the top will be brief.
Purists have a lot of fodder when they consider Couples. Most tour players recoil in horror from an elongated backswing that produces a so-called "flying" right elbow, a dramatic re-routing of the club from an outside to an inside plane, and a right-hand grip so loose that it sometimes comes off the club at impact.
But Couples belongs to the long tradition of self-taught and creative shotmakers that includes Sam Snead, Lee Trevino and Chi Chi Rodriguez. He is decidedly out of step with the tendency among today's players to rely heavily on swing instructors to forge their swings to fit textbook molds.
 
Relaxation and Ease
 From the moment Couples stands up to the ball with a miniumum of fuss or positioning, he sets a theme of relaxation and ease. Both his backswing and forward swing are "quiet," with his head providing a calm fulcrum. But amid such a seemingly peaceful endeavor, Couples releases the clubhead into the ball like a force of nature.
One of Couples's former teammates at Houston, Paul Marchand, a teaching professional, was fascinated by the power and purity of Couples's ball-striking the first time they played together as 18-year-old freshmen. Since 1987, he and another pro, Dick Harmon, have subtly fine-tuned Couples's game, but Marchand still speaks of the swing as something natural and unspoiled.
"I don't want to use the word genius casually, and I know he won't like that word, but I really think that when it comes to golf, that is what Fred is," said Marchand. "He just naturally excels at both the physical and mental part of the game. Mechanically, he's never copied anyone, and mentally, his approach to life, which is to keep things loose and fun, transfers perfectly into golf. I'd say 98 percent of what he's doing now is just Fred.
"The thing is, what Fred is doing in his swing is really classic. Through the whole history of golf instruction, there's the continuing theme of the free swing as the thing that every player strives for. You take the ability to do that and throw in a natural feel for the game, and you get Fred."
To Marchand and others, Couples's talents are grounded in being an exceptional athlete. At a well-proportioned 5 feet 11 inches and 185 pounds, Couples has great physical abilities. Both his father and older brother played minor league baseball, and Couples himself harbored ambitions to play baseball professionally until golf became his passion.
"We would have intramural softball games in college, and no matter how deep the outfielders played, Fred always seemed to hit it over their heads," said Marchand. "In basketball, he had so much range on his jump shot that we called him "Downtown" after Fred Brown. On tour, one of Fred's favorite things is just talking sports on the practice tee. He's just a ballplayer, plain and simple."
What works for Couples probably wouldn't work for someone with less athletic talent. At the same time that he appears so natural, he is decidedly unorthodox.
His grip, with his left hand turned away from the target in an extremely "strong" position, is one that encourages a great deal of hand action in the swing. Most pros use a "weaker" grip to minimize the sometimes capricious action of the hands, particularly under pressure.
 
Open Stance
 Couples also addresses the ball with the imaginary line across his shoulders, hips and feet pointing to the left of his intended target, in contrast to the accepted method of lining up directly at the target. But the "open" stance is also one used by players such as Trevino, Rodriguez, Paul Azinger and Ray Floyd, all of whom say they are able to "see" and swing toward the target better from this position.
On his backswing, Couples starts his club outside the target line along a very upright plane. By the time he gets to the top of his swing, Couples has made a shoulder turn that is exceeded in pro golf perhaps only by John Daly's. Remarkably, in contrast to his massive shoulder turn, Couples's lower-body pivot is mimimal. His left heel stays on the ground and his hip turn is perhaps only half of his shoulder turn. It's an economy of lower-body movement in consistency on the forward swing.
As a result of his enormous upper-body turn, Couples's right elbow at the top of the swing gets away from his body more than is considered ideal. This disconnection of the arms from the body requires a compensatory move on the forward swing. When Couples's timing is off, making the move too late can cause a push to the right -- his most recurrent missed shot. Bringing the arms forward too early can cause a pull or a hook to the left.
"Fred has had the problem of getting too long and loose, and we've gotten him to tighten his turn a little bit," said Marchand. "If he's had a swing thought in the last four or five years, it has been to get a little bit more compact."
While the backswing could have some extraneous movement, Couples's return to the ball is a study in simplicity and efficiency. Whatever technical flaws Couples commits in his backswing, he rectifies them the moment he starts back to the ball.
With a deft turn of his hips toward the target, Couples reroutes the club to inside the target line, dramatically dropping his right elbow into his side. This "figure 8" move is a staple of another great player, Trevino. " 'Cupcakes' does it, too," says Trevino with a satisfied smile, employing his nickname for Couples.
"Once he drops down into that solid position, that's when Fred can really freewheel," said Marchand. "He uses his lower body very efficiently. It's not a big move with his legs, but it's a tremendous leg action exactly at the right place. It's a very quick and well-timed move. It's some kind of violent release, but because Fred is so smooth, it looks real peaceful."
So peaceful, that photos of Couples just past impact have shown his right hand actually coming off the club.
Couples, who actively avoids talking about his swing, said he trusts Marchand and Harmon because they have struck a delicate balance.
"They don't try to change me, they just try to improve what I have," he said. "I work on things on the practice tee, but once I'm on the course, I don't want to be standing over the ball worried about my swing.
"I try to picture the shot, step up and hit it. I don't try to analyze my game while playing. I'm not someone who hits a bad shot, then stands there and tries to figure out what went wrong. I just try to hit the ball solid. It's just timing and coordination. I don't even want to know how to explain it."
It's the same way a lot of geniuses feel.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Fred Couples is hoping to add the U.S. Open to his list of titles. (pg. 1); When he sets up to hit, Couples lines up in an "open" stance, facing slightly left of the target. He starts the club outside the target line. At the top of his swing, Couples's right elbow moves away from his body -- too far away in the opinion of purists. It forces him to compensate on his downswing, sometimes causing him to push the ball to the right. Couples positions himself perfectly as he moves into his downswing. It is efficient, and seemingly effortless, but it is loaded with power. Rotating his hips toward the target, he reroutes the club onto an inside plane, sliding his right elbow into his side. He's so smooth that it often looks as if he's not swinging hard at all. (Steve Szurlej/Golf World)(pg. 2)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1646 words

HEADLINE: The Physicians' View When Managed Care Comes to Town

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

DATELINE: HUNTINGTON, W.Va.

 BODY:
West Virginians like to say they are "independent cusses," which may be why this is one of the few states where health insurers still have little influence over how a physician conducts his or her practice.
But physicians here, like most across the country, are under growing pressure to trade independence for security. Employers and insurance companies are pressing doctors to join a web of insurer-sponsored medical networks, often called managed-care networks, that try to slow rising health costs by limiting fees and weeding out unnecessary or inappropriate treatments. 
 Half-a-dozen physicians in this quiet Ohio River city of 55,000 people voiced their fears and hopes about plans for a new network at a recent dinner organized by state Blue Cross representatives hoping to persuade them to sign on. Their comments illustrated well the concerns being heard from many of their counterparts nationwide.
The West Virginians seemed reluctant to forfeit professional autonomy, but they recognized that their options are shrinking as more employers offer their workers financial incentives to go to doctors belonging to networks. Employers typically cover 80 percent of the charges by a network doctor and only 60 percent for care by physicians outside the network.
Since not all doctors in most communities are invited to join a network, those selected are under pressure to conform to rules against wasteful or unnecessary practices, or risk being dropped and losing a steady source of patients and income.
Even though they are not members of an insurer network, the Huntington doctors said they were already devoting hours of their own and nurses' time each day to defending their judgment calls against second-guessing by insurance-company nurses and doctors who had never seen their patients and sometimes had little knowledge of their medical specialties.
Dr. Robert A. Hess, a family practitioner, said his nurses often wasted time answering questions from "persons who don't know anything." Dr. Kenneth Wolfe, an ear, nose and throat specialist, added: "I will only talk to doctors. I let my nurse talk to their nurses."
The doctors also said they would resist joining a network that forced them to subtract 10 percent or more from their charges, which they said was the discount taken by some large employers like the CSX Corporation.
Another concern is the practice among some networks of requiring permission from a "gatekeeper" doctor before seeing a specialist. Some networks subtract the specialist's fee from the gatekeeper's income. "It's a financial incentive to not give treatment," Dr. Wolfe said. "Some cases are not going to get needed care."
But the Huntington doctors seemed ready to accept a pre-set schedule of fees and to be paid only for services the insurer deemed appropriate -- if they could help set the charges and guidelines. They also offered to let Blue Cross representatives review their patients' records periodically to look for improper charges, as an alternative to the current time-consuming practice of daily second-guessing by insurance-company nurses.
Mountain State Blue Cross and Blue Shield, based in Charleston, is one of at least three large insurers recruiting doctors for networks in Huntington and in Charleston, the state capital. The Prudential Insurance Company recently started a network for telephone workers at a Bell Atlantic affiliate in Charleston. And the Aetna Life and Casualty Company is planning a network in Huntington and nearby Ashland, Ky.
Mountain State Blue Cross invited the six Huntington doctors, all of whom have large practices, to discuss its plans with Ralph D. Alexander, a senior consultant with Milliman & Robertson, a national actuarial and benefits consulting firm that specializes in starting networks.
Mr. Alexander said the new Blue Cross network would address many of the concerns of physicians. Doctors in the network would help draft "practice standards" to govern their work. Their patients' records would be reviewed periodically to see whether the physicians were conforming to the standards, but the doctors would not have to answer to insurance reviewers before or during treatment, he said.
There would be a schedule of approved fees that, taken as a whole, would not be lower than customary charges in the area now. But the doctors would not be told the amounts that the network will pay before they sign up, Mr. Alexander said later in a telephone interview.
For their part, the doctors denounced wasteful practices, particularly inappropriate diagnostic tests, which they said some patients demand and some doctors willingly perform. "I like the side of it that would get rid of some of the waste," Dr. Wolfe said, citing a patient he had seen who had been given a certain test 30 times. "In 19 years," he said, "no patient of mine ever had that test more than three times."
But some of the physicians were cautious in approaching a project that they all knew could affect their practices and incomes. Dr. Terrence W. Triplett, a family practitioner, said afterward that he was concerned that the network might exclude some local specialists. "Does that mean I would have to refer my patients out of town, to end up having to ship them 50 miles away? I wouldn't like that."
Dr. Triplett said that his overall impression of the Blue Cross concept was positive but that he would like to see the network rules spelled out. "The information given at the meeting was fairly superficial," he said.
Some Huntington doctors were skeptical of the whole idea. Dr. Dennis Burton, president of the Cabell County Medical Society, said in an interview that the state "is a very traditional medical market." Dr. Burton, a neuroradiologist who said he had not been invited to the Blue Cross dinner, added: "West Virginia is in the lower 25 percent of the U.S. in medical costs, so there is not a big incentive to control costs."
But even so, economic forces are pushing doctors to join networks. "I don't know that we, as physicians, are in control of these things," Dr. Triplett said.
Huntington lost 13.9 percent of its population between 1980 and 1990 as jobs dried up in its depressed coal-mining hinterland. And Dr. Subrat Lahary, a surgeon, noted at the Blue Cross dinner that the Federal Government has cut Medicare payments for surgery in half for the elderly, who are at least 30 percent of his patients.
Dr. James S. Todd, executive vice president of the American Medical Association, said most doctors view managed care as "a fact of life."
He added, "It has the potential to improve the quality and effectiveness of care. But in many areas of the country, cost comes before almost everything else."
Some networks have exclusive contracts with particular hospitals, but Mountain State's network will use both of Huntington's large hospitals, thus avoiding inflaming the Blue Cross plan's already tense relations with the state's hospitals.
Mountain State was established by Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Ohio, based in Cleveland, after the former Charleston-based Blue Cross plan collapsed in 1990, leaving behind millions of dollars of unpaid bills. Some doctors said that, consequently, they still had "problems with trust" in dealing with the Ohio Blue Cross unit.
In April a Federal jury in Charleston awarded $7.4 million in actual damages for unpaid claims, and $15 million in punitive damages, to 13 West Virginia hospitals that had sued Ohio Blue Cross and Blue Shield, , which is appealing the punitive award. In a related development, the national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association agreed in February to pay $8.6 million to the hospitals.
Medical networks already cover 77 million Americans. Networks like those in West Virginia, which typically pay doctors a fee for each service, are sometimes called preferred provider organizations. Another type of network, the health maintenance organization, typically pays doctors a pre-set amount for each patient, no matter how much treatment they provide. A growing number of H.M.O.'s, called point-of-service plans, permit patients to go outside the network and still get some of the bill paid, just as preferred providers do.
About half the nation's doctors work with medical networks, which are supposed to slow the steep increases in medical costs, at least for the employers who use them. But the networks have barely gained a foothold in West Virgina, where annual medical costs per employee are about $2,700 in Huntington and $3,000 in Charleston. West Virginia is also one of only four states that do not have a locally based H.M.O. (The others are Alaska, Mississippi and Wyoming.)
Philip Cline, vice president of the J.H. Fletcher & Company, which makes mining equipment, said the company's medical costs for 152 employees averaged $2,150 last year. Employees pay the first $250 of their medical bills each year, after which the company pays all charges.
"Most people in West Virginia are independent cusses," Mr. Cline said. "They want to pick their own doctor."
But few employer health plans are as comprehensive as Fletcher's. One reason for the low figures in the state is that many West Virginians pay a hefty share of their own medical bills. Michael Marra, benefits manager of the Ashland Oil Company, one of the region's largest employers, said it pays about 65 percent of the health-care costs of nonunion workers, or $2,404 per employee in 1991. Ashland employees paid the remaining 35 percent.
The new networks hope to reduce employers' costs even more. "There is going to be a lot more competition in health care," said Tom Wolf, a former hospital board member and businessman in Huntington and Ashland, Ky., who owns a string of McDonald's restaurants and a radio station. "I think doctors are going to be making a lot less money," he said.

PUB-DATE: June 14, 1992

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 423 words

HEADLINE: Making Sure a Woman's Place Is in the House

 BODY:
To the Editor:
To have representative numbers of women and minorities in positions of leadership and power in this country, we will need far more than the five new women in the Senate and 20 in the House of Representatives you project in "Steady Local Gains by Women Fuel More Runs for High Office" (The Week in Review, May 24). Even doubling the number of women in Congress would leave that body nearly 90 percent male. 
 Last summer, after nearly 20 years with the Federal Government, I reluctantly left my job in Washington and moved with my family to Madison, Wis., enabling my wife to become director of a new Asian American studies program at the University of Wisconsin. A choice had to be made: my career or hers. Though I've adapted to new situations before, including two years in the Peace Corps, I found the switch to the so-called mommy track surprisingly difficult.
I knew from the outset that job hunting in a new environment during a recession would not be easy. What I didn't anticipate were the discomforts of financial dependence, career uncertainty and underemployment -- the traditional situation of women.
On the other hand, by taking a leap of faith into the backseat, I've learned quite a bit about myself, about my children, whom I now see more, and about my wife, whom I now see less because she's working so hard and joyously. I've also come to realize how important, if painful, it is for people like me to step aside so that others can come to the fore.
Political partnerships, such as that between Hillary and Bill Clinton, are mistakenly perceived as a liability. They should be praised and could be a model for correcting gender inequities in the House and Senate. Certainly, the wives of some incumbents could do at least as competent a job as their husbands, as evidenced by Representative Lindy Boggs.
A second way to equalize the numbers of men and women in Congress rapidly would be for incumbents to identify and act as mentors for like-minded and talented women who would replace them in office. During the transition, the men would be the power behind the throne.
"Ladies First" must become the political chivalry of the 1990's if we are to achieve a truly representative government in the coming decades. Too bad, the men most apt to step aside are just the ones who are already progressive on women and minority issues.
 
GELSTON HINDS JR.
Madison, Wis., May 25, 1992
 
The writer is working to elect Ada Deer as Wisconsin's first woman in the House of Representatives.

HEADLINE: Mr. Quayle's Lectures, and Leadership

 BODY:
No one disagrees with the values that Vice President Dan Quayle posits for the nation. Of course two devoted parents are better than one; of course children need to learn right from wrong; of course adolescent pregnancy extracts painful, perilous costs.
Then why is the Vice President railing about a so-called "cultural elite" that, he claims, opposes those values? That's election-year politics, a straw man. The question is not, "What are the right values?" It's whether or not Vice President Quayle, and his Administration, have a plan to help poor, broken and desperate families live by the values he rightly cherishes. 
 Nearly a quarter of America's children live in single-parent families, most of them headed by mothers. Nearly half the women who raise children alone receive no child support. That's true even though Federal law requires the Government to help states track down deadbeat fathers and force them to pay up.
Plenty of the people Mr. Quayle derides as "sophisticates" believe the Government has to do better at fulfilling that responsibility. Does Mr. Quayle?
Plenty of people think more states need to develop training programs that include a wide range of services, including education and job training, to help poor mothers get off welfare. Does Mr. Quayle?
Plenty of people believe that women who leave welfare for work should receive transitional day care when they need it, as mandated by Federal law. Does Mr. Quayle?
If he agrees with these value judgments, then he needs to say how he and his Administration want to help these families in distress. These and other highly constructive provisions are all found in the Family Security Act of 1988. But the act currently has only about a quarter of the funds needed for it to work. The Administration has opposed increasing financing.
The states too have been slow to respond, in part because, given the recession, they lack the matching funds required. A proposal circulating in Congress would provide Federal funds even if the states can't match them. This proposal deserves the Administration's support.
The Vice President preaches a good sermon on family values. If he means to act on them, pressing to underwrite the Family Security Act would be a practical way. He could even start tomorrow when he visits New York, home to such a disproportionate share of troubled families. In the process he could demonstrate the difference between lectures and leadership.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Immigrants Don't Take Jobs of the Poor

 BODY:
To the Editor:
On behalf of the New York State Task Force on New Americans, I take issue with "The Riots: Underclass vs. Immigrants" (Op-Ed, May 15) by Edward N. Luttwak of the Center for Strategic and International Studies. Mr. Luttwak scapegoats immigrant communities in Los Angeles for the disorders that followed the verdict in favor of the four police officers who beat the motorist Rodney King. 
 Mr. Luttwak, presenting a view that has been invalidated by most academic studies, argues that immigrants are taking jobs from the American underclass, resulting in social unrest.
The presumption that immigrants take jobs from those in the unskilled underclass has lost support among economists. George Borjas argues in the book "Friends of Strangers" that ratios of immigrants in major metropolitan labor markets have trivial effects on wage rates and no effect on employment. Immigrants, it seems, are doing jobs that American-born workers do not want.
In 1990 the Alexis de Tocqueville Institution, the American Immigration Institute and the Hudson Institute released a survey of 38 leading economists, including 7 former Nobel laureates and 20 past presidents of the American Economic Association. The survey concluded that immigration had a very favorable impact on the country's growth and that immigrants did not take American jobs.
Almost two-thirds of those who were surveyed believed that increasing the level of legal immigration would have a favorable impact on the United States standard of living.
The displacement notion was rejected by New York State. Last year, our task force and two Assembly legislative commissions held a six-hour hearing on the impact recent immigration had on the state economy and labor force. Our hearing and subsequent research confirmed that the displacement of poor native workers by immigrants is largely insignificant. A more comprehensive view would support legislation to keep American jobs in the United States and upgrade training for local workers, while maintaining the economic benefits that immigrants contribute to the United States economy.
Perhaps more objectionable is Mr. Luttwak's attempt to cast African-American interests against Latino interests by commenting that black leaders "betray the uppermost interest of their poorest followers in order to coalesce with Hispanic groups that oppose all serious efforts to contain immigration." It is this racial demagogy that creates tensions between ethnic groups and harms the goal of racial and ethnic harmony. It is these tensions that create riots; the issue Mr. Luttwak professes to resolve.
Mr. Luttwak is making a transparent attempt to pit the American poor against the immigrant poor, and the Latino immigrant against the African-American. The reality is that immigrants are not the cause of riots, unemployment or the depression of wages, but have been a blessing to America. We are indeed a nation of immigrants.
 
THOMAS F. CATAPANO
Member of Assembly, 54th Dist.
Albany, May 27, 1992

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
A Rare Charmer in Griffin's Clothing

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
"I'M talking to this guy from Mercedes," my friend said, "and what he says is that one of these days Saab is going to put out a car that looks like something. When that happens, this guy says, the rest of the manufacturers are going to be in real trouble."
My friend was chuckling when he told me, because he worked for Saab, and he knew there was truth to the comment. A lot of people are pretty sure the Swedish cars are great, but only a certain segment of the population finds the styling sufficiently palatable to go out and buy one. 
 Svenska Aeroplan AB, Saab for short, has been producing odd-looking automobiles ever since the first one rolled off the line in 1949. And, when the 9000 Turbo came into being in 1985, the theme continued. The 9000 was less weird than its siblings, true, but the design was still a bit clunky.
The trunk and roof are high, the nose is low. It is a front-wheel-drive four-door sedan, and there is a close-coupled and bulky look that fails to appeal if what you want is pizazz. So it may be that it took a particular sort of gussying-up to make me take notice.
And that, for at least one model in this year's lineup, is exactly what Saab has done.
The car is the Griffin 9000 special edition, basically a 9000 CD Turbo, but dressed in rare fashion with a leather-and-polished-walnut interior and every creature-cosset known to man.
The company calls the metallic paint Eucalyptus Green, and the interior is mauve, in this case sort of a cross between purple and brown, with the leather seats trimmed in suede. Being a gadget freak, I freely confess to being smitten, but all of the come-on also makes me realize that the 9000 is a truly wonderful car.
And I'll risk it here: The solidity and performance make this the best sports sedan I have ever driven, and the suspension makes it one of the best-riding cars on the road.
Given that, the $42,195 sticker (plus $440 destination charge) is a steal, and -- except for one thing -- that bargain status ought to give pause to the other makers of European luxury cars. That one thing, unfortunately, will be the Griffin's scarcity.
According to the company, it is building one green Griffin for every 620,000 Americans, which translates into total production of only 400 cars. The tester was No. 11, according to the silver plaque on the dash, and owners of these numbered "editions" will get gold cards authorizing free scheduled maintenance for the first three years.
As for the car itself, there are special 16-spoke molded wheels shod with performance tires, a black-and-chrome vinyl band around the midsection, black and chrome bumpers, a standard four-speed automatic transmission, and an intercooled and turbocharged four-cylinder engine that produces 200 horsepower.
For safety, the '92 model has new side-impact protection and increased rigidity, resulting from reinforced partitions in the doorsills, a new front-seat crossmember on each side of the car and a strengthened connection between the sills and the pillar behind the door.
In addition, a driver's air bag is standard and "pretensioners" instantly lock both front seatbelts if impact occurs. Antilock brakes also contribute to safety, but that is to be expected in a car that has everything from heated power sideview mirrors to headlights with their own washers and wipers.
The front buckets are heated, too, of course, and there is a flip-and-slide sunroof, full power equipment including a one-touch driver's window, central locking and a cellular phone that hides under a burled walnut panel in the center console. A nice feature also makes the phone portable, so you can take it with you to use elsewhere.
Beyond the leather-wrapped wheel, the instrument panel is dominated by a 140-mile-an-hour speedometer and a 7,000 r.p.m. tach. The remaining gauges account for gas, temperature and turbo boost, and then there is a trip computer to tell you average speed, instant and average fuel economy, range, outside temperature and estimated time of arrival at your destination.
The audio system is sensational, as well it might be with a 150-watt amplifier, and the compact-disk player has a six-disk changer in the trunk. Unlike most such changers, you can also put a disk into the player itself, which means you don't have to get out of the car to play music that isn't already loaded.
Good as that is, the player creates one of my two small complaints about the Griffin. Everything in the car is so nicely placed and so neatly done, that I don't understand how this happened or why the interior designers didn't notice, but the ashtray, which is good, is above the sound system in the center of the dash. And when it is pulled out, it blocks your view of both radio and CD player.
Spaces for the three elements are the same, and if the ashtray were moved to the bottom the problem wouldn't exist. The only other complaint has to do with placement of the window switches. They are down in the console between the seats and are harder to use there than they would have been had they been located on the driver's door panel.
The buckets are comfortable, power adjustable and with memory settings for three drivers of different sizes. In back, there is an amazing amount of legroom, and the car actually offers more interior space than any other luxury import, compact or otherwise.
There are grab handles for everybody but the driver, and the seatbelts have up-down adjustments to make sure the occupants are secure.
In back, too, the windows go down all the way, something not often found in today's sedans. Should the rear passengers shun the breeze, though, they are accommodated by their own separate air-conditioner.
A remote trunk latch resides in the driver's door, and it opens the high lid to full vertical, exposing a cavern that measures 17.8 cubic feet. The liftover, as low as it can get, is right over the bumper, and a pass-through allows long items such as skis to intrude into the passenger compartment through a panel behind the rear seat's fold-down armrest.
The trunk houses a full-size spare in a well under the floor, and a hideaway on the right side of the compartment holds tools. And, should the weight of the cargo upset the car's balance, the problem is taken care of by an automatic load-leveling system.
The suspension also includes stabilizer bars, front and rear, and there is a computer-driven traction-control system to prevent wheelspin on slippery or otherwise unfriendly roads. However inhospitable the surfaces, though, it's a sure bet the Griffin won't let you know it. You just have to beat those 1-in-620,000 odds.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The 1992 Griffin, a special edition of the Saab 9000 CD Turbo sedan. Only 400 are planned. (Saab Cars U.S.A.)

HEADLINE: A CLOSER LOOK;
Ecology, the Economy and Bush

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE awkward interplay between election-year maneuvering and environmental concerns received plenty of attention last week as President Bush took a hang-tough, us-against-the-world approach toward the Earth Summit. At the same time, a factor that played a huge role behind the scenes was largely ignored. That factor was economics.
The Administration demanded and won a weakened version of a treaty on climate change on the grounds that accepting tough new rules to limit carbon dioxide emissions would hurt economic growth. Similarly, Mr. Bush said he would not sign the biological diversity treaty, which aims to conserve millions of plant and animal species, because the Administration feared it would damage one of the economy's fastest growing sectors: the biotechnology industry. 
 The United States was the only major country to reject the biodiversity treaty, helping turn Mr. Bush into the Darth Vader of the Rio meeting, which was attended by more than 100 heads of state. The United States also found itself isolated when it refused to join Germany's call to strengthen the climate change treaty by requiring nations to reduce carbon dioxide emissions to 1990 levels by the year 2000. Many scientists believe the buildup of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping gases in the atmosphere is contributing to the earth's warming.
 
No Apologies
 In Rio, President Bush proclaimed to the other assembled heads of state: "America's position on environmental protection is second to none, so I did not come here to apologize." But nothing about this trip, it seemed, was auspicious -- certainly not its beginning in Panama, where the stench of tear gas and the echo of gunfire from a nearby demonstration forced the President to flee a pro-American rally before he could address it.
Once he arrived at the summit, a lot of what Mr. Bush said and did was focused on the domestic American economy for domestic political reasons. But in seeming so openly to be carrying water for American industries that seek protection from new environmental restrictions, he ran the risk of unflattering comparisons to his trip to Japan, which turned into an effort to sell American autos and auto parts to a clientele that thinks them inferior.
This was particularly evident when the Americans in Rio tried to paint the Germans and Japanese as Johnny-come-latelies on the environment. In fact, in some areas, particularly carbon dioxide emissions, the Germans have been working for some time to make their industries and those of their neighbors environmentally efficient.
Over the last few months lobbyists from a variety of industries have sent a barrage of letters to President Bush and conveyed their views to Vice President Dan Quayle's Council on Competitiveness, which many critics of the Administration say is calling the shots on environmental policy in this Presidential election year. The German environmental minister, Klaus Topfer, said in an interview in Rio that he hoped the cold war was not being replaced by a North-South rivalry on environmental issues. "I am afraid," he said, "that conservatives in the United States are picking 'ecologism' as their new enemy."
 
Focusing on Growth
 Many American business executives and economists, meanwhile, argue that after the initial costs of investing in new technology are absorbed, reducing emissions would lead to greater energy efficiency and, perhaps, higher profits. The Administration's failure to come to grips with this, say many environmentalists, is typical of the live-for-today approach that marks its policies toward oil consumption, forests and other finite resources.
But at home, Mr. Bush has been lambasted far less for his positions on the environment than for overseeing the slowest three and a half years of growth of any postwar Presidential term. So it did not seem a coincidence that Mr. Bush put his accent on economic growth at the summit.
In rejecting the biodiversity treaty, he said it could weaken patent protections for biotechnology companies and thus discourage research and innovation. "Remove incentives and we will see fewer of the technological advances that help us protect our planet," he said. This approach has a welcome audience in most pharmaceutical and biotechnology firms, which say that the treaty would hamper efforts to test and use organisms from the third world for new products, and that its ambiguous language would make them share patents with developing countries.
Many scientists backed the treaty, however, fearing that one-fourth of the planet's species could disappear over 50 years. The treaty aims to get developing countries to do more, like protecting forests, to help species survive. To compensate them, it says countries that provide species used in products shall be provided technology under "most favorable terms."
Sounding the alarm for industry, G. Kirk Raab, president of Genentech, a leading biotechnology company, wrote a letter to President Bush saying, "The vague language relating to 'technology transfer' and equitable sharing appear to be code words for compulsory licensing and other forms of property expropriation."
Pharmaceutical companies regularly screen thousands of tropical plants in search of a cure for cancer and a means of crippling the virus that causes AIDS, for example. Industry officials admit that they cannot quantify how much the treaty might add to costs and reduce research, but they argue that developing new drugs is an uncertain process already, and new costs would only put more pressure on it.
Environmentalists say such opposition is overblown. They interpret the treaty as saying companies do not have to turn over technologies or pay royalties unless they agree to. And they argue that if the Administration really cared about Rio, it could have easily negotiated a few changes in the treaty, or accepted the ambiguous document and negotiated more satisfactory implementing documents in future years.
As for the climate change treaty, the Administration argued that it would be wrong to accept strict regulations to reduce carbon dioxide, noting that many scientists say no one has definitively proved that greenhouse gases are warming the globe. Administration officials also cite studies showing that a program to cut carbon dioxide emissions, perhaps through a tax on fossil fuels, would reduce output. Environmentalists, though, say there is enough evidence linking carbon dioxide to global warming to warrant acting now, and they cite studies showing that cutting carbon emissions could create jobs overall by creating a need for new technology.
 
The Checkbook
 The Administration also expressed some reservations about Agenda 21, the summit's overarching, non-binding, moral document, which sets a blueprint for global environmental protection. But in the end, Mr. Bush signed it. Agenda 21 calls on industrialized countries to vastly increase their aid to the developing world, especially to protect its environment. Mr. Bush said "the day of the open checkbook is over," but he nevertheless pledged $1.4 billion for research on climate change and $150 million to preserve the world's forests, which absorb carbon dioxide.
While it blocked a tougher climate treaty, the Administration boasts that the United States is one of the few countries with an action plan on carbon emissions -- a plan it says will limit the growth of emissions but will not cut them to 1990 levels. "A serious longer-term commitment is going to require a full public policy sea change," said William Cline, an economist for the Institute for International Economics.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAPMAIGN: Voters;
Words on Bush's Lips in '88 Now Stick in Voters' Craw

BYLINE: By JEFFREY SCHMALZ

 BODY:
Fed up with politics and politicians, many Americans have seized on one catch phrase as a symbol of their disgust, repeating it over and over like a sarcastic mantra, "Read my lips: No new taxes."
 In interviews with hundreds of voters around the country in the last five months, the slogan, which was the bedrock of George Bush's 1988 campaign for President, was uttered time and again by voters angered not so much that their taxes had increased as by their belief that Mr. Bush had lied to them, breaking not a routine promise but a sacred compact. 
But the political fallout seems to extend far beyond Mr. Bush. If so strong a commitment by the President of the United States cannot be trusted, many people seem to think, then no politician or his word is good. As a result, the President's reversal seems also to have hurt Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the presumed Democratic nominee. And it seems to have helped open the way for a Ross Perot.
 
'Yeah, Right'
 "I'm disgusted with all politicians," said Ron Purkhiser, a 50-year-old welder in Akron, Ohio. "They say one thing, then they go ahead and do the opposite. 'Read my lips: No new taxes.' Yeah, right."
 No one seems more taken aback by the sweep of the reaction than political insiders. After all, they had thought, the pledge not to raise taxes was so obviously impossible to keep that no one took it seriously. But in their public opinion research, they are finding that people took it quite seriously and that they viewed it as the ultimate test of whether a politician's word was any good.
 "I think a lot of us didn't have a sense of just how serious a pledge George Bush had broken," said Peter D. Hart, a longtime Democratic poll taker who is conducting surveys and discussion groups for The Wall Street Journal and NBC News. "Now I'm finding that it's cost him more than anything else and hurt politicians in general. The promise was as close as a politician can come to putting his imprint in Grauman's Chinese Theater. The voters took it as a blood oath. How can a politician take a blood oath to the voters again?"
 Mr. Bush's reversal seems to have most benefited Mr. Perot, who is seen as a nonpolitician and therefore someone who might actually be trustworthy. It has also helped him avoid taking specific stands. People say they find it refreshing when he says he cannot offer specifics because he does not know all the answers. And in any case, they say, they prefer vagueness to lying.
 
Many Sources of Outrage
 "I'd like to see Perot be more specific," Robin Johnson, 30, said in Canoga Park, Calif., after signing a petition to put him on the November ballot. "On the other hand, even when politicians come up with a stand on the issues, you can't believe it." Then to prove her point, she added, " 'Read my lips: No new taxes.' "
 To be sure, many other factors are helping fuel the cynicism about government and politicians. People are frightened about the economy. They sense a nation adrift. They are at once outraged and amused by members of Congress and their check-writing scandal.
 And to be sure, voters are awash in contradictions. Perhaps their biggest source of frustration with government is their sense of gridlock, that nothing is being accomplished. Yet it was to break such a gridlock in budget negotiations that Mr. Bush agreed to the tax increase.
 On the one hand, voters say they want frankness. On the other, they make it almost suicidal for a politician even to open the possibility of a tax increase.
 Just last week, Mr. Perot said he would "absolutely not" raise taxes except in "an incredible emergency," and even then only with an unspecified form of advance clearance from the American people.
 But whatever the arguments or contradictions, Mr. Bush's reversal is a visceral issue for many voters. They think they were lied to, and that's it. And this was no ordinary promise. The slogan made for the most memorable moments of the campaign, with Mr. Bush affirming it time and again.
 
Some See Help for Perot
 "The Congress will push me to raise taxes, and I'll say no," he said in his acceptance speech at the Republican National Convention on Aug. 18, 1988. "And they'll push, and I'll say no. And they'll push again, and I'll say to them, Read my lips: No new taxes."
 William J. Bennett, who was Mr. Bush's Secretary of Education and director of drug policy, as well as a political adviser, recalled meetings where he and others urged the President not to go back on his promise.
 "There's no question this has helped fuel Perot, has made the people cynical about government," he said. "Some of us fought as hard as we could, at some point beyond the limits of courtesy, for him not to sign on to the tax increase. I spoke to him several times. I said his pledge wasn't just a campaign promise. It WAS the campaign. You can't take the definition of yourself and flip it. I've found that the American people don't have to agree with you. What they want is a straight line, being true to your word."
 Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director, who played an important role in the budget negotiations with Congress, did not return a telephone call seeking comment. But Mr. Bennett and other Republicans familiar with the President's thinking argued that Mr. Bush had not made his promise cynically, that he had genuinely believed that economic growth would make a tax increase unnecessary.
 Two people present at White House political discussions said some of Mr. Bush's political advisers had argued that everyone knew all along that the promise would have to be broken, and that therefore actually breaking it would be politically manageable. They even argued that Mr. Bush might be portrayed as politically courageous for doing so.
 
Taxes Increase for Few
 Around the country -- in shopping malls and union halls, in libraries and bowling alleys -- few people interviewed said their Federal taxes had significantly increased. Most do not even know the specifics of exactly what taxes were raised. But no matter. They know that George Bush broke his word.
 "The politicians say: 'I'll do this. I'll do that,' " said Keith Ditmor, 51, who works in the chassis department of the General Motors plant in Ypsilanti, Mich. "Then they get elected and do nothing. If I had my way, I'd throw out every politician. I would. They're liars. Look at George Bush. 'No new taxes.' "
 In Woodside, Queens, Laura Stevenson, a 27-year-old sales manager, said: "I basically think that once they get into office, they're going to do whatever they want. Look at good old George Bush. He hasn't kept his promise."
 The President announced that he was receptive to a tax increase on June 26, 1990, as part of a broad budget agreement with Congress. The plan, which he later signed into law, raised to 31 percent from 28 percent the income tax rate on adjusted gross incomes over $80,000. In addition, personal exemptions were phased out as income exceeds $100,000. The payroll tax for Medicare, which had been collected on only the first $54,000 of earnings, was extended to earnings of up to $125,000. The gasoline tax was increased by a nickel a gallon. And taxes were raised on alcohol, tobacco and luxury items.
 
'It's Credibility'
 "But don't make the mistake of thinking this is an anti-tax issue," said William Schneider, a political analyst with the American Enterprise Institute, a Washington research group. "That's not what this is about. It's credibility. I ask Perot petition signers, 'Where does he stand?' They say, 'It doesn't matter to me that he has no position, because then he's not going to lie to me.'
 "This election is Perot on one end and Bush and Clinton on the other end, the typical politicians," he continued. "The flip on taxes is a great symbol. It said he can't be relied on. He lies. And other politicians are getting put in the same basket. That's why Clinton's phrase 'I didn't inhale' is so resonant."
 Mr. Bush now says that if he had it to do over again, he would not have agreed to the tax increases. But the damage is already done. Patrick J. Buchanan ran extensive television commercials before the New Hampshire primary that merely showed Mr. Bush speaking over and over, "Read my lips: No new taxes." Surveys of Republicans leaving the polls after primary voting in New Hampshire, Florida and Texas found that 3 in 10 were influenced in their balloting by Mr. Bush's reversal on taxes, with their votes going overwhelmingly to Mr. Buchanan.
 But the overall effect of Mr. Bush's reversal on him and politicians in general is difficult to measure. Many poll takers believe it is responsible for part of the large mistrust of politicians. A New York Times/CBS News survey of 1,530 adults conducted in late April found that 71 percent of people agreed with this statement: "There is practically no connection between what a politician says and what he will do once he gets elected." It is not possible to compare that with sentiment before Mr. Bush's reversal; the question was not previously asked.
 But the voters do not need any poll results. They know what they think.
 "Campaign speeches are all fabrication," said Harold Klein, 68, in Miami Beach. "Bush and his read my lips. We've been lied to for so long."
 In Sherman Oaks, Calif., where people stood 10 and 20 at a time to sign Perot petitions, Michael Banger, 32, wrote his name with a great flourish. Like so many of the signers, he had a look of satisfaction bordering on pride. Or was it revenge? "Read MY lips," he said. "No more politicians."

HEADLINE: Incinerators See Shortages of Trash

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
THE superintendent of the Windham Energy Recovery Facility, Thota S. Naidu, expected 38,000 tons of trash to burn in the incinerator last year. He got 31,000. "I think I know where it went, but I can't say," said Mr. Naidu, who several weeks ago met with officials from the nine northeastern towns under contract to the incinerator, warning them that they must meet their tonnage obligations. "Let's just say it went to the place where they could get rid of it cheapest." At the Windham incinerator, the disposal fee is $86 a ton, and that fee will increase to $98.75 on July 1 because of operating costs. There are landfills in Rhode Island, on the other hand, charging $30 a ton. It was only five years ago that a garbage barge from Islip, N.Y., went on its famous odyssey because it could find no place to unload. Today, the seven regional mass-burn centers in Connecticut find themselves competing for trash.
Rebellion appears to be stirring in those towns that are locked into contracts requiring them to pay twice as much or more than what their neighbors are paying to get rid of trash. "Six years ago I saw this coming," said Donald E. Burdick, the First Selectman of Griswold, which is wrangling with the regional authority over where its trash should go. "I said garbage was going to be like education, the cost was going to go out of control, and it has." 
 Charles L. Atkin, a supervisor in the State Department of Environmental Protection's solid waste unit, said that trash across the state had become a valuable commodity, necessary to fuel the expensive waste-to-energy plants that have been constructed.
Mr. Atkin said the garbage situation has become so bad that some incinerators have had to import trash. When an incinerator in Preston was being tested, for instance, the operator had to bring in garbage from New York.
Mr. Atkin and others attribute the turnaround to several factors, but most significant in everyone's assessment is the poor state of the economy. Simply put, when people don't buy things, they don't throw away things. The state's mandatory recycling law has also taken its toll. Recycling has cut by about 25 percent the material that would otherwise go into the trash, material like paper, cans and bottles that are reused, and yard waste that is composted. So-called source reduction has also had an impact, Mr. Atkin said. People are being more careful to buy things that are not overpackaged, and state and Federal laws are starting to restrict some forms of packaging.
In the late 1980's, some towns signed contracts with regional resource recovery authorities that required them to deliver a certain amount of garbage at a set price each year. If they do not deliver, they still pay. Mr. Atkins said his office has been getting an increasing number of calls from communities that wanted help in making sure trash got to the town-authorized disposal center.
"If it's a question of illegal dumping," Mr. Atkin said, "we can go after the haulers for that, but if they're just bringing it to another town because it's more economical, we really can't get involved. It's a nightmare to try to police it, especially if you have a hauler who's picking up in five towns, that might be sending to different facilities."
At the Bridgeport incinerator, the disposal fee is $65.50 a ton for trash, but member towns often charge commercial haulers even more, to cover the cost of operating transfer stations. In Fairfield, for instance, the fee is $75 a ton to commercial haulers at the town transfer station, and the director of solid waste and recycling, Richard S. Cellar, said he worried that these haulers are going directly to the incinerator, or to disposal centers outside the region, and that Fairfield will not meet its minimum tonnage requirement.
The Town of Fairfield has hired an enforcement officer to check up on haulers. "A few years ago you had to worry about people sneaking in garbage that didn't belong to the town," Mr. Cellar said. "Now you worry they're not bringing you what they should."
 
Drumming Up New Business
 At some incinerators, one method of coping with the shortfall has been to look for new business. Bridgeport recently signed contracts with the towns of Woodbridge, Bethany and West Haven, and is trying to sign Stamford, which has been told to upgrade or shut down its aging trash incinerator. "The closer the plant runs to capacity, the more cost efficient it becomes," Mr. Cellar said.
But in many cases towns are not interested in signing a contract. Today several plants are offering rates that are below the contract rates; at the Preston center, for instance, member towns pay $65 a ton, outsiders pay $55.
That could change quickly if the economy turns around and trash starts to pile up, Mr. Atkin said. In that case, the same incinerators begging for garbage today could have a surplus, and the below-contract rates could climb above negotiated prices. But towns are often tempted to turn away when a hauler brings trash someplace where it will not cost the town as much.
"It's a very significant problem, one we've spent a lot of time with since last November, when we saw it starting to develop," said William R. Darcy, president of the Connecticut Resources Recovery Authority, an agency that owns or has financed five of the state's seven regional incinerators.
A few years ago there was no need for enforcement officers, Mr. Darcy said. Today he dispatches between six and eight officers daily to follow trucks and to police the state line for bootleg garbage.
 
No State Governance
 Mr. Darcy said state law does not give his organization the authority to penalize errant haulers. Instead, he notifies the towns and they can decide to suspend the hauler's collection license, levy a fine or take other action.
"We don't want to raise prices to the municipalities because some are not delivering the tonnage required by their contract," Mr. Darcy said.
The situation led to a confrontation in eastern Connecticut, where the Town of Griswold received a $47,000 bill for trash it had not delivered. "They haven't fulfilled their contractual obligation," said Milton Y. Suzich, executive director of the Southeastern Connecticut Regional Resources Recovery Authority in Preston. "They're not doing all they can to insure the town's waste is going to Preston."
Griswold's First Selectman, Mr. Burdick, acknowledged that some residents were taking trash to a landfill in Canterbury, but he said he did not believe the contract required Griswold to track down the offenders. "I hope we don't have to go to court to break the contract, because that's costly and only the lawyers win," Mr. Burdick said. But the regional authority, he said, is "out to create a monopoly, and that's supposed to be against the law."
Mr. Suzich said that about half the other 10 towns under contract to the southeast regional authority were also falling short of what they had promised to deliver, so that instead of 154,000 tons required by contract the authority expected to collect 140,000 tons from the 11 member towns this year.
 
Now Garbage Counts
 But the authority has determined that all the other towns are taking steps to make sure all their trash gets to Preston.
Madison and Guilford, for instance, have sent police officers to check on trash haulers, and have conducted hearings on two haulers whose loads started dropping without explanation. "They're getting the message that they can't bring Madison garbage to another town," said Madison First Selectman Thomas R. Rylander. "We have to protect the garbage that we have." Realizing what he has said, Mr. Rylander laughed, and added wistfully, "It wasn't too long ago towns didn't care where their trash went.
"Just a few years ago nobody wanted garbage," he continued. "All we had were landfills, and we didn't want stuff being put in there, so if they brought it somewhere else we were just as happy. But everybody's looking for garbage now. It's a very popular item."
