HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY Q & A: THE REV. KATRINA MARTHA SWANSON;
Trying to Preserve an Inner-City Parish

BYLINE: By TINA TRASTER-POLAK

DATELINE: UNION CITY

 BODY:
ST. JOHN'S EPISCOPAL CHURCH here celebrates its 145th anniversary this year, but as is the case in many urban parishes across New Jersey, its long-term survival is uncertain. The migration to the suburbs, waning church attendance and costly maintenance have led to the closing of inner-city churches throughout the state.
The Rev. Katrina Martha Swanson, who has been at St. John's for 13 years, feels the pressure. In an interview, she spoke of the difficulties and rewards of ministering to her congregation, the impact of the recession and unemployment on her parishioners and her concern that urban churches are being sacrificed to the interests of suburban churches. 
 She also discussed the unsuccessful efforts she and her husband, the Rev. George Swanson of Ascension Church in Jersey City, have made over the last four years to rebuild his fire-gutted church. The couple have sued the Episcopal Diocese of Newark to gain control of more than $700,000 in fire insurance money for that purpose.
A spokesman for the diocese said that the diocese had refused to relinquish the money because the rebuilding of a church must have the bishop's consent, and that the small size of Ascension's parish made it difficult to support a parish or a priest. Ascension has since been turned into a mission church.
The daughter of a clergyman, Ms. Swanson was born in Boston 57 years ago and grew up in the mid-Atlantic states. She is a graduate of Radcliffe College and was in the first group of 11 women ordained by the Episcopal Church. She and her husband have two sons and live in Jersey City.
Q. How has Union City changed since you have been here?
A. There are more younger people. Many families with more children. There's a greater mixture of new people. There's a large Cuban population and older Swiss and German immigrants, but there are many more people from South and Central America, the Caribbean, India and the Middle East. The congregation has changed a lot. We have a great increase of people from South and Central America.
Q. You've become known for your bilingual sermons. Do you think the Hispanic people you minister to, and other ethnic groups, feel assimilated into American society?
A. I am not sure people coming to the United States want to be assimilated into the American culture. They want to be citizens. But they are pretty clear about the benefits of their own cultures, for example courtesy and nurturing -- two aspects they don't find in American culture.
Traditionally, first-generation immigrants have come to America and never learned the language. Frequently, they never go out into the ordinary work force. After a generation or two, their families do learn the language. Here in this community we have both first and later generations, and the early generations still have not assimilated.
Q. Is religion alive in Union City?
A. This is one of the saddest things in cities across the nation. People have neglected God. People say, "I'm of this or that faith," and maybe they are saying prayers at home. But they are not joining together to worship God on a regular basis.
Q. Why?
A. In the 1950's when the church was strong, social life was connected with the church. Perhaps our social structure is so mobile, maybe church life along with family life has broken down. Maybe people are more apt to recognize their relationship with God when they need God. That was true in biblical times. People today are too tied up with their own lives to remember that they have a relationship with God.
Q. How active is your congregation?
A. I wasn't here years ago when there was standing room only in this church. Today, the congregation, by and large, has two kinds of people. There's a core group of people who feel that it's part of their lives to be here every Sunday; that's around 40 or 50. And then there's a group of people, also about 50 people, who feel comfortable being in church once a month or quarterly, all of whom feel they come regularly.
Congregation members are very active in their community service, however. For example, they help with the homeless shelter; they run an annual party for elders. They take seriously Jesus's suggestion to do things for others.
Q. How has your church been helping the homeless?
A. When the Marielistas, a group from Cuba, came to Union City in 1980, religious leaders got together to discuss how we could respond to their needs. At that time the Rev. Gary Kugler of St. John's Lutheran in Union City opened up a shelter to house them. Gradually, the shelter was used by other homeless people. For many years the shelter has been begging other parishes to help them. Last year, a group of other church people started the Inter-Religious Fellowship to help St. John's with its overflow of homeless people. We became one of those parishes this winter.
Q. Have recent hard times changed the way people interact with the church?
A. During the last few months people have been greatly affected by unemployment. A lot of people are getting onto my prayer list for finding jobs. Normally people get onto a prayer list when they are sick or have family problems or when someone has died.
I see a lot more asthma, which is caused by the emotional stress of the recession. It may be a symptom of an increasingly polluted environment; people from places like the Caribbean or other countries with cleaner air may find it harder to adapt, but I've seen an overall increase in people who've lived here a long time. People are also hanging onto colds and viruses longer.
I've also seen a lot more depression. People are so stressed out. Running all the time, so terribly busy trying to hold down two or three jobs.
Q. Do your personal views mingle with your priestly practices?
A. Some of my functioning as a priest has my personal signature -- for example, my deep belief in openness and inclusiveness. Some of my important concerns have to be put on the back burner, like inclusive language, language that does not exclude women.
A lot of church language uses male language. It takes a lot of work to change that, and because I work so hard at the bilingual service, delivering the sermon in English and Spanish, I don't have the energy to clean up the language of its male domination.
Q. Are female priests any less accepted than their male counterparts?
A. There are many more female priests today than there were 10 years ago. When I was first ordained in 1974, people would stop and ask me whether I was really a priest. When I moved to Hudson County from Kansas City in 1977, people here really seemed to accept me, to take me for granted. I didn't get many questions.
Interestingly enough, the questions are beginning to start again. I don't whether it's due to some sort of antiwoman backlash. It seems the women's movement is not as well accepted as it was four or five years ago, that women are having a tougher time.
Q. Does being a man rather than a woman cast a different slant on being a priest?
A. Normally I like to avoid that question. Being a priest is an individual thing. I liken it to a snowflake image; each priest has his or her own imprint, his or her own answer to God's call. But male priests are a little more corporate minded, a little bit more ambitious. Women priests are more mission and pastorally oriented.
Q. What's it like being married to a priest?
A. There are pluses and minuses. You really understand one another's life. Having gone from clergy wife to priest partner, though, gave me a much deeper understanding about the priesthood even though I'm fourth generation of a clergy family. The negative side is that we both have tough schedules.
Q. How do you and your husband influence each other?
A. George and I have worked at not competing; rather, we work as partners. We're more apt to seek out each other's ideas. For example, I learned through him that it was inappropriate for a priest to be authoritarian. Now I value the idea of shared ministry. From me, George has borrowed a style of worship. At St. John's we encourage people to add their personal prayers to the liturgy.
Q. How has the controversy over Ascension Church affected your personal views on the politics of the church?
A. The authority of the canon law mandates that a congregation buy fire insurance. The people of Ascension had been buying that over the years. And when the church burned down and they needed to have their fire settlement, their money was stolen from them and a contract was broken.
I was deeply disappointed. The Episcopal Church has meant a great deal to me. I've been so proud that it's been so broad and so democratic and a church where all people participate in decision making. And this action was very, very disappointing.
Q. Why is the diocese reluctant to rebuild Ascension?
A. The diocese looks at the church's survival in terms of a balance sheet; it is a valuable piece of property that can be sold in order to build churches in the suburbs.
The administration often tells horrified stories about Hoboken having three churches within walking distance and the same in Jersey City. People outside cities don't relate to urban living.
Q. Are urban parishes losing their will to survive?
A. The battle will be more quickly lost unless the religious communities in the suburbs feel a bond with us. We need to bring people from the suburbs on board to work with the people in the cities. In the past year we've had people from the suburbs helping out, volunteering with painting projects.
Many religious leaders in the suburbs grew up in places like Union City. If we create a link, then the people of the suburbs will be more apt to vote with us, they will be more willing to protect our integrity, rather than grabbing money for their own needs.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Rev. Katrina Martha Swanson at St. John's Episcopal Church. (Najlah Feanny for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in: The East Village

BYLINE: By BRET SENFT

 BODY:
LAST month, after eight years uptown, Lisa Russell moved to the East Village. "It's funkier, and a lot more fun," said Ms. Russell, a People magazine writer. "Most of my life was happening here anyway -- there are more cafes, bars, movies."
In a Manhattan sobered by recession and social ills, those in search of a counterculture life style may find its last vestiges here. Rents are high, but food is cheap. And the multicultural mix includes a handful of anarchists serving as guilty conscience to a neighborhood seeking, privately, at least, to improve its qualtity of life without betraying its history of social consciousness. They hold mini-demonstrations and Friday night speakouts. 
 "This neighborhood is an example to the world of standing up against oppression and the police state," said John Potak, one of a group of loosely organized activists who, among other things, have set up a RAGE-ON! (Revolt Against Gentrification Erasing Our Neighborhood) hot line -- 713-5743 -- for details of coming demonstrations.
The area has known quieter days. It began as a farm, or bouwerie -- embracing what is now Fourth Avenue to the East River, 17th to Fifth Street -- bought by Peter Stuyvesant from the Dutch West India Company in 1651. To the east, the property's salt marsh was filled in and in 1834 became Tompkins Square Park.
Part of Stuyvesant's property in 1799 became the site of St. Marks-in-the-Bowery, a landmark church at Second Avenue and 10th Street that was damaged by fire in 1978 and restored in 1984.
Poor immigrants, initially Irish and German, flooded the area in the 1850's, spurring tenement construction. Italians and Eastern European Jews arrived in the early 1900's, Poles and Ukrainians after World War II, Puerto Ricans in the late 1940's, beatniks in the 50's and artists from Greenwich Village in the 60's.
Beth Flusser and her husband, Richard, moved to Stuyvesant Street 32 years ago and raised two daughters. "Back then it was an affordable place to live, with a 'new frontier' quality about it," she said. "There was no commercial activity."
Then came gentrification. Suzanne Wasserman, on Stuyvesant Street from 1982 to 1988, has since moved to Stuyvesant Town. "There were incredible changes during those years," she said. "It went from very quiet, all Ukrainian little shops, to yuppie restaurants everywhere and heavy traffic."
Changes include new, upscale Italian restaurants on East Fourth Street: Frutti di Mare, La Strada and Cucina di Pesce. Stingy Lulu's Luncheonette, a 24-hour, 50's-style diner, opened last month at 129 St. Mark's Place. Then there are the Indian restaurants -- about two dozen on Sixth Street between First and Second Avenues, with some on the avenues.
PERFORMANCE venues include La Mama E.T.C., 74A East Fourth Street; Theater for the New City, 155 First Avenue; the Living Theater, 272 East Third Street, and two multiplex theaters: Loew's Village Theater VII, 66 Third Avenue, and Village East City Cinemas, 189 Second Avenue.
A thriving gallery scene in the mid-80's all but vanished by the end of the decade. Pat Hearn, for one, had galleries on East Sixth and East Ninth from 1984 to 1989, but is now onWooster Street.
"The galleries needed more storage and office space," she said. "And the rents kept escalating -- for the price of a small storefront, people went to Broadway between Houston and Broome, for example, to buildings renovated specifically for galleries."
The neighborhood's funkiness seems to include graffiti-covered buildings, garbage strewn by the homeless collecting redeemables and heavy drug traffic.
"This is where people come to get drugs," said Rick Carmen, chairman of Community Board 3. "And for many without other economic opportunities, it is our neighborhood's biggest employer."
Yet the allure of bohemian decadence keeps housing prices up. The building stock includes "more five-story walk-ups than anything else," said Gary Brenner of City Estate Agency. Rents in these and in brownstones and renovated spaces, he said, are $600 to $1,000 a month for studios, $750 to $1,400 for one-bedrooms and $1,200 to $1,800 for two-bedrooms.
Luxury buildings went up during the 1980's. But more than half the owners in the Christodora House, an 85-unit condominium on Avenue B overlooking the park, have rented their spaces, waiting out the recession before selling, according to James Roman, sales manager for the Halstead Property Company, a brokerage, and Red Square, a high-rise rental at 250 East Houston built in the late 80's, "still has empty apartments and a steady turnover."
St. Mark's Real Estate, which handles rent-stabilized apartments, said studios fetch $600 to $700 and two-bedrooms, $1,000 to $1,100.
Tompkins Square Park, where there have been summer riots since 1988, was closed last June for renovation and is scheduled to reopen late in July. Its bandshell is being replaced by a portable stage.
"It was obsolete, an eyesore, a symbol for the anarchist-thugs," said Councilman Antonio Pagan, who also seeks limits to the area's social services burden, most recently, a proposed shelter on East Seventh Street for people with AIDS.
The Lower East Side has one-third of all such services citywide, many in the East Village, said Mr. Pagan, adding: "Such an over-concentration, in any neighborhood, is not healthy."
But Armando Perez, co-founder and chairman of Charas/El Bohio community cultural organization at 605 East Ninth Street, said that "we have a tremendous problem with drugs and AIDS here" and that "to just say 'No more social services' just doesn't make sense."
EIGHT of School District 1's 22 schools are in the East Village, several with new alternative programs. P.S. 19 has been designated a Chancellor's Model School Project, adding a new 7th and 8th grade, with new focus on math, science, technology and humanities. Last September, the Neighborhood School at P.S. 63 began pre-K to first-grade instruction, building towards six grades; its nontraditional, alternative program eschews textbooks for a child-centered curriculum designed by its director and teachers, with parental participation.
The Earth School at P.S. 64, will have an integrated curriculum with emphasis on ecology. Junior High 60 will expand to become the district's only high school, modeled after the Coalition of Essential Schools, a nationwide program using portfolios to assess student progress, a lower teacher-student ratio, with smaller groups built on themes of learning.
The district has been given Federal and corporate funds for programs, including $1.5 million in computer equipment from I.B.M. for P.S. 19's new 7th and 8th grades. The Parent Developmental Center at P.S. 63 provides training in school-based management (parent-staff collaboration on education decisions).
LaSalle Academy at 44 East Second Street and Notre Dame School, 104 St. Mark's Place, are, respectively, Roman Catholic boys' and girls' high schools, with competitive entrance exams. St. George's Academy, 215 East Sixth Street, has 200 students in its K-12 school, serving parish children of the adjacent St. George's Ukrainian Catholic Church.
There are also three Roman Catholic parochial elementary schools: St. Brigid's, at 185 East Seventh Street; Mary Help of Christians, 435 East 11th, and Immaculate Conception, 419 East 13th.
Almost 90 abandoned city-owned buildings east of Avenue A, long controversial among housing advocates, "have all been identified" for homesteading, cross-subsidy and rehabilitation programs, said Valerie Jo Bradley, an assistant commmissioner of the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development.
In addition there are several hundred squatters in about 20 other abandoned city-owned buildings for which there are no programs in sight.
"We live in fear of eviction," said Art Cabrera, an unemployed construction worker who with fellow squatters renovated a building on East 10th Street. "But we will defend our homes. We have nowhere else to go."

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 390 words

HEADLINE: How Columbia Weathers the Economic Storm

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Short of Money, Columbia Weighs How Best to Change" (front page, May 25) leaves mistaken impressions about the results of steps Columbia University is taking to meet the financial pressures it shares with many colleges and universities.
Columbia will not dip into endowment principal to cover the planned operating deficit for next year. Temporarily we will spend more of the return of the endowment to cover critical needs in the operating budget, while we plan for complete elimination of the deficit in 1994-95. The endowment will continue to grow. 
 The university will not have to trim $72 million more from its projected $1 billion expenditures to achieve its budget target for 1993-94. Half that amount will be realized by additional revenues and expense reductions next year that will carry forward. Our experience demonstrates that we can achieve the remainder of the saving needed without damage to academic programs. And even after these savings are realized, the budget will still grow each year.
The addition next fall of 110 students to an enrollment of 19,300 hardly qualifies as crowding. The maximum class size for the core curriculum courses in Columbia College will continue to be 22. The 60 new graduate students enrolling in master's degree programs will add 7 students on average to approximately 8 of the 27 departments in the Graduate School, which has a total enrollment of 3,200.
Students admitted to the college with financial aid this fall face no uncertainty about its continuation the following year, contrary to your assertion. They will receive the financial assistance required to complete their undergraduate degrees.
The size of the nearly 500-member arts and sciences faculty will be reduced by less than 2 percent next year, not 8.6 percent, as part of a planned reduction following earlier increased faculty hiring in anticipation of retirements now occurring.
The arts and sciences receive nearly $35 million annually in publicly sponsored project funds exceeded in the university only by the medical school. Also, $30.5 million supports research work at the university's Lamont-Doherty Geological Observatory. You incorrectly assert that the arts and sciences receive few research grants.
 
JONATHAN R. COLE
Provost, Columbia University
New York, May 29, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1196 words

HEADLINE: THE EARTH SUMMIT;
Battle in Rio: The Day After
Friends and Foes Agree On a Sharper Sentinel

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 14

 BODY:
The Earth Summit, which wound up with predictable fanfare today, has given the world its first real glimpse of the kind of global diplomacy that is becoming possible now that the the cold war is over. But the conference has also shown how difficult negotiating worldwide solutions to worldwide problems is likely to be.
For decades East-West tensions made it hard to take joint approaches to challenges affecting all the world's nations, including environmental problems like threats to the atmosphere, population growth, and international migration. 
 Yet over the last 10 days, the Earth Summit brought together the greatest number of world leaders that have ever assembled with a single aim -- in this case to seek a global agreement that shifts mankind's search for economic betterment onto a more environmentally sound plane by asking developing countries to industrialize in environmentally sustainable ways.
 
A Time of Promise
 They came together at a time of extraordinary promise in world affairs, after the demise of Communism, which has reordered priorities not only in the industrialized world but also in the developing world.
The summit agreement that was approved today has already been denounced by some groups as weak -- as "business as usual" and "a failure to set a new direction for life on earth," as Friends of the Earth called it today. And countries of the developing South have expressed disappointment that the industrialized North was not more generous.
But for many, the accord is important mainly as the start of a process that could eventually change the way the world approaches the challenge of fostering economic growth in the Southern Hemisphere, shifting the basis of all new aid and investment toward environmental responsibility.
 
A Watchdog Group
 Just as the world has set up international agencies to insure respect for human rights and to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons, so the Earth Summit created a new Sustainable Development Commission to monitor the world's compliance with the promises it made at Rio.
"The Rio Conference does not end at Rio," the Brazilian President, Fernando Collor de Mello, said today.
The strength of public interest in the meeting -- 10,000 private environmentalists and 8,000 journalists attended -- suggests that governments will not be allowed to forget what they have begun.
But the Earth Summit also showed that tackling global challenges in today's world means forging agreement among some 180 countries that are no longer focused on the East-West divide, and who may regard the United States as no more than one player among many.
 
Re-examining the U.N.
 The Soviet Union's disintegration has allowed the United States to dominate the United Nations Security Council in recent years, using it to achieve its aims in many areas and arousing fears of a "unipolar" world under effective American domination.
But the Earth Summit was a reminder that outside the field of peace and security, the United Nations lacks other small, powerful bodies like the Security Council that the United States, as the remaining superpower, can work through to achieve its ends.
The United Nations also remains the only international framework that exists for approaching global challenges, however, and its machinery often requires what can be a slow, fumbling search for consensus among its nearly 200 members.
The agreement sought by the Earth Summit participants on the environment and development, as on any other global issue, was intended to be a bargain between North and South that both halves would find in their interests.
The developing countries hoped to pick up some of the economic gains they tried but failed to win in the 1970's when they called for a new world economic order. This time, they tried to persuade the North to eradicate poverty in return for cleaner growth in the South.
The Northern governments, it was hoped, would agree to this because of the strength of environmentalist groups back home and because their own efforts to fight pollution would come to little in the end if the Southern countries did not follow suit.
But the initial outcome fell short of Southern expectations largely because of the growing rifts within Northern and Southern camps.
Opposition of countries like Malaysia and India to any binding commitment on preserving the world's forests meant that the South could not offer the one concession that might have encouraged the Bush Administration to take the Earth Summit more seriously.
Similarly, the genuine fear among small island states that they will soon be flooded if temperatures rise left the developing world divided over the urgency of curbing "greenhouse" gas emissions. Ultimately it meant that the Southern countries could not hold the global-warming convention hostage to Northern concessions.
In a complete change of position since the first oil-price shock of the 1970's, when Saudi Arabia and other oil exporters told the industrialized countries that they would have to reduce consumption if they wanted prices to decline, major oil exporters are now fighting the world consensus in favor of saving energy.
 
Issues That Cross Divide
 Some concerns cut across the North-South divide. Efforts to promote family planning as the key to population control, higher living standards and reduced pressure on the environment ran into opposition from a curious coalition, including the Vatican, conservative Islamic nations and some feminists who argued that male-dominated governments should not interfere with women's lives.
At the conference, the United States made no attempt to exercise the kind of leadership it had shown at a world environment meeting 20 years earlier in Stockholm that brought environmental concerns into sharper focus on the diplomatic agenda.
Instead the Bush Administration appeared divided and paralyzed by ideology and political concerns, reinforcing the perception that in an election year it is incapable of facing up to new foreign policy challenges.
Among industrialized countries, Japan alone appeared ready to offer the South meaningful new aid, but it made no attempt to lead the Northern bloc. Indeed, Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa, citing a legislative debate at home about whether to commit troops to international peacekeepiung forces, did not even attend the Earth Summit.
As a result the United States, Britain and the Germany successfully resisted being drawn into any specific commitments on new aid, despite pressure from France and the Scandinavians to be more generous.
 
East Bloc's Argument
 Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union infuriated the South by asserting that their "transitional" status as countries on the road to capitalism justified special aid.
And Germany confirmed the Southern countries' worst fears by citing its commitment to helping the former Communist countries of Eastern Europe as a major reason that it could not do more for the South.
The collapse of Communism, widely seen as ushering in a new era of more constructive international diplomacy, has thus ended up by pushing North and South even further apart.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Accords for Nature's Sake"
 
Biodiversity Convention
 A legally binding treaty that requires inventories of plants and wildlife and plans to protect endangered species. It also requires signers to share research, profits and technology with nations whose genetic resources they use. The United States did not sign.
 
Global Warming Convention
 A legally binding treaty that recommends curbing emissions of carbon dioxide, methane and other "greenhouse" gases thought to warm the climate by trapping the sun's heat close to earth. The United States signed, but insisted that the document not set targets for reducing carbon dioxide emissions.
 
Declaration on Environment and Development
 A non-binding statement of 27 broad principles for guiding environmental policy that emphasizes protecting the environment as part of economic development, safeguarding the ecological systems of other nations and giving priority to the needs of developing countries, the "most environmentally vulnerable." Adopted by concensus yesterday.
 
Agenda 21
 A non-binding 800-page blueprint to clean up the global environment and encourage development in an environmentally sound manner. Adopted by consensus yesterday after developing countries abandoned their demand for specific commitments of aid from industrialized nations to pay for the plan.
 
Statement on Forest Principles
 A non-binding document that recommends that countries assess the impact of economic development on their forests, and take steps, both individually and with other countries, to minimize the damage. Adopted by consensus yesterday.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1446 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
With Independent Candidate, The Race Just Won't Let Up

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
The clear lesson so far about a three-way Presidential campaign is that there are no intermissions. So the ordinarily languid month of June, falling between the end of the primaries and the beginning of the conventions, has become a season of elbowing, risk-taking and struggling for position.
As recently as a few weeks ago, the campaigns of President Bush and Bill Clinton seemed utterly confounded by the dynamics of this race, paralyzed by a web of conflicting advice. Now, prodded by the continued strength of Ross Perot, they are making some decisions and taking some actions. 
 The Bush campaign, unable to reverse the President's slide in the polls, is trying at least to stabilize his political condition by making Mr. Perot seem a frightening, unacceptable alternative.
 
Giving Clinton an Edge
 The Clinton campaign, after weeks of drift, is trying to regain the public's attention by giving the Governor of Arkansas an edge and defining him as something more than just another politician: to wit, a Democratic nominee willing to go before the Rev. Jesse Jackson's Rainbow Coalition and chide it for racial insensitivity -- toward whites.
The Perot campaign, now leading in polls, is trying to let Perot be Perot, while fending off the follow-up questions that his advisers know he is not yet ready for, the questions that could break his can-do spell.
Those who doubt the intensity of this race, five months before Election Day, need only listen to the escalating series of attacks on Mr. Perot now coming from the President's surrogates.
 
Labels for Perot
 Rich Bond, the Republican Party's national chairman, pointed the way last week in a speech to a convention of bakers. "If you want a vague, mysterious and authoritarian figure," he said, with "the risk factor that will be involved in making that choice for this nation and this world over the next four years, then your man is Ross Perot."
The buzzwords, apparently emerging from campaign research on Mr. Perot's vulnerabilities, are "temperamental," "unknown," and determined to operate "outside the rules." Charles Black, a senior adviser to the campaign, described the effort simply, "Make him risky."
It is a method used against past Democratic nominees with considerable success, particularly Michael S. Dukakis in 1988. By the end of that campaign, the Massachusetts Governor had been cast as a shadowy liberal who was itching to dismantle America's defenses.
Moreover, this strategy dovetails with the belief of top Bush advisers, including the campaign chairman, Robert M. Teeter, that this election will still, in the end, come down to trust and leadership traits, which they argue gives even a damaged President an invaluable edge.
 
Staying Above It All
 While the surrogates are busy slashing and burning, Mr. Bush is trying to stay above it all. With a series of foreign policy events beginning with last week's trip to Panama and Rio de Janeiro, the Bush campaign hoped to highlight his image as a steady commander in chief. Last week's trip was less than triumphant, beginning with the near tear-gassing of Mr. Bush in Panama, but his aides have high hopes for his meeting here this week with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia.
By the end of the week, Mr. Bush will embark on a campaign trip to California and Texas, two states that were once anchors of Republican Presidential victories, but are now considered Perot territory. He will pay careful attention to the party's base, with a foray expected into Orange County, Calif.
Mr. Black has made it clear in recent days that the Bush campaign will try to chip away at Mr. Perot's coalition along ideological lines, through issues like his support for abortion rights and his opposition to the war in the Persian Gulf; Texas is considered ripe for that approach.
Bush aides say they believe they can solidify the Republican base this summer without paying a price for it among the swing voters in the center this fall. "What we're doing right now doesn't hurt us a whit," asserted one strategist.
 
Clinton Showing Independence
 But many Democrats argue that the Republicans may be painting themselves into a corner by highlighting their social agenda, like their opposition to legalized abortion.
There are voices in the Democratic Party urging Mr. Clinton to move left and focus similar attention on his party's base. The most prominent, perhaps, is the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who used his Rainbow Coalition meeting this weekend to make the case for the new arithmetic of a three-way race, which he said could make victory possible by galvanizing and turning out the Democratic core voter.
Mr. Clinton countered with a speech on the "remarkable commonality" between the group's goals and his own, like the need to reinvest in the nation's economy and its people. But he also sought to signal his independence, chiding the group for giving a platform to Sister Souljah, a rap performer who was quoted by The Washington Post as saying after the riot in Los Angeles, "If black people kill black people every day, why not have a week and kill white poeple?" Mr. Jackson was tight with anger after Mr. Clinton's remarks.
Ordinarily, a Democratic nominee would use his pre-convention period to mollify Mr. Jackson, not provoke him. But Mr. Clinton is in a different context. He is trying to reclaim the themes and the image he began with in this campaign, when he succeeded in casting himself as a new kind of Democrat, gutsy enough to break with the old orthodoxies, not beholden to conventional politics and willing to stand up to powerful constituents, like Mr. Jackson.
 
Emphasis on Economics
 This, of course, is the very position now held by the independent, Mr. Perot.
Allies said Mr. Clinton would also be refocusing his often meandering message with a single-minded emphasis on economics, which his strategists say will become the driving issue of this campaign. (Part of this refocusing is simply self-discipline on the part of a candidate who never met a policy question he didn't like.)
A new economic strategy will be announced sometime in the next several days, and it is expected to highlight Mr. Clinton's commitment to "investing in people" through measures like new college loans and national apprenticeship programs. It is also expected to have a strong populist tone.
Mr. Clinton also plans a remarkable siege of television appearances over the next 10 days, from two hours on the CBS News program "This Morning" on Monday to an hour on MTV on Tuesday and Larry King's call-in program on the Cable News Network on Thursday.
The Democrats, whose candidate is third in the polls, have not embarked on a campaign of attacking Mr. Perot with the intensity the Republicans have shown. Mr. Clinton himself occasionally criticizes Mr. Perot, although the Governor's campaign clearly prefers to let the Republicans handle that duty. There are strategic reasons for this: Mr. Clinton badly needs to improve his image, and going on the attack against a rival, immediately after a bitter primary season, is not the best way to do it. Moreover, the Clinton campaign clearly views much of Mr. Perot's support as an anti-Bush vote that could, eventually, come its way.
 
Advantage to Perot
 Mr. Perot, in many ways, has the easiest hand to play over the coming days. He will embark this week on a swing through California, Colorado and Massachusetts for a series of rallies with supporters in the drive to put him on the November ballot.
He continues to be the focus of investigative articles and persistent questions about just where he stands on issues.
A woman telephone caller named Roberta gave him a fairly tough grilling last week on the NBC News's "Today" program, highlighting the vast difference between the idea of wanting to reduce the Federal budget deficit and the unpleasant reality it would involve, like cuts in benefit programs for senior citizens.
Still, Mr. Perot has retained his appeal. "Clearly, he's making mistakes in terms of inconsistencies and the like, but he's still coming across as different and someone who will change things," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic poll-taker. "It's as if Perot is operating in one sphere and Bush and Clinton are operating in a completely different sphere."
James Squires, Mr. Perot's press secretary, assails Republican attacks on Mr. Perot as "deliberate calculations to raise the specter of fear." Whether there is an cumulative effect to the attacks, the unflattering news articles and the wiggling around issues on live television, is still unclear. For now, though, Mr. Perot keeps his rivals scrambling.

HEADLINE: Japan Takes On the Mob, and the Mob Fights Back

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 12

 BODY:
With hit movies like "Tampopo" and "A Taxing Woman," Juzo Itami has developed a knack for making this serious-minded nation laugh at its quirks. But when he decided to join a growing national debate with a new film about fending off the mob, satire gave way to a real drama.
On May 22, just a week after the new movie opened, three men attacked Mr. Itami in front of his house, slashing him repeatedly in the face, neck and left hand, leaving him alive but disfigured. Suddenly, the film director's bandaged face became a gruesome symbol of a kind of war the Japanese have been waging recently against the yakuza, or mob. 
 The problem is not the existence of the yakuza. For decades the gangsters have swaggered openly through Japanese society, movies and popular novels, street samurai with neck-to-knee tattoos and, often, sliced off little fingers, the result of a well-known punishment for violating the rules. The police admit the yakuza operated under an unspoken pact: as long as they conducted their illegal activities on the fringes of society, using a minimum of violence, they would be left alone. Occasionally they were used to suppress Communists and other radicals.
But the remarkable economic boom of the 1980's shattered the old understanding by giving the yakuza a great deal more wealth and audacity. As a growing series of scandals have shown, the yakuza have moved from smoky gambling dens to the stock market, from rackets on construction sites to the real estate development industry, from ties with the neighborhood police to influence over national politicians.
The Government has responded with an unparalleled attack on the yakuza. The police have been armed with tough new laws, staging a series of raids for weapons and encouraging citizens' groups to use the courts to throw gangsters out of their neighborhoods. The police have even set up a hot line in some areas to help yakuza defectors re-enter legitimate life.
The fight has increasingly become not just an issue of law and order, but of the Japanese self-image as an unusually harmonious people, free of the kind of violence that is most often identified with the United States.
And the yakuza have fought back -- with lawsuits, street protests and, when they felt it was necessary, violence. One gangster threatened that the yakuza would stop buying the Cadillacs and Mercedes Benzes they favor in an effort to bring foreign pressure on the Japanese Government. The confrontation has grown increasingly tense, and the stakes are now high for both sides.
Even though the gangs engage in illegal activities, from extortion and gambling to prostitution and drug dealing, it is not illegal to be a member of the yakuza or to do business with them.
One of the new law's most bitter opponents is Tokutaro Takayama, the imposing boss of the Aizu Kotetsu, a yakuza group based in Kyoto with more than 2,000 members. Mr. Takayama explained during an interview in a hospital room in Kyoto, where he was recovering from an auto accident, that his group had filed suit seeking the repeal of the law because it denied them the right to earn a living.
 
'Create a Police State'
 "You may think it sounds funny for an outlaw to claim a law is unconstitutional, but this law is different from any they've used in the past," he said, surrounded by more than a dozen of his gang's members, several of whom were shy a joint of their little fingers. "What people don't realize is that it will affect everyone. The intention of the police is to control everything and to create a police state."
Mr. Takayama said he had not seen Mr. Itami's new movie, "Minbo no Onna," which could be translated roughly as "Woman Mob Fighter." It is about a wisecracking lawyer who shows the staff of a luxury hotel how to fend off yakuza extortion schemes, including the ploy of surreptitiously slipping a huge bug into a plate of food, then complaining of contamination.
But he was short on sympathy for the attack on Mr. Itami and suggested that the public should pay heed.
"Nobody would put a cockroach in a restaurant's food like that," Mr. Takayama said. "Itami was just out to make money without any consideration of human rights. If he's really not just in it for the money, he should let people see the movie for free."
The police say there are 88,600 yakuza who belong to 3,300 different groups, with most affiliated in some fashion with one of the three major gangs. The police estimate their annual income at $10 billion, but admit the figure could easily be several times that. Increasingly, they run legitimate businesses, often in real estate, construction and golf course development.
One reason they have been able to expand so fast is because of their links with the police. These ties were a product, in part, of the chaos that followed Japan's defeat in World War II.
 
A Shadow Security Force
 The police realized they simply were not strong enough to control the forces unleashed by the country's devastation, particularly the once-violent Communist movement. The yakuza were used as a shadow police force to throttle leftists. In return, they were left alone, as long as they left ordinary Japanese alone.
"We haven't used our power only for doing bad things," insisted Mr. Takayama. "I myself personally wounded the head of the local Communist Party after the police asked us for help."
But the tacit agreement has meant that traditionally the yakuza are not nearly as violent as the Mafia and have a record of killing fewer people.
Today, Japan is concerned less with Communists than with economic growth. And so, too, the yakuza have evolved, slipping from the fringes to the mainstream of Japanese business and political life.
 
Ills, Social and Economic
 "At one time the gangsters represented a social disease," said Seiji Iishiba, a lawyer who once headed the organized-crime unit of the Tokyo Metropolitan Police, and the author of the book that was the basis for Mr. Itami's movie. "But now it's an economic disease. In the high-growth era, the gangs grew at the same pace as the economy by targeting not individuals, but businesses. They are part of civil society."
Hiroshi Ishizuki, director of the anti-mob division of the National Police Agency, said, "Looking at all the scandals we've had, people were becoming worried that if they allowed the yakuza to continue any further, the entire legitimate society would be swallowed up by them."
Some legal experts are calling for even tougher measures that would give the police the ability to confiscate the huge assets the yakuza have accumulated, a more important instrument of the gangsters' power these days than knives and guns. That, however, has raised the question of whether the Government really has the stomach to confront the depth of yakuza influence.
"A tougher law would touch the core of the Japanese economy," warned Setsuo Miyazawa, a professor of criminology at Kobe University.
In business, organized crime ties go to the top of some major corporations. Last year All Nippon Airways, Japan's second-largest airline, confirmed reports that its incoming and departing chairmen had accepted an invitation to an expensive dinner with what they knew to be a group of gangsters specializing in corporate extortion.
It has been disclosed that Sagawa Kyubin, one of Japan's largest trucking concerns, provided loans or loan guarantees totaling some $2.5 billion to Susumu Ishii, boss of a major yakuza group until he died last year. He reportedly used this hoard for a series of big investments. Nomura Securities and Nikko Securities lent Mr. Ishii more than $200 million and executed a major stock trading scheme for him.
Mr. Ishii is also reported to have used a series of front companies to make several millions of dollars in investments in the United States several years ago.
What most shocked people here is that his group apparently succeeded in hiring Prescott Bush, brother of President Bush, as a consultant. Mr. Bush has denied he was aware of the reputed yakuza connections of his Japanese business partners, and there has been no suggestion he violated any laws.
Under the new anti-mob law, which took effect in March, the police can officially designate yakuza as "boryokudan," or violent organized crime groups. Part of the criteria is the number of members with criminal records, with the percentage set at a little more than 4 percent.
Once a group is so designated, the police can inspect their offices without warrants and ban them from their club houses during gang wars.
Mr. Ishizuki of the police agency responded to criticisms of the potential scope of the law by saying it had been crafted with care so that it could only be used against boryokudan. But some legal experts say it could be abused and applied to other groups, like political organizations.
Some left-wing militants have criminal records because of their involvement in illegal demonstrations or violent resistance to Government policies. There is concern that if the police arrested and charged more of these political campaigners, their groups could then be designated boryokudan under the law and harassed.
 
Law Is Faulted
 Mr. Iishiba said the law's two crucial shortcomings are that it does not permit the police to confiscate ill-gotten gains from the gangs, and that it does not include a witness protection program. Yakuza intimidation of potential witnesses works, he said, because the police are so ineffective. For instance, the police had said they were providing Mr. Itami with special protection before his assault.
"The new law is aimed at the lower-level people," said Professor Miyazawa. "It doesn't affect the most senior people in the organizations, who have control over these huge amounts of money. That's a big weakness."

A1); Juzo Itami, a film director, was attacked by three men last month after his film about fending off the Japanese mob opened. (Associated Press) (pg. A7)

LENGTH: 1375 words

HEADLINE: NORTH KOREA PLAN ON FUELING A-BOMB MAY BE CONFIRMED

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
Administration officials say that the first experts to conduct a detailed survey of North Korea's nuclear installations have confirmed that the country has been building a large plutonium-reprocessing plant, but that the inspectors have so far found no evidence that enough nuclear material has been produced to make an atomic bomb.
The preliminary findings, expected to be announced in Vienna at a meeting of the International Atomic Energy Agency that begins on Monday, cast doubt on the Central Intelligence Agency's worst-case estimates that the hard-line Communist Government could become a nuclear power within a few months to a year. 
 But some United States military and intelligence officials, deeply suspicious of North Korea's sudden willingness to allow inspectors into its most secret installations, say there is circumstantial evidence to suggest that another "pilot plant" for extracting plutonium has been hidden underground or in the mountains.
 
Insists on Alternatives
 A detailed report circulated before the Vienna meeting by Hans Blix, the director general of the atomic energy agency, says senior North Korean officials told him they would abandon their reprocessing effort if Japan, South Korea or Western nations would assure a supply of nuclear fuel and technology that would allow North Korea to build civilian nuclear power plants.
The report, which had a limited distribution but is not classified, is based on Mr. Blix's trip to Pyongyang in May to make arrangements for the first visits by the expert inspectors.
United States officials say that North Korea's offer amounts to a virtual reversal of the nation's earlier vociferous contention that it is not building a major reprocessing plant, which would allow it to convert nuclear waste into bomb-grade material. Under an agreement with South Korea reached late last year, both countries agreed never to build reprocessing plants.
 
'The Pressure Is Working'
 "They are moving toward an admission that they have had a bomb project under way, but they are trying to save face," said a senior Defense Department official deeply involved in monitoring the North Korean effort. "It tells you that the pressure is working."
North Korea's nuclear program has been a source of growing concern to the United States. Especially worrisome is the nuclear complex at Yongbyon, about 60 miles north of Pyongyang. Suspicions that North Korea is trying to develop atomic weapons have centered on the vast installation, which includes several nuclear reactors and buildings that military experts say are part of a weapons program.
Although there is general agreement among United States experts that Yongbyon houses a reprocessing plant, an essential element for making bomb fuel, there is still considerable disagreement over North Korea's intentions and how far the project has come. Officials here say many more inspections are needed before the guesswork is removed from the analysis.
Given the extremely closed nature of North Korean society, United States officials say that apart from satellite images, until now very little intelligence has been available on the true scope of the North Korean nuclear effort. The experts' confirmation of the reprocessing project was based on inspection of the Yongbyon complex.
 
Alternative Supplies
 United States officials, trying to create incentives for President Kim Il Sung of North Korea to abandon the suspected bomb project, say they have not dismissed the reported offer to abandon the reprocessing project. But if North Korea received any technology for its nuclear-energy program, it would likely come either from Seoul or Tokyo, and only in exchange for regular inspections of all nuclear installations.
North Korea's surprise offer to halt its program is further evidence that Mr. Kim's Government, out of money and suddenly without help from its Chinese and Soviet allies, is beginning to abandon its philosophy of juche, or self-reliance.
Japan, South Korea and the United States have ruled out any large-scale trade or economic aid until North Korea's suspected bomb program is halted and Pyongyang agrees to extensive inspections.
"We don't want to play by the rules we did in Iraq before the gulf war," an intelligence official involved in assessing the North Korean program said this week, referring to how Iraqi officials kept their nuclear program out of view of inspectors. "The North Koreans have looked at what Iraq did, and I am sure they are convinced they can do it better."
 
Is There Fuel Enough?
 One of the mysteries surrounding the North Korean program is whether its nuclear power plants have created enough waste fuel for a weapons project. According to United States officials, North Korea turned over to the international agency this month detailed records of the plants.
After several months of study, the agency's experts will probably be able to estimate how much plutonium was in waste fuel created by the plants. If that does not accord with the waste they find in North Korea, it will be an indication that some of the spent fuel has been diverted.
The international agency's first full inspection of North Korea's installations ended last week, and the agency has said nothing publicly about its findings. But United States officials say the team visited only the sites that North Korea had declared part of its nuclear program.
The visit included Yongbyon, which Mr. Blix also briefly toured in May. Soon after the visit he said the site would be termed a reprocessing plant in the West "if it were in operation and complete."
Mr. Blix, however, is not a technical expert, so the United States was awaiting the report of the team that has just emerged from North Korea. The inspectors reportedly found the Yongbyon complex empty, save for equipment for some small experiments.
"It was even less complete than Blix had thought," said a United States official with close contacts to Mr. Blix's agency.
Some United States and Japanese officials believe that the installation, which North Korean officials call a "radiochemical" or "radiological" laboratory, was opened to inspection because the country's efforts to reprocess nuclear waste on a large scale have failed. According to that interpretation, Mr. Kim's Government has run out of money to make further attempts to fabricate bomb fuel, and has decided to use site inspections as a bargaining chip to get Western economic aid.
But officials in the Defense Department and the intelligence agencies, who have taken a considerably more alarmed view of the project, say the empty building is simply another piece of evidence that the nuclear effort has been moved elsewhere.
 
Going From Little to Big
 In his report, Mr. Blix himself raises that possibility, expressing doubt that North Korea would move directly from small-scale experiments to a huge, risky reprocessing installation to produce plutonium in volume.
"The timetable of the operations and the industrial logic seemed to suggest that a small pilot plant should have preceded the 'radiological laboratory,' " he wrote. "The jump from a modest radiochemistry experiment laboratory" to a full reprocessing plant, he added, "is hard to understand for anyone whose thinking is formed by international experience." But he added that "the existence of any such pilot plant was categorically denied" by North Korea.
Given North Korea's extensive experience at building deep tunnels -- many have been discovered underneath the heavily mined demilitarized zone between North and South Korea -- few doubt that such an installation could be easily hidden.
Although Washington has said explicitly that the North Koreans are well along the path toward nuclear weapons, Mr. Blix and his staff have been far more circumspect. In his report this week, Mr. Blix is expected to simply describe the installations the inspectors have seen and not draw any conclusion about North Korea's intentions.
According to United States officials, the inspectors, who left North Korea on June 6, placed seals on some nuclear supplies and installed surveillance equipment in an effort to insure that no materials they saw are diverted to other uses.

HEADLINE: TOWARD THE WASHINGTON SUMMIT;
Yeltsin, Due in U.S. Today, Is Still Complex and Elusive

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 14

 BODY:
It is a year now since Boris N. Yeltsin became the first elected President of Russia, and the reviews are as diverse as the extraordinary chain of events that transformed him from the maverick leader of a Soviet republic to the master of the Kremlin.
Though he travels widely and gives frequent interviews, the burly, 61-year-old President remains a complex and elusive figure. He is still enormously popular at home, but abroad his stiff and formal demeanor have denied him the celebrity status enjoyed by his archrival, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
 
In Wake of Gorbachev
 That contrast is certain to hang over Mr. Yeltsin's visit to the United States starting Monday, which comes in the wake of Mr. Gorbachev's successful voyage. The trip is Mr. Yeltsin's second to the United States as Russia's President and his first full-dress summit meeting, and he will have the rare honor of addressing a joint meeting of Congress. 
 His immediate intent will be to convince a skeptical Washington of the value of backing his reforms, and to reach an arms accord. But the greater goal Mr. Yeltsin has set himself is to establish that he and a sovereign Russia are the true successors to the mantle of a great power, and therefore to a special relationship with the United States.
However hard he tries, Americans are likely to remain divided over the man who has been cast by history to attempt the formidable task of guiding a battered and bankrupt nation to democracy and a free market.
His own compatriots are hardly of one mind about him. Political commentators speak of three identifiable Yeltsins: the Communist apparatchik from Sverdlovsk, the politician who became the gadfly of perestroika, and the radical reformer who has made it his goal to wrench Russia on the way to democracy and a free market.
All three are critical to Mr. Yeltsin's unusual appeal and force. It was the fact that he rose through the ranks that gave strength to his opposition stance and credibility to his calls for reform.
Much of Mr. Yeltsin's authority still derives from his path to power -- his fall from Communist grace in 1987, his defiant return through democratic elections and his open opposition to Mr. Gorbachev, his election as Russia's President and his triumphant resistance to the August putsch from atop a tank.
 
Democracy and the Economy
 But it is by their deeds, and not their legends, that politicians are ultimately judged, and for Mr. Yeltsin the immediate yardstick is his effort to guide Russia toward a market economy and democracy.
He is universally respected for showing the courage to begin the painful transition that had been promised from the outset of perestroika, but always postponed. But the program designed by his chief economist, First Deputy Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar, is assailed by the right for hurting the poor, by the left for falling short of the mark, and by the West for wavering.
 
Skeptics Cite Economic Failures
 Skeptics argue that the sum total of the reform so far has been to free prices and to withhold billions in salaries and internal transactions, and that the Government has failed to protect the needy, to begin any significant privatization or to free the price of oil, a step on which the International Monetary Fund places particular emphasis.
"Let's be fair," wrote Leonid Skoptsov in the newspaper Nezavisimaya Gazeta. "All the conclusions about how progressive and reformist the Gaidar team is are made on the exclusive basis of written and spoken declarations by members of the team about how progressive and reformist they are."
The International Monetary Fund, for its part, is delaying an agreement worth $24 billion to Mr. Yeltsin because of his reluctance to free the price of oil.
But his defenders point out that when Mr. Yeltsin was elected a year ago, Russia was still a part of the Soviet Union with an economy and foreign policy that were controlled largely by the Soviet Government. It was only last fall that his Government began shaping its own economic program, and it was only in January -- when the Soviet state and the economy lay in ruins -- that the reforms were started.
 
Sources of Resistance
 These, furthermore, have come up against resistance from threatened industries and from Parliament, which retains a strong contingent of Communists and has so far blocked moves toward private property.
In an interview last week, Mr. Yeltsin said of the reforms: "For seven years, there was only talk on this issue, but nobody could dare take unpopular measures because this was bound to be followed by a drop in the popularity rating of the President. We launched economic reforms Jan. 2 in conditions of deep economic crisis. Nonetheless we dared do this. Nobody promised that the reforms would give serious results as early as May or June; this is not serious."
The very fact that a nation reared under a paternalistic dictatorship has swallowed the huge price increases without major social disruption, as many had feared, is viewed by many as a success in itself.
 
Authoritarianism Is Criticized
 On the political front, Mr. Yeltsin has been praised for rejecting the repressive props of the Communist Government, the all-controlling party and the political police, and for introducing the first rudiments of lawful government. But he is criticized for adopting authoritarian methods and for allowing the malignancies of the past to fester on -- the corruption, the privileges, the bloated bureaucracy.
Most of the senior officials around Mr. Yeltsin are former members of the Communist Party, including some who were high-ranking officials. The huge government bureaucracy is still largely drawn from the former apparat, and Mr. Yeltsin's subordinates have shown little restraint in parceling out the country houses, resorts and cars of the old regime. Few if any of the liberal democrats who rallied behind Mr. Yeltsin have found their way onto his team.
There are those who argue -- as Mr. Yeltsin's former press secretary, Pavel Voshchanov, does in a bitter article in the current Komsomolskaya Pravda -- that nothing has really changed.
"Our yearning to present last August as a victory of democracy is, alas, only self-delusion," Mr. Voshchanov wrote, scanning the cast of former apparatchiks who have stayed in place. "For the greater part, Communists were defeated by the same Communists, only ones who cast off the external attributes of their party. The criminal party is gone, but the criminal state it created remains."
It is true that Mr. Yeltsin and his Government have not moved quickly to reduce the K.G.B. or the military, which remain formidable and threatening. Yet there is no evidence that Mr. Yeltsin has treated these structures as anything but an inherited burden, which will take time to dismantle.
And if former Communists prevail in the administration, that is because the overwhelming majority of managers, experts and officials in the past had no choice but to join the party, whatever their private tenets.
Answering some of the more frequent criticisms of Mr. Yeltsin, Vitaly Tretyakov, editor of the paper Nezavisimaya Gazeta, argued recently that Mr. Yeltsin was responsible neither for the collapse of the Soviet Union, nor for the fact that the structures, patterns and psychology formed over 70 years cannot be eradicated in one day. "One must take into account that for me, as for a majority of the residents of the former Soviet Union, 'U.S.S.R.' is not uniquely a dirty word," he said.
 
Fear Is Gone; Criticism Is Possible
 And however large or small the changes from the past, a critical difference is that the fear and the obsessive secrecy, the mandatory double-think and phony triumphalism are gone. The credit does not go to Mr. Yeltsin alone, but if he is the brunt of considerable criticism, one reason is simply that such criticism has become possible.
A year in command has inevitably eroded some of Mr. Yeltsin's luster. The liberal urban intelligentsia, never entirely at ease with the peasant's son from the Ural Mountains, has become more openly disdainful of his stiff demeanor and his alleged inclination for the occasional tipple. One-time allies like Vice President Aleksandr Rutskoi and the Speaker of Parliament, Ruslan Khasbulatov, have formed rival political camps.
Abroad, Mr. Yeltsin has won respect for his swift assumption of the Soviet Union's responsibilities, including its nuclear arsenal, and for pursuing Mr. Gorbachev's foreign policy of cooperation with the West. Yet he has never come close to Mr. Gorbachev's magic, and his missions abroad have remained stiff and formal.
That is especially strange given that at home the Russian President has achieved a popularity deeper than anything Mr. Gorbachev ever attracted.
The contrast is the subject of considerable discussion, especially in the context of the open rivalry between the two men. To a foreigner, Mr. Gorbachev may seem more polished and friendly. To a Russian, Mr. Yeltsin is terse and candid where Mr. Gorbachev was long-winded and pedantic; Mr. Yeltsin is independent where Mr. Gorbachev sought consensus.
 
His Popularity A Strong Force
 Whatever the reasons, public opinion polls have tracked popular support for Mr. Yeltsin even through the throes of political upheaval and soaring prices. He may never match the 91 percent approval he had after his resistance to the coup in August, but a full two-thirds of the Russians polled say they still want him to carry on, against 17 percent who want him out.
For good or for bad, Mr. Yeltsin's personal popularity has probably been the strongest single force behind the reforms of the last year. One fact rarely appreciated by the West is that there is no strong constituency for economic reform -- not workers or peasants, who became accustomed to earning little and working even less; not managers, who were taught to meet targets, not to compete; not entrepreneurs, who have gotten fat speculating on shortages; not the military or the bureaucracy, and not even the intelligentsia, which always thought itself above commercial considerations.
 
Favorable Assessments
 It is inevitable in this context that Mr. Yeltsin has made compromises and adjustments, that he has come under criticism and attack. But in the welter of commentaries marking Mr. Yeltsin's first year as President, the predominant conclusion was that he had done well, even surprisingly well.
"Politics is the art of the possible, and the achievement of Yeltsin is that he wants to carry out reforms precisely in this country, accepting Russia as she is: with a drunk and hungry proletariat, with bribe-taking bureaucrats, with the eternal habit of the whip, with an intelligentsia in opposition to the Lord Himself," Vadim Poegli wrote in the paper Moskovsky Komsomolets."

HEADLINE: TOWARD THE WASHINGTON SUMMIT;
Arms and Aid the Main Topics at Bush-Yeltsin Talks

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
When President Boris N. Yeltsin and President Bush meet on Tuesday, they will seek to cement Washington's budding friendship with the new Russian nation in two ways: through arms control and by bolstering Russia's economic reforms.
Both efforts are needed, Administration officials say, because if Russia's painful transition to a Western-style market economy fails, a fledgling democracy could be snuffed out and a hostile dictator could come to power. 
 Seeking foreign policy gains in a difficult election year, Mr. Bush hopes to sign a far-reaching agreement with Mr. Yeltsin that would make sharp cuts in the two nations' stocks of nuclear warheads.
For his part, Mr. Yeltsin hopes to use his first full-blown summit meeting with Mr. Bush to usher in a new era in relations between the two cold-war adversaries. Hungry for Western aid, the Russian President is seeking to establish regular, even warm, relations. But he is in a delicate position because he does not want to concede too much in the arms talks, lest Russian hard-liners skewer him for knuckling under to Washington.
 
Signs of Compromise
 American and Russian officials said Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Russian Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev had showed some willingness in talks on Friday in London to retreat from long-held positions that have blocked an agreement.
The United States agreed, those officials said, to give up its demand to eliminate all of Russia's land-based, multiple-warhead missiles, which American officials contend would present the greatest threat in any nuclear confrontation. And the Russians, they said, agreed to large cuts in these missiles, including the SS-18, which has a range of about 7,000 miles.
While the Bush Administration is eager to engage Russia as a friend through the arms pact and through plans to cooperate in space, it had also hoped to deliver a multibillion-dollar aid package in time for Mr. Yeltsin's visit. Administration officials admit to a little embarrassment over their failure to push the package through Congress, which is reluctant to approve billions of dollars in foreign aid in an election year when funds are short for domestic programs.
 Mr. Yeltsin is not only meeting with President Bush, on Tuesday and Wednesday, but will also address a joint meeting of Congress. Administration officials say they hope Mr. Yeltsin's visit and the address on Wednesday will spur Congress to finally approve Washington's part of a $24 billion aid package that the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations pledged to Russia in April.
Like Mr. Yeltsin, Mr. Bush has a difficult balance to strike in their meeting. If Mr. Bush pushes Mr. Yeltsin too hard on arms control or economic reform it could weaken the Russian President at home, undercutting their mutual goal of insuring that Russia's new democracy survives and remains friendly. Last week Mr. Yeltsin accused the United States of trying to take advantage of an economically weakened Russia in the arms talks.
Mr. Yeltsin and his delegation are expected to sign about a dozen accords, including agreements to establish an early warning center on ballistic missiles, to cooperate in the rescue of each other's astronauts and to create a Russian-American Business Council to promote investment in Russia. The two sides will also discuss how to use $400 million earmarked by Congress for dismantling Russian warheads.
Administration officials say the economic reforms that Mr. Yeltsin has undertaken since January, which have included removing most price controls, slashing the budget deficit, and laying the groundwork for large-scale privatization, are tough and courageous. But they worry that in recent weeks his Government has retreated somewhat from its plan for rapid change.
Plans to print more money, extend more credit to inefficient enterprises and delay the freeing of oil prices could slow down efforts to stabilize Russia's teetering economy, they say. They also worry that Mr. Yeltsin has added some conservatives from the military-industrial complex to his Cabinet.
 
Possible Delay in Aid
 Mr. Yeltsin's Government has long said it hopes to sign a pivotal agreement with the International Monetary Fund by July 1, a move that would unblock billions of dollars in planned aid for Russia. But several Administration and monetary fund officials said some snags in Russia's reform program could delay that agreement for a month or two.
"In terms of the basic course of reform, things continue to move favorably and very rapidly," said Jeffrey Sachs, a Harvard economics professor who is advising Russia on the reforms. "They started with a collapsing economy, huge budget deficit, pent-up inflationary pressures, and intense shortages, and while they have made a lot of progress, there are still some major issues that have to be resolved."
Russian officials say that signing an accord with the monetary fund is crucial because more than half of the $24 billion aid package will not begin flowing until such an agreement is in force. Although Russia has already received about $4 billion from the package, the accord would open the door to about $4 billion in loans from the I.M.F., World Bank and other institutions, a $6 billion fund to stabilize the ruble, and $2.5 billion in deferral of debt payments.
Mr. Yeltsin's economic reforms are aggravating the crisis that was bequeathed to him by seven decades of Communist rule. Industrial output is expected to plunge by 24 percent this year and farm output by 12 percent, while prices are expected to soar more than tenfold.
 
I.M.F. Seeks Assurances
 Officials on both sides of the negotiations said that fund officials want answers in several areas before reaching an agreement. Because the fund is planning a ruble stabilization fund, it wants Moscow to explain how it intends to coordinate monetary policy with the other former Soviet republics that plan to continue using the ruble.
 The fund wants Moscow to agree to bring its budget deficit down, and will ask the Russians how soon they will remove price controls on oil and how big a tax they will place on oil, which would also narrow the deficit.
 "We're very concerned that the fiscal deficit has been moving in the wrong direction, that monetary discipline has been insufficient and that the inflation rate continues to be way too high," a senior Administration official said. "The most important thing is to get a high-quality program in place. That's more important than the exact timing."
