HEADLINE: Symbol of Cuba Sparking Battle In a Florida City

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KEY WEST, Fla., June 12

 BODY:
Amid the bars, T-shirt emporiums, souvenir stands and pornography shops that line Duval Street, the main downtown street of this cluttered resort town, the San Carlos Patriotic and Educational Institute easily stands apart. Dignified, elegant and glowing from a just-completed $3 million restoration, the building is a monument to Key West's past, one of the few still standing.
Founded in 1871 by Cuban tobacco workers in Key West's cigar factories who had helped establish the city, the San Carlos Institute is to Cubans what Independence Hall is to Americans. It was from the veranda of the institute 100 years ago that an exiled Jose Marti began the Cuban revolution that led to the end of Spanish rule and insured Key West a place of honor in the history textbooks read by generations of Cuban schoolchildren. Today it sponsors concerts, lectures and exhibitions of Cuban art that honor figures like Carlos Manuel de Cespedes, who led a revolt in 1868 that nearly brought independence from Spain. The institute is also planning to open a library and to offer classes in English, Spanish and history. 
 "To the Cuban people, this is the most sacred place outside Cuba, a place that triggers deep emotions because it is the cradle of Cuban independence," said Rafael A. Penalver Jr., a Miami lawyer who is president of the institute and led the eight-year effort to restore the building.
Barely six months after reopening, however, the institute finds itself fighting the city government as it fought the Spanish Government a century ago. The City of Key West, arguing that the San Carlos Institute is not a historical and cultural center but just another commercial enterprise, is demanding $35,194 in fees. It has threatened to close the institute if the bill is not paid after the city commission's vote on an appeal of the fee, which is scheduled for Tuesday.
 
Cubans See Power Struggle
 The city authorities say their decision is based on an ordinance that requires new buildings to pay a onetime fee to help provide the expanded sewer, electrical and water systems required by Key West's recent growth. But Mr. Penalver says he thinks the city's demand is a smoke screen.
"There are some power groups in Key West that would like the San Carlos to be a shopping center, a theater or anything else that would serve the economic interests of their hotels and businesses," he said. "It is a power structure that has excluded Cubans, and its members see the San Carlos as an important element in this city that they do not yet control."
Supporters of the institute say the $35,000 would be difficult to raise after having asked donors for the $3 million for the renovation, and they say the fee is discriminatory. Key West has provided fee exemptions to several other buildings of historical significance that are run by not-for-profit organizations.
"They've already exempted the old city hall, the lighthouse, the wrecker's museum and a church, so why not us?" asked Jose Garrido, the owner of a marine electronic business who is president of the local Rotary Club.
But three of Key West's five commissioners have expressed opposition to granting the institute such a waiver, complaining that the building is run by Mr. Penalver and other Cuban Americans from Miami, as well as citing the city's need for the fees.
 
Court Battle With City
 To Cuban-Americans here, the dispute brings back unpleasant memories of the mid-1980's, when the building lay in ruins and the Historic Key West Preservation Board, a government body, became its custodian and tried to lease it to a company that planned to convert it into a restaurant and theater. Local Cubans fought the action in the courts and, when a local judge ruled in favor of developers, headed off the project with a lobbying effort that won the support of the Governor and State Legislature.
The Mayor of Key West, Dennis Wardlow, said through his secretary that he would not comment on the dispute about the fees. But other city officials denied that they were acting on behalf of any commercial interests.
"There's no merit to that premise whatsoever," said the City Manager, Felix Cooper, arguing that the city merely wanted to assure that "a large facility built for public use and that charges money" paid its fair share. He did say that if the San Carlos did not pay it would be operating illegally, and there was "a possibility the city would levy a fine on the property" and even sell it at auction if the fine was not paid.
The city's refusal to recognize the San Carlos institute as a cultural center has irritated the Cubans here, who account for about 20 percent of Key West's permanent population of 25,000. Cuban-American leaders recall that the city refused to contribute to the restoration effort.
 
'Now It Is a Palace'
 "When the situation was chaotic, nobody wanted it and we could get no help," said Dr. Jose Bofill, a doctor who is a former president of the institute. "For years, it was a disaster, a place where birds roosted and drug addicts slept. Now it is a palace, a symbol of the Cuban people, and the same people who wouldn't help, the people to whom it meant nothing, want to take it away from us."
From its earliest days, the San Carlos Institute has been the focus of the intellectual and cultural life of the Cubans who helped found Key West. In the late 19th century, when segregation prevailed elsewhere in Florida, the institute was one of the only places where white, black and Hispanic children attended classes together, and that sense of egalitarianism led citizens of Key West to rebuild the center after it was destroyed by a fire in 1886 and a hurricane in 1919.
After Cuba became independent in 1902, the government in Havana supplied teachers and money to the institute, eventually becoming part owner of the building and putting a consulate and tourist office in it. The Cuban Government has never relinquished its claim to the institute and has fought efforts to seize the building as compensation for American holdings in Cuba that were nationalized when Fidel Castro came to power.
"Technically, it's still Cuban soil," Mr. Garrido said. "It's the only piece of Cuba that's free, which makes it even more of a shrine to us."

HEADLINE: Japan Businesses Lose Confidence in Economy

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 14

 BODY:
Business confidence in Japan has rapidly deteriorated in the last three months and has reached the lowest level in five years, the Bank of Japan reported Friday.
Economists said the report, reflecting a survey of business sentiment, indicated that a rebound of Japan's sagging economy, which optimists had expected to begin this summer, would be delayed until later this year or perhaps next year. 
 The survey results were worse than expected, said Robert Alan Feldman, director of economic research for Salomon Brothers in Tokyo. "I think it does indicate that recovery will be delayed," he said.
Officials of Japan's central bank said that they were not particularly uncomfortable with the new numbers and noted that the results had some hopeful signs. Companies in the survey, for instance, generally reported that they expected business to improve in the fall.
 
Sharper Trade Tensions Seen
 A deepening Japanese economic slump could further inflame trade tensions with the United States and Japan's other trading partners. With its economy weak, Japan's imports are slowing, causing its trade surplus to bulge. And if consumption remains weak in their home market, Japanese companies will be tempted to try to export more goods.
The report released by the Bank of Japan was the Tankan, a quarterly survey of businesses here.
The most closely watched number from the survey, an index reflecting the sentiment of leading manufacturers, dropped to minus 24 in May from minus 5 in February. The new figure means that the number of businesses saying that business conditions are unfavorable exceeded the number saying conditions are favorable by 24 percent.
 
More Public Spending Sought
 The drop in the business confidence index is one of the sharpest single- quarter drops ever experienced, reflecting how quickly the mood here has swung. And the new level is the lowest since minus 27 was recorded early in 1987, when Japanese businesses were trying to cope with a sharp rise in the yen.
Analysts said the survey results could make it more likely that the Japanese Government would try to stimulate the economy with more public spending, by approving a supplemental budget of several trillion yen for this fiscal year. The United States has been pushing for such supplemental public spending to spur the world economy and increase Japan's imports.
Some speculation also arose that the Bank of Japan would be moved to stimulate the economy by cutting the discount rate, now 3.75 percent. But analysts said the central bank was unlikely to consider such action until it sees the supplemental budget.
Some analysts, however, said the survey results showed that Japan's economy was still suffering from an excess of inventories, which will force manufacturers to reduce production rates for months to come. "The inventory adjustment problems are more difficult than the Japanese companies anticipated," said Noboru Kawai, the economist for Morgan Stanley Japan.
 
Consumers Aren't Spending
 Consumer spending is also weak, in part because overtime has been reduced and some workers have been laid off, said Yoshihisa Kitai, senior economist for the Long Term Credit Bank of Japan. He said the Bank of Japan's survey found a sharp drop in confidence among retailers.
"Maybe the Japanese economy has not reached its bottom," said Mr. Kitai, who thinks, however, that recovery will be delayed only until the fall.
Of course, Japan's slump is only by comparison with its past performance. Most analysts expect the economy to grow by 1.5 percent to 2.5 percent this fiscal year, about half of what Japan would consider sufficient but well above what other nations manage in a recession.
Moreover, the unemployment rate here is only about 2 percent. The latest survey does show, however, that fewer businesses than before now believe there is a labor shortage.
One result of the weak economy is a bulging trade surplus. The Finance Ministry reported on Thursday that Japan's trade surplus in May jumped 88.9 percent over the figure for May 1991, reaching $7.87 billion. The surplus with the United States shot up 51 percent to $2.9 billion.

HEADLINE: Congress Steps Up Work on Taxes

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
Congress and the Bush Administration are again dishing up a variety of proposals to change the tax laws, including some tax increases that have been on the back burner since the President vetoed a comprehensive tax bill in March.
Taking up the provisions a few at a time, as if they were so many tapas or dim sum, the Government is assembling a smorgasbord of revenues -- a menu without the kind of politically unpalatable main course, like a cut in capital gains taxes, or income tax breaks aimed at the middle class, that doomed the earlier bill. 
 In recent weeks, tax legislation has been picking up momentum, and experts predict that Congress will produce at least one bill, and probably more than one, that will raise money to pay for social programs even while continuing a handful of important tax breaks. Lawmakers are likely to try to pass such legislation before the Fourth of July recess.
"I intend to move as much as I can before the July 4 recess," said Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, chairman of the Finance Committee, which reviews all tax legislation. Both the House of Representatives and the Senate are actively writing tax bills, often with differing results.
Last week, for example, when the House voted to extend unemployment benefits, lawmakers proposed to pay the cost by putting a $1 million cap on the deduction a corporation can take for an executive's salary. When the Senate Finance Committee later approved its own version of the unemployment bill, it chose to raise the money with less controversial tax increases.
On Tuesday, the same Senate committee will consider legislation to extend a dozen existing tax breaks due to expire at the end of the month. That means the committee will have to propose offsetting tax increases to pay for those costly provisions, which the House has not yet acted on.
Meanwhile, the Administration has given Congress a list of tax measures that the White House said could pay for its proposed program of urban enterprise zones -- a program that relies heavily on tax breaks to draw investment into depressed cities.
Lawmakers are still arguing about where to find the revenue to pay for all these programs, differences that could be magnified by the hard feelings over the failed attempt to write a constitutional amendment calling for a balanced Federal budget. The proposed amendment, strongly favored by the Administration, narrowly failed to gain approval in the House.
Even when it does not balance the overall Federal budget, under the "pay as you go" budget rules enacted in 1990, Congress cannot establish spending programs or enact new tax breaks without adopting offsetting cuts in spending or increases in taxes.
The trick is to put together deals that compensate for the costs of new legislation without a wholesale revision of tax laws.
There are several reasons for Congress to move swiftly. Unemployment benefits will run out early in July if no new law is passed. Twelve tax breaks, each of intense interest to a constituency, are due to expire at the end of June. And by the Fourth of July recess, Congress and the Administration would like to show off an urban initiative that responds to the needs of cities like Los Angeles, charred by rioting in May.
With neither side seeking an all-out brawl over taxes, the debate is centering on provisions that are not merely uncontroversial, but positively soporific: how companies might be allowed to depreciate intangible assets like their customer lists, for example, or whether to require tax withholding on lump-sum pension payments that are not rolled over immediately into individual retirement accounts.
But there are also hot political potatoes to handle -- not only the tax treatment of executive salaries, but also proposed changes in the Social Security law that would allow retirees to earn more income while still collecting retirement benefits and would increase the amount of wages on which workers must pay Social Security taxes.
 
Amount of New Taxes Is Unclear
 Nobody can say yet how much money the new taxes must raise. It depends, for example, on whether the unemployment bill costs $5.8 billion, as the House voted, or about $2.4 billion, as the Administration prefers. And it depends how much is to be spent on enterprise zones and related urban aid.
On June 3, Assistant Treasury Secretary Fred T. Goldberg, who is in charge of the Administration's tax policies, outlined tax changes that he said would raise nearly $10 billion by 1997 -- enough, he said, to pay for the Administration's versions of the urban bill and the unemployment bill, perhaps with some left over to pay for repealing taxes on luxuries like pleasure boats, or for extending the expiring tax breaks.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, has been pushing for a single tax package that would wrap all these provisions together while excluding others from being added on.
Aside from the tax increases earmarked to pay for urban aid and unemployment, the most likely tax bill to be enacted is one that would extend 12 tax breaks that are due to expire. Congress typically extends these provisions only for short periods, to avoid having to provide long-term financing for their costs, which add up to an estimated $21.3 billion from 1992 to 1996.
Among the tax breaks that are facing expiration are a 20 percent corporate tax credit for research and experimentation; a tax credit for investments in low-income housing; a 25 percent deduction for the cost of health insurance premiums paid by self-employed people; an exclusion from taxable income of education benefits paid by employers, and a 10 percent business tax credit for investment in solar and geothermal energy.

HEADLINE: THE EARTH SUMMIT;
What Some Preach in Rio Is Not What They Practice at Home

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
Environmentalists from the global North and South, who may not agree on much else about how to save the world's environment, are united on one contention: When the Earth Summit is over and nations face the task of putting promises to work, the people most likely to make a success of saving the planet will not be found in large international bodies but in small grass-roots organizations caring for their own land.
Whether governments in many developing nations will allow them to assume this role is another matter. In some of the nations whose leaders were most strident in Rio in condemning the industrial world -- among them Malaysia, India and Indonesia -- environmental groups and individual campaigners have been harassed, assaulted and arrested. In Kenya, an environmentalist. Wangari Maathai, was nearly beaten to death by policemen this year. 
 "The third world cannot wrap itself in a green flag and lecture to everybody," said Michael Wright, senior vice president of the World Wildlife Fund, who ran its program linking local development to human needs. "It's a mixed record."
While good working relationships between governments and grass-roots organizations have developed in places as scattered as Zimbabwe, Costa Rica or Bangladesh, leaders of environmental and social-action groups in many other developing countries have drawn official ire by challenging government excuses for environmental failures. They rarely get an international hearing.
 
World Bank's Role Opposed
 These dissident environmentalists say, for example, that poverty is frequently not the main cause of the degradation of forests and waters, or the explanation for overpopulation. They doubt that more money in the hands of their governments will solve environmental problems as long as politicians are not held accountable by the people and corruption erodes enforcement of laws protecting nature. They oppose the global environmental policy role being assumed by the World Bank.
"There continues to be a significant gap between ecological priorities perceived by these environmental and social-action groups and the ecological priorities of governments and global organizations," said Smitu Kothari, who leads protests in India against the dislocations caused by a huge hydroelectric and irrigation project in the Narmada River valley. The project, supported by the World Bank, has drawn criticism from human rights and environmental groups in Japan, the United States and Europe as well as in India.
"The World Bank is one of the most unaccountable institutions on the planet," Mr. Kothari said in an interview. "It doesn't consult local people. Unless local communities really come into their own and are given control, you are not going to be able to save land and recover our ecosystems."
Government pressure on environmentalists has been most intense in the Malaysian state of Sarawak, in northern Borneo, where loggers with political connections are razing tropical rain forests and displacing thousands of indigenous people. Earth torn from hillsides once covered with jungle tumbles into Borneo's powerful rivers, which run brown as chocolate, discharging streams of mud into the turquoise waters of the South China Sea.
Two organizations, Friends of the Earth Malaysia and the World Rain Forest Movement, have been under official scrutiny and criticism for years. Another Malaysian group, the Environmental Protection Society, has been called "a thorn in the flesh of the nation" by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad. In 1987, five environmentalists were imprisoned as "security risks" for opposing a proposed dump for radioactive waste.
Malaysia, now Japan's largest supplier of tropical timber from Southeast Asia, is among those nations most opposed to an international treaty that would monitor forest use.
Even in the Philippines, where President Corazon C. Aquino has encouraged the growth of environmental groups and given local organizations and clans the power to make decisions about the use of their natural resources, journalists who expose links between politicians and concessionaires doing illegal logging or mining get death threats, a Filipino reporter who received such a warning said in an interview from Manila.
In China, rapid desertification, the loss of lakes and rivers and the destruction of forests were catalogued by He Bochuan, a lecturer in philosophy at Sun Yat Sen University in Guangdong, in a book recently translated into English as "China on the Edge: The Crisis of Ecology and Development." He saw official policies at the root of most problems.
"False reporting, ineptitude and bad management are the main causes for the huge discrepancy between the impressive claims and the meager results of China's reforestation campaign," he wrote, explaining why China lags well behind most other nations in protecting or restoring forest cover.
 
A Natural Link
 The book was withdrawn from circulation in China after the suppression of the democracy movement in Tiananmen Square in 1989. The link between environmentalism and political change is a natural one, leaders of the movement say.
"In Eastern Europe it was the environmental groups that first acquired legitimacy as nongovernmental forces and became the focus of opposition," said Lester R. Brown, president of the Worldwatch Institute.
Mr. Wright of the World Wildlife Fund said that environmental action thrived best in a democratic, multiparty setting where popular participation in government is strong.
"It's hard to find an environmentally responsive dictatorship," he said.
Mr. Brown sees a lot of hope in the phenomenal growth over the last few years of nongovernmental organizations in the developing world and their increasing ability to communicate internationally with like-minded people. But he said that these groups needed to expand in size and membership to exert influence on recalcitrant governments.
Nongovernmental organizations "have to broaden their bases to include the stalwarts of the community, otherwise governments like Malaysia's and others' can continue to make life very difficult for environmentalists," he said.
 
Intellectual Leadership
 Mr. Brown said that environmental groups had provided the intellectual leadership worldwide on ecological issues.
"There is not a single national government with a global environmental research organization," he said. "At Rio, we could see the dependence on environment groups for information."
After Rio, said Mr. Wright, the world has to get down to building "intermediate organizations" to serve as links to local environmental groups.
"We've got to get something between the megadonors and the poor woman in the village trying to feed her family," he said.

HEADLINE: Housing Aid Goes Unspent By Poor Cities

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13

 BODY:
While Mayor David N. Dinkins and the City Council were reducing spending in New York City's recent budget crisis, hundreds of millions of dollars earmarked for the city was languishing unspent in Federal accounts.
At the beginning of this year, New York had accumulated more than $674.5 million in a program to modernize and rehabilitate public housing, according to a computer search by the Department of Housing and Urban Development. The city had not even let contracts for $414 million, including $213 million appropriated three or more years ago. 
 The same pattern has developed in Hartford, Trenton, Newark and other financially troubled cities in the New York region and around the country. And the unspent money has become a symbolic centerpiece in the growing debate over the Federal Government's responsibilities toward America's troubled inner cities.
According to an informal H.U.D. review of two major housing and community development programs, there was $7.2 billion in unspent Federal funds through the end of last year, some of which was appropriated as much as 15 years ago. There were additional unspent billions in transportation and environmental protection programs, Federal officials said.
 
Conservative Defense Since Reagan
 Since the Federal Government began retreating from the urban-aid business at the start of the Reagan era, many conservatives have used the issue of unspent money as a defense against charges of abandoning the cities. In the wake of the Los Angeles riots, the argument has only intensified, with Bush Administration officials pointing to the money to defend their reluctance to provide any new infusion of aid, like a $35 billion anti-recession program proposed by a coalition of Mayor Dinkins, municipal leaders and their allies in Congress.
"It's the 'rattling of the tin cup' approach," said Alfred A. DelliBovi, deputy secretary of the Federal housing department. "You always hear that cities need more money. Before mayors call for new spending, they should look at their capacity to spend. There's always a surplus. The No. 1 job for cities is managing it."
While big-city officials and their legislative allies acknowledge the unspent funds, they say that because of recent increases in their rates of spending, the total is far less than claimed by H.U.D. They also draw a radically different lesson. They say the money has not been spent because of a guerrilla war by conservative ideologues in the Federal bureaucracy. The bureaucrats often attach so many burdensome conditions to Congressional appropriations that it becomes impossible to proceed quickly, if at all, city officials complain.
"They feel that if they can't kill a program on the floor of the House or Senate, they'll kill it by regulation," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat and a senior member of the Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs Committee. "Anyone who thinks H.U.D. regulations are ideologically neutral is not living on this planet. Somebody who wants to stop a project has more power than 100 people who want to move ahead."
A result is often a deadlock in which cities lose appropriated money. In congratulating Cesar A. Perales on his appointment as Deputy Mayor in New York, Anna Kondratas, H.U.D.'s assistant secretary for Community Planning and Development, noted earlier this year that the department had withdrawn $5 million from homeless programs because of the city's inability to meet Federal regulatory requirements. And she warned that other planned programs were in danger of losing funds.
 
Local Labyrinths, Too
 New York officials acknowledge local problems that contributed to the accumulation of the unspent money. Even the least controversial projects are often confronted by neighborhood opposition, legal challenges, Byzantine labor rules and mountains of paperwork. They can combine to create a bureaucratic labyrinth and stymie the best-laid plans.
A typical example of how the Federal money goes unspent can be found at Park Place, a 156-unit building at Park Place and Howard Avenue in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.
The Federal housing department received the city's plans to build the project on May 17, 1978. The schedule was approved on July 27, 1979, and almost $14 million was appropriated on Sept. 9, 1980. Construction was to start March 5, 1983.
But problems began almost immediately. The contractor defaulted, leading to foreclosure proceedings. Then there were problems moving 30 tenants. The project needed one extension after another. Seven years after construction was to have begun, the developer still needed more time to complete the drawings.
Construction finally began this spring.
But New York officials argue that the problem of unspent funds was less severe when Washington was not trying to sabotage urban programs.
Felice Michetti, Commissioner of the New York Department of Housing Preservation and Development, recently complained that the Federal agency's rules prevent New York from using $127 million it received this year under Home, the first program in years to provide funds to build low-income housing. In a letter to Mr. Schumer, she noted that Congress had reacted to the recession by waiving rules requiring cities to match Federal grants from the progam. In direct conflict with the intent of Congress, she said, the housing department responded by limiting the Federal grant for Home to 67 percent of the construction costs. In effect, the change required localities to make a 33 percent matching grant.
The Commissioner also complained that the housing agency was insisting on "a very narrow" interpretation of its rules by refusing to finance projects that call for spending more than $57,856 to build or renovate a two-bedroom unit. Since New York real-estate and construction costs are among the highest in the country, she called the Federal rules "too restrictive" to allow the construction of the most basic housing.
"The city blames the Feds, the Feds blame the city," Representative Schumer added. "Both are right."
 
Republican Districts Get More
 Urban officials contend that while officials in the Bush Administration criticize the cities -- with their large share of poor and minority residents -- for inefficiency in using Federal money, there is much less reluctance to finance projects to benefit traditional Republican districts in the suburbs and rural areas. While economic development grants used to be split evenly between urban and rural areas, rural areas received 87 percent of the funds in 1991, city leaders complain. And despite urban plight, the ratio last year improved only slightly, with cities getting about 20 percent and rural areas 80 percent.
While New York has been barraged by new social problems -- including AIDS, crack and homelessness -- Federal budget cuts during the 1980s have cost it a total of $33.7 billion, city officials calculate. That is more than New York's annual budget of $28 billion. Over all, the share of the city budget paid by the Federal Government has shrunk by almost half in the last decade, to 9.3 percent in the 1990 New York fiscal year from 17.9 a decade earlier.
Federal housing officials say their regulations are necessary to make cities cost-conscious, and they say private business is more efficient in using its investment capital. They say that the cities caused their own budget problems by overspending during the 1980's and failing to prepare for the predictable downturn.
The housing officials say their study of spending under the Community Improvement Assistance Program in eight cities found a total of $1.2 billion in accumulated funds. There was $732.7 million in unobligated money -- funds for which no contracts had been let -- including $305.5 million appropriated at least three years ago, a period they use as a standard for efficient management.
 
D'Amato Blames Cities
 In addition to New York, Trenton had $15.2 million in unspent money of which $14.3 million was unobligated; Newark $105.1 million of which $29.5 million was unobligated; Hartford $11.7 million of which $10.2 million was unobligated; Boston $65.9 million of which $25.9 million was unobligated; Philadelphia $255.4 million of which $160.3 million was unobligated, St. Louis $44.9 million of which $36.5 million was unobligated, and San Francisco $47.1 million which $42.0 million was unobligated.
"It's incredible," said Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the Long Island Republican who is making what he sees as expansive New York welfare programs and mismanagement of city resources into a mantra of his campaign for re-election to a third term. "It's unconscionable. It's inexcusable that billions of dollars that should be going into the economy are just sitting there."
New York has taken major steps in recent months to make better use of its Community Improvement money, Federal and city officials say. The city has set a $25 million-a-month spending target, hired more staff and tried to reduce delays by computerizing and contracting out architectural work, among other things. A result has been a rapid increase in the rate at which New York spends the money and, according to city officials, a 50 percent reduction, to $100 million, in the three-year backlog. Mayor Dinkins and other city officials say that New York now can handle, and desperately needs, extra Federal help.
But Federal officials remain unconvinced. They say delays and more delays remain the rule, and note that despite the recession, which has hit the construction trades particularly hard, it took the city more than four years to break ground for two new Federal office towers in Foley Square in lower Manhattan.
Mr. Schumer acknowledges that local problems cause delays in cities like New York. "But it was much quicker with a friendly administration in the White House," he contended. "There's a war mentality now."

HEADLINE: TOWARD THE WASHINGTON SUMMIT;
A Grim Record: Hatred, Starvation, an Execution, More Hatred, Chernobyl

 BODY:

LENIN ORDERS DEPORTATIONS
At the time he wrote this letter in 1922, Lenin was the unquestioned leader of the ruling Communist Party and Stalin was his right-hand man, serving as party Secretary General. The excerpt indicates Lenin's desire to rid the country of any potential political opponents.

 	 	 			July 17, 1922	
Comrade Stalin!
On the matter of deporting Mensheviks, National Socialists, Kadets, etc. from Russia, I would like to ask a few questions, since this operation, which was started before my leave, still has not been completed.
Has the decision been made to "eradicate" all the NS's? Peshekhonov, Myakotin, Gornfeld, Petrishchev, et al.?
As far as I'm concerned, deport them all. [They are] more harmful than any SR [Socialist Revolutionary] -- because [they are] more clever.
Also A. N. Potresov, Izgoyev and all the "Ekonomist" contributors (Ozerov and many, many others). The Mensheviks, Rozanov (a physician, cunning), Vigdorchik, (Migulov or something like that), Liubov Nikolayevna Radchenko and her young daughter (rumor has it they're the vilest enemies of Bolshevism), N. A. Rozhkov (he has to be deported; incorrigible); S. A. Frank (author of "Metodologiya"). The commission supervised by Mantsev, Messing, et al. should present lists and several hundred such ladies and gentlemen must be deported without mercy. Let's purge Russia for a long while!

 	 	 		. . .	 	This must be done at once. Before the end of the SRs' trial, no later. Arrest a few hundred and without a declaration of motives -- get out, ladies and gentlemen! . . .
With a communist greeting, -- LENIN
 
WARNING ABOUT FAMINE IN SIBERIA
A confidential report in April 1932 illustrated the devastating effects of farm collectivization in Siberia. At the time, the Soviet authorities went to great lengths to keep the widespread famine secret from the outside world. The following is from a physician's report sent to Grigory K. Ordzhonikidze, a confidant of Stalin.
Filipp Borodin has earned 650 work-days, has a wife and 5 children ranging from one and a half to nine years of age. The wife lies ill on the oven, 3 children sit on the oven; they are as pale as wax with swollen faces. . . . Filipp Borodin himself sits on a bench and continuously smokes cigarettes made of repulsively pungent tobacco, cries like a babe, asks death for his children.
In tears he asks Comrade Sukhanov: "Give us at least one kilo of potatoes, give us at least one liter of milk, after all, I worked all summer and even now I work unceasingly. . . . According to the statement by Comrade Sukhanov and the brigadier of the kolkhoz "Red Partisan," Borodin was a noncomplaining worker.
Borodin does not even have food substitutes for nourishment; two days ago he and his family ate two sickly piglets thrown out of the common farmyard. In the Borodin home there is unbelievable filth, dampness, and stench, mixed with the smell of tobacco. Borodin swears at the children: "The devils don't die. I wish I didn't have to look at you!" Having objectively investigated the condition of Borodin himself, I ascertain that he (Borodin) is starting to slip into psychosis due to starvation, which can lead to his eating his own children. . . .
 
PUB-DATE: March 25, 1932
Regional Health Inspector
Dr. KISELEV
 
BUKHARIN PROCLAIMS INNOCENCE
Nikolai V. Bukharin, a leading Bolshevik theorist and a friend as well as a frequent intellectual opponent of Lenin, led the so-called "right opposition" to Stalin in 1928-29 and was perhaps the most prominent victim of his purges. Here is his protestation of innocence in a February 1937 letter to Soviet leaders just before his arrest, and his plea for mercy after his conviction in a show trial on March 13, 1938, the presumed day of his execution.

 	 	 			February 20, 1937	
Dear Comrades!
I have sent to the Plenum of the Central Committee a two-part "Deposition" of nearly 100 pages, responding to the cloud of slander contained in the testimony. . . .
As a result of all this, I am a nervous wreck. The death of Sergo [Ordzhonikidze], whom I loved as deeply as a member of my family, was the final blow. The position in which this slander has put me, when I can neither rejoice together with my Party comrades, together with the whole country (Pushkin Days), nor grieve and mourn over the body of Sergo is an insufferable position and I cannot endure it any more.
I swear to you once again on the last breath of Ilich [Lenin], who died in my arms; on my deep love for Sergo, and on all that I hold sacred that associating me with all these acts of terrorism, sabotage, Trotskyite pacts, etc. is unheard-of base slander. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	In this most extraordinary situation, from tomorrow I will go on a full hunger strike until the charges of treason, sabotage and terrorism against me are removed. I will not live with these accusations. . . .
 
Farewell.
Be victorious.
Yours,
N. BUKHARIN
 
A Plea for Mercy
I beg the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet of the U.S.S.R. for mercy. I consider the verdict of the court to be just punishment for my most grave transgressions against the socialist motherland, its people, party, and government. There is not a single word of protest in my soul. I should be shot ten times for my crimes. . . .
If I allow myself to petition the highest government organ in our land, before which I appear on my knees, it is only because I believe that through a pardon I can be of value to my country; I do not say -- and I am not able to say -- that I can expiate my guilt; the crimes I committed are so monstrous, so enormous, that I cannot atone for the guilt -- no matter what I may do for the rest of my life. But I assure the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet that my stay of more than a year in prison has forced me to do a great deal of thinking and to reconsider much from my criminal past. . . .
Step by step, I have re-examined my past life. The former Bukharin has already died; he no longer lives on this earth. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	Let a new, second Bukharin grow -- let him even be [called] Petrov -- this new man will be the complete antithesis of the one who has died. He has already been born -- give him the opportunity of any kind of work at all. . . . I shall strive to prove to you, with every fiber of my being, that this gesture of proletarian generosity was justified.
 
Nikolai Bukharin.
Moscow, March 13, 1938.
Internal N.K.V.D. prison.
 
ANDROPOV NAMES HIS ENEMIES
A memorandum written by the head of the K.G.B., Yuri V. Andropov, on Nov. 15, 1976, gives details on the activities of leading dissidents and steps taken against them. Mr. Andropov later succeeded Leonid I. Brezhnev as Soviet leader, holding power from 1982 until his death in February 1984. 
In recent years our adversary's special services and propaganda bureaus have attempted to give the impression that a so-called "internal opposition" exists in the U.S.S.R., rendering support to those who inspire antisocial and anti-Soviet activities and promote the banding together of participants in a variety of anti-Soviet activities.
Accordingly, in 1969 antisocial elements headed by Yakir and Krasin founded an "initiative group" in order to form an organization made up of participants of the so-called "movement for democratization."
In 1970, in order to activate the antisocial efforts of individuals with hostile leanings, Chalidze established the so-called "Committee for the Protection of Human Rights" which, in addition to himself, includes among its members Academician Sakharov and Shafarevich, a corresponding member of the Academy of Sciences of the U.S.S.R.
In 1973 the so-called "Russian Section" of Amnesty International, headed by Turchin and Tverdokhlebov, assumed organizational responsibilities for individuals with anti-Soviet leanings. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	As a result of measures taken by the Committee for State Security, the "initiative group" and the "Committee for the Protection of Human Rights" have been completely compromised and have virtually ceased to exist. The activities of the "Russian Section" have been curtailed.
Nevertheless, despite the failure to create an "internal opposition" in the U.S.S.R., our adversary has not abandoned this idea.
On May 12 of this year, on the initiative of Yuri F. Orlov, born in 1924, unemployed, corresponding member of the Academy of Sciences of the Armenian S.S.R., the antisocial elements announced the formation of a "Group for Implementation of the Helsinki Accords in the U.S.S.R."
This "group" includes the following individuals: Ginzburg, A. I., has on numerous occasions been brought to criminal accountability, born 1936, Jew, unemployed; Grigorenko, P. G., born 1907, Ukrainian, retiree; the professional criminal Marchenko, A. T., born 1938, Russian, in exile in Irkutsk Oblast; [also] the Jewish extremists: Rubin, V. A., born 1913, Jew, emigrated to Israel; Shcharansky, A. D., born 1948, Jew, unemployed; and Slepak, V. S., born 1927, Jew, unemployed; [also] participants in various hostile activities: Sakharov's wife Bonner, Ye. G., born 1922, Jew, retiree; Bernshtam, M. S., born 1949, Jew, emigrated to Israel; Landa, M. N., born 1918, Jew, retiree, unemployed; Alekseyeva, L. M., born 1927, Russian, unemployed, and Korchak, A. A., born 1922, Ukrainian, fellow at the Institute of Terrestrial Magnetism, Ionosphere and Radio Wave Transmission, Academy of Sciences of the U.S.S.R.

 	 	 		. . .	 	The Committee for State Security is taking measures to compromise and put an end to the "group's" hostile activities.
Reported by way of information.
 
Chairman of the Committee on State Security
ANDROPOV
 
K.G.B. WARNING ON CHERNOBYL
More than seven years before the Cherno byl nuclear disaster, the K.G.B., led by An dropov, had reported to the Central Committee of the Soviet Union that there were serious design and construction problems at the power station.

 	 	 			February 21, 1979	According to data in the possession of the K.G.B. of the U.S.S.R., design deviations and violations of construction and assembly technology are occurring at various places in the construction of the second generating unit of the Chernobyl A.E.S. and these could lead to mishaps and accidents.
The structural pillars of the generator room were erected with a deviation of up to 100 mm. from the reference axes, and horizontal connections between the pillars are absent in places.
Wall panels have been installed with a deviation of up to 150 mm. from the axes. The placement of roof plates does not conform to the designer's specifications. Crane tracks and stopways have vertical drops of up to 100 mm. and in places a slope of up to 8<0>.
Deputy head of the Construction Directorate, Comrade V. T. Gora, gave instructions for backfilling the foundation in many places where vertical waterproofing was damaged. Similar violations were permitted in other sections with the knowledge of Comrade V. T. Gora and the head of the construction group, Comrade Yu. L. Matveyev. Damage to the waterproofing can lead to ground water seepage into the station and radioactive contamination of the environment.
The leadership of the Directorate is not devoting proper attention to the foundation, on which the quality of the construction largely depends.

HEADLINE: 3 Men Killed and 2 Wounded In Shooting After Clash at Party

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
Three men were killed and two others were wounded outside of a Brooklyn party yesterday when an argument over a woman led to a drive-by shooting, witnesses and the police said.
Without saying a word, two men in a red sports car sprayed a group of about 15 people mingling outside during a party at 279 Buffalo Avenue in Crown Heights, the police said. The police provided this list of victims: 
 Kevin Augustus, 22 years old, of 41 Convent Avenue in Harlem, who died at the scene from a gunshot wound.
Anthony Zayala, 22, of 1415 Curtis Street in Los Angeles, who died at the scene of stomach and back wounds.
Linden Arnold, 24, of Belize City, who was taken to St. Mary's Hospital, where he died of a gunshot wound to the leg. Mr. Arnold was in New York on vacation, family members said.
Two other men, Erwin Franklin and Norman Budd, were treated at area hospitals for gunshot wounds to their legs and released yesterday. The police would not provide their addresses because they are witnesses in a continuing investigation.
The police said they have made no arrests in the shooting, which took place at 3 A.M. yesterday.
The owner of the house at 279 Buffalo Avenue, who insisted that his name not be used for fear of retribution from the gunmen, said that he had not seen any of the victims among the 50 people dancing inside at the party but that he had noticed them in a group drinking beer and smoking marijuana nearby. "I came out to tell them to leave, but they were arguing very strongly about a girl, so I went back inside," he said.
Moments later, he said, two men ran into the basement, saying they had been shot. "Then two other guys came into the basement and one of them was carrying two guns," he said. "I pleaded with them to leave, and they did. Then I locked the door and called the police."
One local resident, Fred Campbell, an unemployed 28-year-old, said: "It's like Dodge City out there. Every night there's shootings going on."
In the Bronx, a dozen members of Linden Arnold's family gathered in his parents' apartment. His mother, Valerie Linden, said that her son had run a dry-cleaning business in Belize City and that he had come to New York with his family last Tuesday.
"A friend called us and told us the awful news," she said as Mr. Linden's 2-year-old son cried at her side. "He was supposed to go home tomorrow."

HEADLINE: Dinkins's Europe Trip Polishes City's Image

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, June 14

 BODY:
What people say about you behind your back is typically more telling that what they say to your face.
By that measure, the delegation led by Mayor David N. Dinkins that just made a whirlwind tour of Britain, France and Germany to promote New York as an indispensable place for foreign companies to do business was successful. 
 Maybe not a smash success. Judging from interviews with a handful of British executives wooed by the delegation of city and state officials and business leaders, the tour probably will not result in an immediate deluge of investment. But it certainly persuaded some executives to think more kindly of New York. While they wished the delegation had come prepared to discuss financial incentives, they said the visit provided them with contacts that could lead to deals.
"Those contacts couldn't but be helpful," said Charles Herbert, chairman of the Tussaud's Group, a division of Pearson P.L.C., whose exhibition centers include Madame Tussaud's wax museum here. At the moment, New York is vying with at least Berlin and Tokyo as the site for a $30 million to $40 million wax museum Pearson wants to build in the 1990's.
 
Meeting of Minds
 But judging from Mr. Herbert's tone, the 45 minutes of courting by the delegation -- lacking Mr. Dinkins -- helped New York's cause. "We were talking to some high-powered business people -- people speaking our own language," Mr. Herbert said, mentioning Preston R. Tisch, president of Loews Corporation, and David A. Olsen, chairman of Johnson & Higgins, the insurance broker.
He was also happy to meet Barry F. Sullivan, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development. "Certainly, if we're to go into New York, we would be approaching people in his office to see what kind of financial deals there would be for people like us."
Executives at Ladbroke Group, a British conglomerate with betting shops, hotels and home-improvement stores, struck a similar note. "It was useful to have an exchange of views and make personal contact," they said in a statement.
The Ladbroke executives intend to pursue the possibility of buying the Offtrack Betting Corporation, which was the subject of their talks with the delegation. They said they are "seriously interested" in buying or managing the agency. State Comptroller Edward V. Regan has urged the city to consider selling OTB's 95 branches to private interests.
Long before the New York delegation arrived here, Tussaud's had been exploring sites in Manhattan, including the theater district around 42d Street and the South Street Seaport area. Rebecca Robertson, president of the 42d Street Development Project, the state-financed redevelopment group, had been courting them.
If the wax museum goes into the theater district, one of its main themes will be the entertainment industry. But comments by some New York executives appear to have reduced the theater district's chances. "One or two said that area of redevelopment was going to take a long time to come to pass," Mr. Herbert said.
 
Pluses and Minuses
 Given New York's depressed economy, Mr. Herbert said it would take "tremendous incentives to get us to go there in the next year or 18 months." On the other hand, the Germans and Japanese have not been exactly deluging him with offers. "Berlin is also a city down on its luck at the moment," he said. And Tokyo is one of the few places whose real estate prices make New York's look like a bargain.
Tussaud's plans to choose the lucky city within a year or two.
It will also be quite a while, if ever, before New York has its own Virgin Megastore, selling music, computer games and the like.
The delegates pushed Times Square as a potential site for one of the huge stores in their talks with Richard Branson, the British entrepreneur whose empire includes the Virgin Retail Group and Virgin Atlantic Airways.
But Los Angeles has been chosen for the first Megastore in the United States, because it does not have any similar stores of comparable size -- more than 20,000 square feet -- William Whitehorn, a spokesman for Mr. Branson, said. It is scheduled to open by the end of the year.
British executives complained that the New Yorkers bore no tangible gifts, which they interpreted to mean that the Dinkins administration was new at wooing foreign investment.
Roger J. Saul, owner and chairman of the Mulberry Company of London, an apparel, accessories and home-furnishings manufacturer and retailer, said the Japanese are offering favorable loan terms and tax breaks to encourage investment.
Mr. Saul plans to open retail stores in the United States and is trying to decide whether to begin with a flagship store of 3,000 to 4,000 square feet in a major city or with a smaller store in a wealthy suburb or smaller city. The big cities he is considering include New York, Chicago, Boston and Dallas, and he is also thinking about a store for Beverly Hills.
 
'New York Is Serious'
 "It seemed to be a quite a high-powered, charismatic delegation, and I was pleasantly surprised by the tone," Mr. Saul said. "It means New York is serious about trying to further business relationships outside their four walls." He said that what would matter even more than the initial trip was whether there would be a follow-up.
The British executives stress that if they do invest, it will be for the long-term. And they have faith that New York's current dismal economy will rebound.
"Americans and New Yorkers are quite resilient people. They're get-up-and-goers," said Mr. Herbert of Tussaud's.
Mr. Saul agreed. "We believe now is the right time to go in," he said. "Real estate opportunities are tremendous." He just wants a little help from his new-found friends.

HEADLINE: Civil Rights Leader Retires Angry

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ATLANTA, June 14

 BODY:
The Rev. Joseph Lowery, one of the founding ministers of the civil rights movement, retired from the pulpit Sunday with an angry sermon attributing the country's social woes to Government indifference.
"It is not our economy we need to be worried about," said Mr. Lowery, who at 70 years old has reached the mandatory retirement age for United Methodist ministers. "What's imperiled today in America is her soul. 
 "We can deal with the economy. If we lose our souls, what, then, is there for us? There is no sanctuary for the soul from the sorrow of the society in which we live."
About 1,500 people packed Cascade United Methodist Church, where Mr. Lowery had been pastor for six years. Mr. Lowery said he would remain as president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, which he has headed since 1977.
Mr. Lowery and the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. were among the ministers who founded the Leadership Conference in 1957.
Mr. Lowery accused the Bush Administration of inattention to domestic concerns, citing its failure to encourage industry to create jobs in America, rather than overseas, and its reluctance to extend jobless benefits.
He then moved to Vice President Dan Quayle's touting of "family values" and said, "If you're concerned about the family, Mr. Quayle, why don't you extend the unemployment benefits so children can eat?"
"You would send women, children -- families in homemade boats -- to certain death on the shores of Haiti. And you talk about family values," said Mr. Lowery, who waved his arms and spat out words rapid-fire.
After the service, several in the congregation wept.
"You have graduated from Cascade, but your ministry to the world is just beginning," Marilyn Arrington, a parishioner, told Mr. Lowery.

HEADLINE: Travel Industry Plans For Life After Castro

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Convinced that Fidel Castro's rule is nearing its end, executives in the American travel industry are laying plans for a surge of American visitors to Cuba.
While most of the executives play down any talk of an immediate bonanza from Cuban tourism, they note that the estimated one million Cuban-Americans represent a large pool of potential travelers along with other Americans who want to visit a nearby tropical island that has been largely off limits for more than three decades. 
 "Top management here has been talking about plans for the Cuban market, and I have no doubt that top management at most other cruise lines has talked about it, too," said Doug Falk, executive vice president of Kloster Cruise Ltd., which owns the Norwegian Cruise Line.
 
Interest Among Airlines
 Airline executives also talk about Cuba after Mr. Castro. United Airlines recently received tentative approval from the Transportation Department for Havana flights if the State Department allows them, which is unlikely as long as Mr. Castro remains.
Executives of the Radisson Hotel chain, who were invited to Cuba in 1989 to discuss managing a proposed new hotel, say they still plan to operate a hotel outside Havana if Washington gives its approval.
And the Port of Miami recently proposed building a downtown port annex to accommodate cruise lines and Miami-Havana ferry service. Before Mr. Castro took over, ocean liners and ferries sailed to Havana from New York, New Orleans, Miami and Key West, Fla.
Long a playground for American visitors, with its beaches, casinos and night life, Cuba was placed off limits for United States citizens when relations between Washington and Havana deteriorated soon after Mr. Castro came to power in 1959. While American citizens are not prohibited from traveling to Cuba, United States law forbids most Americans to spend money there. It also prohibits American investment.
Still, Cuban leaders are trying to attract investors as the country deals with the worst economic crisis of the Castro years. Last week, 125 foreign business executives, most of them Americans, were greeted by Mr. Castro and other top officials during a day of briefings in Havana on investment opportunities that remain largely off limits.
 
A Year-Round Spot
 Mr. Falk said the island could serve as a year-round destination itself or as a port-of-call for ships stopping at other Caribbean ports. During their stay in port, the ships could double as hotels for their passengers; Cuba has a shortage of first-class hotels.
Jay J. Lewis, president of Market Scope Inc., a marketing research firm in Miami, estimated that 500,000 cruise passengers would visit Havana in each of the first three years after Mr. Castro departed, rising to 1.8 million cruise passengers and 600,000 ferry visitors by the 10th year.
"It will be a long, long time before Cuba's infrastructure is anywhere near what will be required to handle more American tourists," Mr. Lewis said. He estimated that only 2,000 cruise passengers visited Cuba in 1988, the latest year for which data are available. In contrast, 1.2 million cruise passengers visited Nassau, the Bahamas, in 1990.
The number of Cuban visitors is unlikely to increase much while Mr. Castro is still around; two months ago President Bush, in an apparent concession to the anti-Castro Cuban American National Foundation, signed legislation restricting ships that visit Cuba from calling at American ports.
Scheduled air service between the United States and Cuba ended soon after Mr. Castro came to power. But even though United States airlines are barred from flying to Cuba, their interest in that country dates from at least October 1927, when Pan Am began flying from Key West to Havana -- the first permanent air service from the United States to a foreign country. Pan Am acquired a second certificate to fly to Cuba when it purchased National Airlines for $400 million in 1980.
Pan Am's deteriorating financial condition forced it to sell its Latin American routes, including the Miami-Havana and Key West-Havana routes, to United last year, shortly before Pan Am went out of business.
"United is closely watching the situation with Cuba and would be very anxious to commence service at the earliest possible date," said Lawrence M. Nagin, the carrier's executive vice president and general counsel. American Airlines also hopes to be granted routes to Cuba.
Since the breakup of the Soviet Union, which subsidized Cuba at about $4 billion a year, the Cuban economy has steadily deteriorated. Mr. Castro has turned to tourism to generate foreign exchange.
To attract Canadians, Germans and other foreign visitors, Havana has formed joint ventures with hotel developers from Europe and the Caribbean, giving the foreign companies majority ownership of new construction and discretion over management practices.
Cuba continues to seek foreign investment and management expertise, which is why its officials had invited the Radisson executives to the island.
"We didn't meet Castro, but we met other high Cuban officials," said Curtis L. Carlson, whose Carlson Companies owns the worldwide Radisson chain. He was accompanied by Juergen Bartels, president of the Carlson Hospitality Group and an official of the Banco Nacional de Mexico. The talks in Havana were conducted with the head of Cubanacan, one of several state tourism agencies.
Mr. Carlson said the group was shown five potential hotel sites outside Havana and plans for modern hotels for each site. They agreed to manage one of the five properties, and the Cubans accepted.
"When they asked when we could start, we had to tell them not until Washington gives us the go-ahead," Mr. Carlson said. While nothing exists in writing, he added, Radisson considers its oral agreement with the Cuban Government to be in effect.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Dan Quayle, Malcolm X and American Values

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
BLACKS realize increasingly that physically, politically, economically, and even to some degree socially, the aroused black man can create a turmoil in white America's vitals -- not to mention America's international image.
Spike Lee was dismissive. Betty Shabazz was hopeful. Robert Little was skeptical. All three -- the film-maker, who is completing his production of "X," and Malcolm X's widow and brother -- were incredulous at Vice President Dan Quayle's revelation last week that he was mining the slain black nationalist's autobiography for clues to racial conflict and to its mitigation, reported in The Wall Street Journal. 
 Four months ago, Mr. Quayle addressed the Economic Club in Manhattan, where he bashed the city's bureaucracy and laid the groundwork for his critique of New York as the welfare state incarnate. Today, Mr. Quayle is due back to preach American values to another thoughtful choir, the Manhattan Institute, and, according to his spokesman, David Beckwith, "more of what's wrong with New York." Which might suggest that, if today's speech is inspired by Malcolm's views, such as those quoted here, a little knowledge can be a dangerous thing.
Human rights! Respect as human beings! That's what America's black masses want.
"It's a joke," Mr. Lee said last week of the Vice President's move. "Every time Malcolm X talked about 'blue-eyed devils' Quayle should think he's talking about him. How does he see himself having a role in reversing racial conflict? He doesn't have any blacks or Hispanics or Asian-Americans among his senior staff."
Mr. Lee added, "He says teach a person how to fish rather than give a person a fish, but the people who've got the fish, they're all white males."
Why was it that when Negroes did start revolting across America, virtually all of white America was caught up in surprise and even shock? I would hate to be general of an army as badly informed as the American white man has been about the Negro in this country.
"He talks about traditional values," said Dr. Shabazz, an official at Medgar Evers College of the City University of New York. "Is he saying that only certain people have values and other people don't?
"What I think is very sad is some people feel that white people should have as their agenda only Caucasians. And that if black people don't have white people as their agenda they're considered hatemongers."
And, she said, "If New York is the welfare state, it is because we have helped everyone else but ourselves."
One thing the white man never can give the black man is self-respect!. . . The black man in America has to lift up his own sense of values.
"I don't know what would make the Vice President more sensitive, given the ideology he espouses," said Mr. Little, who heads New York City's Child Welfare Administration.
"States, unfortunately, are having to make up for Federal disinvestment," he said. "Are poor people receiving enough dollars to adequately survive? No. Being on welfare in and of itself limits your income to a substandard level."
It takes no one to stir up the sociological dynamite that stems from the unemployment, bad housing, and inferior education already in the ghettos. This explosively criminal condition has existed for so long; it fuses itself; it spontaneously combusts from within itself.
Mr. Quayle was referred to Malcolm's autobiography by Digger Phelps, the former Notre Dame basketball coach since recruited to the Government's anti-drug crusade. Five years ago, Mr. Phelps presciently sensed the national mood when, asked about mandatory drug testing of players, he replied: "Somebody's got to do something. I'm going to give up some Constitutional rights."
If Mr. Quayle is reading the autobiography nearly 30 years after it was first published, he deserves two points for his own belated cultural outreach and his embrace of Muslim self-discipline as one vehicle for instilling them. (After all, Malcolm was a convert, too.) Beyond suspending alternate-side parking rules on Moslem holidays, though, it's uncertain how Mr. Quayle would have government promote the religion's agenda.
Whenever something white men disliked happened in the black community, typically white public attention was directed not at the cause, but at a selected scapegoat.
Listening to Dr. Shabazz and to Mr. Little would provide another dimension to Mr. Quayle's postgraduate education. An unforgiving Mr. Lee says, though, that he would not even invite the Vice President to a screening of his new film next fall. "He should pay $7.50 like everyone else."
Billboards are already promoting the film. Beneath a huge "X" is the word November, which is when the film opens and when Americans vote. The X is for Malcolm. But it also means the unknown -- whether the rest of America is persuaded that New York epitomizes the failed welfare state and that Mr. Quayle would do a better job of helping the poor help themselves.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Housing Data May Give Signals on the Economy

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Struggling to make sense out of economic statistics that are mixed at best, credit market participants are questioning whether the sluggish recovery that seems to be developing could falter.
One reason for such doubts is the way the housing industry, an important source of growth in the first quarter, seems to be sputtering. 
 After surging during an exceptionally balmy winter, housing activity tailed off in March and April, in part because of unseasonably cool weather and in part because of rising mortgage interest rates.
 
Awaiting the Housing Data
 Housing numbers for May, scheduled to be released on Tuesday, may provide a better picture of just how healthy housing is.
In advance of the report, most analysts are forecasting that housing starts are running at an annual rate of just over 1.1 million units, relatively unchanged from April. A sampling of builders across the country found most to be mildly upbeat. But some questioned if in the current climate low mortgage rates would be enough to fuel demand.
"Housing is a question mark," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank. "If housing starts to flatten out at current levels of around 1.1 million units at an annual rate, the economy can continue to grow, but at an even more sluggish pace than I think. It will be a concern to the Fed."
Despite recent sluggishness, there are some reasons to be optimistic about the housing market.
 
Movement in Mortgage Rates
 At around 8.5 percent, rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages are higher than they were in January, but nearly half a point below where they were in March. And employment has been rising, albeit glacially, in recent months. Moreover, the abnormally frantic pace of building that went on during January and February tends to exaggerate the recent weakness.
"The last couple of months wouldn't have looked so bad if the first couple of months hadn't looked so good," said Michael Carliner, an economist at the National Association of Home Builders in Washington. "Some of the activity that went on this winter was borrowed from the spring."
Mr. Carliner expects housing activity, after stabilizing in the second quarter at an annual rate of around 1.2 million units, to accelerate modestly through the second half of the year, assuming mortgage rates stay at close to current levels and employment and income levels show further improvement.
In addition to weak employment and income growth, analysts point out that demographic trends, including the shrinking number of first-time buyers, are working against housing.
 
Not 'Terribly Strong'
 The volume of potential home buyers "has not been terribly strong," since March, said William J. Gillilan, president of the Centex Corporation, a Dallas-based company that is one of the nation's largest home builders. "On the other hand, our sales rate as a percentage of those who are looking has been as good as at any time in our recent history."
Robert J. Buchert, president of the American Heritage Construction and Development Corporation in Cincinnati, said that after a sluggish March and April, activity picked up slightly in May.
"I can't say that conditions are good,' he said. "I'm more optimistic about 1992 than I was at this time last year, but my optimism is dampened from what it was in January and February."
J. Roger Glunt, president of the Glunt Building Company in Turtle Creek, Pa., near Pittsburgh, said business was worse than it was a year earlier. Voicing an opinion shared by a number of builders, he said potential home buyers lacked the confidence necessary to buy.
"A year ago, people felt a lot better, even though the economy was not good," he said. "That is not the case right now."
 
Decline in Consumer Credit
 Even though mortgage rates are low, consumers are extremely reluctant to take on new debt, no matter how cheaply they can borrow the money.
The urge to pare debt levels was vividly illustrated in April consumer credit numbers reported last week. The monthly decline was the steepest since the credit crunch in the spring of 1980.
The decline in mortgage rates in the last month or so has thus far not prompted a rise in a weekly home purchasing index compiled by the Mortgage Bankers Association.
"The index is running well below February levels," Christopher Flanagan, a mortgage-backed-securities analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company wrote in a weekly report to clients, "and suggests that this summer's home-buying season will be relatively depressed, despite low mortgage rates."
He added, "Economic uncertainty is forcing borrowers into behavior that is radically different from their behavior in similar interest rate environments of the past."
Lyle E. Gramley, chief economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association, said his group was expecting a gradual improvement in housing for the rest of the year, one that would be sufficient to stimulate the economy. He added, however, that the risks of stagnation were greater than risks that demand might explode.
