HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON;
Russians Say I.M.F. Demands May Nullify Benefits of Loans

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
Officials negotiating Russia's aid package with the International Monetary Fund asserted today that the fund was seeking to impose demands so burdensome that they could weaken the nation's teetering economy and nullify many of the benefits of a $24 billion aid package for Russia.
In high-stakes public posturing aimed at winning American support, these negotiators sought to pressure the I.M.F. not to be so tough on Russia just hours before President Boris N. Yeltsin arrived here for a summit meeting at which economic aid will be high on the agenda. 
 The negotiators said that in seeking to work out a reform agreement, the monetary fund was calling for such stringent restrictions on the use of a planned $6 billion fund to stabilize the ruble that the fund would be rendered almost meaningless. The talks resume in Moscow this week.
Moscow's negotiators also said the I.M.F. was squeezing Russia by asserting that much of the $3 billion in loans intended for the country should be used to build up hard currency reserves, rather than to finance imports of spare parts and raw materials desperately needed by Russian industry.
Speaking at a conference in Washington, Petr Aven, Russia's Minister for Foreign Economic Relations, also said the I.M.F. was delaying an accord by paying too much attention to small details when the important thing was that Russia was embracing sweeping reforms to create a market economy.
"It is urgent to get this aid moving, given the crisis in Russian industry," said Jeffrey Sachs, a Harvard economics professor who is helping Russia negotiate with the I.M.F. He said delays in signing an agreement were unfortunate because Moscow broadly agrees with the I.M.F on the need for swift and comprehensive reform.
At the same conference, Michel Camdessus, the I.M.F.'s managing director, said the fund was seeking a strong agreement that would help lock Russia into its reform. Russia has to sign a monetary fund reform agreement to unblock much of the $24 billion aid package that the Group of Seven industrial nations promised last April.
 
Baker Urges No Delay
 With the I.M.F.-Russia dispute heating up, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Treasury Under Secretary David C. Mulford stepped into the fray to mediate. Mr. Baker said the Russians needed to continue their reforms, but added that the I.M.F. should not delay a pact because of "the crossing of each and every 't' and the dotting of each and every 'i'."
Professor Sachs said another problem was that if the other former Soviet republics do not pay this year's debt service of roughly $6 billion, the I.M.F. says Russia should pay it from the $24 billion in Western aid. He said this would greatly decrease the beneifts of the aid package and should not be counted as part of the package. I.M.F. officials note that Russia has agreed to be jointly responsible for the debts of other republics.
Monetary fund officials criticized the public campaign by the Russians to pressure on them. They said Mr. Sachs was wrong to object to the strict conditions the I.M.F. sought to place on the stabilization fund. "If we gave the Russians the fund under the terms they want, the money would would disappear into a black hole in two days," one monetary fund official said.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House;
Quayle Attacks New York as Home of Liberal Failure

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
A month before the Democratic Party arrives in New York for its national convention, Vice President Dan Quayle returned here yesterday to lambaste the party's liberal leaders, warning, "We must not let them do to the rest of America what they have done to the people of New York City."
Attacking policies ranging from condom distribution in schools to high local taxes to rent control, and politicians like Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, whom he dismissed as "liberalism's sensitive philosopher-king," the Vice President used a speech to the Manhattan Institute, a conservative policy research group, to paint New York anew as the epitome of liberalism's failures. 
 It was the latest in a series of attention-getting election-year speeches in which the Vice President has struck out at issues, policies or personalities that conservatives see as embodying liberal excesses. It echoed sentiments that Mr. Quayle had made in a speech to the Economic Club of New York in February.
 
Counterattack Was Ready
 But this time, local politicians were forearmed by days of news reports heralding Mr. Quayle's trip, which also included a private 55-minute meeting with John Cardinal O'Connor to discuss abortion and other issues. Even before Mr. Quayle's midday speech, Mayor David N. Dinkins had issued a three-page statement condemning it, and Mr. Cuomo had dispatched Lieut. Gov. Stan Lundine to the steps of City Hall to complain that Mr. Quayle was simply recycling an old Republican strategy of attacking the disorders of urban America to play to his President's conservative base.
In fact, Mr. Quayle injected himself into issues -- like rent control and condom distribution -- that not only divide New Yorkers themselves, but that Republicans have also long insisted should be left strictly in the hands of local governments and school boards. His prescriptions for change rested on broad exhortations to hold down taxes, turn over some city services to the private sector and teach "basic values" in public schools -- all issues over which the Federal government has little control and with which New York City and State have been grappling for months.
"Here is what's right with New York: the decent, hard-working people who live here," Mr. Quayle said in his 20-minute speech at the Waldorf-Astoria. "Here's what's wrong with New York: the entrenched government establishment and its liberal ideology that have failed them.
"In so many ways the liberal Democrats chose the perfect site for their convention -- almost as if they feel a strange compulsion to return to the scene of the crime," Mr. Quayle said. "And as we watch this spectacle on our televisions, I suspect many Americans from around the country will be left with this conviction: We must not let them do to the rest of America what they have done to the people of New York City."
 
An Easy Target
 Mr. Quayle is far from alone in sounding the theme of New York as a failed metropolis. Last summer, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, now the Democrats' presumed nominee, was quoted as saying that holding the convention in New York was "a risk," because it could make the Democrats seem to be supporting "status-quo programs and interests that don't work."
Mr. Clinton later said his remarks had been distorted, but he has approached urban problems warily, preferring to characterize them as national problems and declining to embrace a large Federal aid package backed by the United States Conference of Mayors.
Still, the Vice President's analysis failed to discourage Mr. Dinkins and other local officials who hope to use the convention as a showcase for the city's strengths. They often complain that under the Reagan and Bush Administrations, the share of the city's budget financed by Federal funds has shrunk from nearly 20 percent a decade ago to just over 10 percent now, depriving it of perhaps $30 billion in total aid.
"I think it is rather sad that this person, who is a heartbeat away from the Presidency, who could, like that, become the leader of the free world, would occupy himself in such a fashion," the Mayor said late yesterday. "Would that he would spend that same energy to try to find a resolution to some of the problems that beset our cities and our country, and we've got a lot of them."
 
Values, Not Condoms
 In his speech, Mr. Quayle again promoted the "family values" he has been touting for days, saying at one point that "our schools are in a crisis because they have, in many ways, lost their moral bearings.
"When eighth-graders are squandering the gift of youthful innocence in premarital sex, the solution is not to give them a condom," he said. "The solution is to give them a value-based education, to teach them what is right and wrong, to teach them that they and they alone are responsible for their actions."
Later, he added, "My friends, there is only one school of life's true values and that is the family, especially the traditional family."
But he had a harder time with a question from a member of his audience who asked what the Administration had done to support family values. He answered by saying that for one thing, he was talking about them, and that the Federal Government spent billions of dollars a year on education. He even cited a Great Society social idea, the Head Start early education program.
 
'Let's Play Ball'
 For his part, Mr. Cuomo, a frequent target of the Vice President's barbs, could not resist a taunt of his own, challenging Mr. Quayle in a live interview on the WNWY-TV program "Good Day New York" to a game of one-on-one basketball.
"If you really want to come and make a fool of yourself, bring your jock and a pair of sneakers and let's play ball," the Governor said.
Mr. Quayle later told reporters: "You better tell Mario before he takes me on in basketball he'd better have his scouts out there, because this is serious business for this Hoosier."

HEADLINE: U.S. Reports a Stronger Saddam Hussein

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
Despite stringent economic sanctions and diplomatic isolation, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq is stronger now than he was a year ago, according to a classified intelligence report that will be presented to President Bush and his chief aides.
The interagency report, known as a National Intelligence Estimate, concludes that Mr. Hussein has begun to rebuild some of his country's infrastructure by importing goods from Jordan in violation of the United Nations-mandated sanctions and by tapping into hidden Iraqi reserves, said Administration officials familiar with the report. It also states that he is trying to reconstitute his military and is strengthening his political base by imposing more repressive measures on his population. 
 On the other hand, the report says that as long as the sanctions are in place, living conditions for most people in Iraq will continue to worsen and pressures on Mr. Hussein will increase.
The conclusions of the report reflect a change in nuance rather than a radical departure from previous intelligence analyses about Mr. Hussein's position. Soon after the Iraqi leader suppressed rebellions by Kurds in the north and Shiite Muslims in the south, the Central Intelligence Agency concluded that he could remain in power for years. At the time, some senior White House, Pentagon and State Department officials were portraying Mr. Hussein as getting weaker by the day.
 
'We Expect Him to Stay'
 "This is not a flip-flop in our thinking, but more a question of degree," an Administration official said in describing the report. "The main point is that Saddam is still there and we expect him to stay. It used to be that people were saying that the sanctions were making him weaker. They're not saying that anymore. He is clearly stronger than he was a year ago."
When asked at a press breakfast last week about Mr. Hussein's ability to survive, James R. Lilley, the Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs, said, "As long as he's able to get his hands on enough stuff to buy off his cronies, the Republican Guard, his chances of staying in power are pretty good."
The report, which reflects the thinking of the Central Intelligence Agency and the other intelligence agencies, was formally approved on Thursday and is scheduled to be distributed to Mr. Bush and senior officials this week.
Its timing is particularly embarrassing for Mr. Bush, who has had to defend his Administration's conciliatory policies toward Iraq before its invasion of Kuwait against both Democratic critics in Congress and Ross Perot, who have accused him of appeasing Mr. Hussein and leading the United States into a war that might have been avoided.
One factor that has enhanced Mr. Hussein's position is the widespread smuggling of construction materials, industrial, electrical and communications equipment, spare parts and luxury goods to Iraq from Jordan in violation of economic sanctions imposed soon after the August 1990 invasion of Kuwait. Intelligence officials also suspect illegal shipments of military-related equipment.
 
Rules for Jordan Trade
 Under rules set up by the Security Council, Jordan sends large amounts of food and medicine to Iraq through its port at Aqaba and overland across its 100-mile border with Iraq.
But Iraq has been allowed to set up a number of exporting offices in Amman, and satellite photos show virtually no truck traffic at the border, indicating that Jordan is doing little or nothing to stanch the flow of goods across the border, American intelligence officials said. A senior Administration official estimated that about 30 percent of all trade from Jordan to Iraq was illegal.
Iraq is believed to have drawn on reserves from secret foreign bank accounts and sales of gold reserves to pay for the embargoed goods, senior United Nations officials say.
Mr. Bush is said to be particularly distressed at the scale of the smuggling, particularly because he received a pledge from King Hussein during his visit to the White House last March to abide by the international sanctions.

HEADLINE: Republicans Seek to Sell New Jersey Nonprofit TV

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 15

 BODY:
Republican legislative leaders unveiled a plan today to allow the transfer of the New Jersey Network public television system to an outside noncommercial television operator, most likely Channel 13/WNET in New York.
The Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, and the Assembly Speaker, Garabed Haytaian, who lead overwhelming Republican majorities that dominate the State Legislature, said the plan to transfer the system, which the state owns and operates, would cut costs and mean "more independent" programming. 
 George L. Miles Jr., executive vice president and chief operating officer of WNET-TV, who joined the two legislative leaders at a news conference announcing the plan this morning, said his station was "committed" to negotiating with the state regarding the network's operations.
But William F. Baker, the president of WNET, said in a telephone interview today that the plan was fraught with difficulties and by no means certain. "It's not a fait accompli," he said. "It's only a beginning."
 
New Jersey Must Stay
 Among the difficulties is a requirement that WNET continue most of a heavy schedule of New Jersey programming now provided by the New Jersey Network.
"We would have to provide it all on our outlet," he said, adding that the rule could create difficulties in a market that would include New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Just how much New Jersey programming viewers in other states would tolerate remains a question, Mr. Baker said.
He said that he was nonetheless intrigued by the idea of taking on a larger audience. "We are both poor entities, and combining us would give us some clear benefits, but the risk is in taking on other liabilities," he said.
In proposing to divest the state of the network, Mr. Haytaian and Mr. DiFrancesco cited the high costs as the chief reason.
 
A Potential Windfall
 Mr. DiFrancesco also cited a potential windfall that he said could result from the state's selling three North Jersey stations that are now part of the network. "We could try to convert NJN's UHF stations in North Jersey -- channels 50, 52 and 58 -- to commercial outlets and sell them to private operators for as much as $150 million," he said. The stations are WNJM, Channel 50, in Montclair; WNJT, Channel 52, in Trenton, and WNJB, Channel 58, in New Brunswick.
But a spokesman for the Federal Communications Commission in Washington quickly threw cold water on the sale idea. Beyond the optimistic assessment of how much the stations might be worth, the transfer of their noncommercial broadcast licenses to a commercial operator would be illegal, said Stephen Sewell, a spokesman for the commission.
"As the rules now stand," Mr. Sewell said, "they cannot be used for commercial operation. We would not approve a transfer."
But the two Republican leaders seemed determined to press the plan as part of a broad program of privatization they envision.
 
State Aid Cut in Half
 They said the state's new budget, to be announced later this month, would appropriate only $4 million for the New Jersey Network, a reduction of 50 percent from last year's $8 million.
"We expect that this will take the station through the first six months of this year, until negotiations are finalized," Mr. Haytaian said.
Mr. Haytaian said it was too early to speculate on future appropriations for noncommercial television, adding that New Jersey pays about 60 percent of the cost of operating its network, compared to an average of 25 percent for other states that support some noncommercial television.
As outlined, the transfer of NJN would be accomplished by abolishing the New Jersey Public Broadcasting Authority, the state agency that now oversees the network, and transferring its functions and employees to the Department of Commerce, Energy and Economic Development.
 
Cut Cord, Keep Plug
 Mr. DiFrancesco insisted that he and Mr. Haytaian have "no intention of pulling the plug on public television in New Jersey." Instead, he said, the bill introduced today would "allow public television in our state to retain its own unique identity while cutting the umbilical cord between public television and state government."
In a letter to Mr. DiFrancesco on June 10, released today, Mr. Miles said that WNET was "enthusiastic" about beginning discussions for a takeover, and he pledged to "establish a major presence" in Trenton and "maintain a news bureau in South Jersey."

HEADLINE: Basketball Title Brings Chicago Night of Looting

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, June 15

 BODY:
When the sun rose over the city's West Side today, Frank Ingram tiptoed through the shards of glass on the floor of his looted pawn shop, his dreams shattered during a night of celebration turned ugly.
A few hours earlier, the shop was overrun by looters when hundreds of people spilled into the streets throughout the city following the Chicago Bulls' defeat of the Portland Trailblazers to win their second straight National Basketball Association championship. 
 Before the night was over, 100 people were injured, 95 of them police officers. More than 1,000 people were arrested; 61 police vehicles damaged, including 4 by gunfire, and several fires set. Officials this evening had no count of the number of stores looted and no financial estimate of the damage.
 
Cars Turned Over
 Looters ravaged stores on the West and South Sides, and hundreds of revelers streamed down fashionable North Michigan Avenue at 1 A.M., shattering a string of windows.
In the Rush Street area, Chicago's Near North Side night club district, hundreds of people poured into the street when the game ended shortly after 9 P.M. They surrounded two taxicabs and turned them over like children's toys. Dozens of men then began jumping on the cars, diving head first into the growing crowd.
One cab started burning, and the other was pushed through the plate glass window of an ice cream shop.
"Some people got cut with glass but they just kept jumping," said Frank Rosales, the manager of the Five Faces ice cream shop on Division Street. "We were scared. At one point, gasoline started leaking from one of the cabs and people started throwing matches and lit cigarettes into the gas."
 
Trapped in Burning Store
 In apparently the worst incident of violence, a store employee and his friend suffered burns when looters set a South Side liquor and grocery store afire. The employee, Khalid Hasan Ali-Rifagee, 23 years old, was listed in serious condition today, and his friend, Cindy Schanstra, 23, was listed in fair condition.
The couple were in the store when looters rammed their car through a security gate to break in. The two hid in a crawl space as the looters rampaged through the store and then set it on fire, said John Easton, a spokesman at the University of Chicago Hospitals, where Mr. Ali-Rifagee and Miss Schanstra were taken.
"They were afraid to leave because they could hear gunshots outside," Mr. Easton said. "But when the smoke got too bad, they left."
From the hospital today, Miss Schanstra said that she and Mr. Ali-Rifagee had called the police four times as the looters banged on the door. "The cops still didn't show up," she said. "We're kind of disappointed in the police. If they had shown up, it wouldn't have gone on as long as it did and I wouldn't be sitting here in this hospital now."
She said the store owner finally arrived and helped them to safety.
The other three reported civilian injuries involved shootings, two people shot by store owners and one 23-year-old man who shot by a police officer on the West Side after he threatened the officer with a gun, the authorities said.
Up and down one block of Madison Street on the West Side, about two miles from the Chicago Stadium where the basketball game was played, stores owned by black, white, Korean and Middle Eastern merchants were looted and in at least one case, burned.
Firefighters, protected by the police, continued to wet down a charred department store still smoldering hours after it was set ablaze.
"They were not discriminating in the devastation," said the area's alderman, Ed Smith. "They hit them all. They even hit the post office and the phone company."
The superintendent of police, Matt Rodriguez, said at a City Hall news conference today that the warm weather, the tight economy and the tense environment in the aftermath of the Los Angeles riots contributed to the trouble after the game.
 
How Americans Celebrate
 Mayor Richard M. Daley said the violence was the work of a handful of opportunists and an example of an ugly modern-day method of celebrating sports victories.
"When you celebrate something in America, you break a window and grab something," Mr. Daley said. "When people have an excuse to loot, they loot, when they have an excuse to shoot, they shoot."
The Mayor defended the city's response to the trouble and said 1,300 additional police officers had been dispatched Sunday but had a difficult time because trouble erupted in several spots across the city.
But several merchants whose places of business were destroyed, including Park Jung, said today that the police did not respond quickly enough to the violence.
The 32-year-old Mr. Park said that when he arrived at his men's clothing store on the West Side shortly after 9 P.M., more than 100 people were in front of his business and breaking in.
He said that when he asked several police officers for help, one of them told him to "take care of your life and leave." That's what he did.
"So I left," Mr. Park said today. "What else could I do? I hate America. I'm going back to Korea."
Mayor Daley said additional police officers would be assigned to patrol the most troubled areas tonight as the city prepared for a final victory celebration on Tuesday at Grant Park on the downtown lake front.
One million people are expected to flood the area for a rally as they did a year ago. Last year, the Bulls' first championship season, there was little serious trouble during the rally but there was some isolated looting the night of the final game.
 
Being Black Is No Help
 Back on Madison Street, Mr. Ingram, the owner of the looted pawn shop, said he had operated his business there for 20 years. Before that he worked on the street for someone else.
"It's more than a business," he said. "I'm here because I have a strong feeling for the West Side and my people.
"My theory about what happened is that the Bulls winning didn't have anything to do with this," he said, looking over the shattered and empty display cases. "The economy is what caused this. There are so many people out of work with no means of support. The Bulls' winning was just an excuse for people to express their anger."
Mr. Ingram said that when he first arrived at the store, the police chased at least a dozen looters away. But he added that they returned every time the officers left.
At one point, with the looters banging on his door, Mr. Ingram pleaded with them to leave his store alone because he was black.
"Prove it," he said a looter shouted.
"I had to open the door and show my face," Mr. Ingram said. "Then a man said 'Leave him alone, he's black.' But then another man said, 'I don't care, kill him.' "
Mr. Ingram said he was not sure whether he would remain on the West Side. "Unless people start getting some jobs this is going to keep on happening," he said. "I'm very angry and very disappointed but I understand what's happening. People are desperate, people are hungry, people are scared."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
On TV, Clinton Finds an Audience That Listens

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL

 BODY:
Listen to Bill Clinton on the morning talk shows. No saxophone. No sunglasses. He is serious, concise and eager to repeat his claim of outsider status in an election year suddenly gone screwy.
As an elected Democrat in a year when voters want almost nothing to do with politicians, the winner of the Democratic primary race spent yesterday morning pursuing his new mission: trying to persuade voters to keep an open mind about his chances of becoming President. 
 In one vital respect, Mr. Clinton's appearance on the CBS News program "This Morning" was a breakthrough of sorts: Only one questioner aside from the co-host, Paula Zahn, mentioned Ross Perot, and no one mentioned President Bush except to criticize current Administration policies.
Instead, the studio audience of 81 friendly people recruited by CBS employees from interest groups and acquaintances, and other voters connected by satellite links from five cities, allowed Mr. Clinton to expound upon his favorite topics.
 
Finding the Right Word
 A saleswoman in the New York audience asked about restoring confidence. "One word," Mr. Clinton said, "investment. Change the tax system so there is more incentive for people to invest, corporation and individual. Spend more of the tax dollars you give the Government investing instead of just squandering. Invest to create jobs, generate wealth. That's the best way to build consumer confidence."
Mr. Clinton returned to this theme repeatedly, following the advice of campaign strategists who say he needs to drive home a few select points.
Mr. Clinton said for the first time that he would not rule out imposing an import fee on oil, a measure supported by the domestic petroleum industry but opposed in the areas of the country where residents are dependent on oil.
He also said he would recommend "significantly modifying" the 1986 revision of the tax code because it focused too little attention on investment tax credits and other provisions that he said would help the economy.
 
A New Kind of 'Badge'
 At the same time, the Arkansas Governor used his status as leader of a small, poor state, a status he once described as a liability in national politics, as a badge of honor.
"I've been on the outside of this," Mr. Clinton said. "I've been in Little Rock, Ark., balancing my budget, developing a partnership with business, creating manufacturing jobs, educating, doing the things that we as Presidents should do. And I understand the frustration people have."
Mr. Clinton has scheduled taped or live appearances on the Cable News Network, ABC, NBC and MTV within the next week.
Yesterday, the Governor told almost everyone what they wanted to hear. He advocated tax relief as well as new tax incentives. He said he favored expanding education programs but pledged to streamline government bureaucracy. He promised that he would maintain a strong defense while reducing military spending. And he told a representative of B'nai B'rith that he opposed the creation of a Palestinian state.
 
A Need for Discipline
 He said the initiatives he has proposed could be paid for out of a combination of budget cuts and new investment. "The economic investments would logically be paid for by being very disciplined about what you do with defense cuts," he said.
But the Governor also said that he was not yet ready to call for a repeal of the luxury tax unless it was tied to increased tax rates on corporations and the wealthy, and that he was not "prepared to embrace" a plan to help the domestic automobile industry by reinstituting Federal tax deductions for interest on consumer loans.
Most of the two-hour program was warm and appeared to be dominated by representatives of interest groups or questioners who were familiar with and friendly toward Mr. Clinton.
He received applause twice: when he said that he favored a woman's right to choose abortion and when he said that he would lift Federal regulations that prohibit federally financed clinics from dispensing abortion advice.
Mr. Clinton and his aides said they were happy that the candidate had begun answering real questions from real people who care little about issues that have preoccupied the press.
"It's different," Mr. Clinton said as he was leaving the West 57th Street studio. "They asked questions which to you are old news, but to them are new. The American people are still just, a lot of them, digesting this election."
By using his televised forums to focus on what he plans to do to revive the economy, Mr. Clinton hopes to demonstrate that he has the ideas he says Mr. Perot lacks, and the ability to take action that he says President Bush has not shown.

HEADLINE: New York's Senior Representative to Retire

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
In the third blow in a week to New York State's influence in Congress, Representative Frank Horton, the dean of the state's Congressional delegation who faced a tough re-election battle because of redistricting, announced today that he was retiring.
The 72-year-old Congressman -- whose 30 years in the House spanned seven Presidents, five Speakers and four minority leaders -- said he had pondered retirement for "some time" but made the decision on Sunday after discussing it with his wife. 
 Mr. Horton, a Rockefeller Republican who voted with liberal Democrats more often than with the Bush or Reagan Administrations, said he did not want to run against a longtime friend, Representative Louise M. Slaughter, a Democrat, his likely opponent under a redistricting plan adopted by the State Legislature. The two currently represent districts that include parts of Rochester.
 
'That's Enough'
 "If I'd had the same district, I wouldn't even have thought about it, I would have run willy-nilly," Mr. Horton said in an interview after announcing his decision to retire in a nearly empty House chamber. "None of the things I've been doing are finished. But with redistricting, you have to think about it. There comes a time when you have to do something for yourself. After 30 years, that's enough."
The ranking Republican on the Government Operations Committee, Mr. Horton had an important, though unpublicized, influence on the operation of the Federal Government. He was instrumental in placing inspectors general -- financial watchdogs -- in Federal departments and in passing the 1989 Whistleblower Protection Act, which guards Federal employees who expose waste, fraud and abuse from reprisals.
"What was most extraordinary about Frank is his style: Frank prefers accomplishments that will help people rather than insider partisan squabbling that leads nowhere," said John Conyers Jr., the Michigan Democrat who is the chairman of the Government Operations Committee and who would often spend time with his colleague debating jazz and baseball. "He is a coalition builder, a problem solver and a team strategist."
Known as one of the least partisan representatives, Mr. Horton was an expert in maneuvering New York representatives onto important Congressional committees, and he often boasted he was the only minority member ever to serve as chairman of a state Congressional delegation.
 
Voter Dissatisfaction
 Mr. Horton's decision adds to the upheaval reverberating through the House in the wake of mushrooming voter dissatisfaction and the checking scandal. So far, 71 Representatives have announced their retirement or have been defeated in primaries, insuring the greatest turnover in the House since World War II.
The wholesale turnover is likely to be particularly difficult for New York State and for the New York metropolitan area, which by most measurements receives less Federal money per capita than almost any other region. National population shifts have cost the state three seats, the most in the country. In addition, New Jersey is to lose one. That means an 8.3 percent drop in the size of the two states' delegation.
"The impact for New York is that California is going to eat our lunch," said Representative Slaughter, who now appears to have a clear path to re-election. "We're not only losing people, we're losing seniority." California is gaining seven seats under redistricting for a total of 52.
Mr. Horton is the third member of the state delegation to announce his retirement in the last week. He follows Representative David O'B. Martin of Canton, a veteran Republican who has used his seat on the Armed Services Committee to win Federal money for his economically distressed, upstate district, and Representative Raymond J. McGrath of Valley Stream, L.I., a practical-minded moderate who focused on local concerns and the seventh-ranking Republican on the Ways and Means Committee.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Excerpts From Clinton's Remarks in Appearance on a CBS Program

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from remarks by Gov. Bill Clinton on the CBS News program "This Morning" in a question-and-answer session with an audience. 
 ROSS PEROT
I think the Perot phenomenon -- I don't know about Perot because he hasn't told us what he would do or what he believes on so many issues -- but the phenomenon happened because the American people were disappointed and frustrated and angry that nothing gets done in Washington. And they think both parties are to blame, and I think they're right about that. Although I think if you want to be President, if you want to be the lead dog in the hunt -- the Republicans have craved the White House successfully all these last two and a half decades -- you have to take primary responsibility for the country.
So I don't want to get into that. My campaign was long before Ross Perot and was started when George Bush was at 70 percent, because I didn't think we had responsible leadership and because I wanted to change the direction of my party and the Republican President.
STUDENT FINANCIAL AID
I would scrap the existing student loan program. The student loan program we have today costs you $3 billion in defaulted loans. So what I would do is to set up a new loan program that would take the best of two great American ideas: the G.I. Bill and the Peace Corps. I would set up a national service trust fund and let any American borrow the money they need to go to college, any American, because it's very important people go and stay.
Then after college they would pay it back in one of two ways, either as a small percentage of income at tax time every year, so if you wanted to be a teacher, you wouldn't be discouraged from being a teacher because you had a big student loan, because your payback would be a percentage of your income; or by giving two years of service to our country here at home. Go back to your hometown and work at a reduced rate, just like a Peace Corps volunteer would, except rebuild America. Be a teacher. Be a police officer. Work in a drug program. Keep kids out of gangs. Do things that need to be done in your community.
If you do that for two years at a reduced salary, then you don't owe any money any more. We could educate a whole generation of Americans and solve a lot of our social problems.
AIDS
First I'm going to put one person in charge. We need to treat this problem as a major national health problem for all Americans. It is very rapidly growing. It is going into the entire country, into all the populations. We are still denying the dimensions of the problem.
Second thing I will do is to fund the Ryan White Act. The third thing I want to do is to implement the recommendations which have already been made from the AIDS commission. They filed two good reports.
The fourth thing we've got to do is to broaden the research and development efforts, especially to include more women and minorities, where the AIDS rates are growing at a very rapid rate.
And finally I think we've got to redouble our efforts at education and prevention.
SEX DISCRIMINATION
I'm going to make it clear that we will not tolerate sexual harassment in the Federal workplace. And I'm going to appoint people to positions in Government, both women and men, who will speak out against gender bias and sexual discrimination and will work against it and will live and act against it. I think it is a big, big problem still in this country.
MILITARY BUDGET CUTS
First we need to define the defense we need. What will it take for us to be the strongest country in the world still? And we need to pay for that. We know we don't need as many troops in Europe. We know the Germans and the Japanese should pay more of their own way. We know we may not need 12 carrier groups. We may not need all the weapon systems. What do we need?
Second thing we've got to do is take every dollar by which we reduce defense and invest it in converting from a defense to a domestic economy so that the factory workers and the scientists and the technicians have jobs in this economy.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Vehicle Sales Rose 4.2% in Early June

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 15

 BODY:
Sales of cars and light trucks made in North America increased 4.2 percent in early June, picking up momentum as consumers seemed to grow more confident about the economy.
Light-truck sales jumped 11.4 percent in the June 1-10 period, which offset a drop of two-tenths of 1 percent in car sales. It was the third consecutive 10-day period in which vehicle sales exceeded levels of a year earlier. 
 "It really signifies that the recovery is for real and there is some substance to it," said John Kirnan, an auto industry analyst with Salomon Brothers Inc. in New York. "I have a very difficult time seeing how this recovery can be short-circuited, short of external factors such as an oil crisis."
 
Old Cars on the Road
 He credited the increased demand to the aging of cars on the road, increased consumer confidence and lower personal debt. The average age of cars and trucks on American roads is at an all-time high, about eight years for cars and eight and a half years for trucks, Mr. Kirnan said.
The domestic auto makers sold cars and trucks at a daily rate of 34,664, compared with 33,277 for the June 1-10 period last year. There were nine selling days in the period this year and eight last year.
Car and truck sales by the Big Three rose 2.7 percent, while sales of Japanese vehicles made in North America soared 19.4 percent.
For the year, total vehicle sales are up 6.3 percent from the rate a year earlier. Sales of the Ford Motor Company, the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation rose a combined 6.7 percent. Sales of the Japanese "transplants" were up 3.9 percent.
For the 10-day period, Ford's sales rose 8.6 percent. The company's car sales were up 6.3 percent and its truck sales increased 11.7 percent.
G.M.'s sales were down 1.7 percent, with car sales falling 3.9 percent and truck sales rising 2.7 percent.
Ward's Automotive Reports estimated that Chrysler's sales rose 5 percent, with an 11.7 percent increase in light-truck sales offsetting an 18.8 percent decline for cars; Chrysler reports its sales once a month.
 
 
Junky Trade-Ins
 Dealers say they were seeing more optimistic shoppers in early June.
"The first 10 days of June were phenomenal," said James Basil, general manager of Basil Chevrolet in Depew, N.Y., outside Buffalo. "The people coming in were in a much better frame of mind and more confident about the economy."
His sales increase was caused in part by a three-day promotion with nearby dealers. Mr. Basil said many buyers offered junky old cars as trade-ins.
"A lot of the cars we took in were older cars -- '85-'86 and older," he said. "There weren't many we could resell. Some people were buying new cars out of necessity."
Chrysler's jump in truck sales was spurred by a rebate of up to $2,100 on the popular Plymouth Voyager mini-van. The rebate expires on Monday.
"It's been like Christmas," said Alan Helfman, general manager of River Oaks Chrysler-Plymouth in Houston. "I have a smile on my face every day I come to work."
Mr. Helfman said the hot sales had nearly depleted his supply of Voyagers. "I don't even need this rebate, I'm doing so well," he said.
Among Japanese auto makers, Toyota's early-June sales were up 52.7 percent. Isuzu's sales rose 9.4 percent, while Mazda's increased 43.7 percent; Mitsubishi's gained 85 percent and Nissan's rose 16 percent. Honda's sales fell 4.9 percent, and Subaru's were down 3.8 percent.

HEADLINE: Most Stocks Decline, but Dow Is Up 0.54

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks edged higher yesterday, but declining shares outnumbered gainers in the broad market amid fears about the health of the United States economy and weakness in overseas stocks.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed with a gain of 0.54 point at 3,354.90. Declining shares outpaced advances 932 to 742 on moderate New York Stock Exchange volume of 164.1 million shares, compared with 181.9 million shares Friday. 
 "The recovery is laboring," said Hersh Cohen, president of Shearson Asset Management. "There's justifiable concern about its durability and vigor."
He said that while stable interest rates are a plus for the market, many investors think stock prices are too high. With no consistent trend to the equity market, "it's very difficult to get terrifically excited about one group or stock," he said.
Lingering concern about corporate earnings -- revived by a disappointing second-quarter forecast by the Monsanto Company -- also diluted buying interest.
A sharp 2.5 percent drop in Tokyo's 225-share Nikkei index had little impact on Wall Street despite fears of a spillover, analysts said.
Light bargain-hunting helped blue chips late in the session, analysts said.
Tom Callahan, an executive vice president at Yamaichi International, said, "There is an element of confusion out there." He added that some investors were hesitant about buying depressed growth stocks but unwilling to commit more money to cyclicals.
"The concern is that the consumer sector is not coming back, and the consumer is a big part of the economic recovery," he said.
Bob Walberg, an analyst at MMS International, said the mixed performance might suggest the market was trying to consolidate.
But he added, "There are very few reasons to get excited about the market." He expects stocks may sell off again this week.
Telefonos de Mexico fell 1 7/8, to 50, on worries about the union's plans for its stake in the company and concern about Ross Perot's negative position on free trade with Mexico.
Monsanto slumped 5, to 54. It said that second-quarter profits would be below analysts' estimates and that it would be taking a charge of 21 cents a share to cover a settlement on a Superfund cleanup site.
 
Inquiry Into Tobacco Concerns
 Philip Morris Companies dropped 1 1/4, to 73; American Brands lost 3/8, to 47, and RJR Nabisco eased 1/4, to 9 3/8. after reports of a criminal investigation into possible misleading research by several tobacco companies.
The Penn Central Corporation rose 1 3/4, to 21 3/4. Salomon Brothers initiated coverage with a buy rating.
A County NatWest analyst repeated an underperform rating on Whirlpool Corporation, which fell 1 1/2, to 35.
After tumbling sharply Friday, Ross Cosmetics rebounded 2 1/4, to 7 1/4. The company said its accounting practices, which United States regulators are investigating, are sound.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 0.53, to 410.29, but stocks of mostly smaller companies represented by the Nasdaq composite shed 0.51 point, to 569.01.
The American Stock Exchange index fell 2.54, to 388.78.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index of all listed common stocks rose 0.11 point, to 225.62. The average share gained 2 cents.

HEADLINE: Thrift Is Under Siege in Japan As Use of Credit Cards Soars

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 12

 BODY:
For years the Japanese have been unwavering in their devotion to thrift, regarding personal savings as a measure of national strength. Then they met credit cards.
Now the world's most fervent savers have discovered not just the joys of shopping with plastic but, in soaring numbers, the burdens of indebtedness. 
 Credit card use is still modest by Western standards. About 200 million cards are in use here, where the population is 124 million, compared with more than a billion of all types in the United States, where the population is twice the size. But the number of cards being issued, the amount of debt card holders are carrying and the number of individual bankruptcies are rising at a pace far greater than in the United States, doubling in the last year.
 
A Lure for the Young
 Credit cards are particularly popular among the young. Newspapers and magazines have been reporting that newlyweds and first-time job holders sometimes get more than a dozen cards from companies eager to lengthen their membership lists. The press recently told the tale of a university student who began to buy textbooks and clothes with his first cards, and swiftly found himself with 21 cards and nearly $40,000 in debt.
The Japan Credit Counseling Association, which advises people unable to manage their debt, says about 53 percent of the people seeking help are age 20 to 29, up from 31 percent five years ago.
Yet the problems are not threatening the financial health of credit card companies. In fact, the default rate on card payments is said to total only about 1 percent, less than half the level in the United States. But public fretting has begun over what some people see as a decline in the discipline that they believe made Japan strong.
"Young people today are excessively protected by their parents," said Kichizo Sakamoto, executive director of the counseling association, which was founded with Government help six years ago. "People of my generation, in their 50's and 60's, went through the war. We experienced hard times. But young people don't have that experience and so they have different attitudes."
Many young people acknowledge this generational shift, which they say is a sign of how Japan's affluence is altering society's standards.
"The saving ethic has changed," said Toshihiro Ikeda, assistant manager of corporate planning at the JCB Company, the country's largest credit card issuer. "In the postwar years the slogan was always: savings is a virtue. Spending is a virtue: that's the new moral."
To get a sense of how shocking some older Japanese find the trend, one needs only to recall the contempt with which Government officials have referred in the past to what they see as one of America's gravest weaknesses, an overreliance on credit.
In the trade negotiations that were known as the Structural Impediments Initiative, Japan suggested that the United States could begin to rebuild its economy in part by limiting the number of credit cards consumers would be permitted to hold.
"Japanese consider bankruptcy very seriously, something that might force people to sneak out of town in the dead of night or consider family suicide," Michio Watanabe, who is now the Foreign Minister, told members of the governing Liberal Democratic Party in 1988, when he was a senior party official. He added, in a statement that spoke volumes about Japanese attitudes about the United States, "Among those guys over there, where credit card use is rampant, there are so many blacks and so on who think nonchalantly, 'We're bankrupt, so from tomorrow on we just don't have to pay anything back.' "
Last year, 23,491 Japanese filed for personal bankruptcy, more than double the level just a year earlier. Officials say the figure is likely to rise another 50 percent this year.
Meanwhile, the amount of cash borrowed on credit cards -- at interest rates of about 30 percent a year -- doubled from 1986 to 1990, the latest year for which figures are available, to 39.5 trillion yen ($311 billion).
To be sure, Japan's savings rate remains extremely high by international standards, at about 13.5 percent. But that is down significantly from 18 percent in 1981. By contrast, Americans in recent months have been saving about 5 percent of their disposable income.
Many Japanese business executives, while noting the enthusiasm with which the Japanese are embracing consumption, say the policies of the credit card companies themselves are a big part of the problem. Seeking to build market share, they have been flooding the country with plastic; some department stores and finance companies issue cards the day the application is received.
Commonly, 500,000 yen ($4,000) is the minimum credit extended, even to young people. And with an interest rate of 30 percent on unpaid balances, the sums owed can rise swiftly.
"Some of the problem lies in the screening that we do when people apply for card membership," said Mr. Ikeda of JCB. "Not enough information is collected."
 
Credit Reporting Is Poor
 Indeed, by American standards the credit card companies are operating blindly. In the United States, the companies have access to data bases that provide a full credit history of card applicants, including their level of borrowings from other sources, the number of credit cards they hold and records of repayment. In Japan, the card companies do not share information and generally have access only to the names of those who have filed for bankruptcy or have defaulted on large debts.
Nobuaki Terasaka, the director of the commercial and consumer credit office at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, said the Government had belatedly recognized how primitive the information systems were and was working with companies to give them better data to screen out problem card holders.
"The flip side of the coin is that not only is there not a well-developed credit information network but there is not a good credit collection system either," said Stephen B. Friedman, president of the Asia Pacific region for American Express International. "It isn't easier to make collections here than anywhere else, and it's probably more difficult."
 
How to Avoid Paying Debts
 Card holders use a variety of strategies to avoid repayment and, at times, dig themselves deeper into debt, industry officials say. Some people simply shift the debt from card to card, borrowing from one to pay off the other. Many industry officials say that when confronted, a relatively large number of debtors simply refuse to pay, declaring the bills are wrong or that a friend made the charges.
Changes in personal habits and society aside, the nation's economic slump, which many economists call a recession, has been a factor. The collapse of stock and real estate prices after the boom of the 1980's has put many consumers on the defensive by wiping out their investments.
But many experts regard the immature state of the credit card industry as simply a reflection of the generally underdeveloped state of most consumer services in Japan, particularly when compared with the technology available to manufacturers.
In spite of all the talk in recent years of giving the long-suffering consumer more attention, the Japanese still pay among the highest prices in the world when they go shopping.
"Very early after I arrived here what I learned is that you cannot say the consumer is the low person on the totem pole," said Mr. Friedman of American Express. "He isn't even on the totem pole."
Mr. Terasaka of the trade ministry said the Government had begun a campaign involving consumer education and better controls at the credit card companies to remedy the situation and ease the public anxieties about Japan's moral fiber.
"Many people want to blame just those with debts, but we don't feel that way," he said. "The credit card companies are responsible for helping them understand how to use credit cards wisely."

HEADLINE: Court Backs Old Standard On State Tax

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
In an important corporate tax case, the Supreme Court today reaffirmed its longstanding approach to state taxation of the income of companies that are based outside a state but that conduct some business within the state's borders.
The case had been closely watched because the Court had indicated that it might abandon this approach, known as the unitary business principle, and give states much more latitude to reach a portion of a multistate company's income that was not related to the company's in-state operations. 
 But the Court unanimously refused to rewrite the rules, and then, by a 5-to-4 vote, declared that New Jersey had transgressed those limits by taxing a portion of the capital gains the Bendix Corporation earned from its 1981 sale of a 20 percent stake in Asarco Inc.
The decision overturned a ruling by the New Jersey Supreme Court, which upheld the $1.8 million tax bill last year. The state court ruled that the stock sale, part of an aggressive investment strategy that Bendix carried out under its chief executive, William M. Agee, was integrally related to the overall operations of the company, part of its "unitary business" although not directly connected to any of its New Jersey operations.
Writing for the majority today, Justice Anthony M. Kennedy said that the New Jersey Supreme Court had misinterpreted the unitary business principle. It was not enough to identify the company's investment strategy, he said. To tax a portion of an out-of-state company's investment income, Justice Kennedy said, a state would have to show that the transaction served "an operational rather than an investment function," which was not the case with the Bendix stake in Asarco.
The two companies did not integrate their managements, he noted, and conducted unrelated businesses. "The mere fact that an intangible asset was acquired pursuant to a long-term corporate strategy of acquisitions and dispositions does not convert an otherwise passive investment into an integral operational one," Justice Kennedy said.
 
Takeover Battle
 The Bendix strategy, in fact, failed. Mr. Agee tried to use the $212 million capital gain from the Asarco sale to acquire the Martin Marietta Company, but his plan was thwarted when Martin Marietta and Allied-Signal Inc. bought up Bendix stock. Bendix is now a wholly owned subsidiary of Allied-Signal, which filed the appeal of the New Jersey ruling. The case was Allied-Signal v. Director, New Jersey Division of Taxation, No. 91-615.
The case, which was initially argued March 4, was viewed as fairly routine until a week later, when the Court unexpectedly ordered a new argument and expanded its inquiry from the facts of the case to the underlying principles at stake. The Justices posed a series of questions for the new argument, which was held April 22, including "what constitutional principles should govern state taxation of corporations doing business in several states?" and whether a new rule, if adopted, should apply retroactively.
In response to this invitation, New Jersey contended that the Court should abandon the unitary business principle and replace it with a rule permitting a state to tax a portion of all income from whatever source of a corporation that does any business in the state.
The Court's retreat from its open invitation was swift. "New Jersey's sweeping theory cannot be reconciled with the concept that the Constitution places limits on a state's power to tax value earned outside of its borders," Justice Kennedy said.
He added that the Court's doctrine of adherence to its own precedents was particularly strong on an issue such as this one, because both states and taxpayers in their planning had relied on what seemed to be a well-settled rule of law. "New Jersey's proposal would disrupt settled expectations in an area of the law in which the demands of the national economy require stability," Justice Kennedy said.
In reaffirming its traditional approach, however, the Court today did not necessarily inject much clarity into what has been a confusing and contentious area of tax law.
The 5-to-4 split on the Court over how to apply the general principles to the specific facts of the Bendix dispute was an indication that many cases such as this will come down to factual disputes, to be resolved at the highest administrative or judicial level to which a taxpayer is willing to take its case.
 
Taking Sides
 In ruling for Allied-Signal, Justice Kennedy was joined by Justices Byron R. White, John Paul Stevens, Antonin Scalia and David H. Souter.
Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote a dissenting opinion that was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Harry A. Blackmun and Clarence Thomas. They said that Allied-Signal had not proved that the Bendix capital gains from the Asarco sale were not "operationally related" to the business Bendix conducted in New Jersey.
Phil Tatarowicz, a state tax expert in the Chicago office of Ernst & Young, said the decision today insured that such cases would remain "fact driven" and that both states and companies would face "tremendous burdens" in developing their sides of tax disputes.

HEADLINE: Robert William Haack, 75, Dies; Led Stock Exchange During Crises

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Robert William Haack, who led the New York Stock Exchange during a period of crisis and change and later became the chairman of the Lockheed Corporation, died on Sunday at his home in Potomac, Md. He was 75 years old.
Mr. Haack died of complications from kidney failure, his family said. 
 A tall, amiable Midwesterner with a talent for public speaking, Mr. Haack in 1967 left the presidency of the National Association of Securities Dealers, where he had served for three years, to take the top full-time post at the New York Stock Exchange. A longtime stockbroker, Mr. Haack was viewed on Wall Street as the perfect choice to lead the nation's largest stock exchange after more than a decade of growth.
In his early years as the new spokesman for Wall Street, Mr. Haack was faced with enormous upheaval. The boom years were beginning to wear on Wall Street, with average daily volume on the exchange having grown from 1.7 million shares traded to more than 10 million shares. Unable to handle the flood of paperwork churned out by the steady growth, the exchange was forced to begin closing one and a half hours earlier.
 
Emphasis on Automation
 He put a high priority on development of several automation programs, including one intended to reduce the physical movement of securities from one brokerage house to another.
That push toward automation has had long-term repercussions on Wall Street and still wins Mr. Haack praise today. "Among his many accomplishments was to bring technology to the back office, a bold initiative that laid the foundation for today's high-tech securities industry," William H. Donaldson, the current chairman and chief executive of the Big Board, said yesterday.
As the 1960's drew to a close, Wall Street began to experience its greatest crisis since the Depression. Between 1968 and 1970, as the boom in stocks gave weight to a bear market, dozens of brokerage firms, including nationally known names such as Hayden, Stone, Inc. and F. I. du Pont, collapsed or were forced into mergers. With public confidence in the brokerage industry shaken, Mr. Haack worked with Congress to develop the Securities Investor Protection Corporation, or S.I.P.C.
The new corporation provided much-needed security to investors who had begun to fear they would lose their savings if their brokerage concerns collapsed.
 
Issue of Commission Rates
 Mr. Haack's aggressive work on behalf of the industry, as well as his deep roots on Wall Street, did not slow the criticism he generated on Wall Street for attacking some of the industry's sacred cows. In a controversial speech before the Economic Club of New York on Nov. 17, 1970, Mr. Haack, saying that the exchange was no longer "the only game in town," publicly called for reform of the New York Stock Exchange itself, proposing that the management of the Big Board be reorganized to open up an institution that until then had been something of a private club.
The speech, which split the leadership of the securities industry and led to some calls for Mr. Haack's dismissal, also attacked fixed commission rates, which were then the lifeblood of Wall Street. Commission rates were the prices paid by the public to brokerage houses for buying or selling stocks. Under the system in effect at the time, the New York Stock Exchange effectively set the minimum rates for the entire industry, blocking competition for lower-cost producers.
While the speech alienated some members of the Board of Governors, it proved to be prophetic. Fixed commission rates were abandoned in May 1975, in what is widely regarded as one of the most significant changes in the industry's history. The change has allowed greater competition among brokers.
Mr. Haack was born on Feb. 15, 1917, in Milwaukee. He graduated from Hope College in Holland, Mich., in 1938 and from Harvard Business School in 1940. That year he began his career in the securities industry as a stockbroker with Robert W. Baird & Company in Milwaukee.
In 1976, in the wake of the international bribery scandals involving Lockheed and other American corporations, Mr. Haack was named chairman of the financially troubled company, a post he held for 20 months. During that time, he worked to restore confidence in the company and revised its finances based around a Federal loan guarantee.
Mr. Haack is survived by his wife, the former Ann Thornett Miller; a son, Thomas, of Darien, Conn.; three daughters, Barbara Sexton of Greenwich, Conn., and Elizabeth Barr and Linda Brooks, both of Potomac, and six grandchildren.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends the Day Mixed; Gold Flat to Slightly Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mixed against leading currencies yesterday and reached a five-month low against the Swiss franc as dealers grew cautious about the future of European unity.
Gold prices were unchanged to marginally higher. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $343.10 per troy ounce, up 20 cents from Friday. The Republic National Bank said gold held steady at a late bid price of $342.50 an ounce. 
 Switzerland's lack of membership in the European Community is apparently helping the Swiss franc as traders grow hesitant ahead of Ireland's referendum Thursday on the Maastricht treaty. The Irish vote is the treaty's first test since Danish voters rejected the blueprint for European political and economic union. Among other changes, the accord calls for a single currency by 1999.
The dollar was quoted at 1.4150 Swiss francs late in New York, down from late Friday's 1.4265. The dollar reached an intraday low of 1.4085 Swiss francs, the lowest level since an intraday low of 1.4015 francs Jan. 24.
The dollar rose around midday against the German mark as short- sellers, those who had sold borrowed dollars for marks hoping for a weaker dollar, bought the United States currency to cover their positions, traders said. By early afternoon the dollar fell again on profit taking by investors who were betting the dollar would strengthen.
The dollar finished at 1.5710 German marks, down from Friday's late rate of 1.5760.
Despite the activity with the mark and the Swiss franc, trading was largely quiet, dealers said. With little significant United States economic news due this week, the market should remain quiet until Thursday's vote, said Brian Welch, a foreign exchange trader at Barclays Bank in New York.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 126.72 yen, up 0.05 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 126.80 yen. In late trading in New York, the dollar fetched 126.80 yen, up from 126.60 late Friday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.8560, from $1.8550 late Friday. In New York it cost $1.8565 to buy one pound, more expensive than Friday's $1.8510.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Are Mostly Flat

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices were mostly unchanged yesterday in uneventful trading.
The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond was unchanged and its yield was 7.85 percent, the same as late Friday. 
 The market had little reaction to a report of slightly stronger-than-expected sales of domestic cars and trucks in early June.
 
May Housing Report
 Instead, the market was awaiting the Government's report today on housing construction in May, which should provide some important clues on the economy's performance. Economists generally expect the data to show an increase but not a significant rise after a sharp decline in April.
An increase may solidify the belief of many traders that the Federal Reserve does not plan to lower interest rates soon, said Ray Stone, managing director of Stone & McCarthy Research Associates Inc. in Princeton, N.J.
At the Treasury's weekly auction, interest rates on short-term securities fell to the lowest level in four weeks.
The Treasury Department sold $11.7 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 3.66 percent and yield of 3.74 percent. Another $11.7 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 3.75 percent, with a yield of 3.88 percent.
In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, short-term maturities were unchanged to up 1/32 point, intermediate maturities rose 1/16 point and long-term issues were unchanged, Telerate Inc., the financial information service, reported.
The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 0.33, to 1,231.55.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 3.70 percent, as the discount slipped three basis points, to 3.63 percent. Yields on six-month bills slipped to 3.86 percent, as the discount held at 3.75 percent. Yields on one-year bills held at 4.11 percent, as the discount gained one basis point, to 3.95 percent.
 
Federal Funds Rate Rises
 A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was quoted at 3 7/8 percent, up from 311/16 percent late Friday.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 9611/32 , up 1/32 point. The average yield to maturity was 6.59 percent, down from 6.60 percent late Friday.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
Scrabble's Word Nerds Live for the Perfect Mix

BYLINE: By Andrew H. Malcolm

DATELINE: WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP, N.J.

 BODY:
THIS is a column about Scrabble and the raczy pleope who play it.
That engrossing word game, invented by an unemployed Poughkeepsie archteict, initially manufactured by a Connecticut ocuepl and now promoted by a Long Island mna, has just moved into its seventh decade of sccuess.
All right, the first two decades weren't so sccuessluf. But after the mid-50's Scrabble sales took off. Today, the National Scrabble Association says, 33 million North Americans play the game. Atlanta, practicing for the Olympics, gets the national Scrabble championship this August. We're talking gib money -- $10,000 for first place. 
 Playing or watching Scrabble is addictive because everyone -- not just newspaper editors -- loves to spot scrambled letters and try to unscramble a word. Scrabble harnesses the relentless human urge to kibitz to a board with 225 squares and 100 letter tiles, including 12 E's, 9 A's and one J, K, Q, X and Z. (Scrabble doesn't harm the profits of the Milton Bradley Company either.)
Unless you just arrived from the planet Pluto, you know that each Scrabble letter (to start, you draw seven from a bag) is worth from one point for an R or E up to 10 for Z or Q. Scores are multiplied if a word falls on a double or triple letter or word square. And using all seven letters on one turn earns 50 bonus points, causing some players to think better of themselves for days.
We all know fitness fetishists and gardening gurus who offer animated insights into their avocations, even without being asked. (By the way, "gurus" would earn 15 points on a triple-word square, but then you wouldn't have your U's to use with the Q. See, there are only nine Q words that don't need a U. But you probably knew that already.)
Chess gets all the brainy parlor-game PR. Scrabble's word nerds are a forgotten minority, a quiet contemplative bunch that can cackle with self-congratulation and read dictionaries for fun. Scrabble players are obviously intelligent, educated, insensitive people, the kind of competitors who quietly lay down "xu," then sit back so smug in their opponent's annihilation.
"That's a good play," says the opponent, meaning no such thing. ("Xu" is Vietnamese money. More importantly, it's 17 points across a double-letter square.)
Violence is rare at Scrabble games, although feelings are running a little warm in some chairs over an official dictionary's accidental omission of "hooty" (11 points standing by itself). No high-fives in Scrabble (too awkward at card tables).
And Scrabble players do not reek of false team modesty either. Has Jackie Millstein stopped beating her husband? "No," she says with admirable honesty. "I win most games. I started playing at 8 with my mother. She played for blood." Mrs. Millstein seems particularly eager to play Allan Millstein in the spring, when Mr. Millstein, a C.P.A., arrives home exhausted. "That," she says ruthlessly, "is not my fault" (24 points on a triple-word square).
Mrs. Millstein heads a cell of Thursday-night Scrabble sharks recently uncovered here at the Bergen County YM-YWHA. People like Len and Carole Koch, Larry Lutzker, Miriam Schrager and Matthew Pasher (who got 84 points on his first word, "voyeurs") gather each week to match word wits. "I'm really into it," said Mr. Lutzker. "I enjoy making words and friends and being social. And I can concentrate while relaxing." (He was even more relaxed after beating Mr. Koch, 274 to 210.)
The group plays two games before the janitor arrives at 10:02, tapping his foot (only seven points by itself but better than passing, which Mrs. Millstein never does as a point of honor). Mrs. Millstein could run Scrabble schemes on riverboats. She can scan the letters eatoge, upside down, and spot a beard worth seven points.
Mrs. Millstein's highest score is 425. According to John Williams, executive director of the scrabble association in Greenport, L.I., that's not a bad amateur score. The official record score in the United States is 719 (Chris Reslock, 1982). The world record score is 725 (but he was Australian). Mr. Williams volunteered that his highest score was 515 and that he once got 149 on one play with "embossed."
Such records appear regularly in the association's newsletter, along with vocabulary-building exercises, hypothetical games and late-breaking Scrabble tournament news. Another growing phenomenon: pairs Scrabble. Pairs helps combat that dread affliction, Scrabble blindness, which causes players to look at "wnneri" and see nothing. Poor pathetic slsuo!
Mr. Williams estimates that members average 15 games a week, although, sadly, not him. His family will no longer play him, charging pedantry. "I've got to go," he says. "I'm in the middle of a game with the computer."
How's he doing? Pause.
"I'm getting killed" (38 with a double-letter, triple-word).

HEADLINE: Bridge

BYLINE: By Alan Truscott

 BODY:
A women's team match played in Corpus Christi, Tex., a week ago in the Pan-American Championships had a meaning on two levels, one of which escaped the attention of the officials, the press and the players most concerned.
In a match that ended at 2 A.M., but was not scored, for technical reasons, until 4 A.M., a team consisting of Gail Greenberg, Dorothy Truscott, Judy Tucker, Lisa Berkowitz, Randi Montin and Pam Wittes eked out a win by 7 imps. This team then went on to win the Pan-American title. 
 The losing team, which had qualified a month earlier to represent the United States in the 1992 world championship to be played in Italy in August, included Jacqui Mitchell, who has been vying with Truscott for many years, in a friendly New York City rivalry between ex-teammates, for the title of world's top-ranked woman player.
Mitchell had a small lead in world master points from 1986 to 1987, and it went unnoticed that the players were exactly tied between 1987 and 1990. Mitchell then gained 2 points for placing 65th in a world championship in Geneva, an example of the inflation that affects bridge players as well as consumers around the world. Truscott's victory in Corpus Christi gave her 8 points and a 6-point lead, putting her back in the top spot that she held from 1978 to 1986. But Mitchell is likely to strike back in August, for her team will be among the favorites in Italy. (The World Bridge Federation has recently complicated matters by deciding to multiply all master points by a factor of 10).
In the diagramed deal, played a year ago in a major team event, Truscott demonstrated a playing maneuver that is often overlooked. She reached four spades as shown, after West had made a weak jump in clubs, and the club ace was led.
A shift to diamonds, allowing the defense to take two quick tricks in that suit, would no doubt have defeated the contract, and did in the replay: South had no reason to know that the heart queen was in the West hand, and took a normal finesse in that suit.
Against Truscott, however, West persevered with a second club in the hope that East could ruff. After winning with the king, South drew trumps by leading to the ace and cashed the ace and king of hearts. This was a safe way to guard against the possibility of a doubleton queen in the West hand.
As it happened this play provided two overtricks, for both dummy's diamonds were discarded on heart winners. But the contract would have been safe whenever East held the heart queen, for South would have crossed to dummy with a trump and led a heart. West would have had no chance to lead a diamond, and the heart jack would have provided a discard for a diamond loser in the dummy.
