HEADLINE: Dow Drops 25.41, Ending At 3,329.49

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Stock prices fell yesterday, as blue-chip issues dropped sharply in the late afternoon from futures-related selling and mounting worries about the economy.
The Dow Jones industrial average finished 25.41 points lower, to 3,329.49, with losing issues overtaking gaining ones, 952 to 775, on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 Big Board volume totaled 194.4 million shares, up from 164.1 million on Monday, as the exchange's composite index fell 0.90 point, to 224.72.
 
Broader Market Lower
 Broader gauges also declined. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 1.97, to 408.32, and the American Stock Exchange composite index declined 2.66, to 386.12. In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index finished 4.94 lower at 564.07.
Although the Government reported a sharp rebound in housing starts and a fourth straight rise in industrial production last month, investors are nervous that the slow pace of recovery will dilute corporate earnings.
"The stock market is viewed as the best investment vehicle at this time," said Edward Shopkorn, the managing director at the Mabon Securities Corporation. "But fundamentals are not so great. It's basically a market without a whole lot of conviction and a lot of concern."
 
Greenspan's Remarks
 Comments from the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, that the central bank would guard against reigniting inflation dashed hopes for any additional immediate cuts in interest rates. But in a note of encouragement, he said inflation was coming under control.
"The U.S. economy has made considerable progress toward price stability over the past decade," Mr. Greenspan said, "and it appears poised to make further advances."
Although low short-term yields in the credit markets have caused many investors to move money from certificates of deposit and money market funds and into the stock market, long-term rates remain high enough to cause anxiety about the health of the recovery.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 7/32 point, or $2.19 per $1,000 of face amount, sending the yield to 7.83 percent, from 7.85 percent on Monday.
"It's been a very difficult market from a trading standpoint," Mr. Shopkorn said. "You need to be in the right groups."
Gene Jay Seagle, an analyst at Gruntal & Company, said that although activity had been tepid, "I think we're getting close to the end of a trading range."
Mr. Tincher said he was focusing on some technology companies because of the recent decline in the sector. But he is shying away from drug stocks despite the recent battering in those issues.
Among technology issues, Compaq Computer, which introduced new lower-priced computers on Monday, lost 2 1/2, to 25. Alex. Brown & Sons cut its rating to "source of funds" from "hold" and lowered the company's earnings estimates.
Goldman, Sachs & Company removed Hewlett-Packard, another computer maker, from its recommended list. The stock fell 2, to 68 1/2.
Time Warner rose 2 1/8, to 109. Prudential Securities Inc. began its coverage with a "buy" rating.

HEADLINE: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Off

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit drifted lower in the week ended today, according to The Bank Rate Monitor.
Analysts at The Monitor noted that the yields were apparently not moved by economic indicators that suggested conditions were getting better. They said yields should coast into July, barring any abrupt action by the Federal Reserve. 
 Once again, the average decline was a little stronger among New York-area banks, marking a three-week trend.
At the auction on Monday of new three- and six-month Treasury bills, which many consider a good barometer of what banks will eventually pay their depositors, average discount rates were down to their lowest levels since May 18. The average rate on a three-month bill was 3.66 percent, down 5 basis points from the previous auction, while the six-month bill was down 8 basis points, to 3.75 percent. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
At New York-area banks, the average money market account was off a basis point, to 3.38 percent, and short-term certificates of deposit were off 2 basis points, to 3.5 percent for a three-month C.D. and 3.67 percent for a six-month.
Commercial banks, which make up one part of the New York-area average, were a little more aggressive this week than were the savings banks. Commercial banks lowered the average money market account a basis point, to 3.16 percent, and the average yield on C.D.'s by 2 basis points, to 3.35 percent on a three-month certificate and 3.44 percent on a six-month.
The move widened the difference between commercial banks and the higher-paying savings bank, which left money market accounts unchanged at 3.6 percent, while lowering a three-month C.D. 2 basis points, to 3.66 percent, and a six-month a basis point, to 3.9 percent.
The sharpest yield changes were reported at the Fleet Bank, which lowered its average money market account by 15 basis points, to 3.15 percent, and at the Republic National Bank, which cut its three-month C.D. by 15 basis points, to 3.41 percent, and its six-month certificate by 21 basis points, to 3.46 percent.
For 20 large banks outside the New York market, yields were unchanged for the average bank money market account, at 3.26 percent, and only down a basis point, to 3.61 percent, for a six-month certificate.

HEADLINE: The Less-Traveled Road to Medical School

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STONY BROOK, L.I., June 12

 BODY:
Mary Gratch spent 10 years trying to become an actress, but once she reached her goal she decided it was not enough. So now she is trying to become a doctor.
As she begins her fourth year at the School of Medicine at the State University of New York campus here, Ms. Gratch represents a future direction in medical education. In the New York region and throughout the country, educators and administrators say, medical schools have been making an effort to recruit a more diverse type of student.
 
Seeking Sensitivity
 Part of the reason for this push is the theory that applicants who know about more than physics and organic chemistry will bring a more sensitive touch to the practice of medicine. But there is also a less idealistic drive at work: as medical school applications declined sharply during the last decade, students like Ms. Gratch were one way to fill the gap. 
 Recently however, speculation has begun within the medical community about how long this trend will continue. Applications to medical school have increased during each of the last two years, a trend that admissions officers attribute to the recession, since medicine is perceived as offering job security. The increase raises questions of what chance former actors, artists, bankers, bakers, teachers and other professionals will have in the future.
"I really feel lucky I did this when I did," Ms. Gratch said. "I'm afraid that in a year or two schools will lose interest in people like me."
Although medical school administrators say they do not keep separate tallies of how many so-called nontraditional students are being admitted, most agree that the number has been increasing.
"There has been a move afoot for some time now to deliberately diversify the population of medical students," said Richard Green, a spokesman for the Association of American Medical Colleges, which last year added an essay section to the medical college admission test (MCAT). "They are trying to give people who may not consider themselves typical medical students a chance to compete. And they are trying to send a message to the typical science geeks and say you will have to know more than organic chemistry, you'll have to know how to think and write."
How well the nontraditional students do in medical school remains unclear because schools do not keep particular track of them and their grades. It is also too soon to tell how they perform as doctors since most of them have only recently graduated.
Medical schools interested in this type of student are sending their message with varying degrees of formality. At Stony Brook, for instance, which has a reputation for attracting nontraditional students, the message is spread by word of mouth. "We have let it be known that we are hospitable to people with unusual training," said Dr. Pierce Gardner, associate dean for academic affairs, "and they come find us."
 
Looking for Students
 At Mount Sinai School of Medicine, in contrast, recruiters go out and look for students. Since 1987, nearly one-quarter of the 115 spaces in each medical school class has been reserved for students with liberal arts backgrounds. Each year Kenneth D. Smith, director of the Humanities and Medicine Program at Mount Sinai, has been making regular visits to Amherst College, Williams College, Brandeis University, Wesleyan University and Princeton University to persuade liberal arts majors to try medical school.
The nontraditional students are a varied group. Some, like David Landis, knew all through college that they wanted to go to medical school but decided to take time off before they began. Mr. Landis, who is now in his fourth year at Stony Brook, graduated from the University of Chicago in 1987 and spent a year running his own bread-baking business.
Others, like Ms. Gratch, never thought about medicine until they were long out of college. After graduating from Catholic University in Washington in 1977, she spent more than 10 years working as a waitress and an actress, finally landing the job that had been her goal: a full-time position in a classical repertory company. "Once I got where I wanted to be, I realized it wasn't enough," she said. "It wasn't challenging enough mentally or emotionally. Art is a kind of a luxury and health care is a necessity. It's more important somehow."
 
A Sudden Rescue
 Lisa Sanders reached a very similar conclusion. Ms. Sanders, who has been accepted at several medical schools, spent more than 10 years as a television researcher and producer. One afternoon about four years ago, she was accompanying the CBS reporter Robert B. Arnot, who is also a medical doctor, on a story near a lake. While reciting his lines for the camera the reporter noticed a woman floating face down in the water. Still wearing his microphone Dr. Arnot jumped into the lake, dragged the woman to shore and saved her life with cardiopulmonary resuscitation.
"I watched him change from a journalist who watches things to a doctor who does things," she said. "It made me realize I'm not a person who wants to just sit around and watch."
Ms. Sanders and Ms. Gratch did what many nontraditional applicants are required to do: they returned to school to take the science classes they did not take in college. Across the country, catch-up courses are being developed to prepare these students. Before 1986 there were only 10 post-baccalaureate programs in the United States, according to Christine Yash. Ms. Yash is coordinator of such a program at Ohio State University and has compiled a directory of similar offerings at other schools. The current directory, she says, has 33 listings.
In many ways, late-medical-comers say, becoming a doctor later in life is harder than taking the more traditional route. "The students who come direct from college have advantages in the classroom," said Dr. Marianne C. Soufas, who spent 10 years as a graphic artist before entering medical school and who graduated from Stony Brook last month. "They're familiar with test-taking, they know how to memorize endless numbers of facts and pack in the kind of knowledge that you need."
 
The Advantage of Distance
 But in other ways, older students say, some distance from college is an advantage.
"I've seen the real world," said Amanda Weintraub Ratliff, who has worked as a private school teacher, a social worker and is currently a llama rancher on an island off Washington State. She will enter medical school in August. "I've gotten all that out of my system and I'm ready to focus," she said.
There is evidence that during the last decade, when the number of nontraditional students increased, the requirements for medical school admission decreased.
Schools traditionally refuse to release statistics about the admission qualifications of specific groups of students, but many administrators who run programs that provide catch-up science courses for those wishing to go to medical school say there was such a drop and it may now be turning around.
Susan Joerling, coordinator of preprofessional programs for the School of General Studies at Columbia University, which provides catch-up science courses, said the rule of thumb at her program used to be that a grade-point average of 2.8 was sufficient for acceptance to the least competitive level of medical school while applications were falling. Now that application rates have increased, she said, a 3.0 is considered necessary.
But older students and many medical school administrators argue that grades alone do not a doctor make. Nontraditional students, they say, bring qualities that modern medicine needs.
 
Not Lured by Wealth
 In general, they say, these students are not as likely to be lured by wealth. One 40-year-old banker at Chase Manhattan who will enter medical school this summer at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons in August estimates that the money he will spend for tuition combined with the income he will forgo during seven years of medical school and residency "is not far short of $1 million."
"I will never recoup that," said the banker, who asked that his name not be used because he has not yet told his employer of his plans. "Money is not the issue. I shall be disappointed if this turns out to be only another money-grubbing game."
Doctors who are not pursuing wealth are more likely to shun more lucrative medical specialties and choose primary care such as pediatrics, obstetrics-gynecology and internal medicine instead. Those are the areas in which doctors are most needed nationwide. Of the nearly two dozen nontraditional medical students and recent graduates interviewed for this article, every one planned a career in primary care.
Many said that because this was their second career they did not want to spend the additional three to five years required to specialize further. But others added that primary care was more consistent with the reason they chose to enter medicine in the first place.
Dr. David G. Lukcso was a professional ballet dancer for eight years before he entered medical school. At first he planned to be an orthopedic surgeon but is instead in the middle of his internal-medicine residency at New York Hospital. "I decided I would be of more benefit to people if I treated the whole person," he said. "Medicine is becoming too narrow and I wanted to do something more broad-based."
This different perspective is what some fear will be lost if competition for medical school continues to increase once again. Dr. Smith, at Mount Sinai, said that school is committed to maintaining up to 25 positions in each class for nontraditional students. Other admissions officers gave similar assurances.
But Ms. Joerling said she has already begun to see a change in the type of student who enrolls in Columbia's post-baccalaureate program.
"For five years we were seeing the career changer," she said. "Now we're seeing people who did the traditional science route in college but who don't think their grades are quite good enough to get into the medical school of their choice. That return to competitiveness is discouraging the less traditional student."
Ms. Sanders, who has a 3.5 grade-point average at the Columbia program, was placed on the waiting list at Yale Medical School and is deciding between Columbia and Tulane, said: "They took me because they didn't have enough 4.0 orgo grinds. If the 4.0 orgo grinds are back, they aren't going to want me."

HEADLINE: Greenspan Sees Benefits In Tying Bonds to Inflation

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 16

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that if the Treasury issued bonds with the yield indexed to inflation, it would help the Fed formulate monetary policy by giving it more information on inflation expectations.
He said that by studying the difference in the yield between indexed bonds and nonindexed bonds, the Fed would get useful information about real interest rates and investors' expectations for inflation. 
 Despite his praise for indexed bonds, Mr. Greenspan said that creating them might not be worthwhile because their benefits in setting monetary policy might be outweighed by additional costs to the Government to finance Treasury debt. He said the decision to issue such bonds should rest with the Treasury.
 
Weighing Benefits and Costs
 "Changing the composition of Federal debt issuance is not a matter to be taken lightly," he said. "Any proposal that has an impact on Treasury financing costs must clearly demonstrate that benefits exceed costs by a comfortable margin."
Testifying before the Subcommittee on Commerce, Consumer and Monetary Affairs of the House Committee on Government Operations, Mr. Greenspan said issuing such bonds presented several problems, including figuring out appropriate tax treatment and insuring that there would be sufficient investor interest.
Mr. Greenspan also made sanguine comments about inflation, saying, "The U.S. economy has made considerable progress toward price stability over the past decade, trimming the core rate of inflation to below 4 percent, and it appears poised to make further advances,"
Citing Britain's success with indexed bonds, Doug Barnard Jr., the Georgia Democrat who is chairman of the subcommittee, urged the Treasury to create such bonds, arguing that they could save the Government billions of dollars. The Treasury has repeatedly refused to issue such bonds.
 
Estimate of Savings
 Testifying after the Fed chairman, William Poole, a Brown University economics professor who served on President Ronald Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers, estimated that if the Treasury had used modest amounts of indexed bonds in the 1980's, the national debt would be $50 to $100 billion lower than it is now. He said the double-digit interest rates still being paid on bonds issued in the early 1980's were pushing up the interest payments the Federal Government has to make each year.
Some economists say a decision to issue indexed bonds might indicate to the nation that the Treasury is willing to accommodate inflation, while others have the opposite interpretation: if the Treasury issues an obligation indexed to inflation, that would give it incentives to hold down inflation.
Mr. Greenspan said the large stakes involved, given the Government's huge need for money, meant that any experiment with indexed debt must be modest. Yet, he said, the size of the bond issue must be large enough to attract adequate trading interest to insure an active secondary market for indexed debt. He said such an issue should be at least several hundred million dollars.
"The prices of indexed debt trading in a thin market would not necessarily convey a significant amount of useful information about the economy as a whole," he said.
"An accurate reading on inflation expectations could considerably aid in economic forecasting by" shedding light on wage and cost pressures and on inflationary expectations, he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
SmithKline to Market 5-in-1 Children's Vaccine

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
SmithKline Beecham, the big British-American drug maker, said yesterday that it had acquired the American rights to make and sell four vaccines, which it plans to include in a one-shot mega-vaccine against common children's diseases.
The vaccine would combine the current diphtheria-pertussis-tetanus shot with a flu immunization and a vaccine, which SmithKline already makes, against hepatitis B. 
 Analysts said the deals would push SmithKline into the front line of the $1.5 billion world vaccine market.
"The growing emphasis on preventive medicine, for both health and economic reasons, is giving vaccines an increasingly important role," said Jan Leschly, chairman of SmithKline's pharmaceuticals unit.
SmithKline, based in London and Philadelphia, said it had agreed in principle with Connaught Laboratories Inc., the American unit of Pasteur Institut Merieux of Lyons, France, to sell a Merieux flu vaccine, Haemophilus influenza type b (PRP-T), which is currently awaiting Federal regulatory approval. The agreement must be approved by the boards of the two companies.
 
Deal With Michigan
 In a separate deal, SmithKline said it would work with the Michigan Health Department to distribute vaccines developed by the state that protect against diphtheria, pertussis (whooping cough) and tetanus. SmithKline will sell the Michigan vaccines, including a rabies shot, in the 49 other states.
The company did not disclose what it was paying for the vaccines.
"A lot of companies are working on developing mega-vaccine combinations," said Rita Freedman, an analyst with the PNC Financial Corporation in Philadelphia. Among them are Merck & Company, the Lederle Laboratories unit of American Cyanamid and the Wyeth-Ayerst unit of American Home Products.
Institut Merieux is also working with Merck to develop a combination pediatric vaccine using a Merck flu vaccine, which would compete with the SmithKline project.
Samuel D. Isaly of Mehta & Isaly Worldwide Pharmaceutical Research projects that world sales of pediatric vaccines will be more than $1 billion by the late 1990's, up from about $750 million now.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Broad Declines As Traders Remain Uneasy

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed lower yesterday against major currencies as traders remained uneasy about the pace of the United States economic recovery.
Gold prices also fell. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $342.20 a troy ounce, down 90 cents from Monday. In late trading, the Republic National Bank said gold fell 50 cents, to $342 an ounce. 
 Currency traders said the market initially reacted favorably to Government reports showing that United States housing starts and industrial production had accelerated in May. But the housing report also showed that housing starts had fallen 17.3 percent in April, steeper than the 17 percent drop initially reported last month.
"The market continues to be disappointed with U.S. economic growth," said Karen Kluge, a currency trader with Credit Suisse in New York. In addition, she said, higher interest rates in Europe make European currencies more attractive than the United States currency.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 127 yen, up 0.28 yen from Monday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 126.60 yen. In New York, the dollar fell to 126.50 yen, from 126.80 yen late Monday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.8605, from $1.8560 late Monday. In New York, one pound cost $1.8645, more expensive than Monday's $1.8565.
In Europe, one dollar bought 1.5665 German marks, down from 1.5715 late Monday. In New York, the dollar traded at 1.5635 marks, down from 1.5710 marks Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday, were: 5.2650 French francs, down from 5.2905; 1,183.25 Italian lire, down from 1,189.25; 1.4045 Swiss francs, down from 1.4150, and 1.19625 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1926.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Data Signaling Recovery Ignored

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday despite economic news that pointed toward a recovery.
The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond gained 7/32 point, or $2.19 per $1,000 of face amount. Its yield declined to 7.83 percent, from 7.85 percent late Monday. Trading was light. 
 The Government released reports showing strength in the housing and manufacturing sectors. Good economic news usually pushes down bond prices because it reduces the prospects for lower interest rates.
The Commerce Department said housing starts rose 11 percent in May, partly recovering from a huge 17.3 percent decline a month earlier. The gain was the largest in more than a year.
In another report suggesting a rebound, the Federal Reserve said industrial production jumped six-tenths of 1 percent in May. The increase was the fourth in a row and the biggest since last July.
 
'Shrugging Off' Reports
 The numbers initially sent bond prices lower, but the market rebounded.
"Right now the market seems to be shrugging off" the reports of economic strength, which would normally be considered bad news for bonds, said Steven A. Wood, economist at BankAmerica Capital Markets Inc. in San Francisco.
Most investors, he said, are "not convinced the recovery is here to stay."
The market received news more to its liking in a report by Johnson Redbook indicating that June retail sales were down from May. Part of the drop was attributed to the fact that Father's Day is late this year, but the market nonetheless took the report as a sign that consumers remained reluctant to spend.
In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, short-term maturities rose 3/32 point to 7/32 point, intermediate maturities gained 3/16 point to 9/32 point and long-term issues rose as much as 13/32 point, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported.
The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all Treasury issues outstanding with maturities of a year or longer, closed at 1,233.83, up 2.28.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills issued at auction Monday fell to 3.72 percent as the discount dropped 2 basis points, to 3.64 percent. Yields on six-month bills auctioned Monday fell to 3.84 percent as the discount fell 2 basis points, to 3.73 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 4.07 percent as the discount was off 4 basis points, to 3.91 percent.
A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was quoted at 3 5/8 percent, down from 3 7/8 percent late Monday.

HEADLINE: 13 Named To Panel On Tonys

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
The administrators of the Tony Awards, who voted last week to drop 9 of the 12 members of the Tony nominating committee and to increase the committee's size, revealed the names of the new members yesterday.
They are the actors Jane Alexander, Geraldine Fitzgerald, Gretchen Cryer and Eileen Heckart; the playwright Arthur Kopit; the costume designer Donald Brooks; the set designer Oliver Smith; the choreographer and director Marge Champion; Jay Harnick, the artistic director of Theaterworks/USA, a children's theater group; Betty L. Corwin, an archivist at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts; the producers Robert Kamlot and Elizabeth I. McCann, and Sister Francesca Thompson, an associate professor of communications at Fordham University. 
 Three members of the previous nominating committee are to stay on: Ted Chapin, the executive director of the Rodgers and Hammerstein Organization; Fran Kumin, the director of artistic programs at Theater Communications Group, and Suzanne Sato, an arts administrator with the Rockefeller Foundation.
The reason for removing the nine nominators, the Tony administrators said last week, was to insure that more panel members would be working theater professionals, rather than academics, writers and arts executives. Mr. Chapin, Ms. Kumin and Ms. Sato are all arts executives.
Last Wednesday, the 24-member Tony Administration Committee also voted to limit the consecutive service of nominators to three years. Future nominators will serve for only one year and may be reappointed only twice. Previously there was no limit; some nominators served a decade or more.
 
Some Said No
 Several people who were asked to serve on the new panel declined. Robert Marx, the executive director of the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, said he wanted "to maintain neutrality." The composer John Kander was also on the nominating-panel list but asked to be removed because he could have a conflict this season, when his show "Kiss of the Spider Woman" may come to Broadway. Also believed to have declined was the playwright Ira Levin, who could not be reached for comment.
A number of those who were dropped from the nominating committee last week expressed surprise over the administrators' action, which had been characterized by some in the theater industry as a "bloodbath."
"I felt they were impugning my credentials as a director," said Carole Rothman, a co-artistic director of Second Stage in Manhattan, who was nominated for a Tony Award for her 1987 direction of "Coastal Disturbances." "It's hard to understand what their definition of theater professional is if they kicked me off."
Ms. Rothman said she was proud of her committee's choices, which, she said, were "based on excellence." They included nine nominations for "Two Shakespearean Actors" and "Four Baboons Adoring the Sun," both of which had closed by the time nominations were made on May 4. (The Tony Awards were presented on May 31 by the League of American Theaters and Producers and the American Theater Wing.) These nominations were known to displease producers of shows that were still running, since a Tony designation generally helps at the box office. "On that day, I announced to the entire committee that we're going to be kicked off," said Ms. Rothman, referring to May 4.
Of the administration committee's attitude toward the nominators, Ms. Rothman said, "I felt it was not high on the list of requirements that the group show any integrity." Of the Tony Awards, she added, "I think that it's a commercial venture and the Tony administration committee views it that way."
 
'A New Concept'
 Isabelle Stevenson, the president of the American Theater Wing and a member of the administration committee, said it "was not trying to impugn Carole's credentials, or those of anyone on the committee." She added: "We didn't consider it personally. We were just trying to dissolve the whole board. Innocently enough, we never thought they would feel offended or hurt. We thought they would understand that we needed to change the committee."
That change was made, she said, "to start with a new concept in mind," the concept being to increase the number of nominators who were working theater professionals.
"There was no implication that the current panel was not doing a good job," she said.
Mrs. Stevenson denied that the administration committee had objected to the choices of "Four Baboons Adoring the Sun" and "Two Shakespearean Actors." "All through the years, panels have nominated shows that have closed," she said. She also denied that the panel had been pressured in any way.
About Ms. Rothman's charge of commercialism, Mrs. Stevenson said: "That is absolutely not true. There is no shred of evidence about that." Of the Tony Awards, she said: "Admittedly, they have become economically important. But the Tonys were founded to award excellence in the craft of theater, and that's what the Tonys are all about: excellence."
But Stuart W. Little, the director of communications at the Theater Development Fund, who was dropped from the nominating panel after one year, said, "Replacing 9 of the 12 was, I think, a criticism of our committee."

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Margaret Sanger, Warrior for Women's Rights

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

Woman of Valor
Margaret Sanger and the Birth Control Movement in America
By Ellen Chesler
Illustrated. 639 pages. Simon & Schuster. $27.50. 
 If he makes time to read 600-plus page books, Vice President J. Danforth Quayle could find plenty of ammunition in Ellen Chesler's "Woman of Valor" for his marching orders to New Yorkers and other American miscreants who aren't paying attention to his lectures about family values. Ms. Chesler's biography of Margaret Sanger, whose personal life was not exactly circumspect and who pioneered the rights of birth control for women from the United States to Japan, shows that the same censorious forces that exist today against feminism, contraception and abortion were at work, even more aggressively, in the first third of this century.
Among the harshest critics of Sanger's writings about sexuality and reproduction was none other than Anthony Comstock, the leader of the New York Society for the Suppression of Vice, whose bluenosed indignation against moral pollution and pornography led to vaguely defined Federal and state obscenity statutes. In outspoken newspaper columns intended to educate women, Sanger challenged Comstock and the Comstock laws. Ms. Chesler, a historian with experience in municipal government, writes that by insisting on exercising her First Amendment rights about the open discussion of sexuality and contraception, Sanger changed "the social discourse of her times and of our own."
Margaret Higgins's first marriage, in 1902 to William Sanger, an architect, introduced her to a world of cultural and radical ferment. The generation that had come of age in the new century felt an obligation to redefine themselves and the country. She had studied to become a nurse; later, she combined her knowledge of health care with the Socialist movement. The Sangers joined Socialist Party Local 5 in New York City in 1911, and William ran for alderman. They were active during the movement's heyday under the leadership of Eugene V. Debs.
"The attractive young couple," Ms. Chesler writes, "became favored comrades, and to their uptown parlor flocked the leading young rebels and scoffers of the day, distinctions among them counting far less for the moment than their common vision of a better world for all."
Among the powerful visitors to the Sanger home were journalists, anarchists, Wobblies, trade unionists, including John Reed, Walter Lippmann, Big Bill Haywood and Emma Goldman, "whose brash manners Margaret never forgave, even as she absorbed her forceful doctrines of radicalism and feminism."
The Socialist Party embraced the cause of women's suffrage as an organizing tool. Margaret Sanger was hired to promote the vote for women, but she viewed this effort as a low priority in the larger struggle of women for economic and social justice. Working part time with Lillian Wald's Visiting Nurses Association on the Lower East Side, she was exposed to the ignorance about birth control and the social pathos of poverty.
In 1916, Sanger opened the first birth-control clinic in the United States, behind the curtained windows of a storefront tenement on Amboy Street in Brownsville, Brooklyn. Handbills were distributed to promote the benefits of contraception over abortion. She had seen women die after self-induced abortions without open and legal medical assistance. After several weeks, the police raided the clinic, Sanger was jailed and the clinic was closed. In this carefully documented book, Ms. Chesler reports that the clinic had served 464 recorded clients.
Sanger continued her efforts in lectures, writings and conferences held in the United States, Great Britain, India and Japan. In 1921, she organized the first American Birth-Control Conference at the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan, with a list of sponsors that included Winston Churchill and Theodore Dreiser. That conference established her as the country's leading spokeswoman for birth control. Prominent women and women's organizations joined her campaigns. Before her husband was nominated to be President, Eleanor Roosevelt served on the board of the American Birth-Control League. Members of the Rockefeller family became major supporters of Margaret Sanger's Birth-Control Clinical Research Bureau.
At the same time Sanger devoted her professional life to birth control, her personal life took a different course. Before and after her first marriage unraveled, she followed her own advice about a fulfilled sex life for women. She had many lovers, including H. G. Wells and Havelock Ellis. The affairs are described from a feminist viewpoint that would not shock the newsstand readers of cover lines in Cosmopolitan magazine. She didn't stop her relationships after a second marriage, to Noah Slee, a millionaire.
Sanger, who died in 1966 at the age of 87, had the comfort of knowing that the United States Supreme Court had made its historic 1965 decision in Griswold v. Connecticut, which gave Constitutional protection to the private use of contraceptives. "Since her death the rebirth of a vigorous feminist movement has given new resonance to her original claim that women have a fundamental right to control their own bodies," Ms. Chesler writes.
"Woman of Valor" is especially timely during this bizarre Presidential election season when abortion rights and Murphy Brown's motherhood are flag-waving issues. Ms. Chesler delivers a scholarly, though heavy, contribution to the debate in her biography of a strong-willed woman who challenged the moral police and the mores of her time.

HEADLINE: Enterprise Zones Are Tested, and They Work

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"No EZ Answer for Cities" (editorial, June 4) calls enterprise zones -- in which Government encourages job-creating investments in ghettos by offering investors tax breaks and regulatory relief -- "flawed in theory and also in practice." You are incorrect on both counts: enterprise zones are tested, and they do work.
The economic problems in America's inner cities have been building for 30 years. Manufacturing and industry have largely disappeared from our inner cities. With the loss of manufacturing went (in this order) good jobs, wholesale trade, retail businesses and a large source of local tax revenues. At the same time we saw a rise in poverty, crime, drug use, homelessness and illiteracy. 
 With a shrinking corporate tax base, cities needed to provide more services with less revenue. As a result, cities were forced to raise revenue from other sources, such as residential property taxes, adding to the outward migration of many middle-class residents and homeowners. Finally, infrastructure continued to decay, and crime rates rose, making cities even less attractive to businesses and residents.
Certainly, we must address education, training, day care and health care. Also, affordable housing, crime and drug abuse. But any urban response that does not include a mechanism to attract jobs and business back into our inner cities is simply destined for failure.
Enterprise zones must be part of that response. They have been established in 37 states since 1982 and have created more than 250,000 jobs and attracted more than $28 billion in capital investments. This has all happened without Federal incentives, which would make enterprise zones more attractive than ever to investors and entrepreneurs.
Enterprise zones have been endorsed by the National Governors Association, the National Council of State Legislators, the Council of Black State Legislators, the Conference of Mayors and the Conference of Black Mayors, among many others.
Properly designed Federal enterprise zones can persuade businesses to build and grow in poor neighborhoods. They will give people incentives to invest in such businesses.
Targeted incentives can encourage employers in enterprise zones to hire and train unemployed and economically disadvantaged individuals who live within the zone. Enterprise zones will create jobs and stimulate entrepreneurship. And they will help restore the tax base to communities that have been forced to provide increasing social services with decreasing sources of revenue.
Enterprise zones are not the whole cure for the social and economic ills of our cities, but they are clearly a big step in the right direction. So let us seize this post-Los Angeles moment and get something passed that works.
 
(Senator) JOSEPH I. LIEBERMAN
(Senator) ROBERT W. KASTEN JR.
Washington, June 5, 1992

HEADLINE: Eating WellGene-Spliced Foods: Is It Safe Soup Yet?

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS

 BODY:
DR. DAVID A. KESSLER, the Commissioner of Food and Drugs, is adamant: there are stringent rules for regulating genetically engineered foods, and he intends to enforce them. "This is not a voluntary system," he said.
 Michael Hansen, a research associate at Consumers Union, is equally adamant: the rules aren't stringent. "Everything is left up to the discretion of the companies," he said. "The industry is on the honor system." 
These uncompromising interpretations of a genetic-engineering policy, published by the F.D.A. last month in the Federal Register, were made after Vice President Quayle told industry executives in May that the policy was part of the Bush Administration's "regulatory relief" program. But, Mr. Quayle added, "we will not compromise safety one bit."
 Many consumer and environmental groups, including the Environmental Defense Fund and the National Wildlife Federation, said that because genetically engineered food is so new, it should be subject to testing before it appears on the market. At the very least, they said, the foods should be labeled so that consumers can decide for themselves whether they want to eat the results of gene splicing.
 They contend that genetic material placed into another food is a new substance and should be treated as a new food additive, which requires premarket testing.
 "Genetic engineers are taking genes from bacteria, viruses and insects and adding them to fruits, grains and vegetables," said Dr. Rebecca Goldberg, a senior scientist with the Environmental Defense Fund. "They are producing foods that have never before been eaten by human beings. Consumers should not be guinea pigs for untested food substances."
 But it is the position of the biotechnology industry and the F.D.A. that gene splicing is nothing more than an advanced form of crossbreeding, a century-old practice responsible for such familiar foods as tangelos, a hybrid of tangerines and grapefruits. They reasoned that hybridized crops have never required premarket testing or labeling, so there is no reason that foods created from gene splicing should be treated differently. According to the F.D.A.'s policy statement, the agency "is not aware of any information showing that foods derived by these new methods differ from other foods in any meaningful or uniform way." To put it another way, as long the components of these new foods are generally recognized as safe, the food itself is considered safe.
 Under this reasoning, the genes spliced into these new foods would not generally be considered new food additives; therefore, they would not require premarket review by the agency. But if the presence of the new genes in a food produces a significant change in the level of important nutrients or creates allergens or previously unknown substances, companies making such foods would have to consult with the agency. The food might still end up on the market, but it would have to be labeled to reveal the presence of the allergen, the new substance or the change in nutrient level, or else require F.D.A. approval.
 It is up to companies producing new foods to decide into which category their products fall. Michael Taylor, a deputy commissioner of the F.D.A., said the agency expected the industry to be accountable. "We have laid out what amounts to a standard of care for evaluating safety," he added. "If they do not come to us and we have any questions, we have the authority to prevent the marketing of that product and we can seize or enjoin the product."
 Dr. Eric Flamm, a microbiologist in the F.D.A.'s office of technology, acknowledged that the agency has a public relations problem. "We are attempting to correct the misinformation," Dr. Flamm said, "by writing letters to the editor and articles that will put the regulation in better perspective." In addition, the agency is planning at least two public meetings with industry representatives and consumers this summer to discuss the issues. Details of themeetings have not been completed.
 The F.D.A. has its work cut out for it. Many scientists do not believe that gene splicing is an extension of the kind of breeding that has gone on for the last century, and they do not approve of the proposed regulations.
 "There is no form of crossbreeding that allows the placing of human genes into a tomato," said Dr. Margaret Mellon, the director of the biotechnology policy center of the National Wildlife Federation in Washington. "This is radically new. To say that it is a minor extension of older technology flies in the face of scientific truth."
 Dr. Mellon was referring to the implanting of animal and human genes into plants, and vice versa. For example, a firefly gene can be planted in corn, and a trout gene in celery. A new designer tomato, FlavrSavr, made by Calgene Inc. in Davis, Calif., which will last for 20 days on the shelf, contains a bacterial gene that confers a resistance to antibiotics.
 Asked if people might build up a resistance to antibiotics by eating these tomatoes and other foods that could contain the same gene, the chairman of the company, Roger Salquist, said, "It is simply not an issue." The gene, known as a marker gene, is used by the manufacturer to identify a successful splicing.
 The F.D.A., however, said it was concerned about the safety of such a marker gene and was evaluating it. In the Federal Register, the agency said that it "believes that it will be important to evaluate such concerns with respect to commercial use of antibiotic resistance marker genes in food, especially those that will be widely used."
 Other critics of the regulations have expressed concerns that a food with an unnaturally long shelf life would lose its nutrients. Mr. Salquist said he was not sure whether this subject had been studied, but he added, "I don't believe there is any decline over time."
 Critics also worry about unknown hazards. "In the past we have been able to know what was dangerous over a long period of trial and error," said Jeremy Rifkin, the president of the Foundation on Economic Trends, a nonprofit public interest group that focuses on environmental, economic and ethical issues raised by technology. "Here we have no information. There may be novel allergenic effects from recombining. It may create new mutations. Some mutations may have long- and short-term effects we know nothing about."
 A case in point could be a sometimes fatal blood disorder that in 1990 was linked to the use of the dietary supplement L-tryptophan, which contained genetically engineered bacteria. While there is no evidence that genetic engineering caused contamination to the supplement, the full answer may never be known. The Japanese manufacturer stonewalled American officials, delaying access to the plant that produced the dietary supplement until the area of the plant making it had been shut down for six months. Dr. Mellon said there was reason to "suspect that genetic engineering might have played a role."
 "It is true that F.D.A. cannot prove that genetic engineering caused the deaths," she said, "but they should also say that they cannot prove that it didn't. They are trying to dampen down any concern about this link." She cited a remark about L-tryptophan by Samuel W. Page, the chief of the natural products and instrumentation branch of the F.D.A., in the Aug. 31, 1990, issue of the journal Science. "The whole question -- Is there any relation to genetic engineering? -- is premature, especially given the impact on industry." Dr. Kessler denied the possibility, though he said research was incomplete.
 Other critics cited the potential for allergic reactions to genetically engineered food among small parts of the population. The F.D.A. "has neglected to consider people who have allergies to foods that are not necessarily considered allergens," Dr. Goldberg said. She cited the case of a woman who is allergic to bananas, a food seldom thought of as a potential allergen, and who is concerned that she may unknowingly eat a food in which a banana gene has been planted.
 Dr. Kessler acknowledged the lack of information in an article for the June 26 issue of Science, a draft copy of which he made available. He wrote: "At this time we are unaware of any practical method to predict or assess the potential for new proteins in food to induce allergenicity."
 There is also a potential problem for vegetarians, Orthodox Jews, Moslems and Buddhists when animal genes are spliced into vegetables and the vegetables are not labeled. The issue is not addressed by the F.D.A. document. "We will be talking to religious leaders," Dr. Kessler said.
 Dr. Goldberg said consumers are entitled to know what is in their food. Some New York City chefs think so, too. They held a news conference on June 2 to say they would boycott genetically engineered foods. But it is impossible to boycott genetically engineered foods if they are not labeled. The chefs said they planned to ask the city's Department of Consumer Affairs to require labeling.
 Mark Green, the city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, said that his office is looking into the "feasibility and legality of a local labeling law."
 Mr. Rifkin, whose foundation is running a campaign to pressure Congress and the F.D.A. to require labeling and testing, said chefs around the country and farmers had joined the effort, which is to include writing to the F.D.A. by Aug. 27, the end of the period in which the regulation is open for public comment.
 But neither Mr. Taylor nor Dr. Kessler would say whether public comment would make them reconsider. "We will evaluate the comments and see whether we have the authority to regulate," Mr. Taylor said.
 Written comments may be sent until Aug. 27 to: Dockets Management Branch (H.F.A.-305), Food and Drug Administration, Room 1-23, 12420 Parklawn Drive, Rockville, Md. 20857. Comments should include the docket number, 92N-0139.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON;
YELTSIN CHEERED AT CAPITOL AS HE PLEDGES ERA OF TRUST AND ASKS FOR ACTION ON AID

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
On a day that the United States gave Russia a set of trade incentives to boost its struggling economy, President Boris N. Yeltsin swept through official Washington like a conquering hero today and announced that he was deactivating the most potent nuclear missiles aimed at America.
Amid chants of "Boris, Boris, Boris!" reverberating through the House of Representatives chamber, Mr. Yeltsin stirred Congress to 13 standing ovations as he vowed that the "idol of Communism" had "collapsed, never to rise again." [Excerpts, page A18.] 
 Having caused a furor on Monday by asserting that some Americans taken prisoner in Vietnam or other wars may still be alive in Russia, Mr. Yeltsin pledged to do whatever was needed to find them. He leaped ahead of the agreement to cut long-range nuclear weapons that he and President Bush announced on Tuesday by telling the joint meeting of Congress that he had ordered the 10-warhead SS-18 missiles that are to be destroyed under the accord removed immediately from active status.
 
Money for Ex-Soviet Lands
 Then he said it was time for the United States to repay Russia's good will by approving a stalled package of aid that includes $12 billion the International Monetary Fund says it needs to begin lending to Russia and the other former Soviet republics.
Appearing later at a news conference with President Bush, Mr. Yeltsin was even more direct.
"If we do not take measures now to support Russia," he said, "this will not be a collapse of Russia only, it will be a collapse of the United States, because it will mean new trillions of dollars for the arms race."
Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Bush took a big step toward thawing commercial relations today by signing agreements granting Russia most-favored-nation status in trade and liberalizing rules for American investment in Russia. [Page A19.] But Mr. Bush will have to expend considerable political capital to insure Congressional passage of the stalled aid package.
 
Bush Appeals to Congress
 He joined Mr. Yeltsin's appeal for action, asking lawmakers to put aside election-year pressure to spend money only at home and move quickly to approve the aid program for former Soviet republics.
"Let me just say to the American people, our support for Russia is unshakable because it is in our interest," Mr. Bush said at the joint news conference, which followed the signing ceremony in the White House East Room. "Success for Russian democracy will enhance the security of every American. Think for just a minute about what that means -- not for presidents, nor for heads of state, or historians, but for parents and their children. It means a future free from fear."
Mr. Yeltsin obtained the favorable tariff treatment he has long sought from Washington when the two Presidents signed the packet of commercial agreements. The documents also prohibit double taxation of profits, provide risk insurance for American investors and expand the availability of export credits for American companies.
Other agreements signed on the final day of the first Russian-American summit meeting expand the official relationship between the two countries, including cooperation in space and the formation of a joint early-warning system for missile launches.
 
Russia at the Center
 Similar accords are likely to be signed in time with Ukraine and other former republics, but it seemed evident that Russia, by far the largest of the 15 countries that have emerged from the wreckage of the old Soviet Union, is at the center of Washington's attention.
Lawmakers said Mr. Yeltsin appeared to have won some converts with his stirring speech and dramatic personal confrontation of lawmakers who had been opposing passage of the aid program. But the measure's prospects in Congress remained uncertain and much certainly depended on how much private arm-twisting Mr. Bush was prepared to do to back the public appeals for passage he has made at every opportunity in the last two days.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Yeltsin also signed an agreement to produce a treaty that would slash the two countries' strategic nuclear weapons to one-third of their current size.
Mr. Bush said the two countries have "indeed formed a truly new relationship, one of peace, friendship, trust and growing partnership." He added, "I am confident that this new relationship and our historic agreements at this summit will lead to a safer, more stable and peaceful world in the next century."
As important as the documents were, the most dramatic moment of the day came when Mr. Yeltsin strode into the packed chamber of the House of Representatives to a standing ovation that was more enthusiastic than the reception Mr. Yeltsin gets in the Russian Parliament and rivaled Mr. Bush's own reception in Congress after the American victory in the Persian Gulf.
The enthusiasm came as something of a surprise since before Mr. Yeltsin's arrival there were few lawmakers who thought that he would outdo his political rival, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in popularity in Washington. But Mr. Yeltsin put his political deftness on display and appeared to win over even those lawmakers who had been demanding that the aid package be held up until Russia accounts for all American prisoners of war who might have been taken to the former Soviet Union.
 
A Display of Skills
 He stood before the House's enormous American flag, with his broad shoulders and swept-back silver hair towering over the rostrum. His broad face creasing frequently into his easy grin, Mr. Yeltsin alternately flattered, cajoled, pleaded, blustered and sternly lectured the assembled Senators and Representatives about their responsibility to promote political and economic reform in the former Soviet Union.
But he seemed bent primarily on assuring the lawmakers that they can now trust the Russian Government, and in doing so he seemed to overshadow even the powerful appearances in Washington by Mr. Gorbachev, the last Soviet President.
"We are firmly resolved not to lie anymore, either to our negotiating partners, or to the Russian or American or any other people," he said, denouncing even the vision of a more humane Communism offered by Mr. Gorbachev. "There will be no more lies, ever."
 
Promise on Prisoners
 Drawing a thundering ovation, Mr. Yeltsin promised to account for every American prisoner of war that may have been brought to the Soviet Union during World War II, the Korean War or the Vietnam War.
"Even if one American has been detained in my country and can still be found, I will find him," Mr. Yeltsin said. "I will get him back to his family."
Then, as the applause died down, Mr. Yeltsin smiled almost mischievously and chided lawmakers who had said the Russian aid package should be frozen until the issue of missing servicemen is resolved.
"I thank you for the applause," he said. But he added, "Yeltsin has already opened the archives and is inviting you to join us in investigating the fate of each and every unaccounted-for American. So now you are telling me first to do the job and then we shall support you in passing that act. I don't quite understand you."
 
2 Legislators Yield
 The two lawmakers who had called for linking the aid package to the prisoners issues, Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Representative Robert K. Dornan, Republican of California, both said later they were persuaded by Mr. Yeltsin.
Mr. Yeltsin also promised to ferret out the truth about how a Soviet SU-15 fighter-bomber shot down the Korean Air Lines Boeing 747 in September 1983. He said at a news conference later that Russian authorities had found a K.G.B. document suggesting that there are hidden files on the subject and are now searching for them.
Both Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Bush, who lavished heavy praise on the Russian President, spent the day seeking to underscore the notion that their meeting marked a watershed in relations between their two countries.
"For many years, our two nations were the two poles, the two opposites," Mr. Yeltsin told Congress. But he said, "That evil scenario is becoming a thing of the past. Reason begins to triumph over madness. We have left behind the period when America and Russia looked at each other through gunsights, ready to pull the trigger at any time."
Anticipating the domestic political pressures he may face in light of the agreement to cut long-range nuclear weapons, Mr. Bush warned at the news conference that it would not produce a windfall "peace dividend" that might be spent on American domestic programs.
"The dividend is declared when you make a profit and our Government is operating at an enormous deficit," he said.
 
'No Human Face'
 Seeking to persuade Congress that his country has taken steps toward democracy and free markets that cannot be retraced, Mr. Yeltsin said, "There can be no coexistence between a civic society, which is pluralistic by definition, and Communist intolerance to dissent. The experience of the past decades has taught us Communism has no human face. Freedom and Communism are incompatible."
He displayed a mastery of the American political dialect, making his speech intensely personal. He thanked his wife and family for their support in troubled times and offering himself as the bulwark of democratic reform. "It is practically impossible to topple Yeltsin in Russia," he said. "I am in good health and I will not say 'uncle' before I make the reforms irreversible.' "
He also reminded the lawmakers that it was he who defied the attempted coup in the Kremlin nearly a year ago. "I will be candid with you," he said. "At that moment I feared. But I had no fear for myself. I feared for the future of democracy in Russia and throughout the world because I was aware what could happen if we failed to win."
 
Recalling Bush's Support
 At a final dinner tonight at the Russian Embassy, Mr. Yeltsin invoked the coup attempt once again as he and Mr. Bush toasted each other with some of the most personal comments to come from their meeting.
Mr. Yeltsin said that when Mr. Gorbachev was a captive of reactionaries and Russia's fate hinged on the world's willingness to ratify a de facto coup, Mr. Bush was the first leader to call him at Moscow's White House, then the seat of Russia's government, and vow his support.
Other leaders followed, he said, but only at Mr. Bush's suggestion, and in many cases only after the collapse of the coup was clear. The American President "was the first to understand the true meaning of the victory of the Russian people," Mr. Yeltsin said.
Mr. Bush's response was brief and apparently heartfelt. "You leave with all of us feeling you are going to make it, somehow," he said. "We are at your side."

PUB-DATE: June 18, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1111 words

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON;
Shaping a New Agenda

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
Although the biggest news out of this week's summit meeting was the agreement to sharply reduce American and Russian nuclear arsenals, the centerpiece turned out to be economic relations between the two former rivals.
In effect, these two days marked the moment when the currency of American-Russian relations shifted from warheads to dollars. Stripped to its essence, what President Boris N. Yeltsin did this week was promise Mr. Bush that Russia would trash thousands of warheads in exchange for long-promised trade privileges, a bilateral investment treaty, removal of cold-war trade barriers and the hope of lucrative American investment and quick Congressional approval of a Russian aid package. 
 To be sure, there were other turning points as well. The meeting finally gave Mr. Yeltsin the chance to step out of the shadow Mikhail S. Gorbachev long cast in Washington. It was only last August that senior White House officials were still telling reporters on background that Mr. Yeltsin was a "demagogue," a buffoon, and a man with more taste for vodka than for the complexities of diplomacy and arms control.
 
Firmly Established
 With his performance today before the United States Congress, with his concessions on arms control and with his frank disclosures about American prisoners of war in the Soviet Union, Mr. Yeltsin has firmly established himself in Washington as the legitimate leader of a reformist Russia. It is safe to say he is no longer perceived as the the coarse populist who was resented for ousting Mr. Bush's "friend," Mr. Gorbachev.
Mr. Yeltsin is delivering the goods in arms cuts and in candor that Mr. Gorbachev promised but never fully accomplished. Throughout his public comments in Washington, Mr. Yeltsin drew a sharp contrast between his intentions -- to destroy Communism and bare its worst excesses -- and Mr. Gorbachev's -- to reform Communism and preserve secrets.
Congress clearly acknowledged Mr. Yeltsin's new status, not to mention an appreciation of his frankness, with gleeful chants of "Boris, Boris, Boris!" at the high points of Mr. Yeltsin's speech in the House chamber today.
In addition to these economic and personal transformations, of course, the arms control accord, radically reducing nuclear arsenals by the year 2003, will fundamentally reshape the nuclear balance. Because the most potent offensive weapons used in a pre-emptive nuclear strike will be destroyed, the fear Americans and Russians have lived under for 40 years will be drastically diminished.
After these cuts are completed in 10 years, the cold war balance of terror will be replaced by a new imbalance. According to the proposed treaty, the United States, as the world's biggest superpower and de facto policeman, will be allowed to maintain an edge in its advanced, mostly defensive, submarine-launched weapons, while the Russians, who can no longer afford the arms race, will accept a secondary status.
 
No Longer a Distraction
 For all of these seemingly positive outcomes, though, a caveat is in order. The arms cuts may not survive unless Mr. Yeltsin or another reformist democrat also survives in the Kremlin. The very reason that Mr. Yeltsin agreed to such a sweeping, asymmetrical deal, American officials say, was to get this issue off the agenda so it could no longer be used as an excuse or a distraction from what is for him the real issue: transforming his economy.
And it is the success or failure of that transformation -- far more than the nuclear balance -- that is likely to determine the stability and quality of United States-Russian relations.
The importance of the economic agreements signed today, offering most-favored-nation trade benefits to Russian exporters, export credits, a taxation treaty, insurance to American companies wanting to invest in Russia and a treaty to govern mutual investment, is that they promote what will really transform the Russian economy: not foreign aid, but private investment.
 
Need for Investment
 One thing American officials have learned from the experience of Poland is that while Western aid is necessary for transformation to a free market, they are not sufficient. There is no capitalism without capitalists, and unless Russia is opened up to investment, unless state-owned industries are privatized quickly, unless the ruble is made convertible and unless there is a modicum of internal stability to attract foreign businesses, no external aid package will be big enough.
To the extent that the American-Russian relationship shifts to economics, the role of statesmen, and even summit meetings, is bound to diminish. Far more important will be a thousand small decisions made by a thousand small businessmen, on whether to invest in or trade with Russia.
Mr. Yeltsin himself noted that as important as American and Western aid and credits from the International Monetary Fund are to his economy, they "will not save Russia; they will not even significantly help us."
The most important thing, he said, is that once Russia gets an I.M.F. stamp of approval "this will open the door for a powerful influx of private capital, and those will not be credits, those will be direct investments from private companies, and that will be a matter of hundreds of billions of dollars, and that will be very important aid; it will be direct aid, it will be civilized aid."
 
On Missing G.I.'s
 But Mr. Yeltsin also learned this week that the shifting relationship is a double-edged sword. It is precisely because Russia no longer seems to be a threat that Congressional interest in acting on Russian aid has been diminishing, especially when American domestic problems seem so pressing. Many in Congress seem to be saying: why pay to heal a country we no longer fear?
Just the barest hint by Mr. Yeltsin that some Americans might have been held as prisoners of war in Russia, prompted calls in Congress to hold up any Russian aid until this mystery is sorted out.
Mr. Yeltsin was clearly frustrated by this attitude that American aid to Russia is a luxury, that can seemingly be held up by any whim, not a necessity in order to stabilize one of the biggest countries on earth.
He told Congress: "Some of you who have just risen here to applaud me have also written in the press that until Yeltsin gets things done and gets all the jobs done, there should be no Freedom Support Act passing through the Congress. Well, I don't really quite understand you, ladies and gentlemen. Yeltsin has already opened the archives, and is inviting you to join us in investigating the fate of each and every unaccounted American. I don't quite understand you."

TYPE: News Analysis

HEADLINE: BUSH AND CONGRESS REACH AN ACCORD ON AID FOR CITIES

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
After a month of hard-nosed bargaining and political posturing, White House and Congressional negotiators agreed today on a $1.3 billion urban aid package including loans and grants for summer jobs for youths and disaster relief for people whose homes and businesses were destroyed in the Los Angeles riots.
The compromise fell far short of what the nation's big-city mayors and some Democratic lawmakers were seeking, and it also excluded law-enforcement and investment programs that President Bush wanted passed quickly in the aftermath of the riots. 
 "It's not sufficient from our viewpoint," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader and chief Congressional negotiator on the aid package. "But it's something we need to get done now. We need to move forward. I think we'll get it passed in both houses, hopefully tomorrow."
 
Break in the Logjam
 Congressional leaders said they hoped that the agreement would mark the beginning of further negotiations to come up with a plan of tax relief and other benefits to businesses willing to locate in the inner cities.
"This action means that the logjam is finally breaking," said Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, who has led the fight in the Senate for more urban aid.
Putting a positive interpretation on a compromise package that excluded more than $800 million in money for Head Start and other summer youth programs he had sought, Mr. Kennedy added, "It is gratifying that Congress and the Administration are also making progress on a further aid package with substantial additional funds for communities with the greatest need."
The compromise roughly split the difference between a House bill providing $822 million in grants and loans to Los Angeles and Chicago, which Mr. Bush supported, and a Senate bill that would have provided an additional $1.5 billion to 75 cities, which Mr. Bush said was too costly. A House-Senate conference committee agreed on a version that came close to the Senate language, but the White House threatened a veto.
 
Factions in Administration
 Today's agreement also served as a compromise between two wings of the Administration: one led by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, which did not want to give an inch to Democratic lawmakers, and the other led by Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp, which wanted to grant substantially more aid.
The package must still be passed by both the House and Senate and signed by Mr. Bush. And even then, a Presidential declaration of a budgetary emergency is required to allow the money to flow. The money would come outside current budget limits by adding to the Federal deficit.
The package includes all the grants and loans to rebuild homes and businesses destroyed in the Los Angeles riots as well as property damaged in an early April flood in downtown Chicago that were in the House bill, and it adds $500 million for summer jobs around the country. The money would allow 360,000 youths to be put to work in various Federal programs, double the number under current ones, Mr. Kennedy said.
An aide to Mr. Gephardt said Democrats had been eager to make a deal with the White House because "the summer youth program is very time sensitive."
But by cutting off the negotiations now, the Democrats conceded several other summer programs they sorely wanted. Among them were an additional $175 million for summer jobs, $250 million more for summer Head Start programs and $250 million for summer school programs for disadvantaged elementary and secondary school students.
The Administration, in turn, sacrificed $250 million that the Democrats were willing to include for its new "weed and seed" program in which SWAT teams and specially trained police officers would rid neighborhoods of gangs and drug dealers to provide security as new educational and other social programs are instituted.
 
Pressure on Bush
 The monthlong negotiations ran into snags on several occasions, with Democrats and the White House adding new conditions. The fact that the majority of Americans have given Mr. Bush low marks on domestic policy and stewardship of the economy has never been far from the minds of those in the White House in this election year.
There is still an outside chance of more setbacks. Normally, such a compromise agreement would win easy passage, but this one could be blocked by an unusual, de facto coalition of rural-state lawmakers who contend it is too generous and urban-state lawmakers who want more aid.
 
The Perot Factor
 In recent days, Democratic and Republican strategists said they worried that the public would punish both parties if they could not agree to some urban aid package. The shadow of Ross Perot's Presidential candidacy seemed to impel both sides to reach an arrangement.
"It was nothing as climatic as a handshake at the table," the Gephardt aide said, adding that the next phase of negotiations would focus on the program for tax breaks for new inner-city businesses. Democrats hope to link various investment incentives to the cuts in the capital gains tax that the Administration wants to grant to businesses willing to risk locating in impoverished city neighborhoods.
Mr. Gephardt said one area in which the negotiators could not agree was the allotment of "weed and seed" money. The Administration wanted 80 percent of the money to go to law enforcement, and 20 percent to the social programs, he said, while the Democrats favored the reverse.
Mr. Gephardt said he thought that the two sides would eventually come to an agreement on the program.
