HEADLINE: City's Survivors, With a Diploma to Prove It

SERIES: Into Uncertainty: The Class of '92 -- Last of three articles.

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
Falasha Spruiell and Charisse Lenoir wearily circled the graffiti-covered high school track, sweating and breathing heavily. The track season was winding down, like high school itself. Only the championships remained -- and graduation.
For Ms. Spruiell and Ms. Lenoir, seniors at Boys and Girls High in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, the long, precarious obstacle course through inner-city adolescence was over. And they had made it. 
 Still, their sense of achievement -- their success when so many around them have failed -- has brought on the realization that they have won one race only to begin another.
"If you think about it, it doesn't really end," said Ms. Spruiell, whose speed on the track has several universities recruiting her. "I've just started, and I have to start at the bottom and work my way up again."
Then she shrugged, as she must have shrugged when she entered high school four years ago, and they began running again.
In a neighborhood where the streets constantly conspire against success, Ms. Spruiell, Ms. Lenoir and the 420 other graduating seniors at Boys and Girls are the survivors. They have resisted the temptations, avoided the violence, heeded the pressure to stay in school when the "in crowd" drops out.
Now, as the final days of high school hurtle toward graduation next Thursday, the seniors at Boys and Girls are preparing for that ritual leap out of childhood with a mix of cool confidence and hard-edged realism.
They have grown up with less, and fought off much more, than their counterparts in less perilous communities. And while they know their futures will be fraught with obstacles -- a weak economy, a faltering job market and a society they feel offers dim prospects for young blacks from the inner city -- they seem less daunted by them, if only because they have already made it this far.
"They've overcome so many major things," said Gary Keenan, the senior class's adviser. "They've seen their friends blown away. They've seen their friends have babies. They've seen their friends drop out. At this point a slowdown in the economy is a pretty minor thing to overcome."
 
'I Want to Make It'
 Errol Roy, a lanky senior who sings gospel, clears almost 40 feet in the triple jump and plans to leave for the University of Florida the day after graduation, said many people he started out with didn't make it.
"They're either selling drugs, on drugs or dead," he said. "I have a lot of friends who say, 'Go this way,' or, 'Go that way. But I say, 'No, I'm going to go home.' I want to make it."
With unemployment for 16- to 19-year-olds in New York City running at nearly 17 percent, and nearly double that in Bedford-Stuyvesant, the seniors say they realize that few opportunities exist without college. Nearly 80 percent of those who have made it to graduation plan to attend college this fall -- roughly average for the city's public high schools.
"Your best bet is going to college," said Porsha Cohen, who lives in the Roosevelt Houses, a public-housing project where the crackle of gunfire sometimes interrupts her late-night studying. "Trying to get an entry-level job is impossible. They're either unavailable or inaccessible. Where does that leave a high school student with just a diploma?"
 
'All-American Kids'
 Like seniors everywhere, they have the irrepressible dreams of teen-agers. Generaldo Scott, who belongs to a church drama troupe called the Creationists that performs works about young people who succumb to drugs and violence, wants to be a talk show host (somewhere between Arsenio Hall and Oprah Winfrey). Angela Simon wants to be a photographer. Charzetta Payden wants to write for teen magazines. Sabrina Knox just wants to get away from New York.
Rashida Rahim, an honors student and cheerleader, plans to study business management at Pace University, or maybe Baruch College. She wants to own a laundry. She'll need $100,000 to get started, she said, maybe through loans. Not to worry -- she has it all figured out. "I'm going to make it," she said.
"If you look at my kids," the school's principal, Frank N. Mickens, said, "they're all-American kids. They're like kids all over the country, their aspirations, their enthusiasm. But they're tough. They know what's going on around them."
Only 36 percent of the students at Boys and Girls graduate on time, slightly lower than the city average. To make it through school, Mr. Mickens said, they have to be determined. To make it in the world, they will have to be better than everybody else -- because they are black, because they are from Bed-Stuy.
"That's not fair, but they understand that," he said. "It's like the same things said to me, what, 27 years ago."
 
Importance of Self-Esteem
 Many seniors credited their success, and their optimism, to the sense of pride Mr. Mickens and the teachers at Boys and Girls have nurtured. In a city where public schools are not always immune to the deterioration around them, these students described the modern, boxy school on Fulton Street as an oasis where the violence of the streets never breached the heavily guarded doors.
In the clean, shiny hallways, banners and posters extol self-esteem, which the students say is vital to resisting failure's incessant tug. "Respect yourself," one poster demands. "NO shorts, spandex, sleeveless shirts, tank tops, culottes, see-through blouses, cut jeans."
Mr. Mickens, who carries a walkie-talkie and at times a hammer as a symbol of his tough approach, has imposed a strict set of rules -- everything from not wearing gold teeth or hanging out in the hallways to wearing ties on Fridays and trying to earn the honor of a Regents Diploma (there will be 50 this year).
In a school where most students come from families headed by single mothers, many of them unemployed or on welfare, Mr. Mickens has become a kind of surrogate father or grandfather, whom many students said they would miss the minute the final bell rang.
"He's on our backs," said Antoinette Haynes, who plans to go to a community college until she can raise the money to go to Cheney State College in Pennsylvania to study education. "I don't know if we're going to get that kind of attention in college."
As she sat on a stool at Pat's Kitchen, a Caribbean restaurant on Fulton Street where many students hang out after school, Tanisha Yates said she needed that kind of support to withstand the pressures to give up.
"Growing up in the neighborhood is really hard for someone going to high school," she said. "There's a lot of drugs and shootings and robberies. A lot of my friends got pregnant and dropped out."
For Ms. Yates, who plans to attend Columbus College in Georgia next fall, the pressures were almost too much. She is an only child whose mother is on welfare. In junior high school, she ran into a lot of trouble. "I used to fight a lot," she said. "I got suspended a lot." She doesn't know why; she was angry, frustrated.
Things improved when she moved in with her grandmother and started going to Boys and Girls -- two events that imposed new order on her young tumultuous life. She studied hard, joined the dance squad and the softball team, became a cheerleader and worked during her school breaks.
She has made it, she said, by sticking with "a certain crowd" who avoided trouble the way most seniors avoid homework at this time of year. "If I finish school," she said, "then I think I have a great future."
 
'It's Your Choice'
 The restaurant's owner, Patricia Wiggins, said she had seen a lot of students like Ms. Yates pass through -- some going somewhere, some going nowhere. "I tell them, 'Hanging out here isn't going to get you anywhere,' " said Ms. Wiggins, who is popular with students who come to order roti, oxtail stew, rice and beans, but mostly burgers. "I tell them to go to college, because there's nothing out here for them."
As they do at every school, the seniors fell into cliques over the years: football cliques, fashion cliques, student-government cliques. There were other, more insidious cliques that most of those who will graduate managed to avoid.
"If you come with your mind made up, you'll get out," Ms. Haynes said. "Just like if you have your mind made up to kill someone, you can do it. It's your choice to choose the right one."
But the pressures always remain. One in three of the girls who graduate on June 25 will graduate as mothers, Mr. Keenan said. And the graduating seniors talked about not dropping out as if they were still trying to convince themselves to stay in -- with only two weeks to go. While most of their close friends will graduate, they all know more who dropped out along the way.
 
Aiming High
 Now, as graduation approaches, the seniors are busy with the usual senior things: finals, the prom and caps and gowns, looking for summer jobs, skipping classes and having fun.
Ms. Spruiell, the state indoor champion in the 600 meters, has been cramming to take the Scholastic Aptitude Test again. She scored a combined 680 the first time -- 20 points below what she needs to qualify for the athletic scholarships that Arizona, Kentucky and Seton Hall have offered her. "Math," she said.
She wants to pursue a master's degree, then a doctorate, in business or school administration. She wants to run in the Olympics in 1996. Her coach, Loraine Tummings, says she has a shot, if she puts her mind to it.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON;
Russia Is Given Most-Favored Status

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
President Bush and President Boris N. Yeltsin flung open the door today to increased trade and investment, signing a package of commercial agreements that brush aside barricades put up during the cold war to block commerce between the United States and Russia.
In a major trade development, the United States granted Russia most-favored-nation status in trade relations for the first time in more than four decades, giving it the same low tariffs that it gives other friendly nations. 
 Other agreements signed today set liberal new rules for American investment in Russia, expand the amount of credit available for American exports to Russia and provide risk insurance for American investments there.
"Today is really a turning point in U.S.-Russian commercial relations," said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International. "It puts an end to 40 years of cold-war restrictions on trade and comerce."
 
Plans for a Hotel
 American and Russian officials said that with today's agreements, the United States and Russia have gone far to replace their frosty commercial relations with warmer ones. Indeed, Commerce Secretary Barbara Franklin said her goal was for the United States to become Russia's largest trading partner.
The accords technically only relate to the United States and Russia. But it is expected in coming months that similar pacts will be worked out with the other former Soviet republics that want them.
"There are plenty of investment opportunities all around the world where things are more settled, but I think what happened today will open the gates to investment in Russia," said Curtis L. Carlson, the Minneapolis-based billionaire whose Carlson Companies owns the Radisson Hotel chain.
Saying the agreements would help advance plans to build a hotel in St. Petersburg, Mr. Carlson was one of many executives who said they would speed up contemplated investments in Russia that had long been on hold.
Economists said the agreements would give Russia more of a psychological boost than an actual economic boost over the next few months, but they said that over a year or two, the accord could mean a significant increase in bilateral trade and in American investment in Russia.
Even after the signing of the agreements, American executives said many obstacles remain to investment, including the lack of convertiblity of the ruble, difficulties in buying land, and the absence of a legal structure to govern contracts, private property and other aspects of a market economy.
At a meeting that was called the first United States-Russia Business Summit, Mr. Yeltsin provided an invitation for investment that was far more welcoming than any speech made by Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Mr. Yelstin and his team of economic advisers also vowed to do what was necessary to attract foreign investment, saying that private capital was needed to supplement foreign aid to rebuild Russia.
Speaking to more than 200 leading American and Russian executives, Mr. Yeltsin often sounded like former President Ronald Reagan in hailing free enterprise and calling for scrapping burdensome regulations.
"Having returned to the world economic system, we believe that Russia will become a fast-growing market," said Mr. Yeltsin. "We hope to accommodate foreign investment to the tune of hundreds of billions of dollars. We have scientific potential, natural resources. We have skilled scientists. We have low wages, measured by world standards. This is a unique combination of factors that provide the opportunity to produce enormous profits."
Under one agreement signed today, the Overseas Private Investment Corporation will greatly reduce the risk for American businesses making investments in Russia by offering insurance that protects American investors against the risk of war, expropriation and difficulties in converting their profits into hard currency.
The president of the corporation, Fred M. Zeder, said American companies had already filed applications for $15 billion in risk insurance for various investments in Russia. He said he did not know what percentage of those projects would be completed.
Another accord greatly expands the ability of the Export-Import Bank to extend loans, loan guarantees and trade insurance to American companies seeking to export to Russia. The Export-Import Bank is negotating with Russian authorities to finance the sale of $1 billion in American oilfield equipment to Russia, as well as $200 million in American equipment for modernizing nuclear power plants and for cleaning up the environment.
A bilateral investment pact signed today sets a framework for American investment in Russia, promises American investors fair treatment, gives them the right to set up offices, and sets up a mechanism for resolving investment disputes.
Not having most-favored-nation status meant that tariffs on Russian goods are 5 to 10 times those on goods from most-favored nations.

SECTION: Section A; Page 19; Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 635 words

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON;
Yeltsin Speaks, and Congressional Wall Tumbles

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
With oratory that thrilled even Congressional critics of aid, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia appeared today to have virtually eliminated an important obstacle to passage of an aid program for the former Soviet republics.
After his speech at a joint meeting of Congress interrupted by standing ovations, legislative leaders said they thought that Mr. Yeltsin had persuaded even skeptical lawmakers of his determination to help find missing American servicemen, and had thus won vital votes for the American portion of a $24 billion international assistance package for former Soviet republics. 
 But lawmakers warned that the battle for Congressional approval would ultimately be determined by whether Mr. Yeltsin's visit also overcame wide opposition among their constituents to granting foreign aid at a time when many Americans are unemployed or pessimistic about their future.
Senators and members of the House expressed pleasure and astonishment at Mr. Yeltsin's emotional attack on the evils of Communism, his willingness to reduce his country's nuclear arsenal and his invitation to American officials to inspect the archives of the K.G.B. and Soviet Communist Party for clues to the fate of Americans missing in the Vietnam War.
"None of us expected to see anything in our lifetime like this," said Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip in the House. "Emotionally, how can you abandon a man like this?"
Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, a senior Democrat on the Appropriations Committee who has been skeptical about Administration proposals for aiding Russia, said of the speech: "It was as historic a postwar event as the tearing down of the Berlin wall. It will win him votes."
When Mr. Yeltsin arrived this morning on Capitol Hill, the aid he sought was caught in the political gridlock that has paralyzed Congress and the White House for most of the last year.
Most liberals were ready to delay aid to the former Soviet republics until President Bush was willing to free up money for unemployment compensation and aid to the cities. Conservatives were ready to block aid until the Russians provided a full accounting of American servicemen from the Vietnam War who Mr. Yeltsin said may still be alive somewhere in his country.
Legislation now before Congress would grant the Administration authority to spend $610 million for the 12 former Soviet republics, excluding the Baltic republics, in 1992 and 1993. It would also authorize the Administration to augment its contribution to the International Monetary Fund by $12 billion, which would go toward financing long-term projects in the republics.
But the measure awaits floor action in both houses, and 103 Democratic lawmakers have signed a letter linking their votes for the aid effort to Republican support for domestic programs.
Democratic leaders said they thought Mr. Yeltsin had gone a long way to bring liberals along. Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said he was preparing to bring an aid bill to the Senate floor.
 
Reassurances on Servicemen
 But the Russian leader made the most headway with Republican conservatives who had threatened to stall aid after Mr. Yeltsin disclosed on Monday that some American servicemen captured in Vietnam, Korea and World War II had been transferred to labor camps in the Soviet Union and might still be alive. Mr. Yeltsin sought out Senator John McCain of Arizona, a Republican who was himself a prisoner of war in Vietnam, for a private meeting to persuade him that he was serious about investigating the whereabouts of the missing.
"I'm satisfied with his commitment," Mr. McCain said after the meeting. He dropped his threat to block the aid package, adding, "I have to take his word when he looks me in the eye."

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON;
Excerpts From Yeltsin's Speech: 'There Will Be No More Lies'

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a speech to a joint meeting of Congress by President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, who spoke through an interpreter:
It is indeed a great honor for me to address the Congress of the great land of freedom as the first ever over 1,000 years of history of Russia popularly elected President, as a citizen of the great country which has made its choice in favor of liberty and democracy. 
 For many years, our two nations were the two poles, the two opposites. They wanted to make us implacable enemies. That affected the destinies of the world in a most tragic way.
The world was shaken by the storms of confrontation. It was close to exploding, close to perishing beyond salvation.
That evil scenario is becoming a thing of the past. Reason begins to triumph over madness. We have left behind the period when America and Russia looked at each other through gunsights, ready to pull the trigger at any time.
Despite what we saw in the well-known American film "The Day After," it can be said today, tomorrow will be a day of peace, less of fear and more of hope for the happiness of our children. The world can sign in relief. The idol of Communism, which spread everywhere social strife, animosity, and unparalleled brutality, which instilled fear in humanity, has collapsed. It has collapsed never to rise again. I am here to assure you, we will not let it rise again in our land.

 	 	 		. . .	 	You will recall August 1991, when for three days Russia was under the dark cloud of dictatorship. I addressed the Muscovites who were defending the White House of Russia. I addressed all the people of Russia. I addressed them standing on top of the tank whose crew had disobeyed criminal orders.
 
'I Will Not Say Uncle'
 I will be candid with you. At that moment, I feared. But I had no fear for myself. I feared for the future of democracy in Russia and throughout the world. Because I was aware what could happen if we failed to win.
Citizens of Russia upheld their freedom, and did not allow the continuation of the 75 years of nightmare. From this high rostrum I want to express our sincere thanks and gratitude to President Bush and to the American people for their invaluable moral support for the just cause of the people of Russia.

 	 	 		. . .	 	We must carry through unprecedented reforms in the economy, that over the seven decades, has been stripped of all market infrastructure, lay the foundations for democracy, and restore the rule of law in the country that for scores of years was poisoned with political strife and political oppression. Guarantee domestic social and political stability, as well as maintenance of civil peace.
We have no right to fail in this most difficult endeavor, for there will be no second try, as in sports. Our predecessors have used them all up. The reforms must succeed. . . .
Today I am telling you what I tell my fellow countrymen. I will not go back on the reforms. And it is practically impossible to topple Yeltsin in Russia. I am in good health, and I will not say uncle before I make the reforms irreversible. We realize our great responsibility for the success of our changes, not only toward the people of Russia, but also toward the citizens of America, and of the entire world. Today the freedom of America is being upheld in Russia. Should the reforms fail, it will cost hundreds of billions to upset that failure.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Russia has brought its policies toward a number of countries in line with its solemn declarations of the recent years. We have stopped arms deliveries to Afghanistan, where the senseless military adventure has taken thousands of Russians and hundreds of thousands of Afghan lives.
 
'No More Lies'
 With external props removed, the puppet regime collapsed.
We have corrected the well-known imbalances in relations with Cuba. At present that country is one of our Latin American partners. Our commerce with Cuba is based on universally accepted principles and world prices.
It is Russia that once and for all has done away with double standards in foreign policy. We are firmly resolved not to lie any more, either to our negotiating partners, or to the Russia or American or any other people.
There will be no more lies -- ever.
The same applies to biological weapons experiments, and the facts that have been revealed about American prisoners of war, the KAL 007 flight, and many other things. That list could be continued.
The archives of the K.G.B. and the Communist Party Central Committee are being opened. Moreover, we are inviting the cooperation of the United States and other nations to investigate these dark pages.
I promise you that each and every document in each and every archive will be examined in order to investigate the fate of every American unaccounted for. As President of Russia, I assure you that even if one American has been detained in my country, and can still be found, I will find him. I will get him back to his family.

 	 	 		. . .	 	I would like now to conclude my statement with the words from a song by Irving Berlin, an American of Russian descent -- God bless America, to which I add, and Russia.

HEADLINE: Mexicans Mollified Over Drug Ruling

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, June 17

 BODY:
Mexico and the United States backed away from a diplomatic confrontation today when Mexican officials said they had received assurances from Washington that there would be no more kidnappings of criminal suspects from their territory.
In Washington, the Bush Administration continued to avoid any explicit promise to refrain from such kidnappings, while the State Department repeated its pledge to extend "full respect for the sovereign rights and prerogatives" of Mexico. 
 The confrontation arose Monday when the United States Supreme Court asserted the right of the United States to kidnap a criminal suspect from another country, in effect sanctioning the seizure of a Mexican gynecologist in 1990. The Mexico Foreign Ministry angrily criticised the decision and said it would suspend United States drug enforcement activities in Mexico.
Today, declaring that the United States had been responsive to their concerns, Mexican official backed away from their threat to suspend the activities of United States agents and to recall its own drug-control agents from the United States.
Mexican officials also planned to resume talks with the United States on Mexico's demands for changes in a 1978 extradition treaty that would expressly bar the abductions.
"What we set out to do was to very quickly find solutions so that this issue would not become a very long, protracted difficulty or controversy," a senior Mexican official said, "and we did."
Mexican officials said that within hours after notifying the United States Embassy here on Monday that it would suspend the activities of the 39 drug-enforcement agents in Mexico, the Government was contacted by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and other Administration officials.
 
No Sources Named
 The officials would not say from whom they had received the assurances that kidnappings would not occur. But Andres Rozental, the Undersecretary of Foreign Relations in charge of North America, said the assurances had come from "the highest levels" in Washington.
A United States Embassy official said he could not confirm that such an explicit assurance had been given. But he said the thrust of the assurance was that independently of the court decision, policy changes had been made since the abduction to render it unlikely that a similar action could take place.
Like the clash over the kidnapping itself, the quick movement towards its resolution reflected the shifting relations between the United States and Mexico in light of their negotiations for a North American Free Trade Agreement with Canada.
With concern rising about the trade agreement, Mexican stock prices fell sharply again today for the third day.
For months, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has worked to convince Mexicans to put aside their mistrust of the United States and enter into a closer partnership that would increase the flow of foreign investment.
His administration has also tried to reassure critics of Mexico in the United States by cooperating more with Washington on problems like drug trafficking, immigration and the environment.
At the same time, however, Mr. Salinas has tried to remain assertive with the United States to rebut domestic criticism that he has mortgaged the country's independence for economic growth. But as Mexico's quick retreat from confrontation over the Supreme Court decision suggested, Mexican officials are also weighing the political costs they must pay in Washington for a vigorous public defense of Mexican sovereignty.
Mexicans, for the most part, hesitated to defend Humberto Alvarez Machain, the Mexican doctor who was kidnapped in 1990 by bounty hunters hired by agents of the D.E.A. Dr. Alvarez is accused of helping to keep alive a United States agent, Enrique Camarena, during torture in 1985.
Yet as Dr. Alvarez's case passed through the courts, Mexican officials became alarmed that the Administration was claiming a right to kidnap him and others if extradition treaties did not specifically prohibit it. The Supreme Court endorsement of that claim set off angry protests here.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House;
Bush Criticized Over Visit to Recycler

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
Days after President Bush angered participants in the Earth Summit at Rio de Janeiro, environmentalists are attacking him again for traveling Thursday to an oil-recycling company that has criticized the Administration's environmental policies.
On the first stop of a three-day campaign trip to California and Texas, Mr. Bush plans to tour Evergreen Oil Company, in Newark, Calif., which has been praised by environmentalists as being on the cutting edge in recycling used motor oil. 
 But environmental organizations asserted today that it was hypocritical of Mr. Bush to visit the company because his Administration has not been an advocate of the oil recycling industry. And they say they are surprised that Evergreen is welcoming Mr. Bush because it played an active role last year in a trade group's lawsuit against the Environmental Protection Agency on the issue.
Officials of Evergreen said today that they were pleased about the President's visit and the publicity it would bring. But Richard C. Fortuna, executive director of the Hazardous Waste Treatment Council, a group of high-tech companies, of which Evergreen is a member, that sued the E.P.A., called the trip an attempt by Mr. Bush to deflect attention from his environmental record.
"For George Bush to go stand in front of a refinery and preach environmentalism would be like Jimmy Swaggart going before the Vatican and preaching infidelity," Mr. Fortuna said.
 
Dispute Over Lead
 The treatment council was a plaintiff in a suit filed in May in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia that accused the E.P.A. of not properly regulating the burning of used oil. Environmentalists say Administration policies encourage burning the oil, which is less costly than purifying it, and thus give big oil companies that burn an advantage over small companies like Evergreen that recycle.
Environmentalists say companies that burn should be required to remove lead from the oil, which would increase their costs, but produce less pollution.
"While Evergreen is trying to clean up used oil, these other companies use it as a fuel," said Daniel J. Weiss, director of the Sierra Club's environmental quality program. "Because the Bush Administration has opposed regulating the lead content in used oil, Evergreen and other green companies have struggled to expand their businesses. This is another example of George Bush as the hypocrisy President, not the environmental President."
In addition to the lawsuit, an Evergreen official, Peter H. Weiner, criticized the E.P.A. in testimony last year before a subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, asserting that "it is time to take the lead out of E.P.A.'s pace in regulating used oil."
 
'Fantastic Press'
 But today, Curtis Morgan, chairman of the 100-employee company near San Jose, sought to play down differences with the Administration.
"This gives fantastic press for us and our industry," Mr. Morgan said. "We couldn't be happier. I don't know what the President's agenda is for coming here, but we're very happy he is."
Pressed on the Bush Administration's policies toward his industry, Mr. Morgan said: "We don't think it's enough, but we think it's a start. Things have been better than they were under the Reagan Administration."
Mr. Morgan said officials planning Mr. Bush's trip were referred to his company by the state Environmental Protection Agency.
Brushing aside the criticism, Torie Clarke, a spokeswoman for the Bush campaign, said: "Some of the environmental groups never miss an opportunity to score a few points. Evergreen happens to be a very good company. They are cleaning up the environment. They are good for the economy. They are on the cutting edge of U.S. industry. And they are very happy to have the President there."
Ms. Clarke said it was "not at all unusual in environmental matters" for companies to take part in suits against the Administration. "These things happen," she said. "It does not take away from the fact that the President is being welcomed."

NEW YORK CITY
 
MARKING GRADUATION AND SURVIVAL
In Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, where the streets constantly conspire against success, the more than 400 graduating seniors at Boys and Girls High are the survivors. They have resisted the temptations, avoided the violence and heeded the pressure to stay in school when the "in crowd" drops out. Now, as the final days of high school hurtle toward graduation next Thursday, the seniors at Boys and Girls are preparing for that ritual leap out of childhood. A1.
 
PORTRAIT OF AN ARSON SUSPECT
The homeless teen-ager accused in a string of recent fires in midtown Manhattan hotels was a troubled young man, in and out of schools and foster homes in the Philadelphia area before arriving here six months ago, educators and social workers who knew him in Philadelphia said yesterday. B3.

New York State has selected a development group to build ice-skating rinks, film and television studios and a marina on the Chelsea Piers as part of a plan to revitalize Manhattan's decaying Hudson River waterfront. B3.
 
NEW LIFE FOR 'FAME' SCHOOL
Last night a legendary 99-year-old building near Times Square, the inspiration for "Fame," both the movie and the television series about the High School of Performing Arts, came alive again. The building is the headquarters of Arts Connection, an organization founded by Linda LeRoy Janklow in 1979 to bring arts education into New York City's schools. C13.

BATTLING A WOOD-FIRED POWER PLANT

But residents feared that the plant would cause air pollution and successfully fought it in what many here viewed as a struggle between a grass-roots movement and a powerful outside developer. But the demise of the project had as much to do with changes in the economics of producing electricity. B7.

HEADLINE: Digging Out and Digging In;
Debate Over Dredging Sharpens as Port Channels Deepen in the Kill Van Kull

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER

 BODY:
The Rev. John H. Walsted tiptoed around a clicking seismograph in the sanctuary of his church, Christ Episcopal on Staten Island. Since the blasts began in November, granite blocks have shifted; a fissure opened in the majestic church's north wall; a crack split the belly of the baby Jesus in a stained glass window too precious to replace.
All this, he believes, has rumbled up from work on a waterway 3,500 feet from his 88-year-old church -- part of a dredging project billed as vital to the economy of the New York region. Like most dredging projects, this one is as massive as it is mundane: workers are blasting at the bedrock in the Kill Van Kull and Newark Bay to deepen the shipping channels from 35 to 40 feet. 
 Engineers reject claims that the underwater explosions are damaging the churches and Victorian mansions on Staten Island's north shore. But blasting has emerged as one of several issues focusing unusual attention on dredging, an almost ignored task that keeps the region's waterways deep and clear for commerce.
 
Depth Charges
 Critics have also raised questions about the long-range competitiveness of New York Harbor and whether the current, expensive work will make the channels deep enough to handle any ship that calls. And in a debate echoed in ports around the nation, a second, smaller dredging project proposed for Port Newark and Port Elizabeth is causing concern among environmental groups worried by the recent discovery of dioxin, a toxic chemical, there.
But few people oppose the dredging itself, which keeps alive a port industry responsible for 180,800 jobs and $17.7 billion each year to the region's economy.
"In New York, our port was God-given," said Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University. "Now we have to supplement God's generosity with our own ingenuity."
This is true for two reasons.
The first is nature: without dredging, silt flowing from the Passaic, Hackensack, Hudson and East Rivers would settle in the channels and slowly choke off sea lanes to a depth of 18 or 19 feet.
The second is competition: ships have grown larger and need deeper water. And in an atmosphere of increased competition among the ports on the East Coast -- where New York still remains the largest by far -- the deepest ports generally attract the most business.
"If ocean carriers lose confidence in our ability to adequately maintain our facility, they may divert their operations -- and that is something we never wish to see happen," said Lillian C. Liburdi, director of the port department of the Port Authority.
The $350 million dredging project was authorized by the Water Resources Development Act of 1986, which provides 65 percent Federal financing for such projects. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is paying the remaining 35 percent, and the Army Corps of Engineers, which disburses the Federal funds, has designed the project and is overseeing its execution.
The most immediate worry has come from the New Brighton and St. George sections of Staten Island, where residents complained of minor damage, most commonly dishes falling or cracks in walls.
Charles Joseph, a dentist on Westervelt Avenue, said that his two X-ray machines were out of commission for three days this spring after the shock waves broke the machines' control board.
Linda Bolesta, a 32-year-old Staten Island resident, has felt her 108-year-old house shudder half a dozen times a day and has found snaking cracks in her walls and in a new concrete floor in her cellar.
And Father Walsted looks nervously at the damage to his church and at its five Tiffany windows, valued at $4 million, recently restored and even more recently plagued with tiny cracks.
The Army Corps of Engineers contends that the blasting is not to blame and has stationed seismographs around the church and in homes in the area. The results, officials say, show no hint that the explosions are the problem.
But just to be sure, the Corps last month reduced by a quarter the amount of liquid explosives used in each blast and dug a trench in the Arthur Kill to absorb shocks.
Less dramatic, but more important for the port's long-term competitiveness, are worries that the dredgers are not going deep enough into the diamond-hard bedrock of the Kill Van Kull and Newark Bay.
There is no question that the channels to Port Newark and Port Elizabeth, the area's main container ports, are now too shallow. The channels are rated at only 35 feet, and some companies already face problems.
One is Naporano Iron and Metal Company, among the largest scrap-metal dealers in New Jersey. The company's co-owner, Andrew Naporano Jr., said that some ships, carrying cargo bound for points around the world, have had to wait until high tide to load and leave the piers in Newark.
"As soon as the tide comes in we have to go like crazy, and God forbid there is a breakdown," Mr. Naporano said. "It's like the clipper ships of old: sail with the tide."
 
10 Feet of Competitive Edge
 Some transportation experts question the decision by the Port Authority to dredge the channel to 40 feet, to be completed by 1994, when New York's main competitors on the East Coast, Norfolk and Baltimore, have already dredged to 50 feet.
Some worry that New York would still be behind even at 45 feet, a depth authorized in the Federal legislation that created the project, though the money has not been appropriated.
"The point is, we are always apparently going to be 5 feet short and 10 years late," said Jerrold Nadler, a New York State Assemblyman who advocates building a huge container port in Brooklyn, a project the Port Authority calls expensive and unfeasible.
Port Authority officials dismiss criticism that the dredging is too shallow, saying the port is used primarily by ships loaded with containers, the 40-foot aluminum boxes that revolutionized the shipping industry three decades ago. And at least for now, experts agree, most of those ships have drafts of 40 feet or less, though some of the newer ships need as much as an additional 5 feet.
There are, however, ships with much deeper drafts that carry bulk cargo like oil and coal, goods that Mr. Bea and others argue are less important to New York than at other ports.
If arguments about the channels' ideal depth sound theoretical, a more immediate issue is how to dispose of silt that is contaminated.
Dioxin has been found along 7 miles of berths at Port Elizabeth and Port Newark, which the authority wants to dredge this summer. They have applied for a permit from the Army Corps of Engineers to dump 600,000 cubic yards of the silt six miles off Sandy Hook, N.J. The project would last three years.
The authority's experts say the amount of dioxin is so small that it is like measuring molecules. And in any case, they intend to cover the material with clean fill to keep it from seeping into the ocean.
But opponents, environmental groups, fishers and some New Jersey politicians, say the dioxin can still work its way up the food chain.
They also say there is an even larger environmental issue: They accuse the authority of not looking at more progressive ways to treat the dredged material before it is dumped and want them to explore decontamination techniques.
"This region needs very much to bring new solutions to dredge material containment than simply moving it from part of the marine environment to another," said Sarah L. Clark, a staff scientist at the Environmental Defense Fund.
But decontamination, a process that uses a number of different technologies and is still in its infancy, costs money, and could raise the price of dumping the silt from $5 to hundreds of dollars per cubic yard. That rise could have a broad impact on dredging projects, given that each year roughly 6 million cubic yards of silt, clay and rock are dredged from the harbor -- enough to fill three towers of the World Trade Center.
"If you change any aspect of what the normal operation is, you could increase the costs," said John F. Tavolaro, the Army Corps's assistant chief of operations. "To what magnitude is uncertain."

The Economy
Statistical and anecdotal evidence is mounting almost daily that the recovery is gathering momentum, dispelling fears that the flameout that occurred in the second half of 1991 will reoccur. [D1] In the latest such report, output per hour in nonfarm businesses grew at a robust annual rate of 2.7 percent last winter. [D2.]
Ford and Chrysler are producing cars at a lower basic cost than their Japanese rivals, according to a new study. But other analysts said the report may have overstated the case. [D1] 
 A House committee voted for tough new rate regulation on most cable television systems but stopped short of the measure passed by the Senate in January. [D13.]
Profits at savings and loan associations rebounded in the first three months of the year to their best total in six years. [D2.]
 
Markets
Stock prices fell sharply, shaken by domestic political concerns, big falls in markets abroad and tremors linked to the pending expiration of options. The Dow fell 41.73, to 3,287.76. [D1.] The Tokyo stock market plunged to its lowest level since late 1986. [D10]
Treasury security prices edged up on favorable economic news, as the yield on the long bond slipped to 7.81 percent. [D17.]
Yields offered by money market funds were down last week. [D9.]
Sugar futures prices soared to their highest levels in nearly a year. [D18.] The dollar posted gains worldwide. [D18.]
 
International
Foreign cars are pouring into Russia, where demand is high. Most are second-hand vehicles, purchased or stolen abroad and often sold for less than $6,000 apiece. [D1.]
China has signed an oil exploration contract with an American company for a disputed stretch of the South China Sea. [A8.]
 
Companies
New York regulators gave the go-ahead for the merger on July 1 of Phoenix Mutual Life and Home Life. It would be the biggest combination ever of two mutual life insurance companies. [D4.]
Upjohn's earnings will not exceed the results of the comparable quarter a year ago, and the company offered early retirement to about 10 percent of its work force in an effort to reduce costs. [D4.]
A class-action lawsuit says Philips misled investors into thinking the company's prospects were improving. [D4.]
The latest computer mouse has a pointed nose and two button "ears." It is intended to be used by children. [D4.]
Intel won its court case asserting that Advanced Micro Devices does not have rights to the microcode in an Intel chip. [D5.]
American Airlines expects a loss in the second quarter because of lower fares, rising fuel prices and sluggish traffic. [D5.]
A new president was named for GM Japan. J. Michael Durrie was given the assignment of expanding sales in Japan. [D5.]
Trustees of bankrupt truckers can pursue limited claims against certain shippers, a Federal appeals court ruled. But it closed off other claims that could have totaled billions. [D7.]
The chairman and chief financial officer resigned from Mirror Group Newspapers, part of Robert Maxwell's empire. [D8.]

Parametric Technology's explosive growth is winning praise from Wall Street analysts, thanks to its innovative Pro/Engineer computer-aided design software. Market Place. [D10.]
From fishing kits to caboodles cosmetics cases, Plano Molding is finding a demand for its products among models and teens and intends to rev it up with an ad campaign. Advertising. [D19.]

HEADLINE: Nimby and Economics Kill Plans for Wood-Powered Plant

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORRINGTON, Conn.

 BODY:
Here in this northwestern Connecticut city surrounded by the forested foothills of the Berkshires, a plan to build a wood-fired power plant might seem as natural as throwing a few more logs on the fireplace.
But residents, fearing that such a plant would cause air pollution, successfully fought plans to build it in what many here viewed as a struggle between a grass-roots movement and an outside developer. 
 The demise of the project, however, had just as much to do with changes in the economics of producing electricity, which undermined a state-sponsored alternative-energy program born in the oil-panicked 1980's.
Since the Torrington project was conceived, prices for oil have dropped and the demand for electricity has fallen far short of what was expected. As a result, there is little incentive to shift to alternative fuels.
So, under a bill passed by the General Assembly, the developer will be bought out as part of an $18 million package. And consumers will pay for the buyout through higher electric bills.

 
Developer Buyout
 The story of the Torrington plant began six years ago, when the developer, Kenetech Energy Systems, through a subsidiary called Bio-Gen, proposed a wood-burning power plant on land in a sparsely populated northern section of the city. Concerns about air pollution led the city to fight the project, but it seemed as if it would be going ahead this April when the City Council agreed to drop its opposition in exchange for $450,000 from the company to cover the city's legal costs.
After hearing about the deal, about 500 angry Torrington citizens, led by Ralph Nader, who grew up in nearby Winsted, marched on City Hall. Eventually the City Council agreed to hold a referendum on whether Torrington should continue to spend money to fight the project. In the referendum, held late last month, the voters said yes -- by a ratio of more than 10 to 1.
In the meantime, the utility company that was to have purchased power from the plant was losing interest. Electrical consumption is down in Connecticut and elsewhere in the region, mainly because the recession has closed businesses and factories or pushed them to relocate.
So the state devised an agreement that would more than repay Bio-Gen for its investment, out of which the company would repay Torrington for its legal fees incurred in the opposition battle. Another developer with a similar proposal in Killingly, a town near the Rhode Island border, would also be bought out under the same legislation. The agreement was approved by the Legislature earlier this month, and Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. is expected to sign the bill within a few weeks.
"We're just very happy we're getting our money and they're gone," said Torrington's Mayor, Delia R. Donne, who took office the year the plant was proposed. "Nobody wants anything in their backyard."
 
Based on Predictions
 State regulatory officials and a spokesman for the power company, Northeast Utilities, admit that a project like the Bio-Gen plant, which seemed like a bright idea in 1986, had become an expensive albatross by this year. Many proposed projects were predicated on the notion that oil prices would keep rising when, in fact, they have fallen to about $15 a barrel today from $35 a barrel in 1985.
At least 25 other power plants, which provide about 10 percent of the electricity used by Northeast's customers, were built under the state program, which began under Federal encouragement after oil prices shot up during the 1970's. About 60 percent of Northeast's power comes from nuclear plants, and another 20 percent from oil. The last 10 percent is generated by company-owned coal-burning, hydroelectric or natural gas plants, said a spokesman, Jeffrey Kotkin.
When economic analysts predicted that Connecticut's dependence on oil would mean horrifically expensive electricity, the State Department of Public Utility Control ordered power companies to sign agreements with suppliers that did not use oil, Mr. Kotkin said.
Those contracts will be lucrative for the next 20 to 30 years for the developers, who receive far more per kilowatt hour than the utility spends on oil-fired plants, Mr. Kotkin said. They are paid 9 cents per kilowatt hour, compared with the 3 1/2 cents that it costs the utility for the other plants, he said, and the price is to rise over the course of the contracts. "The idea was to create a more diverse fuel mix," he said. "But none of them are economically beneficial."
Similarly, a New York State law passed to encourage co-generation, or production of electricity and the use of steam, guarantees generators 6 cents per kilowatt-hour, but utilities say they can make their own power for 3 cents. Richard M. Flynn, the chairman of the New York Power Authority, estimates that over the next 10 years, New York customers may pay $4.5 billion to $5 billion in extra costs because of the provision, which Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is seeking to repeal.
 
Alternative-Energy Plans
 In Connecticut, developers leaped on the alternative-energy plan, and about 30 projects were proposed, including the two wood-burning projects.
William R. Breetz, a Hartford lawyer who represents Bio-Gen, expressed amazement that the project had been so controversial. "A lot of the fear grows out of the evidence that wood smoke by itself is not good to have around you," he said. But he called that "the great irony," noting that emission controls have advanced to the point where the threat of pollution is minimal.
A chief opponent of the project, Steven H. Levy, said the location of the plant, in a valley, would have made the smoke linger around Torrington. "As far as health risks are concerned," said Mr. Levy, who is the treasurer of a group called Citizens Against Pollution, "although nuclear power has risks in an explosion, this has health risks associated with it 365 days a year."
Another opponent, Karen LaRocco, said, "Everybody kept saying there's no way you can fight City Hall, no way you can fight Bio-Gen; it's a done deal." The referendum proved the opposite, she said.
As for the long-term effect on the consumer, Mr. Kotkin said costs will be lower than they would have been if the wood-fired plants had been built. "If these projects actually went through, customer bills between 1994 and 2019 would be $150 million higher," he said. "Public opposition didn't play into our decision at all. Our concern was a financial one."
Mr. Breetz, the Bio-Gen lawyer, disagreed.
"I think public hysteria is a fair description of what has happened," he said, "not only with our project but with a great number of projects. I got a call the other night from a group that wanted to retain our firm to fight a bandstand being proposed in a public park. What we've reached in this country is a sense that people have a right to the absence of change."

HEADLINE: S.& L.'s Earnings Rebound; Outlook Is Less Optimistic

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
Profits at the nation's savings and loan associations rebounded in the first three months of the year, to $1.59 billion, the best performance in six years, the Government said today. Nevertheless, the Congressional Budget Office and private analysts offered lawmakers a less optimistic view of the future of the industry.
Earnings at the healthy portion of the industry, the 2,064 institutions that remain in private hands, more than doubled from $610 million a year ago, the Office of Thrift Supervision said, with 93 percent of the institutions reporting earnings. 
 As for the agency's expected-to-fail list, the office said that after seizing 711 institutions since 1989, only 37 remain to be taken over. In the agency's second-worst category, institutions not in immediate risk, 24 were still a subject of particular concern, the office said.
 
650 New Failures Seen
 But Robert D. Reischauer, the budget office director, told the lawmakers that as many as 650 savings and loans might yet fail, adding that many experts feel the industry could not be declared fully healthy until real estate markets recover.
"The cleanup of the thrift crisis is not over," Mr. Reischauer told the committee. "Thrifts are still not as profitable as they once were."
But he said the data on the industry "provide room for guarded optimism about its long-term viability, albeit as a much smaller player."
The two primary reasons for the recent improvement, the thrift office said, are the Government's seizures of insolvent savings and loans since 1989 and current interest-rate conditions -- the most favorable for financial institutions since the 1970's.
But the office sharply revised the industry's earnings for all of last year, to $1.83 billion, down from an earlier estimate of $2 billion.
Private analysts cautioned against an overly optimistic reading of the improved earnings report.
"From a taxpayer's perspective, the fact that 90 percent of the industry is doing well is secondary to how the worst 5 or 10 percent are doing because that's where the threat lies," said Bert Ely, a financial institutions analyst in Alexandria, Va.
In particular, one or more large savings and loans in California are in danger of failing, he said.
 
Election Politics Cited
 Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan, the chairman of the Senate panel, and other Congressional Democrats have questioned whether the Bush Administration is trying to keep a lid on bad banking and savings industry news until after the election.
Kenneth H. Thomas, a bank and savings and loan analyst in Miami, said the Federal agency might be understating its count of likely failures by 50 percent.
The worst institutions will also probably continue to pile up losses because the Government cannot afford to close them. Regulators have spent $88 billion on failed savings and loans since 1989; the Administration estimates it needs as much as $42 billion more.
 
Bailout Money on Hold
 But Congress let the spending authority of the bailout agency, the Resolution Trust Corporation, lapse on April 1 and election-year pressures may prevent lawmakers from voting for more money before next spring.
"Things can only get worse in those problem institutions and that hurts everybody," Mr. Ely said. "They contaminate the market."

HEADLINE: Economic Memo;
The Tea Leaves Are Ready

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
With the American economy about to wrap up its fifth straight quarter of expansion, the economic priests who consecrate the beginnings and ends of business cycles are likely to convene sometime this summer to declare the nation's ninth postwar recession officially over.
Many economists believe the dating committee will declare recovery to have begun as long ago as the spring of 1991. But it is only now that the evidence of sustained upturn can be said to look persuasive enough to invite confident declaration. 
 Statistical and anecdotal evidence is mounting almost daily that the recovery is gathering momentum -- although unevenly -- dispelling fears that the flameout that took place during the second half of 1991 will reoccur.
 
Reluctant Consumers
 Those fears have centered on reticent consumers, who account for two-thirds of the economy. They have become more tight-fisted in recent months after an early-year spending spree. In May, for example, retail sales rose only two-tenths of 1 percent.
But consumer confidence polls reflect consumers' expectations of brighter prospects for income and employment. A recent one by Sindlinger & Company, for example, shows household confidence rising for the fourth time in a row last week.
The possibility of relapse is also diminished by Government reports on Tuesday that construction of new housing, which had shown signs of faltering after setting the recovery's early pace, rebounded in May while industrial output posted its fourth straight solid advance.
Two more pieces of optimistic evidence emerged today in surveys by the Federal Reserve and the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation.
Dun & Bradstreet found business expectations for increased sales to be the highest in three years, embracing every major industry. "The economic recovery is now firmly reflected in business order books, leading to improved business confidence," said Joseph W. Duncan, the company's chief economist.
The Federal Reserve's "beige book" -- the survey of economic activity it puts together every six weeks to aid in its policy deliberations -- was also quite bullish. It said that "economic activity continues to improve," and that manufacturing appeared to strengthen in all 12 Fed districts.
Although economists tend to dismiss this survey as merely anecdotal, the widespread nature of the improvement did impress some, as did the Fed's finding that long-depressed loan demand seems to be increasing in most districts.
And the Fed's survey was consistent with comments by corporate executives in interviews today.
"Business is starting to turn up for us," said Norman Katz, head of Qual Craft Industries, a producer of scaffolding brackets and ladder jacks in Stoughton, Mass., outside Boston. "Our order books are filled," he added, noting that he had recently hired four more workers and raised wages for the first time in nearly two years.
In Kent, Ohio, Gougler Industries reported brisker business for plastics used in bathroom fixtures and for air hammers for the mining and construction industries. The company, with sales of $20 million a year, has recalled 10 of 15 laid-off production workers in the last two weeks.
Larry Wittensoldner, the company's controller, said he remained cautious -- partly because of the Presidential election campaign -- and was not yet building inventory. But he noted that conditions were clearly improving. "We're on the rise," he said.
Economists expect manufacturers to do increasingly well, benefiting from an economy with generally lean stocks of goods that mean stepped-up demand will quickly translate into new orders. Prospects for export business, which provided early support for the fledgling recovery, may be fading, however, as overseas economies slow.
Last week's report of one-tenth of 1 percent consumer inflation for May was mostly reassuring, indicating that consumers would retain buying power and suggesting that the Fed would not need to raise interest rates anytime soon. But it also pointed to what many experts regard as the most ominous of the various clouds remaining clouds on the economic horizon.
This is the extraordinary slow growth in the M-2 money supply -- currency, checking accounts, savings accounts and money market mutual funds -- which historically has shown a strong correlation with national output.
 
Worried About Lag
 Although some analysts offer benign explanations for this phenomenon, senior Administration officials are known to be worried that this lag reflects underlying economic weakness. This worry, especially when combined with the political imperatives of the Presidential election, suggests an intensifying campaign to urge the Federal Reserve to insure against a fresh downturn by once again cutting interest rates.
Some Federal Reserve officials, however, are wary that further monetary easing would raise long-term rates by fanning the embers of inflation.
But for now the eyes are mainly on the performance of the economy, and on the National Bureau of Economic Research, the private body that has been designated the official arbiter of business contractions and expansions. The bureau determined that the economy slipped into recession in July 1990 and now is watching eagerly to mark the recession's end and the simultaneous beginning of recovery. The seven members of the dating committee, all academics and scattered around the country, are governed not by the number of quarters of growth in domestic product but with four more specific indicators -- employment, production, income and sales.
In a speech last week assessing the recovery, Susan M. Phillips, a Fed governor, said "No one can forecast with confidence exactly when the positives in the outlook will completely outweigh the remaining negatives" and the possibility of setback cannot be dismissed. "But, that said, there are clearly reasons to be encouraged about both the longer-run and near-term prospects."

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON: Reporter's Notebook;
The 'Burly' Yeltsin Acquires a New Kind of Stature: Major World Figure

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
A mere two days in Washington, and Boris N. Yeltsin already has some Americans muttering, "Mikhail who?"
This Russian-American summit meeting has in many ways been Mr. Yeltsin's cotillion -- his debut as a world leader -- and in the minds of many here he has demonstrated that he knows all the steps mastered by the President of the old Soviet Union, Mikhail S. Gorbachev. In the process, he seems to have gained a purchase on the title that Mr. Gorbachev inherited, but which Mr. Yeltsin has had to earn through hard labor: that of a global figure. 
 Mr. Yeltsin came to town with a lingering reputation as a rough-hewn politician, his name usually preceded by the adjective "burly," his past strewn with rumors of heavy drinking and disappearances at odd times. When he first visited the United States, in 1989, his Soviet rivals circulated stories that he lost a bout with a bottle of Jack Daniels during an overnight stop at Johns Hopkins University. Some White House officials regarded him with ill-concealed derision.
But Mr. Yeltsin now seems to have dispatched all that. Unlike Mr. Gorbachev, a somewhat pedantic leader whose style was to lecture his audiences, often for hours, the Russian President is more a kindred spirit of the lawmakers he wowed today in an address to a joint meeting of Congress: down-home, always ready with a sound bite. Something of a horse-trader. Shrewd.
That image is both genuine and cultivated, for Mr. Yeltsin is picking up some tricks from his new friends in the arts of politics and public relations, American style.
Before leaving Moscow, an American senator said today, Mr. Yeltsin was given a present by the United States Ambassador to Russia, Robert S. Strauss, to help him prepare for his speech to Congress. It was a videotape recording of an earlier address to the House and Senate by Vaclav Havel, the Czechoslovakian playwright who rose from political imprisonment to the presidency of his country in a matter of weeks after the fall of Communist rule there.
Mr. Havel's speech caused a sensation; Mr. Yeltsin, needing a powerhouse performance to win Congres's approval of economic aid for his country, topped him. Senator Al Gore, a Tennessee Democrat, called Mr. Yeltsin's remarks "classic oratory -- a piece de resistance." Representative Jerry Lewis, a California Republican, said, "He had everyone in the palm of his hand."
"We understood exactly what he was trying to say," Mr. Lewis said. "He was a politican talking to other politicians."
Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Bush both seemed to grasp the fact today that the Russian leader had escaped the long shadow of Mr. Gorbachev, a man who had mesmerized average Americans and their Presidents alike with his flirtations with democratic rule and his frantic dance atop the Soviet power pyramid.
Asked at a news conference why reports had remained secret so long about the possibility of American prisoners of war being held inside Russia, Mr. Yeltsin replied smartly: "You have had a chance to ask the question of the former President of the former Soviet Union why he kept this a secret. I am not responsible for
And Mr. Bush, significantly, interjected, "Good answer."
 
Shipmates of State
 Beyond the George-and-Boris routine, beneath the flowery toasts and heartfelt pledges of eternal alliance, there is one sure-fire sign that Mr. Bush has also elevated Mr. Yeltsin to his A-list of world leaders. He is taking him out on boats.
Mr. Bush, who competes with John F. Kennedy as our most hydrophilic President, always lures his favorite world leaders, or at least the ones he wants most to impress, out on the water. He squires best-friend Brian Mulroney, Canada's Prime Minister, on high-speed chases around Maine's seacoast in his Cigarette boat, Fidelity. He took another favorite, former Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan, for a more sedate cruise in Fidelity to view the regional wildlife. Unable to find a speedboat for his 1990 summit meeting with Mr. Gorbachev off the Mediterranean island of Malta, the President insisted that both men anchor off the isle in ships.
President Francois Mitterrand of France, not a favorite of Mr. Bush but a needed ally nonetheless, refused the President's entreaties to go to sea. Mal de mer, he said.
The first time Mr. Yeltsin came to Washington as Russia's leader, last February, Mr. Bush rewarded him with a few hours at the Presidential retreat in Camp David, Md. But today, his alliance with the Russian leader sealed and delivered, the President took Mr. Yeltsin by helicopter to nearby Annapolis and sailed with him for an hour and a quarter on the picturesque Severn River.
Alas, his 80-mile-per-hour Fidelity was moored in Maine. The two leaders putted sedately upriver in a converted PT boat once seized from drug dealers and now owned by the Chief of Naval Operations. Top speed: 14 knots.
 
Footnote on Flight 007

At his news conference with Mr. Bush in the East Room of the White House, Mr. Yeltsin offered a glimpse into the dark world of the former Soviet empire, which his Government is only just starting to unravel.
Asked what information Moscow might have about the downing of the South Korean jumbo jet, KAL Flight 007, in September 1985, Mr. Yeltsin began a cloak-and-dagger tale on the evening of Aug. 20, 1991, as the attempted Kremlin coup was collapsing.
"When it was clear that the coup leaders had lost, we seized the archives of the K.G.B. and the former Central Committee of the Communist Party and we placed armed guards around the building," he said. "But several hours before that, one car from each place had time to remove some of the archives from those two buildings and destroy them. We do not know what was in those archives."
Now, he said, the Russians are trying to trace those missing archives by combing through what is left. In doing so, "we stumbled upon one document which we feel might be the beginning of a chain that might help us to unravel the entire tragedy with the Korean Boeing."
Mr. Yeltsin said the document was "a memorandum from K.G.B. to the Central Committee of the Communist Party" that referred to documents "which would clarify the entire picture."
"The next line then says these documents are so well concealed that it is doubtful that our children will be able to find them," he said.
And that, the Russian President said, "is our task." He promised that as soon as the documents were found, "I will be the first to call President Bush personally and tell him about it."

HEADLINE: U.S. Output Per Hour On the Rise

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
After two years of stagnant sales, relentless belt tightening and waves of white-collar layoffs, the productivity of American businesses is on the rebound.
Output per hour in businesses other than farms grew at a robust annual rate of 2.7 percent last winter, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. That is the biggest spurt in two years. 
 "It looks as though productivity is picking up widely," said Michael Harper, director of the office of productivity research at the bureau.
Perkier productivity growth -- typical when the economy recovers from recession -- is good for costs, profits and inflation.
"From the point of view of firms, it's very good," said Mark Lasky, an economist at DRI/McGraw Hill.
Higher productivity is helping to ease cost pressures. Unit labor costs, the bureau reported, have been slowing for several quarters and actually fell a bit in the first quarter. Pay has also been rising more slowly.
 
Gains in Service Area
 The productivity surge reflects efficiency gains in the nation's sprawling service economy -- from airlines to banks to retail chains. And some economists saw that as one of the first concrete signs that the far-reaching effort to streamline service companies and the ranks of their white-collar work forces is paying off.
"The bulk of the efficiency improvements were powered by the tremendous improvements in the service sector," said Stephen Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley. "Services is starting -- and I stress starting -- to turn the corner."
The process still has a long way to go, executives and economists alike agree. "Technology has moved faster than management has been willing to redeploy people," said Scott G. McNealy, chief executive at Sun Microsystems.
Factory productivity actually slipped at a 1 percent annual rate in the first quarter. But experts shrugged off the dip as a measurement fluke. According to Mr. Harper, manufacturing output fell faster than hours until it hit a trough in January. Even though output improved after that, the depressed January level held down the quarterly average.
"This isn't a sign that the gains in manufacturing have come to an end, absolutely not," Mr. Harper said. "Manufacturing output has gone up sharply since January, and hours haven't gone up as fast."
Several economists saw the productivity spurt as a sign -- if hardly proof -- that the nation's long-run productivity trend may be improving. Productivity has been stagnating -- edging up less than 1 percent a year -- for nearly two decades.
"There's a hint of something more than a cyclical recovery," Mr. Lasky, the DRI economist, said. He thinks the latest report is consistent with DRI's forecast of a slightly better trend for the 1990's -- somewhere between 1 percent and 1.5 percent at an annual rate.
To be sure, there are caveats. Productivity always leaps at the start of recoveries because managers are typically reluctant to hire new hands and instead fill new orders by driving workers harder. And, as always, a single quarter -- subject in any case to future revisions -- does not make a trend.
For workers, the productivity report contains mixed news. On the one hand, business can produce more with fewer hands. Indeed, total hours have declined for eight straight quarters through the winter, and the number of jobs did not climb above last year's levels until last month.
But, in the long run, nothing could be better than a productivity revival. The pace of productivity growth basically determines how quickly living standards -- lately a source of worry for many Americans -- can rise.

HEADLINE: Drought Unites South Africa and Neighbors

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, June 16

 BODY:
Past withered cornfields and sun-cracked river beds, freight trains packed with grain have been rolling across the parched farmland of the Transvaal, carrying relief to South Africa's once hostile northern neighbors.
With southern Africa parched by the worst drought in recent memory, South Africa, with its modern harbors, railway network and highways, has emerged as the region's lifeline for grain imports, even as it struggles with its own drought problems. 
 South Africa, which once ranked behind the United States and Argentina as a grain exporting country, is handling up to 10 million tons of imported grain this year. Of this, over 4.5 million tons of corn and one million tons of other grain will be consumed in South Africa, according to Frans Loots, a spokesman for Agriculture Minister Kraai van Niekirk.
 
Imports for Neighbors
 The other 4.5 million tons of corn are being shipped to Zimbabwe, Zambia and other countries facing dire food shortages. By one estimate, two million million tons of corn are being transported to Zimbabwe and at least 800,000 tons each to Malawi and Zambia. Corn meal forms the dietary staple throughout southern Africa.
The logistics of food distribution were thrashed out at a conference in Pretoria on April 22 and attended by officials from South Africa, Zimbabwe, Zamibia, Botswana and Malawi.
The United States has pledged $382 million in food and cash assistance to the southern Africa region to combat the drought. The recipients have not included South Africa, which sold 100,000 tons of its grain to Zimbabwe and Zambia before realizing the extent of its own deficit. Because of the drought, South Africa's food imports are expected to rise by $1.3 billion.
Agriculture Minister van Niekirk said it would cost South Africa $661 million just to import 4.6 million tons of corn, or 70 percent of its domestic requirement, up to next April.
The relief effort has given South Africa the opportunity to display its regional indispensability at a time when it has won new acceptance in Africa because of the steps taken by President F. W. de Klerk to dismantle apartheid.
About half of the grain imported into South Africa is being channeled through Durban, with the rest handled at other ports in Cape Town, East London and Port Elizabeth. Describing the logistics involved, Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha said moving one million tons of imported food would require 30 large ships, 750 freight trains or 33,000 truckloads.
The magnitude of the supply effort raised fears of congestion on railways and roads unaccustomed to such a volume of traffic, but the initial delays were bureaucratic. South African trucks carrying the first grain into Zimbabwe were held up at the border while Zimbabwean customs officials imposed various taxes and road fees. No such problems have been reported for trains delivering most of the grain.
At the same time, South Africa must cope with its own grain shortage. Its annual grain harvests averaged 7.5 million tons, of which up to two million tons were once exported. This year, agricultural officials have predicted a harvest of 2.3 million tons.
Johan Willemse, an agricultural economist, has described the drought as the worst in 59 years.

HEADLINE: China Signs U.S. Oil Deal for Disputed Waters

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, June 17

 BODY:
In an aggressive move to take control of disputed territory in the South China Sea, the Chinese Government has signed an oil exploration contract with an American company for a stretch of the sea that is also claimed by Vietnam.
The contract marks the first time in many years that any country has acted unilaterally to develop the rich mineral resources in the southern part of the sea, which is the subject of overlapping claims by China, Vietnam, the Philippines, Malaysia, Indonesia, Taiwan and Brunei. 
 The last time such a contract was awarded was apparently 1973, when the collapsing Government of South Vietnam gave Western companies oil concessions that included disputed territory. That led to a battle in January 1974 between Chinese and Vietnamese naval forces.
China has pledged that it will use its navy to back the American oil company, and the move seems certain to raise tensions in the area. Vietnam has protested strongly, the Philippines has described the award of the contract as "unhelpful," and other nations are concerned that Beijing now intends to use force to assert its claims.
"There are some indications that China is changing its policy toward disputed areas and taking a more aggressive stance," an Asian diplomat in Beijing said. "But it's still too early to say if this is a turning point."
Randall C. Thompson, chairman of theCrestone Energy Corporation, the Denver-based company that won the contract, said he knew that the area was disputed but had strong backing from China.
"I was assured by top Chinese officials that they will protect me with their full naval might," Mr. Thompson said by telephone. "That's what they told me in negotiations -- that they'll have the entire full naval fleet out there backing me up, if necessary."
Giving the contract to an American company was a canny move by China, because it means that any forceful intervention by Vietnam might harm relations with Washington as well as Beijing. Vietnam has made great efforts in recent years to improve ties with China, and it particularly wants to establish diplomatic and economic relations with the United States.
China claims a huge swath of the South China Sea, extending more than 1,000 miles south of the nearest populated Chinese island. The waters it claims virtually lap against Vietnam, Malaysia and the Philippines. In 1988, China and Vietnam fought a brief naval battle over the disputed waters.
The area includes the Spratly and Paracel island groups, which China calls the Nansha and Xisha chains. These archipelagos, consisting mostly of uninhabited islands, control fisheries and important international sea lanes and are also thought to contain valuable oil and mineral deposits.
The contract, signed on May 8, covers 9,700 square miles that are claimed only by Vietnam and China.
Mr. Thompson said that the area was extremely promising, but that Crestone would first have to conduct extensive data analysis and that it would be a year or two before it sends any boats into the area.
A United States Embassy officer was present at the signing of the contract, but the embassy said later that it had no involvement in the negotiations, that territorial disputes should be resolved peacefully and that freedom of navigation should be preserved.
