HEADLINE: Poles Learn the Hard Way; Schools Are Hurt by Reform

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW, June 17

 BODY:
The only decoration in the physics lab at Copernicus High School is a large display of the molecular structure of cement. In the chemistry classroom next door, a cracked, sun-beaten poster of the Polish-born Nobel laureate Marie Curie looks over lopsided tables and chairs. Broken cupboards reveal only chipped and stained flasks.
The appearance of one of Warsaw's most elite schools is revealing enough, but the state of education is even worse than these dilapidated classrooms would suggest. While the country's economy is at a critical point, it is education here, as in many other countries, that is suffering most. 
 Indeed, Poland's two-year-old economic reform plan, which has slashed state subsidies and increased prices of most goods and services -- but not wages -- to world levels, has hit teachers and students particularly hard.
 
Salaries of $150 a Month
 Budget cuts have forced the elimination of all extracurricular activities, from physical education to classes for students with learning disabilities. Teachers, who are the lowest-paid workers in the nation, earn an average of $150 a month, compared with the national industrial wage of about $200. Low salaries and budget cuts may sound familiar to American educators, but in Poland, as in other former East-bloc countries, teachers were accustomed to relatively high pay for 45 years.
Some schools, like Copernicus High School, are in such financial straits they must appeal to parents for donations to keep afloat.
"Imagine asking parents to help supplement your budget," said Albert Stoma, principal of Copernicus High School. "It's just not right. It is a public school, something the state has provided for decades. And now look. We don't even have enough money for garbage collection, or floor-cleaning detergent. Some days we don't heat the school to save money."
Teachers' salaries, the Ministry of Education says, consume 90 percent of Polish school expenditures. That leaves little for new, much-needed books and new science equipment, let alone computers. Or for competitive salaries for language teachers, especially English instructors, who can easily put their skills to use at well-paying Western companies. In fact, in 1991, a year in which prices rose 70 percent, teachers' wages actually dropped 17 percent.
 
Teacher Shortage Predicted
 "Morale is very, very low," said Krystyna Humiecka, a Warsaw English teacher who, with 20 years of service, earns only $150 a month for her 34-hour workweek. She teaches English privately for three hours a week, earning an additional $120 to supplement her income.
"This crisis is not just affecting us," she said. "Of course students today, and students a few years from now, will suffer, too, because we are going to have a shortage of teachers."
Rafal Krawczyk, a 17-year-old high school junior, said he could sense the struggles his instructors face. "You can see it's hard on them," he said. "You can tell they're worried, and tired. Most of them have to take extra jobs."
Another student complained about outdated textbooks and aging science equipment. "Many schools in Poland are hoping for miracles," Mr. Stoma, the principal, said.

HEADLINE: Council Seeks to Block Limiting Of Its Power Over Landmarking

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Fearing that its power over landmarking decisions was severely limited by a recent court ruling, the New York City Council said yesterday that it would seek to have the decision overturned.
At stake, Council leaders say, is the Council's power to make changes in City Landmarks Preservation Commission decisions without entirely rejecting the landmark designation. 
 Last month, a New York State appeals court handed down a ruling that said landmark designations could not be compromised for political or economic reasons. The ruling by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan overturned a decision by the Board of Estimate in its last days before it was disbanded in the new City Charter.
In 1990, the board tinkered with a landmarks commission designation to allow Peter S. Kalikow, the developer and publisher, to build an enormous apartment tower on the site of 4 of 14 historic tenements that the commission had designated as a historic district.
The 14-building complex between 78th and 79th Streets on the Upper East Side is known as City and Suburban York Estates. It was given landmark status in April 1990 over the protests of Mr. Kalikow and with the support of a neighborhood group that opposed the new apartment tower.
 
Intense Lobbying
 Four months later, after intense lobbying from the developer, the Board of Estimate separated four of the easternmost buildings from the historic district so that Mr. Kalikow could build there.
Preservationists sued the city and eventually won. Last month the five-member Appellate Division said the board had no right to carve up or alter a historic district for "arbitrary or capricious" reasons.
The decision meant the board should only have considered the landmarks commission's arguments for the historical or esthetic importance of the site, not whether it would hinder development, cost jobs or crimp tax revenues.
Now the Council's leadership, which under the 1989 City Charter revision has inherited the old Board of Estimate's power over land-use decisions, fears the broadly worded decision will clip its wings.
"It would turn us into a rubber stamp," said Peg Breen, a spokeswoman for Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone. "It pretty much wipes out the role of the Legislature."
 
No Precedent Is Seen
 The Dinkins administration sees it differently. O. Peter Sherwood, the city's Corporation Counsel, said the administration does not believe the decision will set a precedent that will curb the Council's authority since it concerns a specific project and a defunct board.
Mr. Sherwood said the Mayor decided not to appeal the decision because he agreed with the preservationists. When he was Manhattan Borough President, Mr. Dinkins was one of five members of the Board of Estimate who voted against changing the landmarks designation for Mr. Kalikow's benefit.
Since the Council was not sued in the original lawsuit, its lawyers will petition the Appellate Division for the right to appeal the decision to the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals in Albany, Ms. Breen said.
Ms. Breen insisted that the Council was not entering the fray to aid Mr. Kalikow, who also owns The New York Post, but rather to protect its legislative prerogatives. Yet that is not the way it looked to some preservationists.
"It seems to me the only one whose interest is served by the appeal is Kalikow," said Anthony C. Wood, president of Friends of the Upper East Side Historic Districts, one of the groups who fought for the historic district. "The Council may be more concerned with currying favor with the owner of a daily newspaper than anything else."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Labor;
Union Leaders Seek to Keep Auto Workers From the Arms of Perot

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, June 17

 BODY:
Already buffeted by weaknesses in the auto industry, layoffs at aerospace plants and setbacks in Washington, the United Automobile Workers Union now has a political headache: an independent Presidential candidate enticing its members to break ranks with the union's endorsed candidate.
Yet a recent survey suggested there were insurgent stirrings among union members in support of Ross Perot, and U.A.W. leaders meeting here are publicly taking steps to counter them. They are predicting that support for Mr. Perot will fade as he and his ideas become better known, and they are planning to publicize what they say is his history of anti-union activity. 
 The leaders are hoping auto workers will ultimately turn out strongly for Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, who won the union's endorsement after he aligned himself with striking workers at Caterpillar Inc. earlier this year and supported legislation to prevent the hiring of permanent replacement workers during strikes.
But privately, union leaders say they are not surprised by Mr. Perot's popularity.
 
Linking Decline to G.O.P.
 Rank-and-file support of Democratic candidates has been difficult to muster since 1980, when many union auto workers, especially white men, voted for Ronald Reagan and then for George Bush. Indeed, the disenchantment of union voters with the Democratic Party has been an important factor in the party's poor showing in the last three Presidential elections.
So U.A.W. leaders are now working overtime to make the point that labor's losses in the workplace are linked to Republican economic policies. They charge, for example, that Republican opposition to protectionist policy that would restrain Japanese auto sales in this country helped force the American auto industry to reorganize. That restructuring has reduced U.A.W. membership in the last decade by nearly 40 percent, to less than 900,000 in 1991.
Evidence of Mr. Perot's popularity was found in a small poll that The Detroit Free Press published last week. It said that among of 150 U.A.W. members in the Detroit area, 50 said they would most likely vote for Mr. Perot, 37 for Mr. Clinton and 15 for President Bush, with the remaining 48 undecided. Beyond that, there is anecdotal evidence suggesting that U.A.W. members are ready to abandon their support of Republicans, which makes Mr. Perot's emergence all the more frustrating to Clinton supporters.
Mr. Perot may have attracted some auto workers with statements opposing free trade with Mexico and others promising tough treatment for Japanese automakers. Mr. Clinton, by contrast, favors a free trade agreement with Mexico, which the union fears could cause an exodus of auto-industry jobs south of the border, where wage rates are lower. But many U.A.W. leaders believe Mr. Perot's main appeal is the same among auto workers as it seems to be generally: that he is a departure from traditional politics.
 
An Opening for Clinton
 "I think Perot would be a disaster," said Paul Korman, a U.A.W. assistant regional director from Des Plaines, Ill., "but don't kid yourself, he has support. He's not being very specific, but he's saying all the right things about unemployment and the trade imbalance."
Still, U.A.W. strategists see a potential silver lining in Mr. Perot's candidacy. They had feared that a Democrat running alone against President Bush faced almost sure defeat. But now they say that if Mr. Perot draws more support away from Mr. Bush than from Mr. Clinton, Mr. Clinton might have enough votes "to thread the needle." Such an outcome could also leave no candidate with enough electoral votes to win, and the House of Representatives would choose the President.
Given this possibility, Owen F. Bieber, the U.A.W. president, urged the union officers convening here on Sunday to "work extra hard in key House and Senate races." Standing for election to his final term as U.A.W. president before retirement, Mr. Bieber, 62 years old, faces token opposition.
Mr. Bieber charged that as chairman of Electronic Data Systems Corporation in the early 1970's, Mr. Perot "went to great lengths to keep workers" in an E.D.S. office near San Francisco from forming a union. When the workers did vote to recognize the union, he said, E.D.S. shut the office and moved to a nonunion office.
An E.D.S. spokesman, Tony Good, disputed the union's account. He said the company was neutral on the union vote and later sold the office for unrelated reasons to another company, which eventually closed it.
Mr. Perot, who sold E.D.S. to the General Motors Corporation in 1984, says he had no recollection of the episode in San Francisco. In a telephone interview on Monday, he sidestepped an invitation to spell out his position on collective bargaining, saying that "the highest priority must be to form a united team within a company."
On Monday, Mr. Clinton received a warm, if less than rousing, welcome when he addressed the 2,000 or so delegates here. He sketched his version of traditional Democratic planks like national health care and tuition support for public education.
But delegates eager to hear a protectionist anthem were disappointed. While condemning tax advantages for companies that close United States plants so they can open overseas, Mr. Clinton spoke of the reality of a global marketplace that forced American companies to trade with Latin America: "The world we once knew we will never know again."

HEADLINE: Plan for Ice Rink and TV Studio on Chelsea Piers

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

 BODY:
New York State selected a development group yesterday to build ice-skating rinks, film and television studios and a marina on the Chelsea Piers as part of a plan to revitalize Manhattan's decaying Hudson River waterfront.
The group, Chelsea Piers L.P., submitted the lowest bid of three finalists seeking to develop the aging piers between West 18th and 23d Streets. But officials of the State Department of Transportation, which owns the piers, said the group was selected because its $25 million plan would fit best into a proposed ribbon of riverfront parkland and businesses envisioned by city and state officials. 
 The four Chelsea piers are the first of three riverfront sites that will be leased to private developers as part of a plan agreed to by Mayor David N. Dinkins and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to construct 40 acres of parkland alongside a new highway stretching from Battery Park to 59th Street.
A more elaborate form of the plan, known as Westway, collapsed under opposition from environmental and community groups in 1985.
"I am so excited I can't see straight," said Roland W. Betts, a partner in the development group. "This is great for the city." The group plans to begin construction in January 1993.
The development group includes Sky Rink, an indoor ice-skating rink on West 33d Street, and Silver Screen Studios, which underwrites films by the Walt Disney Company. Mr. Betts is the chairman of Sky Rink and president of Silver Screen Studios.
 
Yachting School Planned
 The group's plan calls for building two glass-enclosed skating rinks, expanding existing television and film studios and opening a yachting school operated by Dennis Conner, the three-time America's Cup champion.
Chelsea Piers bid $157,000 per month for a 10-year lease for the piers. Hirschfeld Realty, the Manhattan development company, made the highest bid, $162,000 per month. The second highest bid, $161,000 a month, was placed by a group that included World Yacht, a dinner-cruise line that currently rents one of the piers.
Abraham Hirschfeld criticized the state for selecting Mr. Betts's group, saying it would be unable to obtain financing. "They will do something with those piers when hair grows on my palms," said Mr. Hirschfeld, a one-time candidate for lieutenant governor. His proposal had called for building a wholesale shopping market, among other things.
But Tom Ryan, a spokesman for the Transportation Department, said Chelsea Piers L.P. was unanimously selected by an eight-member review panel because its proposal was the most appropriate and detailed. The panel thought the other two bids were "vague and speculative," Mr. Ryan said.

HEADLINE: M.T.A. Plan: One Fare Rise Over 5 Years

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
The head of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday proposed a broad new financial plan that would raise the fare on New York City's subway and buses only once in the next five years, while offering an array of new discounts.
Under the plan by the M.T.A. chairman, Peter E. Stangl, subway and bus fares would probably increase 25 cents, to $1.50, in 1994. The authority would also try to attract new riders with a monthly pass allowing unlimited trips for subway and bus passengers. And it would offer discounts for commuters who take a bus and the subway, paying two fares, and for suburban commuters who ride Metro-North or Long Island Rail Road and then take a subway or bus in the city. 
 In addition, the M.T.A. would raise tolls 50 cents, to $3, next year on many bridges and tunnels.
In recent months, Mr. Stangl has struggled to get the attention of city and state elected officials, as well as the general public, on the significant financial problems the M.T.A. faces.
"We need to be bold," Mr. Stangl said. "We need to be more ambitious. If you want a modern, functioning transit system that moves people conveniently at a reasonable price, you have to do these things."
 
Dividing Up Subsidies
 The chairman's plan does not solve the agency's deficits; in fact, it would add to them. But Mr. Stangl is hoping that his proposed innovations will be so appealing that they will induce City Hall and Albany to come up with the money the M.T.A. has been unsuccessfully seeking to solve the system's long-term problems.
The proposal also represents the M.T.A.'s opening public salvo in what will undoubtedly be a prolonged and politically divisive battle over the next year on how to apportion an estimated $16 billion in new government transportation subsidies that are expected to become available over the next six years.
Mr. Stangl made it clear, in a briefing on the plan at his office at M.T.A. headquarters on Madison Avenue, that he hoped the plan would spur some movement on the agency's five-year rebuilding plan, which has languished for a year. The M.T.A. has proposed a $10 billion, five-year plan for continuing the renovation of the subway and commuter lines, but it has received approval only for a one-year, $1.6 billion plan from the State Legislature.
The proposal by Mr. Stangl, contained in a five-year business strategy plan that the M.T.A. produces annually, seeks to tie together the innovations directly with the agency's existing plans. For example, the monthly subway passes and fare discounts would be possible only if the M.T.A. installs an elaborate new automated fare system on the subway; the new automated system is a major component of the M.T.A.'s five-year capital plan.
"If you like the plan, if you think as I do that the services that the M.T.A. provides are fundamental to this region and to its ability to compete, then you have to spend some money," he said.
 
State and Federal Money
 Without such innovations, he contended, the whole transit system could be headed for a long, slow decline, reversing the substantial progress of the last decade. Since the recession began three years ago, the transit lines have lost about 7 percent of their riders altogether, and subsidies from economically sensitive state taxes have declined precipitously.
The discounts and monthly passes would actually cost the M.T.A. money. Preliminary estimates suggest that they would cost an additional $400 million a year, Mr. Stangl said, but that cost could be partly offset by an estimated $150 million in new revenue from increased ridership.
The proposal also identifies how much of the new state and Federal money the M.T.A. would like, including 50 percent of the more than $700 million a year that will be raised by the state's new petroleum business tax. It says the M.T.A. should receive $100 million a year more in Federal transportation money than the $570 million it is already scheduled to get.
Mr. Stangl also said the city should increase its allotment to the transit agency by $65 million, under a complicated transaction involving recalculations of the city's contributions to the pension fund for transit police officers. The city pays for the transit police.
Even if all these requests were granted -- and they would require approval of the M.T.A. board, the Dinkins and Cuomo administrations and the State Legislature -- the M.T.A. would still face a potential budget gap of about $700 million over the next five years. Mr. Stangl said a new regional tax might be needed for the additional subsidies.
Response yesterday to the proposal was generally positive, although several officials noted that the obvious problem was how to pay for the whole package. A legislator who will have a major role in deciding how the new state and Federal money will be divided up, State Senator Norman Levy, the Long Island Republican who is chairman of the Senate Transportation Committee, declined to comment because he had not been briefed on the plan, said James Moriarty, a spokesman for Mr. Levy.
 
The Issue: How to Pay
 Norman Steisel, the First Deputy Mayor, said the Dinkins administration found the new ideas bold and sensible. "The issue is how to pay for it," Mr. Steisel said. The city hopes to work with the M.T.A. to obtain a fair share of the new state and Federal money for mass transit in the region, he said, adding, "The state is going to have to be a more active partner."
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's staff is reviewing Mr. Stangl's plan and "is looking forward to discussing it with the M.T.A.," said Charles F. Porcari, a spokesman for the Governor.
Gene Russianoff, staff attorney for the Straphangers Campaign, a riders' group, said, "Stangl's plan has tremendous potential."
Mr. Russianoff said the proposal to create new discounts and flexibility in fares represented a complete shift in the M.T.A.'s policy. "Before, they were scared to death of taking a risk," he said.
"If Peter Stangl can get New Yorkers an unlimited-ride monthly pass and cut down the cost of a two-fare zone, he'll really have given the city something," Mr. Russianoff said.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Transit: Highlights of M.T.A. Plan"
 Fares on the subways and busses would go up in 1994, probably by 25 cents, to $1.50. Fares on the suburban commuter railroad lines would go up by the same percentage, 20 percent. This would be the only fare increase in the next five years.
 Tolls would increase in January by 50 cents, to $3, on tunnels and bridges including the Triborough Bridge, the Midtown Tunnel, the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel and the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge.
 After the subway's automated fare system begins to be installed in 1994, the agency would start selling monthly passes for unlimited subway and bus rides. The price of the monthly pass has not be set, but has be discussed as the cost of 50 single rides, or $75 on a $1.50 fare.
 Discounts would be offered for New Yorkers who ride both buses and subways to commute to work. The amount of the discount has not been set, but might be half the ordinary fare.
 Suburban commuters who ride the Metro-North or long lsland lines into the city could get discounts when they complete their trips using city buses or the subway. The amount of the discount has not been set.

HEADLINE: Stocks Fall As the Dow Loses 41.73

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Stock prices fell sharply yesterday, shaken by domestic political concerns, big falls in markets abroad and tremors linked to the expiration of options tomorrow.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 41.73 points, or 1.3 percent, to 3,287.76, its lowest close since April 13. On top of a 25-point drop on Tuesday, the Dow is now down 2 percent in two days. 
 The decline was across the board, with falling stocks leading gainers more than 3 to 1. And the Nasdaq composite index was down 10.83, or 1.9 percent, to 593.24.
As the summer approaches, there seems to be a general malaise hitting markets worldwide as bad news is arising in different places at the same time. Thus there is no good news in one market to help offset the bad elsewhere.
Trading in New York yesterday opened after the Japanese stock market had fallen to its lowest level in more than five and a half years, setting off renewed fears about Japan's financial system. [Page D10.]
The main markets also fell in Europe. And the Mexican stock market plunged 5.9 percent.
The decline in the United States "is developing a snowball effect," argued Robert C. Walberg, an equity analyst at MMS International, an economic research firm in New York. "People who have been nervous are saying that it is time to secure profits."
A. C. Moore, an investment strategist at Argus Investment Management in Santa Barbara, Calif., said he did not think the market was in for what he would call a major slide. But he said investors might have to ride out a 5 to 10 percent decline in the Dow, which would bring it close to 3,000 and would be a significant blow for many investors.
 
Perot Causes Uncertainty
 Mr. Moore and Mr. Walberg said several factors were contributing to the fall in the market, including the political uncertainty caused by the emergence of Ross Perot, weakness in technology stocks, the fall in the Japanese market and the feeling that the Federal Reserve will not now push interest rates lower. And then there is the effect of what is known as the triple witching, the day that options and futures contract expire.
"We have a confluence of factors here," Mr. Moore said, adding that the Perot factor "is creating uncertainty as to what, for example, a new tax code would look like." Also, Mr. Perot and his apparent opposition to a United States-Mexico free-trade agreement was cited as one reason for the sharp fall in the Mexican market.
Mr. Moore also said price cutting by technology companies had weakened those stocks, noting that in the last two weeks Hewlett-Packard was off 16.7 percent, Compaq Computer was down 8.3 percent and Microsoft dropped 10 percent.
Mr. Walberg also said the very slow recovery of the economy also meant that the market was unlikely to see any comforting earnings reports for the second quarter. "The market has very little to be excited about," he said.
He said the declines in the Big Three auto stocks yesterday was a reflection of people taking profits now that they think the market is in for a near-term slide. Many investors were waiting for a signal to sell since the Dow failed to securely breech the 3,400 level, a failure that set the market's nerves on edge.
"Some of yesterday's selloff was tied to some options expirations," said Dennis Jarrett, chief market strategist at Kidder, Peabody & Company. "But it was broad," he added, noting the nearly 2 percent decline in the Nasdaq composite index.
John Brooks at Davis Mendel & Regenstein said the quarterly expiration of stock index options, individual stock options and index futures kept many would-be buyers sidelined. And he said they are likely to remain sidelined until next week.
 
Big Changes Among Shares
 Among some of the market movers yesterday were Philips N.V., down 5, to 16 5/8. The company announced that its second-quarter earnings would be substantially below the level a yearearlier, and full-year profit unlikely to match 1991. The company cited a soft consumer-electronics market.
Adobe Systems rose 3 1/4, to 46, after it posted a rise in profits off a 22 percent increase in revenues.
Lower earnings forecast for the second quarter by Upjohn took the stock down 1 3/4, to 32 1/4. Lower Halcion sales, weak prescription drug sales in the United States and a soft agricultural market were some of the factors noted.
Volume leaders were topped by Telefonos de Mexico, as it traded 10.8 million shares to close at 45 3/8, down 3 1/8.
Coca-Cola, according to analysts, indicated a couple of weeks ago that its second-quarter earnings would be in line with their 42 cents to 44 cents a share estimates. But soft-drink volume growth in the second quarter was weak, so investors used the general concern over second-quarter earnings and a weak market to sell their Coke shares, as the stock fell 1 3/8, to 39 3/8.

HEADLINE: Ford and Chrysler Outpace Japanese in Reducing Costs

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
Ford and Chrysler have increased the efficiency of their factories and workers so much in recent years that their basic cost of producing a car is now less than that of their Japanese rivals, according to a study published today.
Auto analysts have long recognized the productivity improvements at the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation. But the assumption within the industry has been that a production-cost gap remains between Detroit's second- and third-largest auto makers and the Japanese car companies, especially the Toyota Motor Corporation, generally regarded as the low-cost producer worldwide. 
 But that assumption is no longer true, according to the report by the Economic Strategy Institute, a research organization in Washington. Based on a yearlong study, conducted with the help of the University of Michigan's Office for the Study of Automotive Transport, the private research group estimates that the direct cost of producing a small car at Ford is $5,415, Chrysler's cost is $5,841 and Toyota's $6,216.
The comparable cost for the other three leading Japanese companies -- Nissan, Honda and Mazda -- are somewhat higher than Toyota, while General Motors is the high-cost producer, at $7,205 a car.
"The good performance of Ford and Chrysler is surprising," said Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., president of the Economic Strategy Institute. "And the figures show that Ford and Chrysler really have become competitive with the Japanese."
The glaring exception in the report's picture of the American industry as an efficient producer is the General Motors Corporation, the nation's largest auto maker. And its laggard position in terms of cost of production helps explain the urgency of its recent management changes, payroll cutbacks and plant closings.
Other analysts agreed that Ford and possibly Chrysler were now quite competitive with the Japanese companies, but said that the Economic Strategy Institute report may have overstated the case. By stating the results in terms of United States dollars, they noted, the biggest single reason for the new-found cost advantage for Ford and Chrysler was the 85 percent decline in the value of the dollar against the yen since 1985.
But more recent studies have tended to focus on the number of worker-hours, rather than dollars, required to make a car.
"Ford has done a terrific job and, in the past few years, Chrylser has made huge gains in its productivity," said James Harbour of Harbour & Associates in Troy, Mich. "But I'd still rank Toyota No. 1 with Ford close behind."
 
U.S. Lagged 10 Years Ago
 In 1981, Harbour & Associates published a landmark study that concluded that the Japanese industry could produce a small car for $1,500 less than Detroit. Some later studies were even more pessimistic about how far the American industry lagged, estimating that Japanese costs were $2,500 or more below Detroit's.
Today, the Economic Strategy Institute report found that in terms of man-hours and total labor costs in each produced the Japanese still have an edge over all the Detroit companies. But the research group calculated that Ford and Chrysler more than made up that deficit by the lower prices in America for other costs like purchasing glass, rubber and industrial fuel.
The report, "The Future of the Auto Industry: It Can Compete, Can It Survive?," written by Mr. Prestowitz, Paul S. Willen and Larry Chimerine, separately figured the costs that are often beyond the direct control of managers and workers. For example, they estimated that higher health care and pension expenses -- nearly half of which go to retirees and laid off workers -- meant an additional cost of $600 on each car Detroit makes, compared with the Japanese.
 
Social Costs Added In
 And the fact that the American industry ran its plants at only 62 percent of capacity in 1991 versus 95 percent for the Japanese resulted in a cost penalty of $800 to $1,500 a car for the Detroit producers. When what the report calls these social costs, including a slightly higher cost of capital for investment in the United States, are added in, Toyota becomes the low-cost producer and Ford slips to No. 2.
"The U.S. industry does carry all these burdens compared with Japan, but they are part of the competitive environment," said Maryann Keller, an auto analyst at Furman Selz Inc.
The Economic Strategy Institute's discussion of the social costs borne by the industry and its policy recommendations for reviving the auto industry will likely be the more controversial part of the report. Its recommendations include drafting an industrial policy for the American industry, putting more pressure on Japanese transplant factories in the United States to buy low-cost American parts, and attaching a "North American content" sticker on all cars sold in the United States.
Mr. Prestowitz, a former Japan expert in the Commerce Department, is an advocate of an industrial policy for leading American industries and he has often been critical of Japan's trading practices. The Economic Strategy Institute is supported by some 200 donors including corporations, foundations, unions and individuals, with auto companies and suppliers accounting for roughly 15 percent of its financing.

HEADLINE: NEW HAVEN JOURNAL;
Soaring Taxes Steal Cafes' Sizzle

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
ON a wall at Louis' Lunch here, a sign proclaims: "Prices subject to change according to customer's attitude."
But customers' attitudes may have a lot less to do with the future of Louis's hamburger prices -- and indeed Louis' itself -- than a tax increase that is making the restaurant's owner consider leaving town. 
 "Our property tax assessment tripled," said Kenneth Lassen, whose grandfather founded this New Haven culinary landmark in 1895 and who works long hours behind the counter with his wife and son. "We can't pass it on to the customers, so we'd decide to move if it becomes economically necessary."
Ray Larson, who has been eating at Louis' for 60 of his 80 years, said that he could not imagine New Haven without the tiny restaurant that claims -- among other contenders -- to be the birthplace of the hamburger.
"It's irreplaceable," he said, as he left the tiny brick restaurant that has only two tables, a half dozen pew-style chairs and five stools across from the ovens. "If they leave, this city's going to the dogs."
Terry Halwes, a scientist who heads a company called Precision Neurometrics, said that Louis' extra-large, extra-lean burgers are a staple of his diet. "There are people whose doctors prescribe his burgers because they're so low in fat," he said.
Louis' is one of a handful of well-known, longtime New Haven restaurants and other businesses whose owners say they may move because of a recent property-tax revaluation that Peter Halsey, the city controller, said would raise taxes for small businesses and homeowners by an average of 238 percent over five years.
Many business owners are appealing their assessments, and some seem to be hoping against hope that city officials may scale back the increase.
"My taxes here will go up by $11,000 just during the first phase in July," said Flo Consiglio, whose husband founded another landmark New Haven restaurant, Sally's Apizza, 54 years ago. "If you bring your prices up to reflect taxes, people won't come. And for many people, pizza is all they can afford to go out to eat these days."
Despite the hourlong lines for dinner, to legions of Sally's devotees, a New Haven without Sally's is as improbable as one without another beleaguered city institution -- Yale University.
"Sally's and Pepe's are the best pizza in the country," said John Massaro, a regular customer, referring to another veteran pizzeria a few blocks away on Wooster Street in New Haven's Little Italy section. "To close because of retirement would be one thing, but it's crazy to have this happen because of taxes."
Mike Spoerndle, the owner of Toad's nightclub who is also contemplating a cost-cutting exit from New Haven, is quick to say that closing is not imminent for his sprawling music emporium, nor for Louis' or Sally's. But, he said, their future in New Haven is far from secure.
"I love it here," he said, surveying a stage where Bob Dylan, the Rolling Stones, Bruce Springsteen and other luminaries have performed since the club opened in 1975. "We've put tons of money into this. But I've been looking at San Diego and Tijuana, because I can't make a living for my family here when they hit us with higher property taxes, cabaret and entertainment taxes and sales tax. And, here in Connecticut, in the insurance capital of America, the insurance rates are pretty bad."
Toad's has its own die-hard fans, including Alderman Michael Morand, who said: "If it left, it would be an irreplaceable loss. Toad's is the best club between New York and Boston."
Like other New Haven merchants, Mr. Spoerndle denounced the city for hitting small and medium-sized businesses with the tax increase while giving tax breaks to retain large businesses like Macy's.
But confronted with the threatened exodus, city officials cast the blame elsewhere.
"The Federal Government has shifted the burdens to the states," Mr. Halsey said. "And the state has shifted the bill to the communities. With business lousy in this part of the world, the easiest thing for people to vent their frustrations at is the local tax bill. We're the closest ones to yell at."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bond Prices Up Slightly

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices closed slightly higher yesterday after an erratic session tied to favorable economic news.
The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond, which gained 7/32 point on Tuesday, rose 5/32 point, or $1.56 per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield slipped to 7.81 percent, from 7.83 percent late Tuesday. 
 The market rose in morning trading after a Government report on productivity showed inflation in check. It declined after the Federal Reserve dimmed hopes for lower interest rates when its "beige book" report showed economic improvement early this month.
Bond prices then reversed course again, as traders sold at higher prices to take profits and apparently reassessed the Fed survey of business conditions in the 12 Fed districts.
Kathleen Stephanson, a money market economist at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation, said she was surprised the market fell after the Fed survey, because the upturn in the economy had been expected.
She said the report on closer inspection showed few surprises, which contributed to the market's late rebound to positive territory.
Trading was light for the third straight session.
Bonds got an early lift following the release of a report that the productivity of American workers rose 2.7 percent during the first quarter of 1992, the largest increase in nearly two years.
The Labor Department said the increase in productivity, defined as output per hour of work, matched the advance posted in the second quarter of 1990, when the economy was sliding into the recession.
 
Lower Prices for Goods Seen
 Traders speculated that an improvement in productivity would translate to lower prices for goods, which in turn keeps inflation at bay. That is positive for bonds because inflation erodes the value of fixed-income securities.
In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, short-term maturities rose 1/16 point to 3/32 point, intermediate maturities gained 1/16 point to 5/32 point and long-term issues rose about 3/16 point, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported.
The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, closed at 1,234.60, up 0.77.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 3.68 percent as the discount dropped 3 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 3.61 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 3.81 percent as the discount fell 3 basis points, to 3.70 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 4.06 percent as the discount dropped 1 basis point, to 3.90 percent.
The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was quoted at 3 11/16 percent, up from 3 5/8 late Tuesday.

HEADLINE: House Panel Passes a Weakened Cable Bill

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
Deciding that it would be smarter to run and fight again some other day, the House Energy and Commerce Committee voted today, 31 to 12, in favor of a bill that would impose tough new rate regulation on most cable television systems but is much weaker than a measure passed by the Senate in January.
The thrust-and-parry strategy marked an attempt by the panel's chairman, Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, to sidestep the deadlocks and jursidictional squabbles that have stalled House action on the bill for months. 
 The upshot is a measure that would regulate prices but does not include the two provisions, including one intended to increase competition, that the industry most vehemently opposed. Supporters had said the provisions were the bill's most important features, one for the public interest and the other for political purposes.
 
'I Want to Win This Thing'
 Supporters of the bill have vowed to put the provisions back when the measure reaches the House floor or in House-Senate conference committee, where they believe they have a better chance of success.
"I want to win this thing in the long run," said Representative Billy Tauzin, a Louisiana Democrat who supports a stronger bill. "What we're doing is drawing the fight to a better field on a better day."
The new bill would require the Federal Communications Commission to set maximum rates for a basic tier of cable television service and allow it to roll back prices for premium services, like those that include Home Box Office or the Disney channel, if the prices are deemed "unreasonable."
But it eliminated a provision that was intended to promote greater competition for cable systems. That provision would have required big cable companies that also produce popular programming to license their shows to such potential rivals as companies that transmit programming by satellite.
The new substitute also eliminated a provision that had been inserted to attract political support from the television networks and over-the-air television broadcasters. That measure would have forced local cable systems to pay royalties to television stations for the right to retransmit their signals. Under current law, cable systems have an automatic license to carry over-the-air television signals without payment.
The partial retreat stems in part from Mr. Dingell's fear that the two provisions would make an overall cable bill much harder to get through the House. Mr. Dingell has been embroiled in an increasingly bitter turf battle with the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, Representative Jack Brooks of Texas, who is determined to change the provision that benefits broadcasters.
The provision affecting competition has come under attack from many Democrats, and it almost prevented the House telecommunications subcommittee from being able to pass a bill several months ago.
Now, supporters of a tough bill say they will try to get their way either on the House floor or in conference committee.
 
Threat of a Veto
 President Bush has repeatedly threatened to veto any measure that imposes significant new regulation on the cable industry. The White House argues that the best way to control cable television prices is to let telephone companies compete in providing television services.
The bill has also come under attack from the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Alfred C. Sikes, who charged last week that the cost of enforcing the bill could total as much as $54.7 million, or 44 percent of the F.C.C.'s annual budget.
But with prices for basic cable television service rising far faster than the rate of inflation, Congressional Democrats see a tough measure as a good way to attract middle-class voters in an election season.
The cable television industry quickly denounced the measure. "Over all, this legislation remains excessive," said James P. Mooney, president of the National Cable Television Association. "The bill still imposes major costs on cable companies that will result in higher consumer prices."
 
Partial Consumer Victory
 But Gene Kimmelman, legislative director for the Consumer Federation of America, declared today's vote a partial victory. "The bill is very strong on meeting consumers' short-term needs. The longer-term desire to bring about more competition has not been dealt with, but we hope it will be at a later point," he said.
The House passed a much more modest regulatory bill in 1990, but that measure was blocked in the Senate that year by a combination of Republicans and a few Democrats. Now, the trouble is in the House, where Republican opponents are being helped out by dissension among Democrats.
The debate over cable television stems from the effects of the Cable Television Act of 1984. That measure, intended to foster the growth of cable television, freed local cable systems from any local price regulation. The theory was that new services, like those that use satellites and microwave transmission, would provide the competition needed to keep prices under control.
But neither of those industries has grown much in the intervening years, leaving cable systems in the vast majority of cities with virtual monopolies.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
New York Lets Insurers Join Forces

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
Approving what could be a model for troubled life insurance companies, New York State regulators gave the go-ahead yesterday to the largest merger in history of two mutual life insurance companies, allowing the creation on July 1 of the Phoenix Home Life Mutual Insurance Company, with combined assets of more than $10 billion.
Industry experts say that if successful, the merger may be copied by other mid-size mutual insurers around the country. Many of them have been losing market share to companies that are larger or have higher financial ratings. The companies announced their merger in December and were waiting for State Insurance Department approval. 
 The merger, of the Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company of Hartford, and Home Life Insurance of New York City, comes at a time of turmoil for mutual insurers, which are owned by their policyholders.
By merging operations to save $70 million a year, the companies' leaders say they hope to reassure regulators and the public about their financial strength. But some critics question whether merging companies struggling with weak commercial real estate portfolios and wary consumers might just create larger companies with bigger problems.
"From the policyholders' perspective, this is definitely going to reduce costs," Terence Lennon, the chief examiner of the State Insurance Department, said. "This industry became stressed in the 1980's, and now companies are going to have to compete on the basis of cost as they never have before. This shows other companies that a merger can be done."
Following another unusual strategy for dealing with mutual insurers' problems, New York is supervising the transformation of the third-largest mutual, the Equitable Life Assurance Society, into a stock company. Equitable is expected to make its initial public offering next month.
John Gummere, the chairman and chief executive of the Phoenix, and William B. Wallace, the chairman and chief executive of Home Life, said in interviews yesterday that they expected major savings from the reduction of the two companies' work forces of 2,450 to 1,667 by the end of next year, and from the combining of their three computer centers into one. The cost reductions, they said, will eventually result in higher dividends for policyholders and more competitive insurance policies.
"It will let us build capital, and it will directly benefit our policyholders," Mr. Gummere said.
As one example of the many difficulties the companies faced in getting regulators to approve the deal, they had to agree to make New York the new company's legal home, but also had to agree to give Connecticut most of its jobs. New York's Insurance Department, which is large and considered more aggressive than those of most other states, wanted to maintain regulatory control over the company to protect policyholders. Mr. Gummere said Connecticut officials, including Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., had insisted on protection for their state's weak economy.
As a result, more than 500 jobs will disappear from Home Life's offices in Piscataway, N.J., and New York City, while Phoenix's Hartford offices will retain their work force of more than 2,000. The company's corporate books will be kept in a new office near Albany, which will employ about 200.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Upjohn Expects Earnings To Be Flat in 2d Quarter

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: KALAMAZOO, Mich., June 17

 BODY:
The Upjohn Company said today that it expected that second-quarter net income would not exceed the $128 million, or 70 cents a share, earned in the comparable quarter a year ago.
The company attributed the flat performance to a decline in sales of its controversial Halcion sleeping drug and weakness in its overall United States drug prescription sales. 
 Upjohn said it was offering voluntary early retirement to about 1,100 workers, or about 10 percent of its work force, in an effort to reduce costs. The amount of the charges for the plan have not been determined, but will be taken in the third quarter, the company said.
All employees aged 53 or older in the United States and Puerto Rico except those in research and development and United States field sales are eligible, and must retire no later than Sept. 2.
 
Decline in Upjohn Shares
 Upjohn shares fell $1.75 today, closing at $32.25 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Upjohn had been expected to earn about 77 cents a share for the second quarter, according to a consensus by Zack's Investment Research.
In addition to the decline in Halcion sales, which the company tied to "controversy concerning the product," a weak United States prescription pharmaceutical business "due to unfavorable timing comparisons in buying patterns" and weakness in agricultural operations because of the "recessionary pressure and drought" put pressure on earnings, Upjohn said.
In late May, the company imposed what it called a short-term wage and hiring freeze on its United States operations to reassess its long-term strategies. The wage freeze was lifted June 9, but the hiring freeze continues, a company spokesman, John Lambrechts, said.
Upjohn said in May that the negative publicity surrounding Halcion and the amount of money spent by the pharmaceutical company to defend it were related to the hiring freeze.
In mid-May, the United States Food and Drug Administration determined that Halcion was safe at prescribed dosages, although it had been banned by the British in September.
Despite the F.D.A.'s findings, prescriptions for Halcion, one of Upjohn's biggest revenue producers, fell 48 percent in the United States during the first quarter of 1992.
Halcion is Upjohn's second-highest revenue-producing drug, with sales of $100 million in the United States and $237 million worldwide in 1991, down about 39 percent from the year before.
Upjohn's stock has steadily declined because of negative reports and patient complaints about Halcion, which can cause memory lapse, anxiety and other side effects. The shares were at a record high of $42 in late February.
Industry analysts said patent expirations on several drugs, including Halcion and Xanax, were clouding the outlook for Upjohn.
Early tests of its Freedox drug used to treat head, neck and spinal cord injuries look promising, analysts said. Approval could come in 1994 or 1995.

HEADLINE: In Moscow, Capitalist Wheels Roll

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 17

 BODY:
Just inside the main entrance of Detsky Mir, a Government-owned department store, the vast lobby has been turned into a glass-enclosed showroom for shiny new Fords. What is striking is not the display -- there are a dozen like it in Moscow -- but that owning a foreign car has suddenly become so acceptable in Russia that even the state encourages the practice.
Aside from providing this new prestige, the influx of foreign cars along with many other imported items is helping to satisfy consumer demand, easing social tension at a time when Russian production is falling and domestic goods are in painfully short supply. 
 Encouraging the import trend, the Government has removed import tariffs for the time being on most consumer products, including cars. The products appear side by side with Russian products in dozens of stores. "We are happy to be flooded with foreign goods; the more the better," said Yuri V. Krichmar, a Moscow city government economist, offering the view held by many officials.
Until perestroika, foreign cars were restricted almost entirely to diplomats. Now the lineup of cars idling at a traffic light regularly includes a Honda, Chevy, Volvo, Ford, Toyota or some other foreign make.
The mass entry of foreign goods is an abrupt change. For decades such products were available only to foreigners in special dollar shops, or to Russians buying on the black market. Now hundreds of consumer items enter the country duty-free and are sold legally in state stores, as well as on the streets, with customers paying sometimes in dollars and sometimes rubles.
The only question is, where are Russians getting the dollars and other hard currencies to import so much? The only source is dollars earned from exports, and that suggests to economists that Russians are earning from exports far more than the $30 billion a year that is declared to the Government.
In recent months, nearly 1,000 foreign cars have entered Russia daily, the Ministry of Autos estimates. They come by land from Europe, by freighter from the United States and aboard cargo ships that ferry timber to Japan and return to Vladivostok with cars.
Some are new, but most are second-hand vehicles, purchased or stolen abroad and often sold here for less than $6,000 apiece. That makes them competitive in price with Russian cars.
"Foreign cars are not necessarily better than Russian-made cars, but they do give you prestige in people's eyes, and that is a nice feeling," said Valery Gleikh, an interpreter, who bought a second-hand 1982 Volvo for his wife for $2,200 and a 1987 Ford for himself for $6,300. "If I get a flat tire fixed, the service station charges me twice the price for fixing a tire on a Russian car. They think I am rich."
Foreign car sales in Russia -- roughly 100,000 vehicles have been sold in the last six months, the Auto Ministry says -- represent more than 20 percent of the 850,000 cars expected to be sold in Russia this year, according to Aleksandr Kovrigin, an Auto Ministry official. The Russian Zhiguli, styled after a 1960's Fiat, is the biggest seller, with foreign cars as a group in second place.
The average Russian income is the ruble equivalent of less than $100 a month. A Pontiac 6000 brought from abroad, for example, ranges from $5,880 for a 1986 model to $19,950 for a 1991 car, payable in dollars. By comparison, a new Zhiguli sedan goes for $2,500 to $5,400 in rubles, if the car is purchased from the factory, a process that can require several years on a waiting list. And to get a new Zhiguli for immediate delivery, the price can be as much as $10,000.
An influx of foreign cars should shorten the long waiting time to buy new Russian cars. And, in fact, some Russian cars, like the Moskvich, a compact, are now available for immediate delivery -- but not because the nation is so saturated with foreign cars, Mr. Kovrigin argued. Since the lifting of price ceilings in January on most Russian goods, the prices of Russian cars have risen twentyfold, and many people who once could afford a car no longer can.
 
Less Wealthy Kick Tires
 But if only the wealthiest Russians are buying new cars, the less wealthy enjoy gazing at those that come from abroad, as shoppers do at Detsky Mir, where the 10 Ford models on display in the glass enclosures seem to Russians as fascinating, and untouchable, as Fifth Avenue store windows are for New Yorkers during Christmas.
"With pleasure I would buy such a car; they are very beautiful and much more reliable than our cars," said Viktor Nekrasov, admiring a black Lincoln Continental that, like the other cars behind the glass, carries no price tag. Mr. Nekrasov, who earns 10,000 rubles a month, or $100, as an Aeroflot pilot, was out shopping with his wife, Natalia, who said, "I have never been in such a car, but I hear it is noiseless, with automatic windows."
No sales representative from the private company that leases the lobby space staffs the display. That will happen soon, a sign promises. Meanwhile, a phone number is given, in case any of the shoppers buying toys and school supplies for their children -- the store sells mostly goods for youngsters -- might also want to purchase the new Taurus or the Lincoln or the other Fords.
But most of the foreign cars being brought in are second-hand, and they -- along with imported goods in general -- are at the low end of Western prices. These goods, for example, are dresses made in China, shoes from Turkey or 1980's American cars purchased at Midwestern used-car lots and shipped here by American entrepreneurs.
Aleksandr Ozolin, deputy director of Grediron, an auto sales agency, represents some of the foreign suppliers who ship cars to him from abroad. A car is imported only after a Russian places an order and makes a down payment. Answering Grediron's half-page auto ad in Izvestia last week, a buyer comes not to a used-car lot -- there aren't any in Moscow yet -- but to a cramped ground-floor office staffed by Mr. Ozolin and five other men, all in their 20's.
Cars are offered from printed lists that tell Mr. Ozolin and his colleagues where they can obtain almost any make or model, foreign or Russian, going back to 1986. Payment is in dollars, if the car, once ordered, is to be brought from abroad, or in dollars or rubles, if it is a foreign car already in the country, perhaps owned by a Russian who decided that maintenance costs had become too burdensome. That is a growing decision, Mr. Ozolin said, at a time when inflation is rising faster than incomes for most Russians.
"We ask a customer how much he is willing to pay, in what currency and if he is willing to pay in cash, which entitles him to a discount, or through a bank transfer, and then we choose a model that fits," Mr. Ozolin said. "You get your car in 30 days." If for some reason, the buyer does not like the car, he is usually charged only for the shipping costs, and Mr. Ozolin turns around and sells it to someone else.
Mr. Ozolin describes the customers as Russia's nouveau riche, mainly traders and brokers. But even they are feeling pinched, with inflation rising at a rate of more than 100 percent a year while incomes go up more slowly. The ratio of sales of second-hand foreign cars to second-hand Russian cars at Mr. Ozolin's agency have fallen to 1 foreign car in 8 sales from 1 in 5 last January.
There are problems besides price. Russia's rutted roads require extra-strong suspension. Russia's low-octane gasoline, lower than in other nations, destroys foreign car engines in a year or two, unless they are specially adjusted. Right-hand-drive cars coming from Japan's used-car lots and selling here for as little as $2,000, are hazardous in Russia, which uses standard left-hand drive. Most troublesome, getting parts can be difficult, although foreign-parts suppliers are beginning to appear. Toyota even has a service center in Vladivostock with 15 repair bays. And Mr. Gleikh says the parts problem is overstated.
"Getting them is no problem if you have hard currency," he said. "You can visit shops in Moscow that have foreign-car parts. And Russian cars are just as difficult to maintain."
The new-car dealers -- Volvo, Mercedes, BMW, Honda, Citroen, Ford and Opel -- play up maintenance in their sales pitches. Nathan M. Jacobson, president of Trinity Motors, a General Motors dealership with American and Russian investors, pitches custom-ordered Chevrolets, Pontiacs and Cadillacs specially equipped for Russia, with maintenance warranties. The selling price is $15,000 to $50,000 a car, in dollars.
In Trinity's first six weeks, five cars have been delivered and 150 ordered, says James Walker, Trinity's business manager. He and Mr. Jacobson are counting on Russians to be as smitten with the quality of American cars as Americans have been with Japanese cars. In addition, they are counting on fleet sales to government ministries, where the watchword, reflecting public attitudes, is often buy foreign not Russian.
"No minister has come in and ordered 250 cars yet," Mr. Walker said. "We'll get those orders, but so far it has been only one or two at a time."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Russian-owned foreign cars such as this Lincoln are relatively common sights now in Moscow's streets . . .; and in informal car markets like one in south Moscow where browsers ogled a Mitsubishi . . .; as well as in American-style showrooms like the Trinity Motors G.M. dealership in the Russian capital. (Photographs by Bill Swersey for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Increases Worldwide But Most Focus on the Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed higher yesterday across the board, but trading largely centered on the European currencies.
Gold prices were mostly lower. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $341.20 an ounce, off $1 from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank said gold slipped 65 cents an ounce, to $341.35. 
 The dollar posted gains worldwide, but dealers said the heaviest trading involved the German mark, which has been particularly active since Denmark's rejection earlier this month of the treaty for European unity.
Many dealers took profits by selling the Swiss franc, which has appreciated recently, then poured that money into marks, according to John McCarthy, manager of foreign exchange trading at ABN-AMRO Bank N.V.
The mark also benefited from selling of the Italian lira. Mr. McCarthy said the Bank of Italy had stepped in to support the Italian currency several times.
The yen also weakened on the heels of a decline in the Japanese stock market to its lowest level in more than five and a half years amid pessimism about the economy.
"All this activity had the net effect of taking the dollar higher temporarily, but we're closing off the highs" for the day, Mr. McCarthy said.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 126.60 yen, down 0.40 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at a higher rate of 127.00 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 127.25 yen, up from 126.50 yen on Tuesday.
In London, the pound fell to $1.8535, from $1.8605 late Tuesday. In New York, it cost $1.8565 to buy one pound, less expensive than Tuesday's $1.8645.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.5750 German marks, up from 1.5635; 1.4175 Swiss francs, up from 1.4045; 5.3050 French francs, up from 5.2650; 1,193.00 Italian lire, up from 1,183.25, and 1.1969 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1963.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.5775 German marks, up from 1.5665; 1.4195 Swiss francs, up from 1.4065; 5.3300 French francs, up from 5.2750; 1.7755 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7650; 1,194.00 Italian lire, up from 1,185.50, and 1.1960 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1955.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $342.60 an ounce, from $342.00 bid late Tuesday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $342.00 an ounce from $342.05. In Hong Kong, gold was unchanged at $341.93 an ounce.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Market Fund Yields Continue Downward Trend

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered by money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down in the latest week.
Walter S. Frank, IBC/Donoghue's chief economist, said several events in the tax-exempt sector, happening almost simultaneously, were driving yields lower. 
 "First of all, there is a great deal of money seeking out short-term tax-free yields," he said. "There are seasonal factors that contribute to the amount of investment money available, and interest-rate payment money that also becomes available for reinvestment to some extent.
"We should see more of the same right into next month, when, traditionally, yields move up, as many municipalities begin a new fiscal year and issue a lot of debt.
"What is interesting," Mr. Frank added, "is that yields in tax-exempt funds are still lower this week, despite money moving out of the funds. It shows the huge pent-up demand there is for tax-free paper in the market."
The seven-day compounded average yield for a tax-exempt fund fell by 18 basis points, to 2.53 percent, while the simple yield dropped by 17 basis points, to 2.50 percent. During the same period, the 30-day compounded and simple average yields fell by 12 basis points each, to 2.82 percent and 2.78 percent, respectively. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Assets of tax-free funds fell by $1.3 billion, to a total of $96 billion.
Donoghue's said the average number of days to maturity of tax-exempt securities held in money managers' portfolios rose by 3, to 53.
For investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, the taxable equivalent of the current seven-day tax-free compounded yield is 3.51 percent, while the equivalent for those in the 31 percent tax bracket is 3.66 percent.
 
Salomon Fund at 3.63%
 In its survey of tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, Donoghue's said that the Salomon Brothers New York Municipal Money Market Fund provided the best return, at 3.63 percent, but that it was still more than 10 basis points below last week's best yield, though it was in line with what had happened to other yields in its category.
Salomon Brothers was also the top fund among those investing in only New York issues, while the Fidelity Spartan Connecticut Municipal Money Market Porfolio gave the best return for funds dealing in Connecticut paper, at 3.04 percent. For New Jersey, the best yield was on the Calvert Tax-Free Reserve New Jersey Portfolio, with a yield of 3.14 percent.
In tracking the taxable funds for the week that ended yesterday, Donoghue's said that assets had declined by $482 million, to a total of $487.6 billion. Out of that, institutional assets accounted for a rise of $884 million, to $165.4 billion, while retail assets were down by $1.3 billion, to $322.2 billion.
For taxable funds, the average seven-day compounded and simple yields were both down by a basis point, to 3.50 percent and 3.44 percent, respectively. The 30-day compounded and simple averages were both down by 3 basis points, to 3.52 percent and 3.46 percent, respectively.
And, like the previous week, the Dreyfus Basic Money Market Fund had the best yield among taxables survyed, 4.39 percent.
Elsewhere, the average bank money market account yield, the prime competitor of money funds, was down by a basis point, to 3.36 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENTS;
2 Wrights Equal an Ellington

 BODY:
WHILE most people think they need more money, Richard Haas, an artist known for his illusionistic murals, thinks they need more currency. He has designed four new bills, including $25 and $200 denominations. They will "fill in important monetary gaps owing to inflation," Mr. Haas said. All four feature prominent American cultural figures instead of statesmen. The fronts are in various colors, but green is still the dominant shade on the backs. Mr. Haas's banknotes were commissioned by Martin Filler, editor of Design Quarterly, the journal of Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, for the summer issue. 
 The front of the $25 bill (above) has a portrait of Frank Lloyd Wright and his Taliesin West studio; his Robie house, in Chicago, is on the back; the $200 bill shows Tennessee Williams. The redesigned $50 bill has Duke Ellington, and the $100 bill has Martha Graham.

GRAPHIC: Photo of Richard Haas' $25 bill. (Naum Kazhdan/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Essay;
The New Hard Line

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In olden times, we hard-liners said: Don't trust the Russians. Fight them every step of the way until the free human spirit wins.
The soft-liners said: Accommodate. Try to understand their fear of us, and some peaceful day the two systems will converge. 
 That was then. Now the new hard-liners say: Trust the Russian reformers. Help them with debt relief and new private investment in this crisis, simultaneously pressing for dramatic arms reduction and withdrawal of imperial forces. The new soft-liners say: Don't help the Russians until we have helped ourselves.
In his dramatic descent on Washington this week, the bold and ebullient Boris Yeltsin put the heat on the new soft-liners.
First he proved he had the political muscle at home to cross the arms-control Rubicon and put an end to the fear of a first strike. Soviet SS-18 land-based MIRV's kept the world on edge for decades. In return, we gave up bargaining-chip land missiles and only half our submarine MIRV's.
Mr. Yeltsin was aware that this agreement, measured by the old calipers, gave the U.S. a strategic advantage. But his new calipers are more realistic: the U.S., which could have ruled the world when it had a nuclear monopoly, proved that it has no such designs. In reality, by giving up his ability to launch a devastating first blow, Yeltsin gave up no Russian security at all.
Second, he showed an ability to improvise under unexpected pressure, which is the mark of the master statesman.
He had concentrated on making the arms deal and lobbying for the Freedom Support Act, which would give him economic breathing room. But he had not foreseen the impact of an afterthought: his revelation that he had discovered evidence of missing Americans in the K.G.B. archives. (They cannot be, as speculated, U-2 pilots; the C.I.A. insists that only Francis Gary Powers was downed.) To Yeltsin's dismay, this became a political impediment to his goal. Americans become passionate on the subject of prisoners of war. Senator John McCain, a former P.O.W., promptly said he would withhold approval of economic aid until the matter was cleared up, and Senator Richard Lugar followed.
Yeltsin moved fast. During his formal address to the joint meeting of Congress, he inserted: "I assure you that even if one American has been detained in my country, and can still be found, I will find him; I will get him back to his family."
Brought the house down. Then he put in the embarrassing zinger: "So now you are telling me, first do the job, and then we shall support you in passing that act. I don't quite understand you."
That changed the political mood. Afterward, Senator McCain went to him, was personally reassured, and withdrew his opposition. Yeltsin's improvisation worked.
Now remains the opposition of the soft-liners led by House Speaker Tom Foley. He is fearful of the selfish, isolationist sentiment of many voters about foreign aid. Nor is he alone; it took Richard Nixon (now touring Russia to escape Watergate anniversary orgies) to pressure George Bush to propose to join the Western salvation package.
Are Democrats to be the new soft-liners? Or will Bill Clinton exercise party leadership and persuade Congressional Democrats to invest a few billions now -- to avert the need for trillions in armaments tomorrow if democracy in Russia fails?
Let's hope so; we won't get much help from controversy-averse Ross Perot (who just canceled his date with Congress to discuss M.I.A.'s, fearful of being asked under oath about his business proposition to the Vietnamese). This is the time for a profile in courage from Mr. Clinton: not just a pious statement, but some responsible arm-twisting.
Give Mr. Bush and James Baker good marks on the arms deal, presuming the timetable can be speeded and that S.D.I. cooperation was not neglected. The new hard-liners hope Bush also pressed the need to get Russian troops out of the Baltics and K.G.B. agents out of Washington.
And give more than a grudging salute to Boris Yeltsin. He left us with a profound thought to chew over: "Today, the freedom of America is being upheld in Russia." By helping freedom there, we advance it here.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Japan Had to Join in U.N. Peacekeeping Effort

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Japanese parliament has at last approved Japan's participation in United Nations peacekeeping operations (front page, June 16). It is more important than ever that your simplistic interpretation of opposition to the legislation in "Japan's Healthy Military Allergy" (editorial, June 2) not be allowed to stand unchallenged.
The Governments of Prime Ministers Toshiki Kaifu and Kiichi Miyazawa have wisely sought to begin a process that would slowly diversify and normalize Japan's security relations multilaterally. The reason is not difficult to grasp. The status quo in East Asia rests largely on the United States-Japan security arrangement, in which the United States provides a defense umbrella for Japan. 
 That relationship alone has made it possible for Japan to avoid creating alternative security structures, and it alone has given Japan's neighbors confidence that Japan is being held in check. But alter those terms, as Congress is certain to do before long, now that the cold war is over and Japan's wealth is exceeded only by our own, and all bets are off. Japan would be left in a security void, which would send both it and its neighbors scrambling in undesirable unilateralist military directions.
Fully aware of that prospect, Japan has persuaded the annual postministerial conference of the Association of South East Asian Nations to address political and security issues, in addition to economic ones. Together with its allies and the International Atomic Energy Agency, Japan has deployed its diplomatic skills and financial carrots to flush out and try to arrest North Korea's nuclear intentions. Japan is playing a major administrative and financial role in disarming and rebuilding Cambodia. And Japan has even explored establishing a working relationship with the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe.
The peacekeeping bill was yet another, and a particularly critical, step in the direction of normalization through multilateralization.
Moreover, the constitutional issue is far more complicated than you suggest. The consensus among many legal scholars in Japan is that the Self-Defense Forces themselves may be unconstitutional. By definition, therefore, any foreign deployment of them also would appear to be so. At the same time, however, it is doubtful that the American drafters of Japan's Constitution would have equated the modest noncombatant activities of peacekeeping operations with the resolution of international disputes by the use of force, which is what Japan's Constitution prohibits.
To complicate matters further, Japan has, like every other signatory of the United Nations Charter, a solemn treaty obligation to negotiate an Article 43 agreement with the United Nations that puts fighting forces, not simply peacekeeping troops, at the disposal of the Security Council.
Finally, it is important not to ignore the electoral dimension of the issue. It is surely true that many individuals in the opposition parties worry sincerely about a revival of Japanese militarism and about the constitutional issues raised by the new peacekeeping unit. But it is also true that a very important election for the upper house of Japan's parliament will be held in July, and several of the opposition parties have been happily posturing themselves as opponents of Japanese militarism.
If Japan's Government can be faulted for anything on this issue, it is for not being bold enough. For example, Japan should propose to its neighbors joint programs and facilities for collectively training their peacekeeping troops. Such an arrangement would build confidence in the region, and in Japan.
A proposal to Russia to use one or more of the disputed Northern Territories for that purpose could realize interesting results, by providing a face-saving device for Russia to return the islands to Japan and to benefit, in turn, from Japan's economic largess.
 
JOHN GERARD RUGGIE
Dean, School of International and Public Affairs, Columbia University
New York, June 16, 1992

HEADLINE: SPORTS PEOPLE: TV SPORTS;
A Setback for Pay-Per-View

 BODY:
An amendment passed last night by a Congressional committee would essentially prevent the four major leagues from pursuing pay-per-view telecasts of their championship games.
The amendment to a bill in the House Energy and Commerce Committee, co-authored by Representatives GERRY SIKORSKI of Minnesota and EDWARD J. MARKEY of Massachusetts, both Democrats, was formulated in the wake of the recent Stanley Cup finals between the Chicago Blackhawks and Pittsburgh Penguins. The Hawks' home games were available only to subscribers who paid a premium. 
 The bill, regulating cable-TV rates, next goes to the House floor for a vote.
The amendment would make it mandatory for local cable regulating agencies to set the price of a pay-per-view telecast. "For political and economic reasons, it would be a ban," said MIKE CONNOLLY, a spokesman for Markey. He explained that local commissions would not allow events of such magnitude to be kept off free television.
The National Football League previously promised Markey that it would not employ pay-per-view of the Super Bowl at least until the end of the century. Basketball and baseball indicated their championship games also would remain on "over-the-air" television.
