HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Financing;
Lagging in the Polls, Clinton Also Faces a Cash Shortage

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18

 BODY:
As Ross Perot has catapulted to the top of the polls and Gov. Bill Clinton has fallen into third place, the Arkansas Governor's fund raising has also lagged, drawing his campaign so deep into debt that he has been unable to pay hundreds of campaign employees on time.
Campaign officials explain that Mr. Perot's surging candidacy has made it harder for Mr. Clinton to raise money. 
 Even as Mr. Clinton has won enough delegates to clinch the Democratic nomination, his campaign has become so financially weakened that for the first time in memory, the Democratic National Committee is providing significant funds directly to the candidate before his formal nomination.
That, in turn, has led to criticism from senior Republicans. The Republican National Committee is now preparing to file a complaint with Federal election officials accusing the Democratic Party of illegally financing Mr. Clinton's Presidential campaign.
 
Move to Embarrass Clinton
 The complaint, which will be filed with the Federal Election Commission on Friday, is largely symbolic and is not likely to bring any significant penalties. But it could still prove politically embarrassing by highlighting the serious cash shortage confronting Mr. Clinton's campaign.
Financially, Mr. Clinton has suddenly become the weakest of the three candidates. His campaign now owes an Arkansas bank more than $2.7 million. "For fund raising, Perot becomes an excuse not to contribute until people know what it means," said Donald R. Sweitzer, a fund raiser for Mr. Clinton who was the finance director for the Democratic National Committee in 1988. "The Perot phenomenon hurts."
The campaign will receive a large cash infusion from the Government at the end of next month's Democratic National Convention. The money will come from citizens who opt to provide $1 from their income taxes to finance the general election.
 
$400,000 Advance From Party
 For now, though, the cash shortage has forced Mr. Clinton to take on a grueling schedule of fund-raisers this month. It also prompted the Democratic National Committee to advance him $400,000 to pay for a half-hour television "town hall" appearance from Pittsburgh last Friday. This is the advance that the Republicans are complaining about. But the more serious problem for Mr. Clinton is that he will have to pay back this advance, and perhaps other loans too, from funds that are usually saved for use after the July convention.
"It has been an unfortunate distraction from the campaign, but it's real," Mr. Sweitzer said. "The fact that the Clinton campaign has been strapped for cash is a problem, but it's not overwhelming."
The Republicans say the $400,000 payment was improper since the election regulations sharply restrict party contributions during the primaries, and Mr. Clinton used the television program paid for with party money to solicit contributions to help pay off primary debts.
"What it really points up is the dire straits Clinton's campaign faces until the convention because nobody's giving him money," said Benjamin L. Ginsberg, chief counsel to the Republican National Committee, who prepared the complaint.
The Democrats respond that they are no longer bound by primary restraints because Mr. Clinton already has enough delegates to win the nomination next month.
"We can make general election expenditures now," said Carol C. Darr, a lawyer for the Democratic National Committee. She said the party based its decision on a 1984 opinion by the election commission that permitted the Republicans to use funds before the convention to run television advertisements for President Reagan.
Once they are formally nominated this summer, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Bush would each receive $55.2 million from the Government to spend on the general election, and their parties will get $10.3 million that can be spent for the conventions and the general election.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Bush will also benefit from hundreds of millions of dollars of "soft money" raised by local party and independent groups that can be used to help the candidates in exercises like voter registration drives and get-out-the-vote appeals.
 
Perot Is On His Own
 Mr. Perot, on the other hand, has pledged to forgo all Federal financing. Under a 1976 Supreme Court ruling, he can spend as much as he likes. The billionaire businessman has said he is willing to spend $100 million or more of his own money, and virtually all the money he has spent so far has been his own.
Mr. Clinton's campaign raised about $2.3 million in May, and campaign officials say it has already raised $1 million this month and hopes to raise another $1.5 million to $2 million in the rest of June. But that is less than expected, and expenses are still significantly outpacing the campaign's contributions -- so much so that it is behind in paying more than 200 campaign employees.
Any debt Mr. Clinton carries over from the primary season will only eat into his available financing for the general election. With the economy still weak, some corporate and individual contributors who gave in the last general election may not give this time. And with Mr. Clinton in third place in the polls, his fund-raisers say they have had a harder than usual time finding new money.
"There are fewer millionaires than there were in 1988 and fewer people who are able to write $1,000 checks," Mr. Sweitzer said. He noted that four years ago Mr. Dukakis was in considerably better financial shape.
 
$2.7 Million in Loans
 Mr. Clinton's latest campaign disclosure statement, which covers the period ended April 30, showed that he had more than $2.7 million in outstanding loans and that he only had $258,000, less than a quarter of Mr. Dukakis's available funds for the similar period four years ago. That is also much less than President Bush has. The President's campaign is debt-free, and in a new filing on Saturday is expected to show that it had more than $8 million in cash on hand at the end of May.
Most of Mr. Clinton's debt is owed to the Worthen National Bank of Little Rock. It is primarily owned by the Stephens family, an influential group that has helped Mr. Clinton raise money in his gubernatorial races and has also contributed substantially to the Republicans. The family has vast holdings in natural gas and real estate and owns one of the nation's largest investment firms.

HEADLINE: Bucking Traditions in Trenton: G.O.P. Budget

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 18

 BODY:
No government document is more political than a budget, and the one unveiled by the omnipotent new Republican legislative majority in Trenton today represents a stark repudiation of nearly two decades of moderate to liberal government under both Democratic and Republican administrations.
Riding a tide of anti-tax anger in New Jersey, the Republicans rescinded or gutted a host of social and other programs for the poor and middle class endorsed not only by their archenemy Jim Florio, the Democratic Governor, but also by his Republican predecessor, Thomas H. Kean. 
 All told, the Republicans, who hold vetoproof majorities in both houses of the Legislature, cut $1.1 billion from the Governor's proposed budget for the fiscal year starting next month, although a large part of it, most notably $385 million in rebates to property taxpayers, amounted to a shift, not a cut. [Page B4.]
The Republicans have also taken aim at about 900 middle managers and about that many other state employees whose jobs would be eliminated when the Motor Vehicles Department and the state-owned New Jersey Network television system are "privatized." Other state workers could come under the ax if the budget gap widens further, as some legislators say it may if the sputtering economy continues to put the lie to predictions of an upswing.
The current Republican policy of restraint is in sharp contrast to Mr. Kean's tenure, when the state budget rose substantially every year, doubling from $6 billion to $12 billion over his eight years in office as the state work force increased 20 percent.
One clear example of the U-turn the Republicans are making this year is their plan to sever the New Jersey Network from the state and turn it over to another noncommercial operator, probably WNET, Channel 13. That was not the way Governor Kean wanted things.
It was in the Kean administration that plans were laid and bonds approved to build a $23 million studio and headquarters for the public television system. The building is even now under construction in Trenton. The new Republican budget cuts the network's $8 million appropriation in half and calls for dissolving the system within six months as part of a sweeping drive to "privatize" state functions.
Political and legal realities seem to have thwarted Republican plans for sharp cuts in aid to higher education, desegregation assistance and affirmative-action programs.
 
Scuttled at 11th Hour
 The original Republican plan, scuttled at the 11th hour because of outcries from education officials that tuition would soar by between $200 and $300 a semester at state-supported colleges, proposed dropping a $30 million appropriation for tuition assistance.
But the Department of Human Services, which primarily assists the poor, was not so fortunate. Its proposed $3.7 billion appropriation was reduced by more than $190 million.
Assistance to mass transit, support for the arts -- another area that was dear to the heart of Governor Kean -- and general assistance to the poor will be hard hit this time.
The budget cuts include $35 million in aid to N.J. Transit, which the Republicans insist will not result in fare increases because of offsetting operational cuts. They are also considering making N.J. Transit private, a prospect that sends shudders through riders who remember the shoddy service and poor maintenance that plagued the private system N.J. Transit replaced more than a decade ago.
 
A Voice May Be Silenced
 The Republican budget ax actually has swung as far back as 1974, the year the Legislature, in the administration of Gov. Brendan T. Byrne, created the Department of the Public Advocate as the "voice of the voiceless" that would bring lawsuits in the public interest, particularly helping the poor.
Under the Republican budget plan, two divisions of the Advocate's office would be all but eliminated. It is probably not coincidental that several Republican legislators called last year for the resignation of the Public Advocate, Wilfredo Caraballo, because he had joined a suit to allow the integration of schools across district lines.
When the court agreed with Mr. Caraballo this week, a prominent Republican newcomer to the Legislature, Senator John P. Scott, who represents parts of Bergen, Essex and Passaic Counties, told his colleagues, "We cannot wait any longer to act and stop the liberal courts and Florio's social engineers."
The Republicans, with two-thirds majorities in both houses -- enough to override any Florio veto -- had also planned to drop about $14 million in desegregation assistance to school districts from the budget, but they reinstituted the funds when it appeared that cutting them could thwart court orders.
Political considerations apparently saved about $100 million in municipal aid when the Republican majority, whose representation across the state is so broad that the cutbacks would affect many of their constituents, restored much of the money in the final version of the budget.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE SUMMIT;
U.S. Backs Easier Terms for Russian Aid

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18

 BODY:
The Bush Administration, in a shift of approach toward aid for Moscow, has called on the International Monetary Fund to ease some demands for harsh reform and not delay an aid agreement once Russia commits itself to broad economic changes.
Administration officials said today that they feared that a delay in signing an accord with the I.M.F. would block the flow of economic assistance and destabilize the Government of President Boris N. Yeltsin at a time when Western governments want nothing more than to consolidate Moscow's fledgling democracy. 
 "The reason we have a sense of urgency on the economic side is if Boris Yeltsin can't succeed on economic reform, he will have a hard time staying as leader in Russia," a senior Administration official said. "This could seriously threaten the democratic reforms that are so much in our interest. The I.M.F. agreement is key to this."
 
Shift Is Linked to Reforms
 The Administration's position this week was in contrast to its statements of a year ago. Last July, for example, at a meeting of the major industrial nations in London, President Bush was less eager than several European leaders to grant President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's request for extensive aid.
Administration officials said then that technical aid was appropriate, asserting that economic aid would be wasted because Russia had not yet begun comprehensive reforms.
The Administration's view began to change after the Soviet Union collapsed in December and President Yeltsin spoke out in favor of radical changes. Last winter, Washington took a leading role in forging the industrial nations' $24 billion aid package. With Mr. Yeltsin's visit, the Administration appears to be taking an even more active role on Russia's behalf.
 
Changes Is Called Too Tough
 Some Administration officials argue that I.M.F. economists are demanding changes that are too difficult to carry out. These include requiring Russia to reduce its budget deficit to zero and removing all price controls on oil: changes that may be so strict that Russia will balk at an accord, which is essential for receiving billions of dollars in new aid.
The Administration's decision to pressure the I.M.F. began to emerge on Monday as President Yeltsin arrived in Washington, and it appears to have solidified after the favorable impression Mr. Yeltsin made from his concessions on arms control and his conversations at the White House and appearance in the Congress.
Last year, the United States and the other major industrial nations making up what is known as the Group of Seven asked the I.M.F. to take the leading role in coordinating aid for Russia because of the fund's experience in pressing developing countries for reforms in return for loans. But now some American officials worry that the I.M.F.'s hard-line bankers and economists might be prescribing medicine far tougher than the Group of Seven doctors had ordered.
During Mr. Yeltsin's visit here, Russian and American officials engaged in rare public jawboning to press the I.M.F. not to drive too hard a bargain.
"If there is such a thing as a Chevrolet three-speed stick-shift agreement with the I.M.F., as opposed to a Cadillac agreement, and if we can get a Chevrolet, then let's do it," a senior Administration official said.
 
Aid Flow Is Tied to Pact
 The Russians are eager for an agreement because it will enable them to tap much of the $24 billion aid package for 1992 that the industrial countries pledged in April. The package includes $11 billion in bilateral aid from various participating countries, $6 billion for a special multilateral fund to stabilize the ruble and about $4.5 billion in loans from the I.M.F. and World Bank.
While I.M.F. and Russian officials say there is broad agreement on what reforms are needed, the talks have become snarled over details, some Russian negotiators say. Marking the American shift in approach, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said on Monday that if Russia committed itself to move forward in several important areas, Washington would press the I.M.F. not to delay an agreement because of concerns about minor details.
American officials have recently said that while they would like the I.M.F. to sign an agreement with Russia as soon as possible, they would be willing to wait a few weeks if that was what it took to insure a solid agreement.
In an apparent sign that the I.M.F. also recognizes a need for urgency, the fund's Managing Director, Michel Camdessus, and Yegor T. Gaidar, Russia's Acting Prime Minister, issued a joint statement today saying they are "in basic agreement on the crucial objectives of an economic strategy devised to restore and sustain growth in the Russian economy on the basis of a market-oriented system."
The two officials met in Washington for three hours today, after a 40-minute meeting Wednesday. Their statement said "both sides were confident" that the negotiations "would lead to an early agreement on a program."
Russia has sought to sign an accord by July 1, but this week some I.M.F. officials said it might not happen until early September.
American pressure on the I.M.F. may not be easy, even though the United States is its biggest shareholder. I.M.F. officials assert, for example, that if they show leniency to Russia in negotiating an agreement, then African and Latin nations will demand similar leniency when they sign agreements with the monetary fund.
 
Fears of Nullifying Aid
 Some of Russia's negotiators expressed fears that the I.M.F.'s technical staff, in demanding tough commitments from Russia, would nullify the benefits of much of the $24 billion in aid the Group of Seven pledged to Russia in April. For example, according to negotiators for Russia, the monetary fund says that if Russia draws any money from a $6 billion fund planned to stabilize the ruble, then Russia should pay back that money within 90 days.
Such a demand, Russia's negotiators said, could render the ruble fund almost meaningless because it would force Russia, which is desperately short of hard currency reserves, to be the main country carrying the burden of underwriting the ruble -- not the 11 wealthy countries that have promised to back the ruble fund.
Administration officials say Russia should commit itself to reforms in three essential areas: reining in its budget deficit, keeping its money supply and credit under control, and making the ruble convertible -- that is, allowing anyone possessing rubles to exchange them for hard currency -- to help integrate Russia into the world economy.
I.M.F. negotiators also want Russia to move in these areas, but they have pressed Russia further, asking Moscow to remove controls on oil prices as soon as possible. In recent months, Russia has let oil prices more than quadruple, creating much hardship.
"They've already had a dramatic increase in prices," a senior Administration official said today. "Clearly the goal should be to liberalize energy prices as soon as possible, but whether that should be an absolute quid pro quo for an I.M.F. agreement, I don't know. There is a limit to what the political traffic will bear right now."
On Monday, Treasury Under Secretary David C. Mulford, said the I.M.F. should be quick to negotiate an accord, but should not rush itself into a weak agreement.
"There has to be a sufficient quality there to establish credibility," he said. "This may take time, and probably it is more important to get the quality in place even if it takes an extra few weeks of negotiation."
One of the most difficult points in Russia's talks with the I.M.F. is that the fund wants Moscow to coordinate its monetary policy with other former Soviet republics that plan to use the ruble. This demand, I.M.F. and Russian officials concede, will be difficult to meet because some of the other republics do not want to sacrifice their control over monetary policy. But Russian officials say that if other republics continue to print billions of rubles, it will be impossible to control inflation.

HEADLINE: As Bishops Meet, Catholics Voice Differences With Church's Doctrine;
Poll Finds Backing Of Female Priests

BYLINE: By ARI L. GOLDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 18

 BODY:
A Gallup poll released here today finds that two-thirds of Roman Catholics in the United States favor opening the priesthood to women, an increase of 20 percentage points over just seven years ago.
The poll, conducted in May by the Gallup Organization and commissioned by a coalition of groups seeking fundamental changes in the structure and policy of the church, was released as the nation's bishops gathered at the University of Notre Dame for their first open debate on a pastoral letter on the role of women in church and society. The letter, crafted over a period of nine years, deplores "the sin of sexism" but affirms Vatican positions against female priests, artificial birth control and abortion. 
 The poll shows that lay Catholics are at odds with their bishops and the Vatican on these and other issues. Sixty-seven percent of Catholics agreed with the statement, "It would be a good thing if women were allowed to be ordained as priests," up from 47 percent in 1985. The poll also found that 70 percent favored allowing priests to marry, up from 49 percent in 1971.
Ruth McDonough Fitzpatrick of the Women's Ordination Conference, a sponsor of the poll, said it demonstrated that the bishops were "clearly not in touch with the pulse of the people." But the poll also found that Pope John Paul II was overwhelmingly popular: 84 percent agreed with the statement that he was "doing a good job in leading the church," and only 10 percent disagreed.
 
Differences by Age
 The poll also showed that Catholics under the age of 35 were more likely to favor change, a finding that the sponsors said signaled that the problems were not going to go away.
The poll, conducted by telephone in English and Spanish among 802 Catholics nationwide from May 5 to 17, has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
Sister Maureen Fiedler, co-director of one of the sponsoring groups, Catholics Speak Out, said the poll demonstrated "nothing less than a quiet but massive grass-roots revolution" in the American church. She added, "The people have developed a whole new consensus of opinion and behavior different from that of the bishops, but which they believe is morally acceptable to their consciences and faithful to the Catholic tradition."
Bishop Raymond J. Boland, chairman of the bishops' communication committee, said today that he had not had time to study the Gallup poll or a Time magazine poll released earlier this week that also showed widespread dissent among the Catholic laity, but he added:
"The church decides its doctrine on 2,000 years of traditional teaching based on the Scriptures and the message of our Lord Jesus Christ. We're not about to change it just because of the polls."
Polls, he said, are of value at times but "extremely transient."
 
Effect on Church Policy
 A number of Catholic experts said today that they were struck by the sharp increase in support for ordination of women, but they were divided on how it would affect church policy. "These people are getting their message across," the Rev. Thomas A. Reese, a Jesuit and author of several books on the priests, said of the liberal Catholic groups. "The bishops are not."
Mary T. Hanna, a political scientist at Whitman College in Walla Walla, Wash., who specializes in religion and politics, said she agreed with Sister Maureen that a grass-roots revolution was building.
She said she suspected that if it were up to American bishops, the church would soon ordain women as priests. "But it's not up to American bishops," she went on. "It's up to the Pope and to Rome, and I don't believe we're going to see it happen in the lifetime of this Pope."
But Andrew M. Greeley, a professor of social science at the University of Chicago, said he did not believe the growing support for ordination of women and for allowing priests to marry would sway American bishops in the least.
"I would say that opposition among bishops has increased with the appointments in the past few years," he said. "Some have been appointed for that reason alone. You have to understand that these are the matters of the highest import when it comes to appointments."
"And I don't think Rome will take note either," Professor Greeley added.
He said he would not characterize the increases as a revolution in Catholic sentiment. "It's a pretty sharp trend line up," he said. "But I would only call it a revolution if you could persuade me that this is something that's really high on people's agendas. This poll can't show us really how important this is to everyone. If people started doing something about their convictions, like cutting off their contributions to the church, then I might call it a revolution."
Representatives of the seven groups that commissioned the study were on hand today at Notre Dame. In addition to groups advocating women in the clergy were those seeking greater roles in the church for married men and homosexuals.
Several of those involved in the sponsoring groups were priests, brothers and nuns. They held a news conference this morning at the Notre Dame Library Auditorium, and later in the afternoon many of them joined a "feminist liturgy" in which women consecrated bread in apparent violation of canon law.
Also on hand at the campus were the bishops, many of whom stayed in the dormitories recently vacated by students. The bishops met for their review of the pastoral letter on women in the nearby Joyce Athletic and Convocation Center. Their four-day meeting included time for business as well as time for prayer and quiet reflection.
 
Bishops' Policies Contradicted
 The sponsors of the poll called the pastoral letter "fatally flawed" because it accepted Vatican policies.
Many of the findings of the survey contradicted the stated policies of the bishops and the Vatican.
For example, the bishops have taken a strong position against the use of condoms as a means to prevent the spread of AIDS. But 83 percent of those questioned favored the use of condoms.
Only 13 percent of Catholics agreed with the bishops that abortion could never be a moral choice. Forty-one said it was morally acceptable in rare circumstances and another 41 percent said it was morally acceptable in many or all circumstances.
Forty-eight percent of Catholics agreed with the bishops that relations between gay or lesbian people in a committed relationship could not be morally acceptable. But 46 percent said that such relations could be morally acceptable.
And while the bishops are opposed to capital punishment, 66 percent of Catholic favor it, reflecting the rough percentage of all Americans who support it.
Respondents to the poll also made it clear that they would like to see the church adopt more democratic principles.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE SUMMIT;
Ol' Khrushchev Trail Leads Yeltsin to Kansas

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WICHITA, Kan., June 18

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia was beaming today when he met Dmitri Antoniadi, a fellow Russian and a student at a university in this city on the Kansas plains.
But his smile grew when he was told that Mr. Antoniadi's father is the manager of a Pizza Hut restaurant in Moscow, part of the capitalist beachhead that the former Communist is so eager to see develop into an all-out assault on the Soviet past. 
 "I'll make a point of going to that restaurant," Mr. Yeltsin told Mr. Antoniadi and about 500 others in a speech at Wichita State University. "I hope he doesn't ask me to pay in dollars. I don't have any."
The audience laughed. Mr. Yeltsin waved and continued on a hectic, four-hour tour that swept through this city like one of the tornadoes that have made Kansas famous from Moscow to Oz.
 
Barbecue and Wheat
 Mr. Yeltsin began at an Air Force base where warplanes were once on around-the-clock alert, ready to destroy the Russian homeland. Accompanied by his host, Senator Bob Dole, Mr. Yeltsin then toured a meat-packing plant, gave his speech at Wichita State University, downed a lunch of barbecued pork and tried harvesting wheat.
Mr. Yeltsin was following a Russian trail first blazed in 1959 by Nikita S. Khrushchev, who whisked across the United States, savoring his first hot dog and marveling at the lush corn fields of Iowa.
"The Midwest is more like central Russia than any other part of the United States," Ronald G. Suny, a professor of Russian history at the University of Michigan, said in a telephone interview. "It corresponds with Central Russia: A great flat plain producing grain. So it makes a kind of symbolic sense for these leaders to go there."
 
A 'Wonderful' Neo-Capitalist
 Mr. Khrushchev had lunch on the farm of Roswell and Elizabeth Garst, near Coon Rapids, Iowa. Mr. Garst died in 1977 but his widow said the other day: "I hope he knows what's going on in Russia. I think it's great. He would, too. It's wonderful, their struggling along, becoming capitalists. When Mr. Khrushchev was here, I think everyone had fun."
The fun in Kansas began today at McConnell Air Force Base, where the welcomers included Melissa Hettich, Miss Kansas World 1992. "I think it's great that he has the opportunity to get a little taste of Kansas because we have a lot to offer," she said.
Such as?
"That's a good question," Ms. Hettich said. "I think it's important to know we have some of the friendliest people around. We don't have mountains but the Flint Hills are beautiful. And the wheat fields are important because they symbolize us."
Standing nearby was Maj. James E. Hazuka and his family. Major Hazuka has spent most of his 14-year Air Force career in the Strategic Air Command, whose only mission has been to bomb the Soviet Union on a moment's notice.
 
'Feel Good About the Future'
 "It's great," he said. "This is something I thought would never happen, a Russian leader standing 50 yards away. I feel very good about the future, with only one exception: the economy. But I don't think Yeltsin can do anything about that."
Mr. Yeltsin quickly charmed the crowd of warriors and their families and friends when he talked of peace and then shook hands with some of the 300 people on hand.
The largest cheer came when Mr. Yeltsin said, "There will never be war between our two countries, I am convinced of that."
Mr. Yeltsin said that some might wonder why he had decided to stop in Wichita, besides Washington the only city in the country on his schedule. "I know you have not been showered with state visits before," he said, adding that he had come to Wichita to learn about agricultural techniques.
Then Mr. Yeltsin worked the crowd like a big-city mayor two days before election day.
Children must hold a special spell over politicians because one of the first hands Mr. Yeltsin shook belonged to Brendan Lindsey, who is 2.
But Mr. Yeltsin wasn't satisfied with just shaking the boy's hand. He took him from his father and held him in his arms. Later, as Mr. Yeltsin's motorcade left the air base, Brendan's father, Troy, a 28-year-old financial analyst from Wichita, said, "I'm very proud. We'll go get some ice cream and call mom."
 
Thumbs-Up, a Lot
 Mr. Lindsey said Mr. Yeltsin had said something to him as he handed his son back, "but they never interpreted it."
"All I could understand," Mr. Lindsey said, "was the thumbs-up sign."
Later, Mr. Yeltsin toured Dold Meatpacking Plant, where he walked up to Marilyn Terto, 34, who was working on the hambone line.
How much do you make? Mr. Yeltsin asked her, to which she answered, $9.43 an hour.
"All right, all right," he said, flashing thumbs-up as slabs of pork whirled past on hooks.
While her husband toured the meat-packing plant, Naina Yeltsin attended a reception in her honor, with Elizabeth Dole as host, at a local hotel. From there she took a wagon ride at the Cowtown Museum, a recreation of a Kansas prairie town 100 years ago.
Another site Mr. Yeltsin visited was the farm of Greg and Sandra Rau, who spent the week sprucing up their 2,000-acre spread. Their farm, a few miles from the Air Force base, was selected to give Mr. Yeltsin a taste of Kansas farm life.
But the visit came at a busy time for the Raus: Because of heavy rains lately, the farmers are behind in harvesting the spring wheat.
"It has been exhausting," Mr. Rau said. "But we're very proud."
The Raus turned their farm into a showcase, parking a fleet of shiny combines and tractors in a field for Mr. Yeltsin to inspect.
Mr. Yeltsin, seeming to know his way around farm machinery, climbed into the cab of a green combine, waved people out of the way and jerked it forward. Clara Belden, a farmer and a high school English teacher, watched Mr. Yeltsin, helped by Mr. Rau, drive the combine around the field.
"I thought that was the magic moment," Mrs. Belden said. "As farmers we know being in that combine is a place we feel most deeply what the harvest is all about.""
Some of it may wind up in Russian bakeries. In 1991 the United States exported 3.9 million metric tons of wheat to the Soviet Union, according to the Agriculture Department, this year just over 4 million tons have already gone to Russia and the other former Soviet republics.
Before he left for the airport for a trip to Canada, Mr. Yeltsin was asked what he would most like to take back with him from Kansas.
"Everything," he said.

HEADLINE: THE SUPREME COURT;
Backers of '78 Tax Revolt Hail Ruling

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 18

 BODY:
Backers of the California property tax revolt that was upheld today by the United States Supreme Court rejoiced in what they said was an affirmation of the citizen's right to keep down taxes.
"The question was, 'Do people have a right to control their own destiny regarding taxation?' And the answer is: yes," said Joel D. Fox, president of the Howard Jarvis Taxpayers Association. 
 Mr. Jarvis, now dead, was the co-author of Proposition 13, the centerpiece of the California tax revolt in 1978 that halted property-tax increases but also contributed in the long run to an $11 billion budget deficit that is now paralyzing the State Legislature, which is struggling to pass a budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1.
 
Governor Praises Ruling
 In an 8-1 ruling today, the Supreme Court left in place what it called California's "grand experiment" in popular limitations on taxation.
"There is clearly no question about it that the dramatic falloff in revenue to local governments and the fact that the state has had to finance more and more of local services has contributed in large measure to the deficit," said Ann Carlson, a lawyer who represented the plaintiff in the case, Stephanie Nordlinger, a homeowner in Southern California.
Gov. Pete Wilson, whose administration has been defined by the challenges of the staggering budget deficit, nevertheless praised the ruling today, saying property-tax controls fostered a positive business climate.
"Proposition 13 is essential to our efforts to protect Californians from unfair and crippling property taxes, especially the elderly who live on limited and fixed incomes," he said. "Only by keeping a tight rein on taxes can we keep California competitive and not allow it to turn into the job-killing machine that higher taxes would result in."
 
What Proposition Did
 When it was enacted in 1978 after a statewide referendum, Proposition 13 set the property tax rate at 1 percent of the property's value and decreed that assessments be rolled back to their 1975-76 level. The tax cannot increase faster than 2 percent a year, under the proposition. Buyers who bought property after 1978 would pay taxes based on the market value.
The rollback was intended to prevent the elderly and other long-time property owners from being forced out of their homes after property taxes had skyrocketed in the late 1970's because of soaring property values. But in a booming real estate market, one of the results of Proposition 13 was to create wild imbalances between the low taxes of long-time residents and the soaring rates of new buyers.
Ms. Nordlinger's lawyers told the Court she was forced by Proposition 13 to pay the same taxes on her modest home in a middle-income neighborhood as the long-time owner of a house worth $2.1 million in an exclusive portion of Malibu. The lawyers argued that the discrepancy in property taxes violated the equal-protection clause of the United States Constitution.
 
Changed 'Way Money Is Raised'
 In addition to its impact on the state budget, Cynthia Kroll, an economist, said Proposition 13 resulted in a reliance by local communities on new development for revenues to support new roads, schools and other services, while maintenance of existing infrastructure suffered.
"Proposition 13 has changed the whole way money is raised in California," she said."It has affected the way development has occurred and has left the state with some real growth dilemmas."
With the recession, such development has also slowed, further squeezing local budgets, said Ms. Kroll, who is regional economist for the Center for Real Estate and Urban Economics at the University of California at Berkeley.
With Proposition 13 in place for more than a decade, said Los Angeles County Assessor Kenneth Hahn, "It would have been absolute chaos if the Court had not made the decision they made, because we have 2.3 million properties which would have had to be reassessed." He said his office had estimated that it would have taken more than seven years to reappraise every property in the county.
Philip M. Tatarowicz, national director of state and local tax services for Ernst & Young, said today's ruling might give an impetus to other states to attempt to adopt California's approach to controlling rising property taxes.
More common around the nation, he said, is a "circuit breaker" system that limits property-tax increases as a proportion of income.
But he noted that the Supreme Court ruling today had been based on specific arguments and that there were still issues that could provide grounds for further challenges to Proposition 13. "So I don't think we've heard the last word," he said.

HEADLINE: Fed Will Push Inflation Fight

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 18

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve Board intends to continue squeezing inflation down, a Fed governor said today.
The official, John P. LaWare, spoke to reporters while attending a hearing of the Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council here. 
 Inflation has been "on a downward trend, and we hope to keep it headed in that direction," he said.
Inflation is running at about a 3 percent rate so far this year, down slightly from last year's 3.1 percent increase in the Consumer Price Index.

HEADLINE: After the Cold War: Views From Vietnam;
Vietnam, Now Master of Its Own House, Tries to Mend Neighborhood Fences

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam

 BODY:
For the first time since French gunboats laid waste to the port of Da Nang in 1858 and began the colonization of what became French Indochina, Vietnam is free of domination by distant powers. But the post-cold-war task of emerging from the umbrella of the old Soviet Union and finding a new place in the rapidly developing region of Southeast Asia is daunting.
"The collapse of the Soviet Union was a devastating blow for us," said Maj. Gen. Tran Cong Man, a Vietnamese Government spokesman. "The Soviet Union was our support, ideologically and psychologically, also militarily and economically. It was our unique model. Now we find it was a false model." 
 The end of the unequal alliance between Hanoi and Moscow means much more than political, diplomatic and economic disarray; it marks a turning point in Vietnamese history.
France, temporarily succeeded by Japan during World War II, returned briefly as a colonial power and was replaced, after the defeat at Dien Bien Phu in 1954, by the United States in the southern half of the newly partitioned country. The American defeat in 1975 enabled the Soviet Union to take over for 16 years as the foreign power on which Vietnam depended.
"It was very unfortunate for us that Vietnam was put in the focus of superpower conflicts for many decades, and it is good for us not to be tied into the framework of bipolar confrontations," Deputy Foreign Minister Tran Quang Co said in an interview here. "We would like to have the same fate as other Southeast Asian countries -- independence, peace and stability. But unhappily for Vietnam, there is still an enormous gap."
 
A Blow for the Old Guard
 The end of Moscow's economic and military support has been a particularly heavy blow for Vietnam's old-guard, orthodox Communist leadership, forcing this country of 66 million people to abandon its dominant position over neighboring Cambodia and Laos.
Its military forces and advisers have been mainly withdrawn, and its leaders now assert that Hanoi never aspired to control the old French Indochina.
Vietnam's signature last October of the Paris agreement to settle the Cambodian conflict formalized its fading from leadership in Indochina. A senior Laotian diplomat said: "We can't speak any more of a special solidarity, as in the past. Cooperation will no longer be on an ideological basis but on the basis of good neighborliness."
The Soviet collapse has obliged all three nations to redirect their diplomacy toward an accommodation with China. During their war against the United States, the Communist leaders in the three countries had the full support of both the Soviet Union and China, despite the rivalry between Moscow and Beijing. The American withdrawal ended this marriage of convenience.
 
Soviet Clients
 Vietnam and Laos slid into the Soviet orbit; Cambodia, under the Khmer Rouge, followed its historic anti-Vietnamese outlook and accepted Chinese tutelage. The Vietnamese invasion of Cambodia in 1979 and the installation of a puppet government in Phnom Penh made all three Soviet clients.
"We committed the error of having one friend only and chose confrontation with China," said General Man. "We should have been more flexible. We will always live next to China. It is a demographic power. We must never confront them."
"We are very happy at having succeeded in normalizing our relations with China," said Mr. Co, the Deputy Foreign Minister, who also served as Vietnam's Ambassador to Thailand. "We think China, at least for this decade, also needs peace and stability for the modernization of the country. They have to shelve any other ambition for another time."
Vietnam wants to use the respite in tension with China to achieve its integration into Southeast Asia.
Le Bang, acting director of the Foreign Ministry's Americas Department, put it succinctly. "After the cold war, we can't rely on anyone and must be friends with everyone," he said.
 
An Old Rival
 In its effort to make friends with the non-Communist countries in the region, linked in the six-member Association of Southeast Asian Nations, Vietnam must deal with the considerable challenge of its historic rival, Thailand.
Vietnamese officials feel their withdrawal from Cambodia has reassured Thailand, but they say that Bangkok has asserted itself economically, in Cambodia and in Laos, as if it wants to achieve through trade and investment what Vietnam failed to gain through military and political might.
"The Thais show a bit of hegemonism," said General Man. "Economically it is difficult for us to do anything against it, but politically and also militarily we still have significant power to influence Laos and Cambodia."
But younger officials expressly deny any Vietnamese intention to act militarily again.
"We gave up the burden of Cambodia," said Mr. Bang. "We are not committing the mistake again of sending in troops and staying too long. The military is nothing today. We can't invade Cambodia and hold it."
 
A Difference in Attitudes
 The difference in attitudes between the older generation and the younger officials is another consequence of Vietnam's loss of its Soviet ally and the collapse of Communism.
Communist dogma persists in open contradiction to the laissez-faire economic liberalism that has been instituted in Vietnam, and which has in great measure succeeded in making up through trade and investment for the loss of Soviet aid, estimated at $1 billion a year. Faced with this success, the leadership of Do Muoi, the Communist Party Secretary General, and Prime Minister Vo Van Kiet faces a general crisis of confidence in Communism and the party.
"Vietnam is gradually going away from socialism," a senior Russian diplomat of long experience in Vietnam said. "Socialism here has become a tradition that is more rhetorical than real. But contrary to us Russians, who were bothered by the gap between ideology and real life, the Vietnamese know how to live with both.
"In the Vietnamese mind," the Russian continued, "there is peaceful coexistence of the old gods and the pragmatism of peasants and traders. Now they are leaving Marxism-Leninism behind on the altars of their ancestors. When they feel the need, at night, they pray to these gods, but during the day they do business."
 
Looking to Washington
 But there is unanimity throughout this country on what Vietnamese want from the United States.
"The remaining big point in our diplomacy is normalization with the United States," said Mr. Co. "I think we are now in the right direction in the process of establishing diplomatic relations, but it's a little too slow."
This was a diplomatic expression of palpable impatience, most pronounced among economic officials and independent-minded intellectuals, with the United States' refusal to end its embargo on dealings with Vietnam.
"I don't think the United States is missing all opportunities," joked Pham Chi Lan, deputy secretary general of the Chamber of Commerce. "But it shouldn't wait too long.
The American embargo is perceived as particularly harmful because United States opposition in the World Bank, International Monetary Fund and Asian Development Bank is preventing development loans for major projects to improve Vietnam's fragile infrastructure.
Several Vietnamese said they consider America's reluctance a potent asset to the leadership in its refusal to loosen its grip.
"America has won the cold war," said a senior military officer. "It can afford to be generous to us."

GRAPHIC: Photo: As Vietnam has normalized relations with China, some trade has resumed between the two countries. It is often carried on the backs of Chinese workers, like these leaving Guangxi Province, northwest of Vietnam. (Patrick Zachmann/Magnum)
